fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy repays Dutch faith
fields.standfirst: Hasselbaink 29, Overmars 35, Kluivert 44, Van Nistelrooy 82
fields.trailText: Manchester United's £19m record signing Ruud van Nistelrooy brought the house down when he scored Holland's fourth to help them draw level with Portugal in World Cup qualifying Group Two.
fields.body:
While Holland's prospects of gracing the World Cup finals in Japan and South Korea next summer hang precariously in the balance, the Dutch maintained their desperate pursuit of the Republic of Ireland at the top of Group Two last night by sauntering past Cyprus, with Ruud van Nistelrooy providing the icing on a very Orange cake.

Manchester United's £19m record signing was introduced to a rapturous reception from his home crowd with 19 minutes remaining, yet still found time to create four excellent chances before finally accepting a free header in front of goal eight minutes from the end. The strike, celebrated wildly, doubled the 24-year-old's tally in his 11 internationals.

"It's like a dream come true," Van Nistelrooy said. "I worked so hard to come back, and it has been a difficult period. I came on for the last 20 minutes, I had four chances and scored one, so I must be happy with that."

His was the fourth of the Dutch quartet, hauling Louis van Gaal's side - who have struggled to make much of an impression in a tricky group - level with the Portuguese who boast a better head-to-head record. Furthermore, Holland have played a game more and their qualification may yet hinge upon a daunting trip to Dublin in September.

Perhaps with that in mind, Van Gaal was less than impressed with his side's display. "We scored three world-class goals today but I can't be happy with our play," he said. "I put on Van Hooijdonk and Van Nistelrooy and the crosses didn't come in. I just thought we were very ordinary."

The ecstatic 30,000 crowd did not share his disappointment, instead leaving much heartened by this romp against a desperately poor Cypriot team. The visitors were outpassed and outclassed

After Michael Constantinou had clipped wide from close range, the Oranje took control. Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's 29th minute free-kick ripped through the gaping defensive wall and past Michael Morphis's pathetic attempt to block; six minutes later Marc Overmars, outstanding on the flank all evening, surprised the goalkeeper with a right-footed shot from outside the area.

Patrick Kluivert produced a beautiful airborne flick with the outside of his left foot from Boudewijn Zenden's free-kick just before the interval - his 32nd international goal in 53 appearances. That provided the platform on to which Van Nistelrooy proudly strode, although Frank de Boer, feeling left out in defence, almost stole the newcomer's thunder with a 25-yard free-kick on to the crossbar.

Not to be outdone, the PSV striker duly forced a point-blank save from Zenden's cross with the goalkeeper forced to parry his follow-up header. A minute later Morphis sprawled across his goalline to palm away a low drive, while he was helpless as Van Nistelrooy lobbed wide. That miss had the Dutchman looking to the heavens for reward; then came the header, again from Zenden's pass, which brought the house down.

Holland (3-4-3): Van der Sar; Melchiot, F de Boer, Hofland; Seedorf (Van Nistelrooy, 71min), Cocu, Van Bommel, Zenden; Hasselbaink (Van Hooijdonk, 71), Kluivert, Overmars (Sikora, 83).

Cyprus (4-4-2): Morphis; Konnafis, Germanou, Filippou, Charalampous; Melanarkitis, Engomitis (Kaiafas, 89), Satsias, Christodoulou (Yiasoumi, 77); Okkas (Agathokleous, 84), Constantinou.

Referee: Baskakov (Russia).

webTitle: Blair in row as Whitehall adverts soar by 157%

fields.headline: Blair in row as Whitehall adverts soar by 157%
fields.standfirst: Full coverage of Election 2001
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was accused yesterday of lavishing tens of millions of pounds of taxpayers' money on television advertising campaigns which glorify the achievements of the Labour government.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was accused yesterday of lavishing tens of millions of pounds of taxpayers' money on television advertising campaigns which glorify the achievements of the Labour government.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, accused the prime minister of presiding over an "obscene" waste of public money after new figures showed that the government spent £62m on advertising in the first three months of this year - an increase of 157% on the same period last year.

In March alone, the month originally pencilled in as a key period for Labour to sell its achievements ahead of the general election, the government spent £30m on advertisements. The amount outstripped the advertising budgets of Britain's corporate giants which spent nearly half as much in the same period. Unilever spent £34m in the first three months of the year, while BT spent just £23.8m.

The most expensive government campaigns last month, according to figures published by the media monitors AC Nielsen MMS, were benefit fraud (£3.4m), entitlements to annual leave (£2.5m), anti-smoking initiatives (£2.2m), the UK Online Internet web site (£2.1m) and lone parents (£1.2m).

Mr Kennedy condemned the spending increases which, he claimed, appeared conveniently close to the election. "I think this level of advertising quite frankly is obscene," he told the BBC. "I really do think some kind of independent, outside regulation is going to have to be introduced to keep a check on what the government is spending on your and my behalf as taxpayers."

William Hague rounded on the prime minister in the Commons for the increased spending, in particular the £3.5m on the government's anti benefit fraud campaign which he said ended up encouraging people to commit fraud.

The prime minister, who said that the government had given £6m to the tourist councils, defended the advertising campaigns, saying that they were designed to recruit people for Britain's public services or to tell people about their entitlement to benefits.

Governments of all colours insist that advertisements paid for by the taxpayer are public information campaigns which tell people about changes to benefits or key changes to law which have an impact on people's lives.

Oppositions of all colours always complain that governments use taxpayers' money to fund party political campaigns. The Tories complained last month that a £15m government advertising campaign to promote benefits to pensioners, fronted by actress Dame Thora Hird, came close to a party political broadcast.

Mr Blair, as a rising frontbencher, campaigned against advertising costs under the Thatcher government which increased fivefold to £100m a year in the year before the 1987 election. As a shadow industry spokesman, Mr Blair complained to the Independent Broadcasting Authority about the £40m "Tell Sid" campaign to persuade people to buy shares in the newly privatised British Gas.

fields.headline: Spending without taxes
fields.standfirst: It isn't possible and we had better admit it
fields.trailText: Once again, Tony Blair is apparently all set to promise that Labour will not raise the basic or higher rates of income tax during the next parliament if Labour is re-elected.
fields.body:
Once again, Tony Blair is apparently all set to promise that Labour will not raise the basic or higher rates of income tax during the next parliament if Labour is re-elected. How then is he to finance his admirable plans to make spending on state schools match private ones, to abolish child poverty and raise health spending to European levels? The public, fed up with the wanton deterioration of public services, is overwhelmingly behind him. Why does he think they will resist paying more taxes for improvements?

We know why. It is the Today programme factor - the prospect that during every radio or television broadcast ministers make during the election campaign they will be taunted relentlessly by interviewers and opposition politicians about the imminence of income tax increases. Who will pay, and how much? This is bizarre, because it will not banish the issue: if they deny income tax rises they will be accused of planning increases in "stealth" taxes. It is time to grow up: this is the right moment to revive the old tradition of ministers not commenting on future tax changes. Why? It is irresponsible for a chancellor to rule out tax changes because cyclical swings in the economy often make changes necessary for prudent economic management, let alone to finance vital spending plans. Every poll points to a big Labour victory. The chancellor is sitting on a budget surplus previous Conservative administrations could only dream about. And he has proved himself (so far) to be a more prudent chancellor than any of his Tory predecessors. Moreover, given the power to raise income tax he may not need to use it, at least in the very short term. Why? Although there is a strong case in equity to raise the top rate of tax from 40% to 50%, in the real world this would raise only a bit more than £3bn (less than a third of last year's £11bn "natural" rise in income tax revenue). The chancellor may think it is not worth the electoral flak for such modest revenue - if there are other revenue sources.

There's the rub. Notwithstanding his huge budget surplus and the £22.5bn windfall from the auction of radio spectrum, long-term sources of alternative revenues needed to resuscitate Britain's infrastructure are drying up. Globalisation and the rise of internet trading are eroding national tax bases. Governments can only remove mortgage relief and the tax privileges of insurance companies once. Unless the government is to find new sources of revenue - such as taxing capital gains on house sales and increases in land values, or through a new energy tax - then sooner or later the users of the new hospitals and schools will be asked to pay. And so they should. Nothing comes for nothing. It is vital that the government does not deviate from the huge spending needed to give Britain a social infrastructure for the new century. If the chancellor, by some magical means, can find the money without increasing income tax, then fine. But if he can't, he must bite the bullet and remind Britain's voters that they can't will the end without providing the means.

webTitle: Northern work ethic wins the day

fields.headline: Northern work ethic wins the day
fields.trailText: The chief executive of lottery operator Camelot, Dianne Thompson, puts her business acumen down to her "northern work ethic".
fields.body:
The chief executive of lottery operator Camelot, Dianne Thompson, puts her business acumen down to her "northern work ethic".

Named Businesswoman of the Year yesterday, the 50-year-old fought a six-month public battle with Sir Richard Branson over the lottery licence last year. Seemingly against the odds, she won. Yesterday, a spokesman for Sir Richard said: "He'll be pleased. He's got a lot of respect for her."

Putting aside her champagne - Veuve Clicquot sponsored the annual award - a delighted Ms Thompson recalled the fight as "stressful and very fraught".

Anxious to share her victory, she talked about the great team work of 800 Camelot staff. In flat, Yorkshire tones, Ms Thompson described personal ability, rather than gender, as crucial to success in business.

She regretted the day she described herself as a "woman with balls, balls of steel", but said she made tough decisions during her 30-year career which has spanned nine jobs in business ranging from ICI to the Co-operative Wholesale Society (CWS). Sacking 2,500 workers at Ratners, the troubled jeweller, is probably the moment she brandished her "balls of steel" most memorably.

But it was for last year's high-profile fight with Sir Richard to win the second lottery licence that she beat 70 other business women to yesterday's accolade. The daughter of a butcher and a Clarks' shoe fitter, she has strived to forge a new image for Camelot since joining in 1997, moving the organisation away from the fat-cattery associated with the previous regime.

After graduating in French and English, Batley-born Ms Thompson had no particular aspirations. A careers' adviser suggested marketing; she bought an "all you need to know" book and started with the CWS.

"Marketing is a great profession. I'm very down to earth, pragmatic and straight forward. Marketing is 70% common sense and 30% flair and intuition," she said.

She regards her private life as less than successful, as her career has cost her her mar riage. A single mother, she says her relationship with her 16-year-old daughter Joanna is very close. Ms Thompson insists on a close affinity to the working class despite her six figure salary and designer clothes. "I haven't changed at all. My values haven't changed. My friends haven't changed," she said. She will receive champagne every year on her birthday -December 31 - as a result of winning the award.

fields.headline: Manu Dibango
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
If African superstar Manu Dibango is anything like his music, he must be a very happy man. This concert was a riotous celebration from start to finish, with the enormous Afro-funk band generating wave upon wave of euphoria in the auditorium.

The drummers, horn section, various singers and guitarists had already taken the stage when Dibango started playing in the wings, serenading us with a leisurely saxophone refrain before strolling into view, resplendent in blue shoes and a big spangly shirt. From the start his tone was as smooth as melted chocolate, his delivery as refreshing as a summer breeze. Some people play the saxophone with their whole bodies, but Dibango made it appear impossibly easy, occasionally looking like he wasn't even playing.

It was immediately clear that in terms of musical style, a melting-pot strategy had been employed. Dibango started his life's work in Cameroon, moved to Paris to learn classical music, then got turned on to jazz and soul. As a result, his compositions and arranging present a colourful patchwork of influences, from Stax-derived guitar riffs to cantering calypso shuffles, classic R&B horn lines to bebop rhythms and sassy American funk. The shrill horn section reflected the leader's love of Duke Ellington, while the general streetside flavour of the music showed a clear debt to Louis Armstrong and the other founding fathers of New Orleans jazz.

The show was awash with infectious humour. Dibango insisted on staring straight into the face of each soloist during their big moment, egging them on with toots of his saxophone before exchanging exuberant high fives. At one point he pretended to terrorise his trumpet player, backing him into a corner behind a speaker stack, then encouraging him back out with apologetic kisses. The atmosphere on stage so resembled a huge party that it wasn't long before everyone was up and dancing.

Inevitably, the high point of the evening was Dibango's big pop hit Soul Makossa, which was socked to us with such good-spirited abandon that it generated an enormous burst of laughter rather than a round of applause. If Dibango walked on stage the happiest man alive, he walked off again even happier.

 At the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), tomorrow, then at Ronnie Scott's, London W1 (020-7439 0747), April 30-May 5.

fields.headline: The Pirates of Penzance
fields.standfirst:
Savoy Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Savoy Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
When the humour genes were being handed out, I missed the one that makes British people of a certain age laugh uproariously at the Victorian jokes in Gilbert and Sullivan. I sit there stony faced while nearly everyone around me dissolves into laughter at the toothless satire. So maybe D'Oyly Carte's production of The Pirates of Penzance, directed by Stuart Maunder and first seen here in 1998, will find more sympathy elsewhere.

We like to think that period performance is a recent phenomenon, a product of the last 30 years of the 20th century, but that overlooks the D'Oyly Carte company, which has been staging these Savoy operas in much the same way for well over a century. Though Roger Kirk's leafy designs suggest a rainforest and a Mayan temple more than a secluded Cornish beach and a crumbling stately pile, the production is otherwise ordinary, two-dimensional stuff. Even Gilbert and Sullivan might have thought it pretty staid.

Everything is sanitised. The pirates have standard-issue pirate costumes (shouldn't they be just a bit grubby?); the Major-General's daughters wear chaste white dresses; the action is equally bland. One longed for a bit of healthy smut - goodness knows, with all those swords and truncheons being waved about there's the scope for it. But G&S fans know what they like, and D'Oyly Carte just go on giving it to them.

Musically, too, it could be a lot better. Sullivan's music is full of catchy tunes and sly parodies of his European contemporaries, as well as occasional discursions into much darker, deeper musical worlds (just where does the act one chorus "Hail Poetry" come from?). That doesn't make it easy to sing or play however. Under John Owen Edwards the orchestra sounded tentative on Tuesday, and the cast is a mixed bag, to say the least. Royce Mills delivers the Major-General's patter song with regulation adroitness and Gareth Jones is a witty Sergeant of Police, but otherwise the best voices are to be found among the women. The soprano of Charlotte Page as Mabel shines out; she has a musicality and sense of style that is too often lacking elsewhere.

 Until June 16. Box office: 020-7836 8888

fields.headline: Bookham sees worse to come
fields.trailText: Bookham yesterday predicted that falling demand for optical components that has shattered its share price over the past six months could worsen.
fields.body:
Bookham yesterday predicted that falling demand for optical components that has shattered its share price over the past six months could worsen.

Shares in the manufacturer fell almost 10% to 271p. They have now lost 95% of their value since peaking last year at a level which saw the Oxford-based company briefly included in the FTSE 100 index.

In a statement accompanying first quarter figures showing a doubling of losses, Bookham warned that the second quarter could see a "sharp downturn" in sales as its customers, which largely sell to debt-stricken telecoms companies, defer orders.

Bookham's four biggest customers - Nortel, Fujitsu, Lucent and Marconi - are all facing financial issues of their own and analysts believe they may not order as many components as first planned.

Around Bookham 190 workers have already taken voluntary redundancy and the chief executive, Georgio Anania, refused to rule out further cuts. "We continue to look at all options as we examine our cost structure," he said.

Capital expenditure for the year is likely to be cut from £80m to £50m which some analysts fear may work to the detriment of product development.

In the three months to March 31, Bookham reported a pretax loss of £11.7m, compared to a loss of £6m in the previous period. Revenues climbed almost four times on a year on year basis to £11.6m.

The figures were in line with revised forecasts issued in January when Bookham first warned that sales were starting to dry up.

Consecutive warnings from the company, plus an unexpected fundraising exercise shortly after it floated, have damaged Bookham's credibility in financial circles.

The number of analysts following the stock is diminishing and, while those that do cover it believe the £238m cash in the bank is enough to take Bookham through to profitability, few are advising clients to buy the shares.

Mr Anania put a brave face on the situation. "We're proud of these figures which are at the top end of where we said they would be," he said.

"It's very tough to gauge what will happen beyond the second quarter but the latest indication from a couple of our customers is that their fourth quarter expectations are a little higher than where they had originally thought.

Investors had been hoping for evidence of customers for new and higher margin components but none was provided.

Mr Anania said: "We've got more than 40 potential customers looking at the products and it's looking reasonably good but we've not announced anything because it's not in our competitive interest."

Founder Andrew Rickman has dropped his dual role of chairman and chief executive to focus on the former office, with Mr Anania taking operational control.

The company is still seeking to replace its finance director, who retired last year owing to ill-health.

fields.headline: Rappers challenge tappers in Bounce
fields.standfirst:
Bounce
Roundhouse, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Bounce
Roundhouse, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
A street-dance troupe from Sweden with a show called Bounce doesn't exactly conjure up the mean streets of New York where hip-hop culture started. As soon as the dancers hit the stage you spot a scrubbed, eager quality about some of them that's far more suggestive of stage school than inner-city ghetto. Yet while Bounce is really a family show - mixing parent-friendly disco and lindy hop amid the breakdancing, and staging boisterously comic gags to further soften the dancers' image - it does convincingly showcase some of the sharpest moves of the street genre.

The production carries a persuasive whiff of urban outfitting. The bare bricks and cold draughts of the Roundhouse provide the perfect location; it's made even more authentic by Lez Brotherston's stage design, with its tangle of iron steps, abrasive lights and wire-mesh fencing. The dancers wear an assortment of trainers and hoodies, and my kids alerted me to several desirably current tracks within the score.

As an ensemble the performers don't venture far beyond the standard jerky, hunkered-down style of breaking and popping, but the show does allow individuals to display some breathtaking star turns. Two tiny breakdancers execute multiple spins on their heads, elbows, backs - even on a skateboard - with the manic speed of cartoon characters. A tapper challenges a rapper to a wild and witty duel of rhythm and a guy who starts out sketching a few ballet steps (causing predictable derision among the other dancers) proves his street cred by segueing from pirouette to faultless breakdance in a second.

These highlights keep the audience sharp and keen but there are too many passages where Bounce loses its nerve and tries to route itself back into more mundane show-dance territory. It strives for a bit of sex (the women's belly-dancing routine) and a bit of art (a slow-motion reprise of the standard moves), and in doing so strikes a dull, even amateurish note. At its best Bounce gives us a classy, lively alternative to commercial dance theatre; at its worst it's a feeble apeing of the mainstream.

 Until June 10. Box office: 020-7316 4768.

webTitle: BBC chairman quits for BT role

fields.headline: BBC chairman quits for BT role
fields.standfirst:
 BT boss bows to shareholder pressure
 BBC searches for replacement
 No 10 pays tribute to Bland
fields.trailText:
 BT boss bows to shareholder pressure
 BBC searches for replacement
 No 10 pays tribute to Bland
fields.body:
The BBC chairman, Christopher Bland, was today confirmed as replacement for his counterpart at BT, Sir Iain Vallance, who has bowed to shareholder pressure and decided to step down.

Sir Christopher will take up his new post at BT on May 1, although Sir Iain is to stay on as "president emeritus" of the company until July 2002.

Sir Iain, who has been with BT since 1987, has been criticised as BT's debt has mounted and its stock price plummeted in recent months.

"For some time now I have felt it right that I should stand down once we could find an able successor," he said.

He has also come under pressure to cut the group's massive £30bn debt mountain, built up from buying third-generation mobile phone operations and stakes in overseas companies.

BT, which was once a state-owned monopoly, said its new chairman would be Sir Christopher, who has headed the BBC's board of governors since 1996.

"BT is an excellent company operating in a highly competitive sector," Sir Christopher said. "I look forward to chairing the board through the next challenging and exciting period."

Sir Christopher said he planned to remain in his BBC job until the corporation found a new chairman.

Downing Street paid tribute to Sir Christopher's achievements as BBC chairman. A spokeswoman for No 10 said: "Sir Christopher Bland has been a very fine chairman of the BBC and will no doubt make a huge contribution to BT when he takes over as chairman.

"The government was informed in advance and was pleased to hear he had agreed to stay on at the BBC until a successor has been found."

It had been speculated that BT's chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield's head would also roll - although under today's plans he will keep his post.

webTitle: UK economy vulnerable to recession, says Hague

fields.headline: UK economy vulnerable to recession, says Hague
fields.standfirst: Special report: global recession
fields.trailText: William Hague will today issue a stark warning that Britain will suffer more than its competitors in a global recession because of the alleged failure of Gordon Brown to prepare the economy for a possible downturn.
fields.body:
William Hague will today issue a stark warning that Britain will suffer more than its competitors in a global recession because of the alleged failure of Gordon Brown to prepare the economy for a possible downturn.

In an intensification of his assault on the government's handling of the economy, the Tory leader will lambaste Mr Brown for raising taxes and increasing burdens on business, adding: "We're in bad shape to hold our own in an economic downturn."

Mr Hague will be careful not to predict a recession - the Tories have painful memories of their 1998 attack on the "downturn made in Downing Street" which backfired when the economy performed well. Amid growing fears, however, that Britain could be hit by the American downturn, he will say that Mr Brown has left the economy vulnerable by failing to cut taxes and reduce regulatory burdens on business.

In a speech at the Institute of Directors in London, Mr Hague will say that four conditions need to be met if Britain is to survive a global recession unscathed:

 Falling taxes;

 A cut in the burden on businesses to ensure they remain competitive;

 A reformed welfare system to keep people off benefits and in work;

 Interest rates set in Britain.

Mr Hague will claim that on all but one count - the setting of interest rates by the Bank of England - the government has failed. "The government is failing to cut taxes, failing to reduce regulations, failing to reform welfare," he will say in his speech which is being organised by the rightwing Centre for Policy Studies.

Drawing a line between the Tories, who have pledged tax cuts of £8bn in the next parliament, and Labour, which he claimed would continue to raise taxes by stealth, Mr Hague said that Mr Brown was the "opposite of a prudent" chancellor.

"Relentlessly raising taxes is the opposite of prudent preparation for economic difficulties," Mr Hague will say. The Tory leader will claim that real prudence requires careful preparation for the unexpected.

"The time to fix your roof is when the sun is shining," Mr Hague will say, quoting the chancellor's favourite US president.

Mr Hague's speech will be dismissed by Labour as an irresponsible attempt to talk down the economy, which is facing testing times. The chancellor gave his strongest hint of the challenge ahead earlier this week when he spoke of "the current instability in the financial and commodity markets".

However, Labour, which is likely to pledge that income tax will not be raised in the next parliament, is confident that the Conservatives are still seen as the party of "boom and bust".

fields.headline: The belly-dancing queen
fields.standfirst:
Natacha Atlas
Union Chapel, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Natacha Atlas
Union Chapel, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Briefly in the early 1990s, the east-west fusion pioneered by bands such as Transglobal Underground threatened to become the next big thing. But what seemed tantalising in theory proved untranslatable in practice, and the sound-clash of Arabic pop and British dance music only finds commercial success now in the diminutive form of Transglobal's Anglo/Egyptian vocalist, Natacha Atlas.

It takes just a moment in her vibrant company to appreciate why her infrequent London shows are generally standing room only. Atlas has a commanding presence not unlike that of rappers such as Li'l Kim, although in other respects (except perhaps a fondness for sequins), they couldn't be less similar. Her natural authority, which only lapsed during snatches of giggly banter with the band, derives from the power of her music. Mainly sung in Arabic to the accompaniment of western and ancient eastern instruments, it coiled upward to the ceiling, quickly coaxing the front rows into self-consciously imitating her dreamy dancing. It doesn't get more multicultural than an English audience swaying to Islamic pop in a 19th-century Christian chapel.

The set extensively drew on her new album, Ayeshteni, which was recorded in Egypt and steers away from the UK trance sound of the first three LPs. Two drummers, one using a tiny hand-held instrument, conjured up a loping beat that rose and fell in time to Atlas's ululations. She sang with increasing urgency, periodically switching into French, relying on intonation to reach those of us who hadn't a clue what she was singing. But a grasp of the lyrics wouldn't have enhanced this seductive experience; her voice, the whirling music and a kaleidoscopic video backdrop provided enough sensory stimulation to be going on with.

The one English-language number, a cover of I Put a Spell on You, was the cue for her famous belly- dancing. As the song swirled to its wild-eyed climax - "I put a spell on you because you're mine!" she wailed from far down in her diaphragm - she whipped off a gold kaftan to reveal a sequinned bra and skirt. She twirled in slow circles, rippling a generous stomach as the drums increased and the audience whooped. Right then Atlas was speaking a language that needed no translation; a stunning end to a sumptuous show.

webTitle: April 26, 2019: what happened to the cash?

fields.headline: April 26, 2019: what happened to the cash?
fields.standfirst: It's windfall day! Eighteen years ago, the prime minister, Tony Blair, unveiled the so-called baby-bond scheme. Today, the first generation of Blairbabies can cash in their Government Organised Redemption Deeds on New Savings or, as they are now known, Gordons. Derek Brown reports
fields.trailText: It's windfall day! Eighteen years ago, the prime minister, Tony Blair, unveiled the so-called baby-bond scheme. Today, the first generation of Blairbabies can cash in their Government Organised Redemption Deeds on New Savings or, as they are now known, Gordons. Derek Brown reports.
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited apologises for this old-fashioned web transmission. We are experiencing temporary technical difficulties with our thought-transference server.

Way back in 2001, people sneered at baby bonds. They were a pointless gimmick; a diversion from the real issue, a crude attempt to woo voters to New Labour.

Today, as the first virtual cheques for up to £7000 are distributed, we know better.

True, the money will not go far towards the government's original aims of 18 years ago. Tuition fees, for example, have just been increased to £35,000 a term, and the average price of a new home is £40,000,000.

Still, £7000 is not to be sneezed at. It will buy an off peak single fare from London to Saffron Walden on the Railtrack Heritage Experience. It's enough for two pints of Kreem Kwench Kweerbeer, or admission to the latest must-see hologram, The Life, Times and Teachings of Dame Julie Burchill.

Thanks to the twin miracles of zero inflation and cheap Chinese labour, £7000 will also buy any number of high-tech gizmos. Indeed, since computers were made obsolete by hand-held knowledge interface serial servers (Kisses), young people have been able to access the very latest in entertainment and personal development tools for the price of, say, a vegetable-effect burger with added digestion granules.

Among the latest eye-catching software offerings are Slightly Naughty Oral Gratification, Bathroom Oriented Graphics, and My Old Ginger. Or, as they are known in street language, Snog, Bog and Mog.

There is also a handy new programme available for calculating the value of future child investment trusts. It's called Creating Outsize Budgets By Lavish Election-Related Subterfuges.

webTitle: Delay in Shire-BioChem deal dismays traders

fields.headline: Delay in Shire-BioChem deal dismays traders
fields.trailText: There was growing anger in the financial markets about the handling of Shire Pharmaceuticals' merger with Canadian firm BioChem yesterday, after rumours of a breakdown in talks triggered a lurch in the two companies' shares.
fields.body:
There was growing anger in the financial markets about the handling of Shire Pharmaceuticals' merger with Canadian firm BioChem yesterday, after rumours of a breakdown in talks triggered a lurch in the two companies' shares.

The £5bn deal, which was supposed to be completed last month, has been delayed by the Canadian government. Reports that talks had collapsed sent BioChem's shares down 12% at one point yesterday, while Shire's jumped 30p to £11.40.

Sources close to the two companies insisted last night that talks were still on track, with an update due alongside Shire's quarterly results today. A 30-day review period is likely to be extended.

The uncertainty has caused havoc for arbitrage dealers, who are betting on the exact amount Shire will pay for BioChem. One Wall Street trader said: "This whole thing has been a complete mess-up. Shire went in there to talk to the Canadians and clearly had no clue how to handle it. They really screwed things up at the first attempt."

Shire has been criticised for initially going solo to negotiate with the Canadian authorities alone. BioChem executives, with knowledge of local issues, were brought in to help only when industry minister Brian Tobin refused to accept the deal.

Mr Tobin wants guarantees that jobs and investment will remain in the politically sensitive province of Quebec. Shire is reluctant to have its hands tied.

Shire's adviser, Deutsche Bank, has been criticised for the complexity of the terms of the deal. Shire will pay a quantity of shares determined by the average price over a 15-day period. One trader complained that it was unclear whether this pricing period ended three trading days - or three calendar days - prior to completion, a potentially crucial detail.

Arbitrageurs have been buying BioChem shares in anticipation of this pricing, but have been left with multi-million pound "positions" as a result of the hold-up. One market source claimed that rumours of the deal's demise originated at Lehman Brothers, which is said to have suffered a setback when a lender recalled shares in BioChem. A Lehman spokesman denied this: "We do not start rumours."

Last week, there was a frenzy of speculation that the merger had been agreed. This theory evaporated when dealers discovered that Mr Tobin was in Florida, observing the lift-off of the Space Shuttle.

Shire declined to comment. Shire wants the deal to reduce its reliance on Adderall, a big- selling drug for attention deficit disorder. BioChem makes drugs for Aids, cancer and hepatitis B.

webTitle: Staff scepticism greets Barclays' plan to open all hours

fields.headline: Staff scepticism greets Barclays' plan to open all hours
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Barclays is understood to be planning dramatic changes to the working regime at its 1,700 branches under a plan to lengthen hours and extend weekend opening.
fields.body:
Barclays is understood to be planning dramatic changes to the working regime at its 1,700 branches under a plan to lengthen hours and extend weekend opening.

The move, amounting to a u-turn which could be announced as soon as today, could create the need for a further 2,000 posts in the bank's 20,000-strong branch workforce.

It is understood that Barclays - which has shed 7,000 jobs from its 70,000 total workforce in the last two years - has decided against further redundancies. By deciding to open branches for longer and introducing wider Saturday opening, the bank is thought likely to tell staff this morning that the equivalent of as many as 2,000 new, flexible working positions will be created.

This is because the bank is expected to pledge to existing employees that it will not force them to alter their working patterns.

The new jobs will most likely cover unconventional hours - earlier in the mornings or late in the evenings and on weekends - which existing staff may refuse. New staff, however, will be required to work more flexible hours.

Barclays, which caused a furore a year ago over plans to close 171 branches on the same day, is thought to be planning to open as many as 1,300 of its branches for longer.

It is not thought to be planning to reopen any closed branches or open new ones in other parts of the country. However, branches on high streets are expected to increasingly open on Saturday, while those in big shopping centres are expected to adopt the longer opening hours of the malls.

The number of jobs in the banking industry has been declining rapidly as a result of attempts by the high street banks to cut costs by axing branches and staff.

Expectations of further mergers and acquisitions among the leading players - raised again yesterday by news of Halifax and Bank of Scotland's merger talks - have further raised concerns about long-term job prospects.

If Barclays' plan for more opening hours does manage to create new jobs in the industry it would defy this trend. Its promise to staff that the move will create jobs rather than remove them will be greeted with some scepticism among staff who were said to have been demoralised by last year's branch closures.

fields.headline: Fierce debate at the Royal Exchange
fields.standfirst:
Les Blancs
Royal Exchange, Manchester
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Les Blancs
Royal Exchange, Manchester
Rating: **
fields.body:
It is hard to imagine how Lorraine Hansberry's play, set in an African country under British colonial rule where the people are mounting an armed struggle for independence, could be staged with more aplomb than it is here. Equally, it is hard to imagine why anyone would want to stage this clunky, schematic play that offers debate but little drama.

Hansberry, who is best known for A Raisin in the Sun, started to write this play in the early 1960s. It was completed by her ex-husband following her death in 1965. It tells of two brothers returning to their African village for their father's funeral as the country erupts into violence. Tshembe is an intellectual who has travelled the world and been part of the independence struggle abroad; Abiosen has embraced Christianity and dreams of being Africa's first black archbishop.

Near the village is a mission hospital where for 40 years Europeans have dispensed religion and medicine to the locals; here both Tshembe and Abiosen's young half-brother Eric, neither black nor white, help out. It is the hospital that becomes the focus of conflict.

Pretty soon the lines are drawn between white and black, Europe and Africa, one brother and another, with a few characters allowed to loiter on the fence. Every character represents something, whether it is the white, liberal American journalist who believes that talking solves everything or the trigger-happy British army officer whose conceited paternalism manifests itself in more ways than one.

The fact that for centuries Africa has been plundered and that those providing aid can be part of a system of oppression was hardly mentioned on stage 30 years ago. Now, though, even primary school children know something of the scars that colonialism have left on Africa. When Les Blancs was premiered on Broadway in 1970 it was perceived by some as black propaganda, but if anything the difficulty with the play is that it is so even-handed. Hansberry allows everyone his or her say, again and again.

It is beautifully acted, particularly by Paterson Joseph as the brother drawn into revolution, but what might once have seemed radical now only seems heartfelt and lacking in complexity.

• Until May 12. Box office: 0161-833 9833.

fields.headline: Fiscal brick wall ahead
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair wants to repeat Labour's pledge not to raise income tax. But with the income gap widening, it may not be a tenable position

Special report: Tax and spending
fields.trailText: Tony Blair wants to promise that Labour will not raise basic or higher rates of income tax. Despite the poll lead and Tory disarray, he feels a need to repeat his highly symbolic 1997 pledge.
fields.body:
Tony Blair wants to promise that Labour will not raise basic or higher rates of income tax. Despite the poll lead and Tory disarray, he feels a need to repeat his highly symbolic 1997 pledge.

What it tells the electorate - erroneously - is that we can have high-grade public services and the abolition of child poverty and feel no pain. What it also does, probably, is commit Labour to the same sleight of hand on taxation it has used repeatedly during the past four years. Gordon Brown, or whoever succeeds him as chancellor, will once again have to pirouette as a fiscal drag queen.

With the kind of confidence that invites hubris, the government says that it has enough in the kitty to pay for existing promises on health, education and poverty. But, short of significant new borrowing, to improve on them the money would have to come in part from an increase in income tax. Knowing nods from No 11 at that point: you can make a pledge on tax rates and still tinker surreptitiously with allowances and thresholds. Labour could, of course, increase the tax burden on business, though that would sit ill with its rhetoric. It could go on increasing the proportion of spending paid for out of indirect taxes, fuel duty, tobacco and the like. Such taxes have environmental and health benefits, but they also tend to hit the poorest hardest.

And that is the nub of the promise on income tax that No 10 seems so keen to make: it would severely curtail Labour's capacity to make Britain a fairer place.

The paradox of Labour in the Blair-Brown era is just how fiscally active it has been, while sticking to its headline promise on income tax. The Tories are right: Labour has taxed and taxed again. Since 1997, tax rose as a share of national income by nearly 3%. And better-off people pay a lot of it: the top 1% of households in the income distribution pay 21% of income tax, and the top 10% pay 50% - a reminder, says Andrew Dilnot of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, that top people do most of the earning.

Income inequality rose under Thatcher, declined somewhat under Major (thanks to the Tories' policy-induced recession) and has been rising again since the mid 1990s. Past history would indicate that with earnings rising as they have been, the gap between haves and have-nots would go on growing. Unless the government intervenes.

Unlike lots of things the government does, state manipulation of incomes does work. Before taxes and benefits are taken into account, the ratio between the average income of the top and bottom fifth of households is about 19 to one. After the taxman calls and social security and pension cheques are paid, the ratio is cut to four to one. The chart is taken from www.statistics.gov.uk/ themes, and shows how income changes thanks to government. In 1999, income tax cost households £90bn; cash benefits paid them some £99bn. But better-off households paid the former while poorer households received the latter.

Indirect taxes are regressive so that, before benefits are factored in, households tend to pay roughly the same fraction of their income in tax. John Hills of the London School of Economics says: "Over all, the tax system is at best proportional and it's only like that because direct taxes are progressive. If you constrict what you do on that front, then what the tax system as a whole can contribute to making things fairer is reduced."

Labour has been lucky and ingenuous. The 1997 promise was about "rates". The tax take is also affected by reliefs and allowances, and Gordon Brown had a go at, for example, mortgage relief and the married couples' allowance. The tax pledge did not prevent Labour making national insurance (which is income tax in all but name) more progressive.

Labour has helped lower-income households through increases in child benefit and child allowances within income support. Over the next few years the working families tax credit and the minimum income guarantee for pensioners will kick in - they are covered in existing spending plans. But if they were to become more generous (and so more effective in terms of the final distribution of income) they would have to be paid for by new money.

If the slowdown in growth is "normal", economists say, Mr Brown's spending plans should hold water. After all, the Treasury's sums recently got the imprimatur of the International Monetary Fund. But Mr Brown has probably had more than his fair share of "happy surprises". Andrew Dilnot cites windfall gains from the introduction of self-assessment by the Inland Revenue and says Labour probably deploys £10bn-£11bn a year more than it could ever have forecast.

The next chancellor still has tricks to take. Personal allowances could be confined to basic-rate payers - showing again that a pledge on rates mean the incidence of income tax will still rise for many. You could, as Labour has, further increase tax on hydrocarbons or raise VAT and use the money on benefits for poorer households (though when they came to spend it, they would find they could not buy as much).

But up the road looms a fiscal brick wall. The commission convened by the Fabian Society argued recently that income tax rises are politically tolerable and necessary if social democracy is to be achieved. So to what Fabian general secretary Michael Jacobs calls a "simple fact". The tax that people pay on earnings "is the only one correlated with income. It is the only mechanism you can deploy when incomes at the top end are rising so fast."

fields.headline: Saving for the future
fields.standfirst: Before it digs deep into its pocket, Labour needs to consider how its new "baby bonds" will be used in a constructive way.
fields.trailText: Before it digs deep into its pocket, Labour needs to consider how its new "baby bonds" will be used in a constructive way. Marianne Curphey reports
fields.body:
At the heart of the debate over the government's new proposals for baby bonds are very real political concerns about how the State should support the poorest members of society.

Gordon Brown has already announced measures in previous Budgets to help children in families on the poverty line. But the latest thinking to come out of Downing Street is a new, state-sponsored version of that old-fashioned savings incentive - pocket money.

Parents have long been aware of the virtue of giving children small amounts of cash as an incentive to save for the future or for a toy or item of clothing they have set their hearts on. But pocket money is usually handed out as a reward for doing jobs around the house - making explicit the link between effort and income.

Some teenagers are encouraged to go even further in their pursuit of disposable income. Many of the UK's most famous and successful entrepreneurs first discovered the value of money and the opportunities it provides by doing a local paper round or swapping collectable cards in the playground.

While the government's scheme to encourage children within poorer families to adopt the savings habit is laudable; it neglects to forge that link between effort and reward. Opposition parties have already denounced as patronising the suggestion that the £5,000 that a child will potentially have built up by the age of 18 should be spent on "worthwhile" causes such as further education.

There will be much hand-wringing in the future about how this "free" money from the government will be used in a constructive way, rather than an opportunity to splash out on new designer kit once the cash becomes available. And how will the scheme be administered? Will bank managers have to interview young customers who want to withdraw their nest egg? These are questions that the government, as self-appointed "parent", needs to consider before it digs into its pocket.

 Marianne Curphey is editor of Guardian Unlimited Money and the author of E-cash, the complete guide to managing your money online. Buy it at Bol.

fields.headline: The biotech buzzword is fusion
fields.standfirst: Born of cloning and enthused by genome mapping, Europe's 75bn industry is forging alliances to take on US rivals
fields.trailText: In bright spring weather, Amsterdam's canal-side cafes proved tempting for Europe's leading biotechnology entrepreneurs, in town this week for the annual Bio-Deal conference. The mood among delegates was relaxed - there were even some attempts at jokes.
fields.body:
In bright spring weather, Amsterdam's canal-side cafes proved tempting for Europe's leading biotechnology entrepreneurs, in town this week for the annual Bio-Deal conference. The mood among delegates was relaxed - there were even some attempts at jokes. Michael Ade, director of German company Ingenium, recited the names of his firm's menagerie of deformed mice - Sumo was genetically altered to be vastly overweight, while "Arnold mighty mouse" and "Claudia beauty mouse" were luckier recipients of Ingenium's gene fiddling.

"These are murine Adams and Eves," he said. "If you take the Bible literally, those two are the first examples of cloning."

Such quips are not to everyone's taste. The public is deeply sceptical, if not angry, about using animals as drugs factories, and biotech is struggling to win popular approval generally. In a Eurobarometer survey last year, only 41% of the 16,000 people polled agreed that biotech would improve the quality of life over the next 20 years.

Those within the industry are in confident form, however, having enjoyed unprecedented success in 2000. Ernst & Young's annual snapshot of life sciences, published yesterday, calculates that European biotech raised €6.5bn (£4bn) last year, against €1.1bn in 1999, and the total capitalisation of public companies in the sector leapt 108% to €75bn.

"European biotech had a great year in 2000," says the report's lead author Glenn Crocker. "Every record which could have been broken has been broken.

"We have now got a fundamentally sound industry, with a set of companies which are actually delivering products - which is, of course, what they're there for."

Setting the pace

Britain is setting the pace, accounting for five of the continent's top 10 biotech companies. Celltech and Shire are in the FTSE 100 index, producing both medicines and profits. Of Europe's 105 public biotech companies, 48 are in Britain. Germany has a larger number of private companies but most of these are small, early-stage enterprises.

Last year's surge was driven by enthusiasm about the human genome project, which mapped the body's genetic structure for the first time. Biotech also gained on the back of the dot.com boom, as anything hi-tech became fashionable. The recent downturn in the stock market has depressed valuations, although biotech has suffered less than internet enterprise.

Despite this healthy picture, alarm bells are just beginning to ring. There is increasing concern that US biotechnology is pulling away from Europe's. Mr Crocker says: "By and large, you could have an almost identical biotech company, and it will be valued at almost twice as much in the US as in Europe."

In the conference hall at Amsterdam's luxury Krasnopolsky Hotel, overlooking the city's Dam Square, there was an audible intake of breath when one British firm, Vertex, mentioned that it had more than $700m (£476) cash in the bank after choosing to float in New York, rather than London.

"We're an Oxbridge company," explained vice-president Iain Buchanan. "We're based in Cambridge, Massachusetts and Oxford, in the UK."

Vertex's bank balance outstrips the wildest dreams of its European rivals. America is operating on a different scale - one US firm, Amgen, which has made a fortune from kidney drug Epogen, is capitalised at more than €70bn - as much as the entire European biotech industry.

In order to bridge this vast transatlantic gap, European firms are keen to form alliances, gaining strength in numbers and critical mass. This week's Bio-Deal conference was typical - executives took turns to give 25-minute presentations showcasing their products and technology, in the hope that someone in the room may be a compatible partner.

Antibodies

British firm KS Biomedix was first up, detailing its method of capturing antibodies from sheep, while Pharmagene explained its technique of testing drugs in human tissue, rather than using animals.

A German company, Micromet, then explained its "Bites" - bispecific t-cell engagers, which activate helpful t-cells in the blood in the area of cancer tumours. "Bites promise to reshape immunotherapy," said vice-president Christian Itin.

Some companies were explicit in their needs - gene therapy specialist Austrian Nordic declared that it wanted a partner to inject precisely €9.7m. Thrombogenics, which takes advantage of Belgian government grants because it carries out research in Flemish-speaking areas, urged someone to step forward to fund phase-three trials of its drug for heart attacks.

Nearly every speaker kept to the conference's 25-minute limit for presentations - a reflection, according to one delegate, of increasing professionalism in the industry.

There were few questions from the floor, because the real business of the event was behind closed doors - in a corridor of "partnering rooms", where executives could meet in private to thrash out deals.

Most companies can boast a relatively healthy financial position, having taken advantage of last year's boom to raise funds from investors. Ernst & Young reckons 60% of firms have at least four years' cash in the bank, while 87% have at least 12 months' money.

This means they can be selective, with less need to sell their science to multinational pharmaceutical corporations. Biotech pundit Mike Ward says: "The reasons people are looking for partners are much less defensive. The desperate need for cash is no longer there - it's more strategic." One delegate commented: "A year ago, the attitude was that any old deal would do the job. Now, people can afford to be more discerning."

The number of tie-ups between biotech companies leapt 41% to 539 last year - including 54 mergers or acquisitions, and 403 strategic alliances. Yet for many in the industry, that is still not enough.

Mr Crocker suggests that the only way for Europe to reach a level comparable to the US would be to form a hi-tech stock market along the lines of New York's Nasdaq. The continental equivalent, Easdaq, has failed to take off.

He says: "Pooling resources has got to be the way forward. Europe is far too fragmented.

"There are some people who might ask whether it matters that the US is extending its lead. It certainly matters to governments, and it matters to employees."

One of Britain's best known biotech entrepreneurs, Sir Chris Evans, shares that concern. He told the Institute of Directors in London yesterday that there was no reason why Britain could not catch up with the US - but it would take at least 20 years. "We have got a quality of science that is on par with America but what they have is a huge venture capital community, entrepreneurial management and a fantastically vibrant stock market in Nasdaq," he said.

Dot.com bubble

Venture capital firms in the US were ploughing in two to three times as much cash at ever stage of development: "While our companies might raise $70m they will raise $470m at one go."

Now chairman of the incubator Merlin Bioscience, Sir Chris complained of the British view that biotech was little different from the dot.com bubble. A young broker, he said, had refused to support his plan to back a biotech venture into a dot.com shell, which had already raised £40m but had no operations. The broker said that biotech was no different from internet businesses. "That young broker did not know his arse from his elbow. I hope he is in the audience," he told Britain's leading directors.

Three years ago, the biotech world was rocked by the near-collapse of British Biotech, one of the industry's standard-bearers. This year, Dolly the sheep's creator, PPL Therapeutics, faces a funding crisis. But the background is very different - this time, confidence in the industry is much less fragile. Rather than battling to stay alive, companies are competing to create the first pan-European biotech multinational.

Biotech by numbers

Market capitalisation of leading European biotech companies, to end 2000 Serono Switzerland €16.4bn

Elan Ireland €13.9bn

Qiagen Netherlands €5.4bn

Celltech UK €5.1bn

Shire UK €4.3bn

Actelion Switzerland €2.3bn

Galen UK €2.1bn

Cambridge Antibody UK €2.09bn

Source: Ernst & Young

Of Europe's 105 public biotech companies, 48 are in Britain. Germany has a larger number of private companies but most of these are small, early-stage enterprises. Last year's surge was driven by enthusiasm about the human genome project, which mapped the body's genetic structure for the first time. Biotech also gained on the back of the dot.com boom, as anything hi-tech became fashionable. The recent downturn in the stock market has depressed valuations, although biotech has suffered less than internet enterprise. Despite this healthy picture, alarm bells are just beginning to ring. There is increasing concern that US biotechnology is pulling away from Europe's. Mr Crocker says: "By and large, you could have an almost identical biotech company, and it will be valued at almost twice as much in the US as in Europe." In the conference hall at Amsterdam's luxury Krasnopolsky Hotel, overlooking the city's Dam Square, there was an audible intake of breath when one British firm, Vertex, mentioned that it had more than $700m (£476) cash in the bank after choosing to float in New York, rather than London. "We're an Oxbridge company," explained vice-president Iain Buchanan. "We're based in Cambridge, Massachusetts and Oxford, in the UK." Vertex's bank balance outstrips the wildest dreams of its European rivals. America is operating on a different scale - one US firm, Amgen, which has made a fortune from kidney drug Epogen, is capitalised at more than €70bn - as much as the entire European biotech industry. In order to bridge this vast transatlantic gap, European firms are keen to form alliances, gaining strength in numbers and critical mass. This week's Bio-Deal conference was typical - executives took turns to give 25-minute presentations showcasing their products and technology, in the hope that someone in the room may be a compatible partner. Antibodies British firm KS Biomedix was first up, detailing its method of capturing antibodies from sheep, while Pharmagene explained its technique of testing drugs in human tissue, rather than using animals. A German company, Micromet, then explained its "Bites" - bispecific t-cell engagers, which activate helpful t-cells in the blood in the area of cancer tumours. "Bites promise to reshape immunotherapy," said vice-president Christian Itin. Some companies were explicit in their needs - gene therapy specialist Austrian Nordic declared that it wanted a partner to inject precisely €9.7m. Thrombogenics, which takes advantage of Belgian government grants because it carries out research in Flemish-speaking areas, urged someone to step forward to fund phase-three trials of its drug for heart attacks. Nearly every speaker kept to the conference's 25-minute limit for presentations - a reflection, according to one delegate, of increasing professionalism in the industry. There were few questions from the floor, because the real business of the event was behind closed doors - in a corridor of "partnering rooms", where executives could meet in private to thrash out deals. Most companies can boast a relatively healthy financial position, having taken advantage of last year's boom to raise funds from investors. Ernst & Young reckons 60% of firms have at least four years' cash in the bank, while 87% have at least 12 months' money. This means they can be selective, with less need to sell their science to multinational pharmaceutical corporations. Biotech pundit Mike Ward says: "The reasons people are looking for partners are much less defensive. The desperate need for cash is no longer there - it's more strategic." One delegate commented: "A year ago, the attitude was that any old deal would do the job. Now, people can afford to be more discerning." The number of tie-ups between biotech companies leapt 41% to 539 last year - including 54 mergers or acquisitions, and 403 strategic alliances. Yet for many in the industry, that is still not enough. Mr Crocker suggests that the only way for Europe to reach a level comparable to the US would be to form a hi-tech stock market along the lines of New York's Nasdaq. The continental equivalent, Easdaq, has failed to take off. He says: "Pooling resources has got to be the way forward. Europe is far too fragmented. "There are some people who might ask whether it matters that the US is extending its lead. It certainly matters to governments, and it matters to employees." One of Britain's best known biotech entrepreneurs, Sir Chris Evans, shares that concern. He told the Institute of Directors in London yesterday that there was no reason why Britain could not catch up with the US - but it would take at least 20 years. "We have got a quality of science that is on par with America but what they have is a huge venture capital community, entrepreneurial management and a fantastically vibrant stock market in Nasdaq," he said. Dot.com bubble Venture capital firms in the US were ploughing in two to three times as much cash at ever stage of development: "While our companies might raise $70m they will raise $470m at one go." Now chairman of the incubator Merlin Bioscience, Sir Chris complained of the British view that biotech was little different from the dot.com bubble. A young broker, he said, had refused to support his plan to back a biotech venture into a dot.com shell, which had already raised £40m but had no operations. The broker said that biotech was no different from internet businesses. "That young broker did not know his arse from his elbow. I hope he is in the audience," he told Britain's leading directors. Three years ago, the biotech world was rocked by the near-collapse of British Biotech, one of the industry's standard-bearers. This year, Dolly the sheep's creator, PPL Therapeutics, faces a funding crisis. But the background is very different - this time, confidence in the industry is much less fragile. Rather than battling to stay alive, companies are competing to create the first pan-European biotech multinational. webTitle: Liverani is first black player to win Italy cap

fields.headline: Liverani is first black player to win Italy cap
fields.trailText: Fabio Liverani will become the first black footballer to play for Italy when he lines up against South Africa today in a friendly in Perugia.
fields.body:
Fabio Liverani will become the first black footballer to play for Italy when he lines up against South Africa today in a friendly in Perugia.

The 24-year-old midfielder, who was playing in Serie C only a year ago, was born in Rome of a Somali mother and an Italian father.

"It will be a special game for me because South Africa has had to battle so much against racism," said Liverani yesterday. "I've battled against those same prejudices. When people whistle at me for the colour of my skin, it gives me an extra charge."

Racism in Italian football has become increasingly evident in recent years. Only last week Lazio were fined after fans taunted Parma's black players in a recent game in Rome.

Liverani is a Perugia player but Italy's coach insisted neither that nor his skin colour had anything to do with his selection. "I had to reward him after such an outstanding season," said Giovanni Trapattoni.

Edgar Davids yesterday strongly denied drug use after the disclosure that the Juventus and Holland midfielder had tested positive for the banned steroid nandrolone.

"I've never used banned substances in my life and certainly not nandrolone," said a visibly uspet Davids. "I refuse even the most simple treatments, like flu vaccinations. I have solid principles on the substances I consume. I would refuse even a glass of wine or any chocolate."

Davids is the biggest name of the seven Serie A players who have tested positive for banned substances this season. If a second test produces the same result, he faces a ban of up two years from club and international competition.

webTitle: Republic of Ireland v Andorra preview

fields.headline: Ireland wary of too many cards
fields.trailText: Mick McCarthy will rest several players at risk of suspension for the visit of Group Two whipping boys Andorra to Lansdowne Road tonight.
fields.body:
Ireland go into tonight's World Cup qualifier against the Group Two whipping boys Andorra with a cloud over the future of the Football Association of Ireland's chief executive, Bernard O'Byrne, who is to leave his post within a week after an internal inquiry in Dublin raised questions over use of his official credit card.

The association has agreed to O'Byrne's request to negotiate a severance package for him after a report into his FAI credit card bills led to both sides taking legal advice.

The 48-year-old O'Byrne, in the post since 1996, denies any improper action in spending Ire£70,000 (£60,000) on the card over a three-year period and will continue in his job until a package is hammered out.

Mick McCarthy, who marks his 50th match as the Republic's manager tonight at Lansdowne Road, said he was "very sorry to see [O'Byrne] go". He added: "I have had a very good relationship with him. For me, he has always been extremely professional and likeable. I think the association has lost a very good bloke."

McCarthy is taking an uncharacteristic gamble in his team selection by going into the game without some of his best players. The part-timers from Andorra are hardly a danger in a group containing Portugal and Holland, as their record of no points and 22 goals conceded in seven games testifies, but McCarthy has four men at risk of suspension and clearly has one eye on the June visit of the Portuguese.

So McCarthy will not expose Robbie and Roy Keane, Kenny Cunningham and Jason McAteer to the risk of another caution tonight, although the Manchester United captain had already pulled out with a hamstring after his hectic weekend. After naming his team yesterday the manager said: "I was aware of the yellow card situation from the last game and I don't want the lads getting suspended.

"I'm not for one minute suggesting this is going to be an easy game because the players who are coming in are all tried and tested internationals."

Those coming in are, effectively, Richard Dunne, Matty Holland, Mark Kennedy and David Connolly, the former Watford striker who appears likely to leave Feyenoord this summer.

Meanwhile Scotland, top of Group Five, travel to Bydgoszcz for a friendly against Poland, who can confirm their position at the head of Group Six by winning in Wales on June 2. Both squads have extensive injury problems and today's fixture has been criticised in Scotland, particularly by the Premier League chief executive Roger Mitchell, as it comes a only days before the final Old Firm derby of the season.

But Poland's coach Jerzy Engel said: "It's no surprise we are playing. Scotland are much, much better than Wales but their systems are similar. It is important to have such a game."

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): Given ( Newcastle); Kelly (Leeds), Dunne (Manchester City), Breen (Coventry, capt), Harte (Leeds); Kennedy (Manchester City), Kinsella (Charlton), Holland (Ipswich), Kilbane (Sunderland); Doherty (Tottenham), Connolly (Feyenoord).

webTitle: Chesterfield fear stiffer punishment after review

fields.headline: Chesterfield fear stiffer punishment after review
fields.trailText: Chesterfield may yet be denied promotion from the Third Division after the Football League board rejected the nine-point punishment for financial irregularities as too lenient.
fields.body:
Chesterfield seem likely to face stiff sanctions which would deny them promotion from the Third Division after the Football League rejected the nine-point punishment for financial irregularities proposed by its disciplinary panel.

The League board revealed yesterday that it considered the penalty too lenient and has asked the three-man panel to reconvene and reconsider the matter. A ruling is expected in the next 10 days.

The board's dissatisfaction was mirrored at the Football Association, where Graham Bean, the compliance officer who headed the investigation into Chesterfield's financial affairs, threatened to resign after hearing the punishment recommended by the panel.

A nine-point deduction would knock Chesterfield off the top of the table but leave them in the third automatic promotion spot. As things stand, the club would have to be docked 31 points to ensure they cannot make the play-offs.

Chesterfield were guilty of irregularities in recording gate receipts and breaching regulations over the transfer of Luke Beckett, and the League's chief executive David Burns said: "The recommendation to deduct nine points does not sufficiently reflect the damage brought to the integrity of the competition."

The board's stance was backed by the sports minister Kate Hoey. "There's no doubt that, if the League had ratified the penalty, it would have thrown a big question-mark over whether football really could regulate itself and look after the integrity of the game.

"The penalty, which would have still allowed the club to benefit from breaking the rules at the expense of the other clubs who have abided by the rules, is just not right."

Only one member of the eight-strong board favoured ratifying the penalty when it met in London on Monday.

The meeting was attended by Gordon McKeag, part of the panel which made the recommendation, and he was asked to explain the decision. A former president of the Football League, he was on the panel with Frank Clark, the former Nottingham Forest manager who is vice-chairman of the League Managers' Association, and Mark Day, once the FA's finance director.

Technically the same three should reconvene but it is thought the FA, backed by its chairman Geoff Thompson, will press for a new panel. It also wants an overhaul of the existing system, with the FA administering punishments as well as investigating.

The League board will have no say over the panel's second decision but Chesterfield will be able to appeal to the FA. The FA said last night that it would try to hear any appeal before the final Nationwide League games on May 5 to avoid the risk of the season ending in uncertainty.

The reaction at Chesterfield was predictably downbeat. "We all thought it was done and dusted," said the assistant manager Ian Banks. "It's another kick in the goolies." Darren Brown, the former chairman, added: "We felt nine points was perhaps too harsh because we had done nothing wrong."

When the board looked at the evidence there was widespread surprise that Chesterfield had not been found guilty on the majority of the charges. However, those charges will not be reconsidered nor was the board in a position to alter the £20,000 fine imposed.

webTitle: Cardiff pitch to be relaid for Cup final

fields.headline: Cardiff pitch to be relaid for Cup final
fields.trailText: The FA has insisted that the battered pitch at the Millennium stadium be relaid before the FA Cup final on May 12.
fields.body:
Thousands of square metres of turf will be transported from Yorkshire to Cardiff in the next week after yesterday's decision to relay the Millennium stadium pitch for the FA Cup final on May 12.

Heavy rain, problems with the stadium's retractable roof and two football matches on Sunday left the surface in a condition that the Football Association described as "not good enough" for the Cup final when inspected yesterday.

The FA insisted the pitch be relaid and work on stripping the surface will begin tomorrow. Replacement turf is to be moved from the Vale of York, where the existing pitch was grown, and the job should be completed by the middle of next week.

"Primarily it is about the right playing surface for the players but it is also about looking right," said Paul Newman, the FA's head of communications. "The final is watched by 400m people in 200 countries and by definition you don't want it to look like a cabbage patch."

This will be the Millennium stadium's third pitch. The first was put down for the 1999 Rugby World Cup and it was relaid as recently as January, five weeks before the final of the Worthington Cup.

The work will cost around £100,000 and the FA will be gratified to hear that the retractable roof should be back in operation today. It has been jammed open for 3 weeks, leaving no protection against the elements.

The pitch was badly cut up on Sunday, when the LDV Vans Trophy final between Port Vale and Brentford was followed by the Football League Youth Alliance Cup final.

The FA's pitch expert Rob Cullagh, who prepared the Wembley surface for 13 Cup finals, and the Millennium stadium head groundsman Tony Horne decided relaying was the best option after inspection. The final between Liverpool and Arsenal will be the first game played on the new surface.

"You don't want in an ideal world to be relaying a pitch three weeks before a major final," Newman admitted. "Having said that, the state of the pitch is such that everyone has accepted that the contingency plan, which was written into the original contracts, should be utilised."

The Millennium stadium is due to stage the Cup final until 2004 while Wembley is rebuilt. "We're confident that the pitch will be in pristine condition for the FA Cup final," said the stadium manager Bob Evans. "The new pitch will only take five or six days to be bedded in."

fields.headline: Capital admits soccer defeat
fields.trailText:
6.15pm: Capital has said it could not match TalkSport's offer for the rights to three London football clubs, writes Ashley Davies.
TalkSport nabs soccer rights
02.01.2001: TalkSport revamps programme line-up
fields.body:
Capital Radio has admitted it had no chance in the battle with TalkSport for the broadcast rights to three London football clubs.

None of the parties involved would reveal the amount TalkSport paid to prise the London and south east commentary rights from Capital.

A Capital spokeswoman said: "TalkSport went into negotiations with a blank cheque. There comes a point when you have to draw the line and we couldn't match its offer."

She said Capital had bid for Tottenham and Chelsea but not for Fulham and would soon announce the retention of West Ham, Arsenal and Charlton.

London Premiership club commentaries have been broadcast on Capital Gold since 1988.

Half of them will switch over to TalkSport at the beginning of next season.

Capital said, despite the loss, it was committed to sport and would increase its sports coverage on Capital Gold.
