webTitle: Kenya crusades for cheap Aids drugs

fields.headline: Kenya crusades for cheap Aids drugs
fields.standfirst: Nairobi is following South Africa's lead by calling for low-cost medicines, writes Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: Nairobi is following South Africa's lead by calling for low-cost medicines, writes Chris McGreal in Johannesburg.
fields.body:
South Africa's humiliation of the world's biggest drug companies, forced to abandon a lawsuit that critics said was aimed at protecting profits at the expense of lives, has prompted Kenya to say it too will pass laws to permit the importation of cheaper medicines.

The east African nation's health minister, professor Sam Ongeri, said Kenya has drafted a bill to allow the government to buy anti-Aids drugs because patented medicines are protected by "unrealistic" property rights laws and are too expensive.

Kenya's decision is a direct result of the collapse of the legal attempt by 39 drug companies in the Pretoria high court to overturn a law permitting the South African government to bypass patents when there is deemed to be a health emergency or where drugs are declared "unaffordable".

Prof Ongeri said 700 Kenyans die of Aids each day, and that 2.2m people in his country are infected with HIV. Half of Kenya's hospital beds are occupied by Aids patients.

But South Africa's legal victory has also had a wider if less immediately visible impact.

It is forcing governments and the drug companies to discuss how they now confront a virus that infects 25m people in sub-Saharan Africa. Most countries cannot afford even the knocked-down prices of generic drugs, and the major pharmaceutical companies still stand to make large profits even selling their wares at a fraction of the price they now demand.

Six of the largest pharmaceutical multinationals have already slashed prices, in part to repair some of the damage done to the image of the industry by the South African court case. But anti-retroviral drugs remain beyond the reach of governments that would have to buy millions of pills each day to treat all those infected with HIV.

African leaders and the drug industry are agreed on one thing - the need for massive funding of a drug supply programme by the west. International health experts have told the United Nations that an international fund of more than £6.9bn a year is required to combat not only Aids but other serious diseases, such as tuberculosis and malaria, which have helped lower the average life expectancy in Africa to just 48 years.

A Harvard university economist, Jeffrey Sachs, said some diseases have reached epidemic proportions and threaten to set back development in Africa by decades.

"It's not just Aids, it's everything in health in Africa that has been allowed to get out of control," he said. "We do not have the means at this stage to solve the problem fully having let it get so utterly out of control."

African leaders are meeting in Nigeria this week to discuss the Aids crisis. The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, plans to take advantage of the publicity generated by the court case in South Africa to give a greater international political profile to the pandemic and "shift this whole international campaign, which is starting to take shape, into high gear".

He argues that a key factor is to rebuild Africa's dilapidated health care systems, and recommends a move toward prevention over treatment.

Nigeria's vice-president, Atiku Abubakar, said the summit "was the first time that African leaders are coming together with other interested parties to discuss how to arrest the latest epidemic".

"The dual epidemic of HIV/Aids and tuberculosis is devastating the continent," he said.

fields.bodyText: South Africa's humiliation of the world's biggest drug companies, forced to abandon a lawsuit that critics said was aimed at protecting profits at the expense of lives, has prompted Kenya to say it too will pass laws to permit the importation of cheaper medicines. The east African nation's health minister, professor Sam Ongeri, said Kenya has drafted a bill to allow the government to buy anti-Aids drugs because patented medicines are protected by "unrealistic" property rights laws and are too expensive. Kenya's decision is a direct result of the collapse of the legal attempt by 39 drug companies in the Pretoria high court to overturn a law permitting the South African government to bypass patents when there is deemed to be a health emergency or where drugs are declared "unaffordable". Prof Ongeri said 700 Kenyans die of Aids each day, and that 2.2m people in his country are infected with HIV. Half of Kenya's hospital beds are occupied by Aids patients. But South Africa's legal victory has also had a wider if less immediately visible impact. It is forcing governments and the drug companies to discuss how they now confront a virus that infects 25m people in sub-Saharan Africa. Most countries cannot afford even the knocked-down prices of generic drugs, and the major pharmaceutical companies still stand to make large profits even selling their wares at a fraction of the price they now demand. Six of the largest pharmaceutical multinationals have already slashed prices, in part to repair some of the damage done to the image of the industry by the South African court case. But anti-retroviral drugs remain beyond the reach of governments that would have to buy millions of pills each day to treat all those infected with HIV. African leaders and the drug industry are agreed on one thing - the need for massive funding of a drug supply programme by the west. International health experts have told the United Nations that an international fund of more than £6.9bn a year is required to combat not only Aids but other serious diseases, such as tuberculosis and malaria, which have helped lower the average life expectancy in Africa to just 48 years. A Harvard university economist, Jeffrey Sachs, said some diseases have reached epidemic proportions and threaten to set back development in Africa by decades. "It's not just Aids, it's everything in health in Africa that has been allowed to get out of control," he said. "We do not have the means at this stage to solve the problem fully having let it get so utterly out of control." African leaders are meeting in Nigeria this week to discuss the Aids crisis. The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, plans to take advantage of the publicity generated by the court case in South Africa to give a greater international political profile to the pandemic and "shift this whole international campaign, which is starting to take shape, into high gear". He argues that a key factor is to rebuild Africa's dilapidated health care systems, and recommends a move toward prevention over treatment. Nigeria's vice-president, Atiku Abubakar, said the summit "was the first time that African leaders are coming together with other interested parties to discuss how to arrest the latest epidemic". "The dual epidemic of HIV/Aids and tuberculosis is devastating the continent," he said. webTitle: Head under fire for holding class with 94 pupils

fields.headline: Head under fire for holding class with 94 pupils
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The headteacher of a Norfolk junior school was under fire yesterday for deciding to teach 94 youngsters in one class for five days after allowing two of his teaching staff to attend a training course on numeracy.
fields.body:
The headteacher of a Norfolk junior school was under fire yesterday for deciding to teach 94 youngsters in one class for five days after allowing two of his teaching staff to attend a training course on numeracy.

Ralph Hedley, head of Queensway community junior school in Thetford, reignited the row over teacher shortages by saying he had been forced to merge three classes when unable to get cover.

But Mr Hedley's action provoked the wrath of the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett - described by aides as "extremely angry" - for allowing his staff to be away on training courses without having temporary supply cover in place. Mr Blunkett said he would write to local education authorities and headteachers to remind them of the importance of organising teacher training so that pupils' education was not disrupted.

The head failed to win the support of Bryan Slater, director of education at Norfolk county council, who pointed out that Mr Hedley had other options which would have been less disruptive for his pupils, and had failed to contact an emergency hotline dedicated to helping schools find supply teachers at a time of national shortage. Dr Slater said Mr Hedley could have asked the staff to postpone their training courses, or contacted the council for help.

Parents of the children affected described the situation as "ludicrous", while the Conservatives said it showed the depth of problems being created by schools' dependence on supply staff as a result of the teacher shortage "crisis".

The schools minister, Jacqui Smith, had earlier taken a more conciliatory tone in media interviews, until the DfEE received more information from the local education authority.

Yesterday Mr Hedley said he had been faced with a "simple choice" between sending pupils home or bringing them together in a single class in the school hall for five days over a two week period before Easter.

Mr Hedley, one of eight full-time teachers at the school, which has eight classes of around 35 pupils, admitted: "I wouldn't say that by any stretch of the imagination this was teaching the children, it was looking after them - as 94 is rather too large a number to teach them individually."

Kim Littlewood, whose daughter was in the expanded class, said: "Our children are suffering ... I don't think they can get the quality of teaching in a class of that size. It should never have happened."

A spokeswoman for Norfolk county council said the head's decision was unlikely to lead to any further action.

Teachers are entitled to five statutory days' training every year. Mr Blunkett is worried that while the number of supply teachers has increased by 2,400 in the past year to 19,000, too many training sessions are being organised during the school day. Changes introduced by the government mean heads could pay staff to go on training outside school time.

"I shall be reminding schools that the priority of heads and teachers should be their pupils," Mr Blunkett said.

Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said: "These numbers frankly give the lie to government claims that there isn't a problem. We have a real crisis of teacher shortages. Children are losing out. The reality on the ground is that schools are facing enormous difficulties in getting enough teachers and in covering classes for children."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "Finding proper solutions to the problems of staffing is only made more difficult by headteachers seeking to cover them up."

 Places have been found for the Northamptonshire pupils who were told they could not be offered places at local secondary schools, it was announced yesterday. Twenty-one pupils in Wellingborough had been forced to stay at home because of a lack of school places. But the local education authority said three pupils had been admitted to schools, while the remaining 18 would be offered places next week.

webTitle: Mississippi to pay for education bias

fields.headline: Mississippi to pay for education bias
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The American state that became a byword for racial hatred during the civil rights era has finally settled a historic class action lawsuit aimed at ending segregation in its university system.
fields.body:
The American state that became a byword for racial hatred during the civil rights era has finally settled a historic class action lawsuit aimed at ending segregation in its university system.

After more than 25 years of dispute, Mississippi has agreed to spend more than $500m (£350m) to help remedy the inequalities which led the US supreme court to rule nine years ago that the state continued to have a segregated university system.

If the plan is accepted by a federal judge, the settlement will bring an end to a class action started 26 years ago by a group of 22 black Americans who claimed that Mississippi maintained a segregated system by giving more funds to universities that were historically attended by white students than to those attended by their black counterparts.

The claim, brought by the late Jake Ayers of Glen Allen, Mississippi, was taken up by the US department of justice, which has approved the deal struck this week between state officials and the remaining plaintiffs.

The agreement calls for Mississippi to spend $246m (£171m) during the next 17 years on academic programmes at three publicly funded universities - Jackson State, Alcorn State and Mississippi Valley State - where almost all the students have always been black.

Another $75m (£52m) will go towards capital improvements in the three colleges, with the rest of the money going to endow student scholarships and other projects, including summer programmes for struggling students.

Jackson State, in the state's capital, Jackson, will get 43% of the endowment funding, compared with 28% for each of the others.

"It is not perfect but it's settled," Congressman Bennie Thompson, one of the plaintiffs, said. "This document represents the best effort for resolving the desegregation of higher education in Mississippi."

"All we need now is the court's approval and we're done," Mississippi's attorney general and a key negotiator, Mike Moore, said. "This is a very big day for us."

"The important agreement that we have reached with the state of Mississippi will increase access to quality educational opportunities and benefit all of Mississippi's students and citizens," the US attorney general, John Ashcroft, said in a statement.

Mississippi's racially segregated university system captured worldwide attention in 1962 when James Meredith became the first black student to gain admission at the state's most entrenched whites-only college, the University of Mississippi, in Oxford.

After weeks of resistance by Mississippi authorities, Mr Meredith was only able to register after the then US attorney general, Robert Kennedy, sent 23,000 federal troops to Oxford to enforce his entry.

Despite the breakthrough, the persistence of unequal funding led Mr Ayers to bring his case in 1975, again backed by the federal government.

In 1987 US district judge Neal Biggers - who must now rule on the acceptability of this week's settlement - ruled that Mississippi had done enough to end segregation.

Five years later, however, the US supreme court overthrew that ruling and ordered Mississippi to remove "all vestiges of segregation".

fields.headline: Tobacco money clouds revue tour
fields.trailText: The good news is that the 40th anniversary tour of the most famous student revue company in the country has been saved by a last-minute corporate donation of £25,000. The bad news is that their saviour is British American Tobacco.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Far Too Happy, the title of its latest show, does not precisely convey the atmosphere at Cambridge Footlights yesterday: sick as chain-smoking parrots might serve better.

The good news is that the 40th anniversary tour of the most famous student revue company in the country has been saved by a last-minute corporate donation of £25,000. The bad news is that their saviour is British American Tobacco.

Footlights, which 40 years ago launched the careers of the likes of Jonathan Miller, Peter Cook, Dudley Moore and Alan Bennett, later followed by most of the Monty Python team, Hugh Laurie, Stephen Fry, Emma Thompson and others, has found itself embroiled in a bitter row over the subtle tactics of the tobacco companies to get around the threatened ban on cigarette advertising.

It was denounced by the anti-smoking campaign group Ash for falling for "a cynical piece of PR" by the tobacco industry.

"Sponsoring the Footlights is an attempt to show that BAT is a company with a sense of humour," said John Connolly of Action on Smoking and Health. "They might as well put up a banner saying 'If you want to be cool and funny, then smoke'."

"I wasn't over the moon about taking tobacco money," the show's director, Phil Breen, said yesterday. "None of us was. But it was that or scrap the tour, or get the cast to pay all their own costs for touring around the country, which would be ridiculous. We're not Hooray Henrys, whatever you might think. We all went to state schools, except one member of the company."

Footlights was founded in 1883, but this year's tour is the 40th anniversary of Beyond the Fringe, which brought together Miller, Cook, Moore, and Bennett.

In 1963 another gang of students with a shared sense of anarchic humour, including John Cleese, Eric Idle and Terry Jones, met at the Footlights. On a US tour of the Footlights Revue they then met animator Terry Gilliam, who gave the Monty Python Show its unique graphics.

The annual show has traditionally opened at the Cambridge Arts Theatre, which helped to sponsor the tour by paying for the set and publicity.

Recriminations were flying yesterday, but a spokeswoman for the cash-strapped theatre said the Footlights' box office has been falling drastically over recent years, and the decision was taken to drop it.

Producer Elen Parry insists the box office is fine, but said she discovered a gaping hole in the £35,000 tour budget only at Christmas, and then wrote more than 200 letters appealing for sponsorship. "It was a question of sitting down and saying 'how much are our morals and principles worth?'"

The answer was £25,000. A BAT spokesman said: "It isn't promoting smoking, it isn't about promoting our brands, this is corporate sponsorship by British American Tobacco plc. If Ash says this is advertising by the back door, they are wrong."

Footlights highlights

 1883 The Footlights Dramatic Club was founded

 1960s The club's heyday, with Tim Brooke-Taylor and Eric Idle as presidents. Members went on to make Monty Python

 1964 The club went semi-professional when Dudley Moore, Peter Cook, Alan Bennett and Jonathan Miller produced Beyond the Fringe for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival

 1976 The club fell on hard times and almost died

 1981 A revitalised club won the Perrier Award for Comedy at the Edinburgh Festival with a show starring Stephen Fry, Hugh Laurie, Tony Slattery and Emma Thompson

 2000 The tour show Sensible Haircut got rave reviews with its send-up of the TV quiz show Countdown

Neil Chatterjee

fields.headline: Vatican's embryo research taboo
fields.standfirst: A paralysed university professor is running for political office in a bid to overturn the Italian ban on stem cell research, writes Rory Carroll
fields.trailText: A paralysed university professor is running for political office in a bid to overturn the Italian ban on stem cell research, writes Rory Carroll.
fields.body:
The Vatican's most dangerous foe in Italy right now is paralysed, locked in a wheelchair, unable to speak and likely to die prematurely. His name is Luca Coscioni and he is hurling his own mortality into an anguished debate about using human embryos to research incurable diseases.

Mr Coscioni, 33, is running for parliament on a Radical party ticket in the hope of reversing Italy's ban on stem cell research. Win or lose, he has made it a campaign issue in the general election. He will raise the stakes tomorrow by lowering his intake of painkillers until the May 13 poll.

Vatican bullying has cowed mainstream political parties into a consensus which denies hope to millions of ill people, says Mr Coscioni.

He suffers from amiotrophic lateral sclerosis, the same disease which afflicts the physicist Stephen Hawking. He can move only one finger and speaks through a computerised synthesiser. He believes he has a chance of being cured if scientists are allowed to experiment on embryos left over from assisted fertility treatment, which are destined for destruction.

"The Vatican is free to believe that it is to fair throw those embryos in the rubbish rather than use them for research that the next five or 10 years could save the lives of millions of people. It is the government's and parliament's duty to avoid such moral blackmail," the candidate told Italy Daily.

His own life story is central to the campaign. A keen marathon runner, six years ago his legs went stiff during training. A doctor handed him the diagnosis in a sealed envelope.

Many sufferers die within five years, though Mr Hawking has survived 33 years. In addition to surviving, Mr Coscioni, an economics lecturer at the University of Viterbo, would like to get better.

Only his wife and mother can understand him when he makes the herculean effort to speak without the synthesiser.

"I make people uncomfortable because I do not want to be a human case but a politician." Some 438 international scientists, including 47 Nobel laureates, have endorsed his candidacy.

Italians who suffer diseases such as Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, spinal muscular atrophy, leukemia and diabetes could benefit if the mainstream parties' conspiracy of silence was smashed, he says.

Tests on rodents suggest stem cells could be used to regenerate damaged body parts. Also known as therapeutic cloning, the research is legal in Britain and the United States.

Pope John Paul II's condemnation encouraged Italy's centre-left government and centre-right opposition to block the research. In a tight election, no one wants to take on the Catholic church. Except the Radicals.

A high profile belies their small size. Mavericks, they are past masters at grabbing attention with Gandhi-style passive resistance and publicity stunts which taunt the Pope and claim the moral high ground.

The Radicals fought successfully in the 1970s to legalise divorce and abortion; unsuccessfully in the 1980s to legalise soft drugs.

Mr Coscioni stands a reasonable chance of winning a seat in the senate, Italy's upper house. Anecdotal evidence suggests an impact at street level. Public recognition is high and people are talking about him.

The candidate has been a regular guest on chat shows but not regular enough for his party leader, Emma Bonino. The former European commissioner will start a thirst and hunger strike tomorrow to demand more airtime.

fields.headline: Language without words
fields.trailText: A professor has organised a photography exhibition of men's bodies that challenges our ideas about how culture and language work.
fields.body:
One of BritainÍs leading professors of modern language has organised an exhibition of photographs of menÍs bodies, clothed and nude, which is currently touring the country. And it's for work, not a hobby.

Michael Worton, Vice-provost of University College London and Fielden professor of French language and literature, has examined the cultural significance of menÍs bodies for years, arguing that while feminism liberated the female body from stigma, it's still taboo for men to examine or discuss other menÍs bodies.

"Since the 18th century men have been called 'rational' and language has been conditioned by that. But the fears and concerns a man feels confronted by another man's body is not rational. So I had to explore the area through a different language, a different medium - photography," Professor Worton said.

The springboard for the photographic exhibition and study was a £45,000 grant given by the Arts and Humanities Research Board (AHRB) to Professor Judy Stills at Nottingham University to write a book about cultural representations of the male body.

As part of the research for the book, the two professors gathered photographs from around the world taken of men, by men. The final result, which was held in a Nottingham gallery and is now making its way around the country, is a study not just of menÍs bodies, but also about language, culture and photography.

Although Professor Worton would not say language and photography are one and the same thing, he feels they are clearly closely related. Studies have shown that we read photographs, much as we read words - from top to bottom, gathering signals along the way. And various theorists have argued that photographs exist primarily to be discussed, that they are themselves a form of language.

But Professor Worton had to turn to photographs to explore something that language failed to achieve. As a result, photographs are a part of the culture of language and yet, "They challenge us to rethink the way language works," he said.

The final result, which was held in a Nottingham gallery and is now making its way around the country, is a study not just of menÍs bodies, but also about language, culture and photography. Although Professor Worton would not say language and photography are one and the same thing, he feels they are clearly closely related. Studies have shown that we read photographs, much as we read words - from top to bottom, gathering signals along the way. And various theorists have argued that photographs exist primarily to be discussed, that they are themselves a form of language. But Professor Worton had to turn to photographs to explore something that language failed to achieve. As a result, photographs are a part of the culture of language and yet, "They challenge us to rethink the way language works," he said.

webTitle: IVF doctor loses bid to change embryo rule

fields.headline: IVF doctor loses bid to change embryo rule
fields.trailText: One of Britain's leading fertility specialists vowed yesterday to appeal after a 46-year-old patient lost the latest round in her legal battle for the right to have five embryos implanted in her womb.
fields.body:
One of Britain's leading fertility specialists vowed yesterday to appeal after a 46-year-old patient lost the latest round in her legal battle for the right to have five embryos implanted in her womb.

Mohamed Taranissi, head of the private clinic where the woman has made eight unsuccessful attempts in five years to become pregnant with IVF treatment, said he and his patient would continue to campaign for the existing three-embryo limit to be relaxed in exceptional circumstances.

"She is obviously going to be very disappointed," said Mr Taranissi. "She knows her chances of a successful pregnancy are not very good. If anything she'd rather help other people in the same position as herself."

Mr Taranissi maintains that he is fighting for the right of medical practitioners to have the leeway to treat patients on a case by case basis.

Yesterday, in the high court in London, Mr Justice Ouseley rejected the request by Mr Taranissi and his patient - who was referred to only as Mrs H - for a judicial review of the rules limiting the number of embryos which can be put back into a woman having IVF treatment. He said he would give his reasons today.

Mr Taranissi and Mrs H were opposed in court by the human fertilisation and embryology authority, which argues that the risk of mothers having twins and triplets if more than three embryos are put back represents an unacceptable danger to the lives of children.

"We're pleased the court has struck a reasonable balance between allowing treatment where it is appropriate and the welfare of children," said Hugh Whittall of the HFEA.

The HFEA is under pressure from the medical community to cut the maximum number of embryos put back from three to two because of the large number of multiple births in younger women.

HFEA guidelines are not binding on IVF clinics. But if Mr Taranissi defied the authority and implanted the five embryos - which he believes would increase her chances of getting pregnant - the HFEA could remove his licence.

Unlike other older women trying to have children with IVF treatment, Mrs H is forced to use IVF because she has blocked fallopian tubes, and is using her own rather than donor eggs.

Arguing in court for a judicial review of the HFEA rules, Nigel Pleming QC said that it was irrational to suggest that a woman who had not achieved a single pregnancy with eight IVF cycles of three embryos each would have twins or triplets if five embryos were implanted.

The HFEA's own figures showed that in the past seven years 250 women aged 46 had received IVF treatment in Britain and none had given birth at all, let alone to twins.

In the US, where there are fewer restrictions on embryo numbers, only 2% of 46-year-olds treated had a baby.

"An increase in the chance of having a baby from zero to 2% is statistically significant, particularly in a 46-year-old woman," said Mr Pleming. "It's going from no chance to some chance."

For the HFEA, Dinah Rose accused Mr Taranissi of drawing false inferences from statistics. The authority agreed Mrs H's chances of becoming pregnant were small. But if she did become pregnant, said Miss Rose, the chances of her having a multiple pregnancy were not necessarily less than those in younger women.

fields.headline: Butterflies across Britain threatened by shrinking habitats
fields.standfirst: The countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Britain's native butterfly species are suffering from loss of habitat and efforts to halt the trend have failed, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
Britain's native butterfly species are suffering from loss of habitat and efforts to halt the trend have failed, according to a report published today.

Following one of the largest and most comprehensive surveys of butterflies undertaken in the UK, the report concluded that of 59 resident species, 15 have declined by more than 50% and five have become extinct.

The report is published by Butterfly Conservation, the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology and the Joint Nature Conservation Committee.

It revealed that even key species such as the pearl-bordered fritillary and the marsh fritillary - listed as of highest conservation priority in the UK biodiversity action plan - are still under threat.

The report also showed that a further 10 species, including the wood white, now warrant highest conservation priority.

The main causes of the decline include destruction and fragmentation of habitat and changing land management patterns which have left butterflies without big enough areas in which to feed, breed and survive, the report said.

Ian McLean, JNCC's head of species, said: "Butterflies are extremely sensitive to the environment on which they depend, therefore they act as excellent indicators of the health of the countryside.

"While some butterflies have extended their range northwards due to the effects of cli mate change, it is clear that there is an overall downward trend in UK butterflies, and that existing measures to try to conserve key species are not effective enough."

He added: "If we don't take action now to halt the present rate of decline, butterflies flying across a summer meadow may become a thing of the past."

Richard Fox, of Butterfly Conservation and the main author of the report, said: "This report highlights priorities vital for conservationists and policy makers to address the decline.

"It is essential that we maintain this effort to assess future changes in the state of Britain's butterflies."

Declining species

• The high brown fritillary (Argynnis adippe) - severe declines means it is now one of our rarest butterflies. Large, orange and black, once common in woodland clearings across Britain. Only about 50 colonies remain in south-west and north-west England and parts of Wales and the west midlands.

• The pearl-bordered fritillary (Boloria euphrosyne) - silvery-white pearl markings on orange, cream and black wings. Undergone a dramatic decline, disappearing from most central and eastern counties of England and almost all of Wales. More stable in Scotland.

• The wood white (Leptidea sinapis) - delicate, white butterfly previously distributed widely in English and Welsh woodlands. Substantial declines during the 20th century have reduced it to Herefordshire/ Worcestershire, Northamptonshire/Buckinghamshire and Devon/Somerset.

• The marsh fritillary (Euphydryas aurinia) - stunning with orange, cream and black wings. Lives in wet grasslands in south-west England, south-west Wales and west Scotland. Lost from much of central and eastern Britain, declines mirrored throughout Europe.

fields.headline: Corelli's curiosity
fields.trailText: Louis de Bernieres should be a contented man. After years of humiliation at the hands of colour sergeants as a Sandhurst cadet and unruly pupils during his time as a supply teacher, the novelist can surely afford to rest on his laurels.
fields.body:
Louis de Bernieres should be a contented man. After years of humiliation at the hands of colour sergeants as a Sandhurst cadet and unruly pupils during his time as a supply teacher, the novelist can surely afford to rest on his laurels. The Hollywood-backed film of his Captain Corelli's Mandolin - the runaway bestseller of the late 90s set in wartime Cephalonia - goes on general release next week. With actors such as Nicolas Cage and Penelope Cruz in starring roles and a ready audience of the book's legions of enthusiasts, box office success must be all but guaranteed.

But de Bernieres appears to have been rattled by criticism that he has played fast and loose with history, accusing his tormentors of "trouble-making" for investigating the truth of the cataclysmic events at the heart of his story. He no longer, he grumbles, feels "entirely comfortable or welcome" on the Greek island whose tourist industry he has done so much to boost. In fact, he has had to put up with so much "brainless and trivial embuggerance", he says, that he has come to regret having written Corelli in the first place.

So far, the attacks have mainly focused on his historical howlers about the Greek anti-Nazi resistance. His novel is the story of a love affair between the daughter of a Cephalonian doctor and a captain in the Italian occupation army, who helps turn his troops against the Germans and survives the subsequent massacre of 9,000 of them. But woven into the human drama is a ferociously hostile account of the role played by the communist-led guerrilla army, who later fought British and American-backed forces in the civil war and are portrayed by de Bernieres as a gang of torturers and rapists.

According to Wehr-macht records, the leftwing resistance killed 8,000 German soldiers in one year and controlled 80% of the country when Hitler withdrew. But de Bernieres, a self- confessed sympathiser with Greece's prewar dictator Metaxas - a man who imprisoned and murdered thousands of political activists, but opposed Mussolini - insists the partisans did "absolutely nothing". Not surprisingly, when such claims percolated through to Greek veterans, there was uproar and de Bernieres was persuaded to drop the most extreme passages from the Greek edition of his book.

The Corelli film's own scriptwriter Shawn Slovo has since publicly dismissed his portrait of the Greek resistance as "offensive and inaccurate" and the movie shows the partisans fighting alongside the Italians in Cephalonia - something de Bernieres insists in the novel against all the evidence is "certain" not to have happened. Even de Bernieres has reluctantly conceded he "might have been wrong", but always stops short of an outright admission of error.

In any case, he now seems more concerned by the challenge to his story posed by the man increasingly accepted as the "real Captain Corelli", 90-year-old Florentine Amos Pampaloni and star of a BBC2 documentary due to be broadcast next month. Pampaloni's experience uncannily mirrors that of de Bernieres's hero. Like Corelli, Pampaloni was a captain in the 33rd artillery regiment, Acqui division, on Cephalonia - in fact he was the only one. Like Corelli, he had an affair with a local girl and played a central role in the decision to attack German troops. Like Corelli, he was shot and left for dead after the Italian defeat. But unlike Corelli, Pampaloni went on to fight with the Greek resistance and calls de Bernieres's tales of the partisans' depravity a "pack of lies".

The novelist insists Pampaloni was not his model and blames journalists who "cannot conceive of authors being able to invent". De Bernieres himself cites a 60s Italian novel, The White Flag by Marcello Venturi (which is explicitly based on Pampaloni's story), as a source in his own book's list of acknowledgements. De Bernieres's central plot is notably similar to Venturi's - an artillery captain on Cephalonia has an affair with a Greek girl, then becomes engulfed in the German- Italian confrontation of 1943 and survives the subsequent massacres - and he even uses a couple of names Venturi invented, including his pseudonym for Pampaloni, Aldo Pugliesi.

Corelli is nevertheless a much longer and more ambitious novel; there is no suggestion of textual copying and de Bernieres says he had already decided on the bare bones of his story when he read The White Flag. But Venturi, who is highly critical of de Bernieres's version of the Cephalonian events, is also angry at what he sees as inadequate recognition and yesterday said he was consulting lawyers about the possibility of legal action. De Bernieres's embuggerance is not, it seems, quite over.

webTitle: Jon Henley  investigates Ravel's missing millions

fields.headline: Poor Ravel
fields.standfirst: Everyone knows he wrote one of the most popular pieces of classical music in the world. What no one knows for sure is where the profits from all those performances have gone.  Jon Henley investigates the mystery of the missing Bolero millions
fields.trailText: Everyone knows he wrote one of the most popular pieces of classical music in the world. What no one knows for sure is where the profits from all those performances have gone. Jon Henley investigates the mystery of the missing Bolero millions.
fields.body:
It is an odd, angular little house, perched above the village of Montfort-l'Amaury like the prow of a ship or, as a mischievous-minded pupil once put it, a badly-cut slice of Camembert. Maurice Ravel bought it with the aid of an inheritance in 1921, did it up at no little expense - it had neither running water nor electricity - and decorated it to his taste, which is to say meticulously and almost mathematically, if rather eclectically.

The composer loved it because it was close enough by train to Paris to allow him to indulge his liking for bright lights and the big city, but at the same time calm and secluded, within a short ride of Rambouillet forest where he walked when his work and the weather permitted.

Possibly the world's most frequently performed piece of classical music was written in this house, in 1928. Composed in haste for a dancer friend, Ravel's Bolero has been used in countless ad campaigns, by Torvill and Dean for their perfect gold medal performance at the 1984 Winter Olympics, and equally memorably as the accompaniment to the rhythmic writhings of Dudley Moore and Bo Derek in 10.

Bolero - which Ravel insisted reflected his fascination for the well-oiled pounding of heavy machinery, but in which others have seen a "veritable hymn to desire" and an "exaltation of the erotic" - is, apparently, played somewhere in the world every 15 minutes. It has been one of France's top three musical exports, classical and contemporary combined, for decades.

Tugged along by its insistent theme, repeated 18 times and cited by at least one psychologist as evidence that the composer was suffering from Alzheimer's, Ravel's oeuvre has generated literally millions of pounds in rights. Most of his work will not be in the public domain until around 2015; it currently brings in around £1.5m per year - at a rough estimate, £40m to date.

What Claude Moreau would like to know is where all that money goes.

The composer's house, Belvedere, is open to visitors most afternoons; 3,000 make the pilgrimage every year. Moreau, the sprightly curator, shows them round its tiny interior (Ravel was just over 5ft 1in tall) and lets them admire his rosewood piano and stare at the bric-a-brac with which the composer, a compulsive collector, filled his glass-fronted cabinets.

The house is more or less as he left it on his death, during brain surgery in 1937 to tackle the degenerative disease from which he had suffered for a decade. It is full of surprises, from Dadaist teacups with holes in the bottom to a porcelain ashtray bearing the words: "Who burnt my table-cloth?"

But there are other, less joyful surprises. The carpets are rotting and threadbare, the silk curtains disintegrating, the ceilings cracked. The pipes burst years ago and downstairs, in Ravel's bedroom, water damage has wrecked the handpainted wallpaper and left bulging, crumbled masonry. The electricity isn't up to scratch and the whole house needs a new roof.

It wouldn't take much money to put it right; probably quite a bit less than what Bolero alone earns in a year. But with all that rights money washing around, the French national museum service doesn't want to pay. Nor, sadly, do the recipients of all that rights money - who are not at all who you might expect them to be. And in the meantime, Belvedere rots.

The story of the missing Bolero millions is one of the greatest artists' rights sagas in history. It is a tangled tale, with all the right ingredients: manipulative confidants, machiavellian machinations, a rewritten will and scheming lawyers.

It starts with the death of Ravelito, as his close friend, the writer Colette, called him. Unmarried and childless, the composer left everything to his brother Edouard, who turned the house at Montfort-l'Amaury into a museum, with - a nice detail, this - Celeste Albaret, who had been housekeeper to no less than Marcel Proust, as its rather idiosyncratic concierge. All seemed in good hands until the day in 1954 when Edouard and his wife were involved in a horrendous car accident. In need of constant help, the couple engaged Jeanne Taverne, a 48-year-old nurse, and her husband Alexandre, a former miner and barber, who acted as their chauffeur. When Edouard's wife died two years later, the Tavernes moved in, never to leave.

In 1957, Edouard Ravel made a rare trip to Paris for the 20th anniversary of his brother's death. To universal satisfaction, he announced his intention of making over 80% of the composer's rights to the city of Paris, with the idea of endowing a Nobel Prize for music.

But once back home, for reasons no one will now ever know but that can be guessed at, he changed his mind: Jeanne Taverne became his sole inheritor. Not even the pleas of Ravel's long-standing publisher, René Dommange of the Durand publishing house, that the rights should be used "for the good of French music", could persuade Edouard to change his mind.

Watching these sordid manoeuvrings with interest, meanwhile, was Jean-Jacques Lemoine, legal director of Sacem, the French organisation responsible for collecting and distributing authors', composers' and publishers' rights. Lemoine knew very well how much Ravel was worth: he was Sacem's single biggest earner.

Edouard died in 1960, unleashing a bitter legal battle between the Tavernes and Ravel's relatives in Switzerland, where his father was born. For the duration of the case, which dragged on for 10 years and ended up in France's highest appeal court, Lemoine astutely froze all the money entering Sacem's Ravel account.

So it was that, in 1970, when the last appeal judge ruled in Alexandre Taverne's favour, Jeanne having died six years earlier, the former miner picked up £3.6m. At around that time, Lemoine resigned unexpectedly from Sacem and founded a private legal practice. His first client? One Alexandre Taverne.

Not content with the £3.6m of accumulated composer's rights, Taverne and Lemoine now set about collaring a portion of the publisher's rights, too. This they did by taking Dommange to court and demanding the rewriting of his original contracts with Ravel, which mostly gave the publisher 75% of the rights from recordings rather than the customary one-third.

Dommange, by then in his 80s, had no stomach for the fight and soon sold out. Taverne, who had since remarried, got his hands on all the Ravel contracts and began drawing up new ones with Lemoine; these covered, among other things, the division of rights due on recordings of Ravel's works. Lemoine set up a company, Artist's Rights International Management Agency, or Arima, specifically for the purpose.

Then, in 1972, in a move that has never been fully explained, Alexandre and Georgette Taverne assigned a portion of their composer's and publisher's rights to Arima. Nobody knows how much: both Georgette, now nearly 80 and living near Montreux, and Lemoine, over 90 and living in Monaco, have refused to discuss the matter, though Georgette's daughter told Le Point magazine last year: "Neither my mother or I have received a penny of Ravel's rights for a very long time - everything was made over to Lemoine at the beginning of the 1970s." He is, the family says, the sole recipient of ill-gotten cash worth at least £30m over the past 25 years.

One man disputes this, saying the Tavernes are still benefiting handsomely from Ravel's talent. But he has a sizeable axe to grind: Jean-Manuel de Scarano was the proprietor of Ravel's publishers, Durand, from 1982 until last year, when he sold out to Bertelsmann. The sale price, reportedly £13.5m, no doubt reflected Scarano's achievement, as president of the French music publishers' association, in persuading the government to extend from 50 to 70 years the period for which compositions are protected by copyright - plus an extra 15 years to account for two world wars. The day that bill became law, in 1995, Durand became worth an awful lot more money. Quite how much more is hard to say, of course, without knowing precisely what was in those Taverne-Arima-Durand contracts signed in the 1970s.

Scarano insists the 1972 assignment of copyright simply entailed the Tavernes making over to Arima 50% of Ravel's publishing rights. "Arima," he says, "is the joint publisher, with Durand, of all Ravel's works. It's quite normal."

It is, of course, anything but normal. Why did the Tavernes make over half their publisher's rights to Arima, and in exchange for what? How much was left for Durand? And just what is Arima? Based in Gibraltar and later in the British Virgin Islands, Arima's shareholders are three companies - Dunsmoor Ltd, Greenford Holdings and Anglo Swiss Directors Ltd - about which nobody seems to know anything.

So that's the deal, it seems, with the Bolero millions. The descendants of Maurice Ravel's brother's nurse may still have their hands on some of them, though there is no way to know for sure. On the other hand, it looks almost certain that the former legal eagle at the French music rights association, hiding behind a string of paper companies, has enriched himself by around £1.5m per year for the past 30 years.

Standing on the balcony of the composer's house last week, Claude Moreau gazed mournfully at the green fields beyond Montfort-l'Amaury church and swore charmingly. She hasn't the money to mend the curtains, the carpets or the roof. "It's scandalous," she says, "an insult to Ravel's memory. We haven't a centime and if we don't get some, it will soon be too late."

Composed in haste for a dancer friend, Ravel's Bolero has been used in countless ad campaigns, by Torvill and Dean for their perfect gold medal performance at the 1984 Winter Olympics, and equally memorably as the accompaniment to the rhythmic writhings of Dudley Moore and Bo Derek in 10. Bolero - which Ravel insisted reflected his fascination for the well-oiled pounding of heavy machinery, but in which others have seen a "veritable hymn to desire" and an "exaltation of the erotic" - is, apparently, played somewhere in the world every 15 minutes. It has been one of France's top three musical exports, classical and contemporary combined, for decades. Tugged along by its insistent theme, repeated 18 times and cited by at least one psychologist as evidence that the composer was suffering from Alzheimer's, Ravel's oeuvre has generated literally millions of pounds in rights. Most of his work will not be in the public domain until around 2015; it currently brings in around £1.5m per year - at a rough estimate, £40m to date. What Claude Moreau would like to know is where all that money goes. The composer's house, Belvedere, is open to visitors most afternoons; 3,000 make the pilgrimage every year. Moreau, the sprightly curator, shows them round its tiny interior (Ravel was just over 5ft 1in tall) and lets them admire his rosewood piano and stare at the bric-a-brac with which the composer, a compulsive collector, filled his glass-fronted cabinets. The house is more or less as he left it on his death, during brain surgery in 1937 to tackle the degenerative disease from which he had suffered for a decade. It is full of surprises, from Dadaist teacups with holes in the bottom to a porcelain ashtray bearing the words: "Who burnt my table-cloth?" But there are other, less joyful surprises. The carpets are rotting and threadbare, the silk curtains disintegrating, the ceilings cracked. The pipes burst years ago and downstairs, in Ravel's bedroom, water damage has wrecked the handpainted wallpaper and left bulging, crumbled masonry. The electricity isn't up to scratch and the whole house needs a new roof. It wouldn't take much money to put it right; probably quite a bit less than what Bolero alone earns in a year. But with all that rights money washing around, the French national museum service doesn't want to pay. Nor, sadly, do the recipients of all that rights money - who are not at all who you might expect them to be. And in the meantime, Belvedere rots. The story of the missing Bolero millions is one of the greatest artists' rights sagas in history. It is a tangled tale, with all the right ingredients: manipulative confidants, machiavellian machinations, a rewritten will and scheming lawyers. It starts with the death of Ravelito, as his close friend, the writer Colette, called him. Unmarried and childless, the composer left everything to his brother Edouard, who turned the house at Montfort-l'Amaury into a museum, with - a nice detail, this - Celeste Albaret, who had been housekeeper to no less than Marcel Proust, as its rather idiosyncratic concierge. All seemed in good hands until the day in 1954 when Edouard and his wife were involved in a horrendous car accident. In need of constant help, the couple engaged Jeanne Taverne, a 48-year-old nurse, and her husband Alexandre, a former miner and barber, who acted as their chauffeur. When Edouard's wife died two years later, the Tavernes moved in, never to leave. In 1957, Edouard Ravel made a rare trip to Paris for the 20th anniversary of his brother's death. To universal satisfaction, he announced his intention of making over 80% of the composer's rights to the city of Paris, with the idea of endowing a Nobel Prize for music. But once back home, for reasons no one will now ever know but that can be guessed at, he changed his mind: Jeanne Taverne became his sole inheritor. Not even the pleas of Ravel's long-standing publisher, René Dommange of the Durand publishing house, that the rights should be used "for the good of French music", could persuade Edouard to change his mind. Watching these sordid manoeuvrings with interest, meanwhile, was Jean-Jacques Lemoine, legal director of Sacem, the French organisation responsible for collecting and distributing authors', composers' and publishers' rights. Lemoine knew very well how much Ravel was worth: he was Sacem's single biggest earner. Edouard died in 1960, unleashing a bitter legal battle between the Tavernes and Ravel's relatives in Switzerland, where his father was born. For the duration of the case, which dragged on for 10 years and ended up in France's highest appeal court, Lemoine astutely froze all the money entering Sacem's Ravel account. So it was that, in 1970, when the last appeal judge ruled in Alexandre Taverne's favour, Jeanne having died six years earlier, the former miner picked up £3.6m. At around that time, Lemoine resigned unexpectedly from Sacem and founded a private legal practice. His first client? One Alexandre Taverne. Not content with the £3.6m of accumulated composer's rights, Taverne and Lemoine now set about collaring a portion of the publisher's rights, too. This they did by taking Dommange to court and demanding the rewriting of his original contracts with Ravel, which mostly gave the publisher 75% of the rights from recordings rather than the customary one-third. Dommange, by then in his 80s, had no stomach for the fight and soon sold out. Taverne, who had since remarried, got his hands on all the Ravel contracts and began drawing up new ones with Lemoine; these covered, among other things, the division of rights due on recordings of Ravel's works. Lemoine set up a company, Artist's Rights International Management Agency, or Arima, specifically for the purpose. Then, in 1972, in a move that has never been fully explained, Alexandre and Georgette Taverne assigned a portion of their composer's and publisher's rights to Arima. Nobody knows how much: both Georgette, now nearly 80 and living near Montreux, and Lemoine, over 90 and living in Monaco, have refused to discuss the matter, though Georgette's daughter told Le Point magazine last year: "Neither my mother or I have received a penny of Ravel's rights for a very long time - everything was made over to Lemoine at the beginning of the 1970s." He is, the family says, the sole recipient of ill-gotten cash worth at least £30m over the past 25 years. One man disputes this, saying the Tavernes are still benefiting handsomely from Ravel's talent. But he has a sizeable axe to grind: Jean-Manuel de Scarano was the proprietor of Ravel's publishers, Durand, from 1982 until last year, when he sold out to Bertelsmann. The sale price, reportedly £13.5m, no doubt reflected Scarano's achievement, as president of the French music publishers' association, in persuading the government to extend from 50 to 70 years the period for which compositions are protected by copyright - plus an extra 15 years to account for two world wars. The day that bill became law, in 1995, Durand became worth an awful lot more money. Quite how much more is hard to say, of course, without knowing precisely what was in those Taverne-Arima-Durand contracts signed in the 1970s. Scarano insists the 1972 assignment of copyright simply entailed the Tavernes making over to Arima 50% of Ravel's publishing rights. "Arima," he says, "is the joint publisher, with Durand, of all Ravel's works. It's quite normal." It is, of course, anything but normal. Why did the Tavernes make over half their publisher's rights to Arima, and in exchange for what? How much was left for Durand? And just what is Arima? Based in Gibraltar and later in the British Virgin Islands, Arima's shareholders are three companies - Dunsmoor Ltd, Greenford Holdings and Anglo Swiss Directors Ltd - about which nobody seems to know anything. So that's the deal, it seems, with the Bolero millions. The descendants of Maurice Ravel's brother's nurse may still have their hands on some of them, though there is no way to know for sure. On the other hand, it looks almost certain that the former legal eagle at the French music rights association, hiding behind a string of paper companies, has enriched himself by around £1.5m per year for the past 30 years. Standing on the balcony of the composer's house last week, Claude Moreau gazed mournfully at the green fields beyond Montfort-l'Amaury church and swore charmingly. She hasn't the money to mend the curtains, the carpets or the roof. "It's scandalous," she says, "an insult to Ravel's memory. We haven't a centime and if we don't get some, it will soon be too late."

fields.headline: David Walker
fields.standfirst: Swashbuckling astronaut who piloted historic space shuttle missions
fields.trailText: Swashbuckling astronaut who piloted historic space shuttle missions.
fields.body:
The American astronaut David Walker, who has died of cancer aged 56, made history in 1984 as the pilot of the US space shuttle Discovery on the first mission to succeed in retrieving satellites from orbit.

The venture was a milestone in proving the ability of astronauts to leave the safety of their spaceships and carry out particularly intricate jobs in orbit. The technology they employed in the weightless conditions of space was developed for routine use in the creation of the huge international space station that is now visible from earth.

The flight was the first of four shuttle missions flown by Walker, including the 1989 voyage that launched the Magellan probe, which went on to successfully map the surface of Venus. Before he retired in 1996, he had logged more than 724 hours in space .

Although one of the new generation of astronauts recruited by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (Nasa) in 1978 for the space shuttle, Walker had a touch of the swashbuckling, derring-do image of the first generation of space jockeys who flew the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo programmes. He had been a test pilot, and a highly- decorated US navy fighter pilot, flying F-4 Phantoms during the Vietnam war.

Walker was born in Columbus, Georgia. He entered the US naval academy at Anna-polis, Maryland, from high school in 1962, got a BSc in 1966, and was posted for flight training by naval aviation training command at bases in Florida, Mississippi and Texas.

In 1967, he was assigned to the naval air station at Miramar, California, to fly F-4 Phantoms aboard the air-craft carriers Enterprise and America before being sent, in 1970, for test-pilot training to the USAF aerospace research pilot school at Edwards air force base, California. He was a member of the experimental engineering and test-pilot team that perfected the F-14 Tomcat's missile system. In 1975, he returned to operational duties with fighter squadron 142.

Walker's first shuttle mission generated excitement in the space industry because it carried, and released, two communications satellites, Canada's Anik D-2 and Hughes's Leasat-1, before rescuing two earlier satellites that were stranded in the wrong orbits; they were the Palapa and Westar communications spacecraft.

The underwriters had paid out $180m on the loss of the misplaced satellites, and offered another $10m to Nasa for the rescue attempt in the hope of recouping some of their loss by reselling the space equipment. The value of the pilots' work to the insurance world was recog nised when the five crew members were awarded the Lloyd's silver medal.

Walker's second flight was as commander of the Atlantis shuttle in 1989, which sent the unmanned Magellan spacecraft on its way to Venus. It was the first US planetary science mission launched for more than a decade, and the first planetary probe to be deployed from the shuttle. Magellan arrived at Venus in August 1990, and successfully mapped more than 95% of the planet's surface.

The mission was later to prove eventful for Walker for a less auspicious reason. He was briefly grounded in 1990 after the T-38 jet trainer he was flying came within 100ft of an airliner outside Washington - he had flown to the US capital for White House ceremonies to honour the crew for the Magellan mission.

While preparing to return to space flight in 1992, Walker revealed one of those glimpses of the tensions at work in any large organisation. He observed: "If I had decided to leave the space programme some time back, I probably could have done so with at least some people happy to see me go. But I didn't, and the opportunity to fly again is satisfying for me."

He was back in command of Discovery in 1992 to launch a classified defence department payload, DOD-1, and try out several military-man-in-space and Nasa experiments. His fourth mission, on the shuttle orbiter Endeavour in 1995, deployed and retrieved a Spartan satellite and the wake-shield facility, the international extreme ultraviolet hitchhiker payload, and other secondary payloads and medical experiments.

Walker eventually logged more than 7,500 hours flying time, including 6,500 hours in jet aircraft. He described flying in space as "the most spectacular human experience".

After leaving Nasa in 1996, he became vice-president of a telephone company in southern California, and was later a consultant for the aerospace industry. He was a technical consultant on the film Deep Impact (1998), about a comet striking the earth.

He is survived by his wife Paige, and two sons from a previous marriage.

 David Walker, astronaut and test pilot, born May 20 1944; died April 23 2001

webTitle: Gandhi dynasty threatens to sue HarperCollins

fields.headline: Gandhi dynasty threatens to sue HarperCollins
fields.trailText: The author of a biography of Indira Gandhi was last night bracing herself for a flurry of writs after members of the Gandhi dynasty expressed outrage at the book's contents - and the claim that Indira's late son Sanjay had "murdered" several of his enemies.
fields.body:
The author of a biography of Indira Gandhi was last night bracing herself for a flurry of writs after members of the Gandhi dynasty expressed outrage at the book's contents - and the claim that Indira's late son Sanjay had "murdered" several of his enemies.

Feroze Varun Gandhi, the late Indian prime minister's 21-year-old grandson, yesterday told the Guardian that his family was considering legal action against its American author, Katherine Frank, and its publisher, HarperCollins.

The family had been deeply stung by allegations that his father Sanjay had "eliminated" opponents during India's infamous Emergency between 1975 and 1977, he said. The biography claims that Sanjay - Mrs Gandhi's younger son, who died in an air crash in 1980 - ordered his "hitmen" to "liquidate" several "human targets". They included at least two underworld figures, one of whom was dumped in a river.

The book, Indira: The Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi, was published this month. It has provoked controversy in India for exploring Mrs Gandhi's "problematic" sex life - and for floating the possibility that her husband Feroze might have had an affair with her mother, Kamala Nehru, in the 1930s, before their marriage. The claim was made in a scurrilous poster campaign in the Indian town of Allahabad.

"There are very serious allegations in the book and she better be able to prove them," Mr Gandhi said yesterday. "If the people who have talked to her retract their evidence then she is going to be in deep water. We have not yet decided our course of action. She can stick by her story. I hope the supreme court [in Delhi] will be able to stick by her story."

The biography is also less than flattering about Sanjay Gandhi's widow Maneka - now a minister in India's Hindu nationalist-led government. It describes her behaviour as "erratic and uncontrolled" and says her "wild outbursts and tantrums" created a "pervasive atmosphere of uncertainty and anxiety" in the Gandhi household during a time of political turbulence.

Last night Frank defended her best-selling biography. She was not panicking at the prospect of a writ from the Gandhi family, she said. "If people want to sue me I can't do anything about it.

"Everything I say is sourced and footnoted. If it happened, it happened. I feel confident that my narrative will hold up and I have told the truth." She added: "I don't feel I have unjustly libelled anybody. I have tried to be scrupulously fair."

Frank, who lives in Britain, said reviewers had tended to ignore the new material in her book - including the revelation that Mrs Gandhi's early life had been blighted by tuberculosis. Instead, they had concentrated on her alleged affairs - with her father's private secretary, MO Mathai, and others.

"The only thing I did was to assess whether these rumours were credible," Frank said. "I included them because everyone in Indira Gandhi's circle knew about them. I find it highly unlikely she had any love affairs, though some people think she did."

It was "1,000% inconceivable" that Mrs Gandhi's husband had an affair with the woman who became his mother-in-law, she said, though they were emotionally close.

Last night a spokeswoman for HarperCollins in London said the company's representatives in India were trying to calm the controversy. She blamed "hysterical" accounts of the book, notably in a magazine, for stirring up trouble.

fields.headline: Alastair Parker
fields.standfirst: Prolific historian of Europe's road to war
fields.trailText: Prolific historian of Europe's road to war.
fields.body:
The death of Alastair Parker, at the age of 73, takes away an outstanding historian, perhaps the leading authority on the international crises of the 1930s, appeasement and the coming of war.

He was born in Barnsley, and was always proud of his Yorkshire roots, as well as the Scottish ancestry which led him to change his first name to Alastair. After naval service at the end of the second world war war, he won a scholarship to Christ Church, Oxford, where he gained a first-class degree in modern history, before writing his doctoral thesis on Coke of Holkham and the agricultural revolution - a topic well suited to his bluff, squirearchical manner.

Appointed by the great Lewis Namier, he lectured in history at Manchester University from 1952 until 1957, when he became fellow and tutor at Queen's College, Oxford, where he remained until retirement in 1997. He made an enduring impact as a colourful, engaging and immensely gifted colleague, an extrovert dean and librarian, and an outstanding tutor and supervisor.

At Manchester, Parker's interests had moved from 18th-century agriculture to Neville Chamberlain, Winston Churchill and the appeasement of Hitler - his passions for the rest of his career. At Oxford, he pioneered a special subject on the origins of the second world war, based on his matchless knowledge of the public records; his considerable linguistic gifts gave him command equally over French and German materials.

His always memorable seminars combined a meticulous grasp of the documents with constant rethinking, and an awareness of the bigger historical and ethical picture. He had an extraordinary gift for entering into the 1930s thought-world.

But, increasingly, Parker became a writing scholar of great authority, with a reputation perhaps even higher in continental Europe than in Britain. He published his thesis on Coke of Holkham in 1975, and made his reputation with his work on 20th-century international history.

He wrote an excellent general survey of Europe: 1919-1945 (1969), and a series of important articles, starting with one on Hitler's invasion of the Rhineland, and including the Ethiopian crisis and the financial and labour aspects of British rearmament. He also did important work on Anglo-American relations in the 1930s, based on research at the Roosevelt library and the US state department archives.

Struggle For Survival (1989), Parker's book on the second world war, is often reprinted, and is a tour de force of total history, in which he covered effortlessly such disparate themes as the British war economy, the impact - and folly - of the strategic bombing of Germany, and Anglo-American discord in 1945.

His next book, Chamberlain And Appeasement (1997), published during his retirement, was even more important. Written with a controlled intensity and often elegant wit, it was a powerful work of reappraisal, scrupulously fair in handling both Chamberlain and his critics, but demolishing myth after myth. Courteously, but conclusively, Parker showed how claims that Chamberlain was buying time in order to resist Hitler were without foundation. Equally, arguments that there was no alternative to Chamberlain's policy were quite false, and an effective Anglo-French alliance, as urged by Churchill, was a feasible, as well as more honourable, choice.

His final, equally fine, book, Churchill And Appeasement (2000), was a labour of love, a tribute to his political hero. Parker was well aware of Churchill's misjudgments on India, Spain, and even the Sudetenland at first. But on the supreme issue of the threat from Nazi Germany, Churchill was magnificently right, urging a grand alliance with the Soviet Union, which might have deterred Hitler at the last. When Churchill entered the government in September 1939, the world knew Britain finally meant business.

Parker had edited a volume on Churchill in 1995, and was writing a short life of him when he died. His next book would have compared British and French appeasement policies; he died while still in his intellectual prime.

Alastair Parker was a great scholar and an unforgettable personality, a warm and loyal colleague, an inspirational teacher and a human being of charm and wit. He once observed to me, of Julian Critchley MP: "My dear Kenneth, you have to remember that being Tory member for Aldershot means you tend to fray at the edges a bit." He loved music and painting; Sotheby's and Christie's knew him well.

His air of a country squire bound for the Hellfire Club went alongside deep social concerns, and a warm championing of Old Labour values. At elections, he canvassed housing estates with unique style. He enjoyed a long and happy marriage to the Oxford social scientist Julia Dixon, an authority on the health service; their daughters, Jane and Judith, both teach in Scotland.

Historians across the world mourn a generous scholar and friend, whose books live on as the legacy of a brilliant mind.

 (Alastair) Robert Alexander Clarke Parker, historian, born June 15 1927; died April 23 2001

He loved music and painting; Sotheby's and Christie's knew him well. His air of a country squire bound for the Hellfire Club went alongside deep social concerns, and a warm championing of Old Labour values. At elections, he canvassed housing estates with unique style. He enjoyed a long and happy marriage to the Oxford social scientist Julia Dixon, an authority on the health service; their daughters, Jane and Judith, both teach in Scotland. Historians across the world mourn a generous scholar and friend, whose books live on as the legacy of a brilliant mind.  (Alastair) Robert Alexander Clarke Parker, historian, born June 15 1927; died April 23 2001

webTitle: Analysis: The EBRD improved its reputation

fields.headline: Bank draughts
fields.standfirst: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development got off to a shaky start, but it has recently changed its approach
fields.trailText: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) has come a long way since a reputation for extravagance saw it dubbed the bank that likes to say yes - to itself.
fields.body:
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) has come a long way since a reputation for extravagance saw it dubbed the bank that likes to say yes - to itself. Now it likes to present itself as the listening bank, closer to the people and countries it was set up to encourage towards democracy and the market economy. So, 10 years on, has the bank proved its worth?

First, remember the context in which the EBRD was set up: the Berlin wall had been smashed into pieces before the world's media. Communist regimes across central and eastern Europe had tumbled - some quickly, others more reluctantly and violently - in the face of popular protest. The predominant emotion was euphoria.

Little wonder western politicians decided the brave new world needed a new style bank. Hence the EBRD with its mandate to encourage democracy; to use public funds yet focus on the private sector; to stick to sound banking principles while taking risks at which commercial bankers jibbed.

In the hothouse atmosphere of 1990/91 it would have been surprising if the bank had not raised expectations that would be difficult to meet, not least within its own London headquarters. The scale of the task was simply enormous. Take Russia: 70 years of communism, no entrepreneurial tradition, no vestige of the structures without which a market economy cannot survive. In some cases not even the basic infrastructure to get food to market.

The EBRD certainly got off to a bad start. Its first president, Jacques Attali, had a grandiose vision of the bank's role. But his presidency became bogged down in controversy (forever encapsulated by the row over the decision to remarble the EBRD's halls at a reported cost of £750,000). Early scandals aside, however, the bank has functioned with increasing effectiveness. It has lent some €17.5bn of its own money and helped bring in further €44.5bn from other investors. Its investment portfolio amounts to €12bn. According to President Jean Lemierre the bank can now lend €3.4bn a year - without having to ask its shareholders for more money.

Nor should its psychological impact be underestimated. The bank has continued to lend money and to persuade others to do so long after the initial euphoria has turned to disappointment in both east and west. The Russian debt crisis in 1998 forced it to draw in its horns but did not drive it away.

But the bank's influence must not be overstated either. It may account for 9% of all foreign direct investment in central and eastern Europe but its resources pale to insignificance compared with the £153bn of German tax payers' money that has poured into the old East Germany.

The bank has also had to change its approach. Where once it may have adapted a top down approach to both political reform and economic development it has increasingly looked to bolster the transition process - both economic and political - through the creation of a new class of entrepreneurs.

It still goes eyeball to eyeball with the big players, tying the prospect of lending to reform, transparency and good governance. Belarus has been warned the taps could be turned off over concerns about fair elections. Gaz-prom's application for money met with a list of questions. No answers, no money.

By contrast loans to small businesses either directly or through EBRD backed banks now total $800m covering 100,000 projects - that is up from 50,000 loans and $250m a year earlier.

The task remains formidable. On the plus side a number of countries are now preparing for accession to the European Union. The EBRD now reckons the banking sectors in Poland and Hungary can function without its help.

The pattern however is, at best, uneven. Last year was the first since the bank was set up where not one of the countries within which the EBRD operates saw its economy contract in real terms. Many are still below the level of 1989 - in some cases dramatically so. In Moldova, for example, per capita gross domestic product is less than $1 a day. In the UK it is around $65. Even allowing for the fact that a $1 will buy more in Chisenau than London the disparity is still enormous. In Russia life expectancy (the most relevant of all benchmarks) has actually fallen over the past decade. As the EBRD's chairman, Laurent Fabius, observed at the bank's annual meeting this week: "There can hardly be any prospect of sustainable growth if the population is in decline."

Even where prosperity has increased not everyone has shared in the benefits. As new enterprises and institutions have been built others have fallen away. Thousands have been left without jobs. Those on pensions have seen their value reduced to next to nothing. In some of the countries of former Yugoslavia war has left its particular legacy with a knock-on effect elsewhere in the Balkans.

The bank's mandate does not run, directly, to social issues such as poverty, health and education. With the benefit of hindsight that looks a mistake. But there are signs it is working more closely with other international financial institutions such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to address crucial social issues.

The EBRD believes firmly that the linkage embodied in its statutes between between economic reform and democracy has been proved beyond doubt over the last 10 years. But it will take a generation, if not longer, to determine if it has actually worked.

 Mark Milner is the Guardian's deputy financial editor.

fields.headline: Horreur in literary Paris at Les Mis 2
fields.trailText: France's literary establishment reacted with horror yesterday to news that nearly 150 years after it was published, Les Misérables, Victor Hugo's masterpiece and one of the best selling novels in history, is to get a sequel.
fields.body:
The outrage would not be greater if a British publisher proposed Hamlet II, the Ghost Returns. France's literary establishment reacted with horror yesterday to news that nearly 150 years after it was published, Les Misérables, Victor Hugo's masterpiece and one of the best selling novels in history, is to get a sequel.

"This is the very opposite of literature," cried the literary biographer Pierre Assouline. "It's a product, not a book." What next, he asked: "A la Recherche du Temps Perdu II: the Biscuit Bites Back?"

Cosette, or The Time of Illusions, by the journalist and author François Cérésa, hits bookshop shelves next week and is already causing enough of a furore to ensure that it becomes an instant bestseller.

"Les Misérables II - a scandal!" trumpeted the conservative Le Figaro yesterday, rather ignoring the fact that Hugo's melodramatic tale of the reformed convict Jean Valjean, the unbending policeman Javert, the evil Thénardier family and little orphan Cosette is a hit musical world wide.

The premise of Mr Cérésa's book is that the holier-than-thou policeman Javert - who doggedly pursues the hero Valjean in Hugo's original, only to commit suicide by jumping into the Seine at the end - does not actually die.

Javert, the author argues, is "the real hero of Les Misérables - he is perhaps not quite as bad as one thinks. I wanted to know more about him, and I wanted the Thénardiers properly punished."

That, say the critics, is like Dallas's JR being reincarnated as Bobby. But Mr Cérésa can take comfort from Hugo's experience in 1862. People stormed the bookshops to buy the 48,000 copies put on sale on the first day, but the reviews, as the author noted, were "reactionary and more or less hostile".
