webTitle: Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council

fields.headline: Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council
fields.trailText:
Funding body

The Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (BBSRC)
fields.body:
Funding body

The Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (BBSRC)

People to know

Chair: Dr P Doyle CBE FRSE

Deputy Chair and Chief Executive: Professor R Baker FRS

Chair of Agricultural Food Committee: Professor D Maskell, University of Cambridge

Chair of Animal Sciences Committee: Professor M Evans FRS, Cardiff University

Chair of Biochemistry and Cell Biology Committee: Dr C I Ragan, Lilly Research Laboratories

Chair of Biomolecular Sciences Committee: Professor D Gani, University of Birmingham

Chair of Engineering and Biological Systems Committee: Professor C Lowe, University of Cambridge

Chair of Genes and Developmental Biology: Dr J F Burke, University of Sussex

Chair of Plant and Microbial Sciences Committee: Professor R Poole, University of Sheffield

Aims

The BBSRC declares three broad aims. They are:

 To advance scientific knowledge and technology with particular emphasis upon agriculture, bioprocessing, chemical, food, healthcare and pharmaceutical related industries.

 To provide trained engineers for biotechnological related industries, so as to contribute to the UK's economic competitiveness.

 To promote public understanding of biotechnology and the biological sciences.

Background

The BBSRC is one of the seven research councils in the UK, and is the
biggest funding agency for academic research and training in the biosciences at universities and institutes throughout the UK. The council receives most of its income through the government's Office for Science and Technology.

Research institutes

As well as funding research in universities, the council provides funding for eight strategic research institutes, has set up six structural biology centres and funds a number of other research centres.

The eight research institutes are:

 Institute for Animal Health (IAH)

 Independent Charitable Life Sciences Institute

 Roslin Institute (RI)

 Institute of Arable Crops Research (IACR)

 Institute of Food Research (IFR)

 Institute of Grassland and Environmental Research (IGER)

 John Innes Centre (JIC)

 Silsoe Research Institute (SRI)

The six structural biology centres are:

 Imperial College Centre for Structural Biology (Imperial
College, London)

 North of England Structural Biology Centre (NESBiC) (Leeds,
Sheffield, Manchester, UMIST)

 York Structural Biology Laboratory (York)

 Bloomsbury Centre for Structural Biology (Birkbeck College
and University College, London)

 Centre for Protein and Membrane Structure and Dynamics
(CPMSD) (CCLRC Daresbury)

 Cambridge and East Anglia Centre for Structural Biology
(Cambridge)

Budget breakdown

Over the five-year period, 1999-2004, BBSRC expects to receive
over £1bn of Science Budget funding from the Office of Science and Technology. The initial allocations are as follows:

1999/2000 £195m

2000/2001 £199m

2001/2002 £204m

Funding summary

1999 - 2000 1998-1999

Income £204.1m £196.1m

Research Grants £188m £177.1m

Staff and other operating costs £16m £15.7m

Staff restructuring £6.7m £4.7m

Notional costs £10.3m £9.4m

Funding by type of spending 1999-2000
Responsive research grants £60.9m

Competitive strategic grants £51.4m

Research initiatives £26.2m

Studentships and fellowships £25.2m

Equipment and facilities £25m

Capital and buildings £8.4m

Admin £6.9m

Restructuring £6.7m

Research by scientific area 1999-2000
Agri-food £33.1m

Biomolecular sciences £30.2m

Genes and developmental biology £28.5m

Plant and microbial sciences £28m

Animal sciences £21.5m

Biochemistry and cell biology £20.4m

Engineering and biological systems £15m

Success rates

Date Number of applications Success rate %

Jul 1998 503 36%

Nov 1998 401 40%

Feb 1999 355 41%

Jul 1999 357 40%

Nov 1999 391 40%

Feb 2000 378 37%

Future issues and priorities

On 1 February 2001 the BBSRC announced a fund of approximately £33m for new research on benefits from genetic studies. Entitled "Exploiting Genomics", this is their biggest ever single research initiative, and involved an invitation to UK scientists to apply for funding to study how new information about the nature and regulation of genes can be used to improve human life.
List of scientific priorities

Subject coverage

Research funded by the BBSRC should aim to improve the understanding of living organisms and biological systems in one or more of these seven major areas:

 Agri-food

 Animal sciences

 Biochemistry and cell biology

 Biomolecular sciences

 Engineering and biological systems

 Genes and developmental biology

 Plant and microbial sciences

Grants

The BBSRC's funds support over 7,000 scientists, postgraduate students and support staff in the UK. They provide over £200m of funding per year to scientists. (This figure includes funding to the eight BBSRC-sponsored research institutes listed above).

Applications that address the themes and priorities of BBSRC's scientific committees can be made at any time, but dates for calls for application are located at the relevant sections of the BBSRC website.

The BBSRC has six funding schemes.

Research grants

BBSRC research grants are intended to provide researchers with support for research projects of timeliness and promise in which the principal applicant(s) will be personally involved. Grants are usually awarded for three years, and are categorised under the following framework:

Responsive research grants

Purpose: Awarded in response to unsolicited research proposals in any area relevant to BBSRC's mission.

Deadline: 5 March 2001 for the June 2001 round.

Responsive research initiatives

These involve a call for proposals in a specific area with one or two closing dates.

Thematic research

Responsive research initiatives which have been opened to a wider range of institutions than normal

LINK Scheme

Collaborative research with industry to accelerate the commercial exploitation of government funded pre-competitive research and to focus on advances in science and engineering with particular commercial promise.

There are a number of ways a researcher can apply to these four categories, including joint research projects, collaborative projects, joint research council/MOD funding, access to national facilities, and the "New Investigators" scheme.

Studentships and training

BBSRC offers support for any research training relevant to its mission and the needs of its research, industrial and educational communities. This includes:

Three-year studentships which can be:

 Research studentships: an opportunity for graduates to receive three years training in research, research methods and employment-related skills.

 Cooperative awards in science and engineering (CASE): Joint supervision by a member of an eligible academic institution and an employee of the cooperating industrial company. Students spend part of their training period working within the company.

 Industrial CASE: The industrial partner defines the research topic and takes the initiative in establishing a link with an eligible academic institution.

One-year studentships which can be:

 Research Master's studentships: These courses provide high-level training in research methods, a significant research component and training in technical and employment-related transferable skills.

 Advanced course studentships: BBSRC provides advanced course studentships for a limited number of approved MSc courses.

And other training schemes such as:

Integrated Graduate Development Scheme

A scheme of modular industrially orientated postgraduate training at Master's level.

Teaching Company Scheme (TCS)

TCS enables collaborative partnerships between the bioscience base and industry. These partnerships serve as a mechanism to transfer knowledge and to develop graduate and postgraduate personnel for industrial careers.

Biotechnology Young Entrepreneurs Scheme A competition

Developed to raise awareness of the commercialisation of bioscience ideas among undergraduates, postgraduate students and postdoctoral scientists.

Research Councils Graduate Schools Programme

These schools provide training in aspects of the business environment and guidance on career choices.

EU Marie Curie Research Training Grants

These grants enable postgraduate students to spend a short time at a recognised Marie Curie Training site in another country.

Fellowships

BBSRC supports three fellowship schemes which enable scientists to devote their time to independent research and scholarships.
They are:

 BBSRC David Phillips Fellowships: For scientists who have demonstrated potential during their research training and initial years of postdoctoral research.

 BBSRC Research Development Fellowships: For younger members of university teaching staff who wish to devote themselves to full-time research.

 BBSRC Professorial Fellowships: A small number of prestigious fellowships for outstanding scientists at the height of their research career.

The BBSRC also supports:

 Royal Society Industry Fellowships: This scheme aims to provide opportunities for post-doctoral employees in either industry, universities or institutes to spend a period in another sector.

 Daphne Jackson Memorial Fellowships: These are two-year awards designed to facilitate the return to research of able engineers and scientists who have taken a break for family or other reasons.

Business and innovation

BBSRC aims to promote opportunities for knowledge transfer within the bioscience community, and encourages the translation of Intellectual Property (IP) and expertise into exploitable processes and products. To this end, BBSRC supports the following schemes:

 LINK scheme: A government-wide initiative which provides up to 50% of
funding for academic/industrial collaborative projects.

 Industrial Partnerships Scheme: Support for academic, industrial or research projects where industrial contributions in cash or in kind are
accepted with no minimum threshold. Collaborations with a minimum cash contribution of 15% have preference for funding.

 Industrial CASE studentships: These studentships fund top quality bioscience graduates to undertake a three-year programme of research (leading to a PhD) on a subject selected and supervised jointly by academic and industrial partners. The distinguishing feature of Industrial CASE awards is that they are made to the company rather than the student.

 Teaching Company Scheme (TCS): TCS enables collaborative partnerships between the bioscience base and industry. These partnerships serve as a
mechanism to transfer knowledge and to develop graduate and postgraduate personnel for industrial careers.

 Industry fellowships: The scheme is administered by the Royal Society and is co-sponsored by the BBSRC. The scheme has supported researchers in the biosciences and has involved a range of industry sectors, from large pharmaceutical companies to small biotech enterprises.

 Faraday Partnerships: Essentially a scheme to encourage the transfer of ideas from the science base to application. BBSRC is currently assessing the possibility of Faraday Partnerships in the Biosciences.

 Developing entrepreneurial skills and new ventures: The scheme supports a variety of competitions and small business research initiatives.

 Modular Training Courses for Industry at Masters level: The scheme aims to provide up to date, industrially relevant technical training for graduates working in industry. Support is provided for the development of individual training modules. Evidence of a clear industrial need for the training is a key requirement of funding.

 Integrated Graduate Development Scheme (IGDS): IGDS aim to enable universities and BBSRC-sponsored institutes to develop post-experience training at the Masters degree level. Programmes are expected to be self-financing after five years.

International

These funding opportunities arise from an emphasis on international collaboration.

 International Scientific Interchange Scheme (ISIS): The opportunity for BBSRC grant-holders to travel abroad in order to explore the potential of an international linkage and possible funding opportunities.

 International Fellowships Scheme: Support to high profile researchers for periods of up to 12 months abroad.

 The Underwood Fund: Provides travel and living expenses to senior overseas scientists to visit the UK to work with current BBSRC grant-holders in UK universities and BBSRC sponsored institutes.

 Wain Fellowships: Enable young research scientists to work or study abroad at a specified academic or industrial institution for a period of up to three months in an area of agricultural research relevant to BBSRC.

 Wain Travel Grants: Provide the costs of travel and living expenses of senior academic members of staff of UK universities to spend a period abroad working in a laboratory on an agreed collaborative programme and/or to consult with others on an agreed collaborative programme in an area of agricultural research relevant to BBSRC.

Communicating Science

BBSRC encourages public awareness of science and promotes an appreciation and understanding of biotechnology and biological sciences. With a view to improving public confidence and stimulating public debate, funding is
available for:

BBSRC National Science Week Awards

Grants of up to £2,000 are available for new and re-run activities.

BBSRC Public Understanding of Science Grants

Up to £10,000 for scientists to develop resources for promoting the appreciation and understanding of advances in the biological sciences.

Address

Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council

Polaris House

North Star Avenue

Swindon

SN2 1UH

UK

Tel: Switchboard: +44 (0)1793 413200

Fax: +44 (0)1793 413201

Website: www.bbsrc.ac.uk
E-mail: All email addresses in BBSRC follow a standard
format of: firstname.lastname@bbsrc.ac.uk

Studentships and training BBSRC offers support for any research training relevant to its mission and the needs of its research, industrial and educational communities. This includes: Three-year studentships which can be:  Research studentships: an opportunity for graduates to receive three years training in research, research methods and employment-related skills.  Cooperative awards in science and engineering (CASE): Joint supervision by a member of an eligible academic institution and an employee of the cooperating industrial company. Students spend part of their training period working within the company.  Industrial CASE: The industrial partner defines the research topic and takes the initiative in establishing a link with an eligible academic institution. One-year studentships which can be:  Research Master's studentships: These courses provide high-level training in research methods, a significant research component and training in technical and employment-related transferable skills.  Advanced course studentships: BBSRC provides advanced course studentships for a limited number of approved MSc courses. And other training schemes such as: Integrated Graduate Development Scheme A scheme of modular industrially orientated postgraduate training at Master's level. Teaching Company Scheme (TCS) TCS enables collaborative partnerships between the bioscience base and industry. These partnerships serve as a mechanism to transfer knowledge and to develop graduate and postgraduate personnel for industrial careers. Biotechnology Young Entrepreneurs Scheme A competition Developed to raise awareness of the commercialisation of bioscience ideas among undergraduates, postgraduate students and postdoctoral scientists. Research Councils Graduate Schools Programme These schools provide training in aspects of the business environment and guidance on career choices. EU Marie Curie Research Training Grants These grants enable postgraduate students to spend a short time at a recognised Marie Curie Training site in another country. Fellowships BBSRC supports three fellowship schemes which enable scientists to devote their time to independent research and scholarships. They are:  BBSRC David Phillips Fellowships: For scientists who have demonstrated potential during their research training and initial years of postdoctoral research.  BBSRC Research Development Fellowships: For younger members of university teaching staff who wish to devote themselves to full-time research.  BBSRC Professorial Fellowships: A small number of prestigious fellowships for outstanding scientists at the height of their research career. The BBSRC also supports:  Royal Society Industry Fellowships: This scheme aims to provide opportunities for post-doctoral employees in either industry, universities or institutes to spend a period in another sector.  Daphne Jackson Memorial Fellowships: These are two-year awards designed to facilitate the return to research of able engineers and scientists who have taken a break for family or other reasons. Business and innovation BBSRC aims to promote opportunities for knowledge transfer within the bioscience community, and encourages the translation of Intellectual Property (IP) and expertise into exploitable processes and products. To this end, BBSRC supports the following schemes:  LINK scheme: A government-wide initiative which provides up to 50% of funding for academic/industrial collaborative projects.  Industrial Partnerships Scheme: Support for academic, industrial or research projects where industrial contributions in cash or in kind are accepted with no minimum threshold. Collaborations with a minimum cash contribution of 15% have preference for funding.  Industrial CASE studentships: These studentships fund top quality bioscience graduates to undertake a three-year programme of research (leading to a PhD) on a subject selected and supervised jointly by academic and industrial partners. The distinguishing feature of Industrial CASE awards is that they are made to the company rather than the student.  Teaching Company Scheme (TCS): TCS enables collaborative partnerships between the bioscience base and industry. These partnerships serve as a mechanism to transfer knowledge and to develop graduate and postgraduate personnel for industrial careers.  Industry fellowships: The scheme is administered by the Royal Society and is co-sponsored by the BBSRC. The scheme has supported researchers in the biosciences and has involved a range of industry sectors, from large pharmaceutical companies to small biotech enterprises.  Faraday Partnerships: Essentially a scheme to encourage the transfer of ideas from the science base to application. BBSRC is currently assessing the possibility of Faraday Partnerships in the Biosciences.  Developing entrepreneurial skills and new ventures: The scheme supports a variety of competitions and small business research initiatives.  Modular Training Courses for Industry at Masters level: The scheme aims to provide up to date, industrially relevant technical training for graduates working in industry. Support is provided for the development of individual training modules. Evidence of a clear industrial need for the training is a key requirement of funding.  Integrated Graduate Development Scheme (IGDS): IGDS aim to enable universities and BBSRC-sponsored institutes to develop post-experience training at the Masters degree level. Programmes are expected to be self-financing after five years. International These funding opportunities arise from an emphasis on international collaboration.  International Scientific Interchange Scheme (ISIS): The opportunity for BBSRC grant-holders to travel abroad in order to explore the potential of an international linkage and possible funding opportunities.  International Fellowships Scheme: Support to high profile researchers for periods of up to 12 months abroad.  The Underwood Fund: Provides travel and living expenses to senior overseas scientists to visit the UK to work with current BBSRC grant-holders in UK universities and BBSRC sponsored institutes.  Wain Fellowships: Enable young research scientists to work or study abroad at a specified academic or industrial institution for a period of up to three months in an area of agricultural research relevant to BBSRC.  Wain Travel Grants: Provide the costs of travel and living expenses of senior academic members of staff of UK universities to spend a period abroad working in a laboratory on an agreed collaborative programme and/or to consult with others on an agreed collaborative programme in an area of agricultural research relevant to BBSRC. Communicating Science BBSRC encourages public awareness of science and promotes an appreciation and understanding of biotechnology and biological sciences. With a view to improving public confidence and stimulating public debate, funding is available for: BBSRC National Science Week Awards Grants of up to £2,000 are available for new and re-run activities. BBSRC Public Understanding of Science Grants Up to £10,000 for scientists to develop resources for promoting the appreciation and understanding of advances in the biological sciences. webTitle: Kanoute: I'm ready to leave West Ham

fields.headline: Kanoute: I'm ready to leave West Ham
fields.trailText: Frederic Kanoute could spark a £10m transfer scramble after revealing he is ready to consider offers to leave Upton Park.
fields.body:
Frederic Kanoute could spark a £10m transfer scramble after revealing he is ready to consider offers to leave Upton Park.

But while Kanoute insists Manchester United, Liverpool and Juventus are all interested, West Ham maintain the striker is not for sale and that they would resist any moves to buy him.

Speaking to the new French weekly magazine Foot Transferts, Kanoute declared: "Chelsea came to see me mid-season to negotiate. They made me a very attractive offer and it was rather interesting for West Ham. But I refused in the end because it was too early to leave. I preferred to stay and at least see the season out.

"Now the season is practically over, it's clear that my way of thinking is going to be radically different. Each offer I receive will get all my attention because now I feel ready. My ambitions have changed.

"I don't see why I would leave this championship though," he added. "I love this style of play. Anyway, I have no desire to return to France."

Kanoute last week claimed he had "never spoken to anyone about leaving West Ham" but he has now revealed: "Manchester United, Juventus, Liverpool are the stuff that dreams are made of. My agent has spoken to me about contact with these three clubs.

"There's nothing concrete at the moment though," he added. "I'm waiting for a firm offer before I start getting excited."

But Kanoute has left his options open by making clear how much he has enjoyed his time at West Ham.

"Everything's gone really well for me this season, I feel good here. The management have put their trust in me and it's the first time I've really been considered as a first-team player," he added.

According to Kanoute's agent, Pape Diouf, his client's future is still up in the air.

"Nothing has yet been decided," he said. "For the moment, he is staying at West Ham. We have had some propositions but nothing has convinced him to leave."

West Ham managing director Paul Aldridge reacted to Kanoute's reported comments by insisting that he would be speaking to Diouf himself.

Aldridge told West Ham's official website whufc.co.uk: "We're certainly not looking to entertain any bids for Frederic Kanoute and any that we may receive would be politely - or perhaps not so politely - refused."

"It would certainly be inappropriate if any clubs were to have made contact with him," he added. "He's under contract for some time to come, having been happy to sign improved terms with us earlier this season."

fields.headline: No 15. Port Vale
fields.standfirst: Rob Fielding, the editor of www.onevalefan.co.uk, wants us to know all about Port Vale. Which might explain why he's written this
fields.trailText: Rob Fielding, the editor of www.onevalefan.co.uk, wants us to know all about Port Vale. Which might explain why he's written this.
fields.body:
Why are Port Vale different?

Millwall may have first rights to "No-one likes us" - perhaps Port Vale fans should adapt a song to "No-one knows where we are".

Port Vale are one of the few clubs with no geographical reference in their name, and the origins of said name are still unclear to this day. Some say the club was founded in Port Vale house, whilst other stories maintain that the club was founded on Port Vale canal wharf in Staffordshire. Whichever story is correct, Port Vale were founded in 1876 as near neighbours of Stoke City and the Vale Park ground is situated in Burslem - one of the Northern towns in the conurbation of Stoke-On-Trent.

The high point

We're still enjoying the celebrations after becoming the first winners of the LDV Trophy. It may not sound much if you're a Manchester United fan, but it was a fabulous day out at the Millennium stadium capped by a dramatic late Vale comeback to secure a 2-1 win over Brentford.

Looking back a little further, the splendidly entitled "Iron Curtain" side of 1954 set a league record for least goals conceded as they powered to the top of the Third Division North and also became the first Third Division side since the war to reach the FA Cup semi-finals.

The low point

It was pretty bad when I first started supporting the Valiants in 1979. The club had just survived being re-elected to the Fourth Division after finishing 92nd in the Football League.

How's it going at the moment?

On the pitch, manager Brian Horton has worked a minor miracle in the second half of the season. With massive debts, he was forced to slash the squad size and offload senior players. But with a handful of experienced campaigners and unproven youngsters, he has taken us from the relegation zone to mid-table security with a run that has seen just one defeat in 20 games and a club-record-equalling six successive away wins.

However, cup commitments and a bog-like pitch have resulted in a massive fixture backlog. Our tiny squad has to play six games in the next 11 days. How would you like to do that, Mr Houllier?

Off the pitch, things are much worse. Without going into details, it is fair to say that chairman WT Bell has been controversial and is not the most popular man in Burslem right now. Fans are being urged to support the Valiants 2001 campaign which is trying to buy him out and establish a fan-orientated club organised along the lines of Bournemouth or Lincoln. It is a campaign that www.onevalefan.co.uk fully backs.

The last fixture

Brentford 1, Port Vale 2. That was nice!

The next fixture

Bristol Rovers v Port Vale - we need just one more win to absolutely guarantee safety. This may be the game we get it in.

Sore point

It has to be the board. Clueless, amateur, pathetic and ridiculous are some of the nicer things the site's messageboard has had to say about them.

The manager

Former 70s Vale player Brian Horton had a difficult task when he replaced the legendary John Rudge. The LDV Trophy win and the recent run will have done much to dispel fans' doubts.

The chairman

Oh dear, oh dear. I think I've said enough about him already.

Rivals

We do have problems with the Stoke-on-Trent branch of Iceland. Stoke City were recently taken over by an Icelandic consortium and are currently aiming for a play-off place. The local derbies are always, erm, passionate affairs, with Vale coming out on top this season thanks to two league draws and a victory in the LDV Vans tie. Yes, we do have lot to be grateful to LDV for.

The kit

The club ditched our traditional black shorts last season. Apparently, a director thought an all-white kit made us look like Real Madrid. We may have looked like the Champions League winners, but this wasn't reflected on the pitch as the season ended in a disastrous relegation to the Second Division.

Players rated

Brian Horton has brought in a crop of youngsters this season. Reliable goalkeeper Mark Goodlad and skilful midfielder Marc Bridge-Wilkinson are already tipped for the top, but personally I feel that 19-year-old striker Stephen Brooker has all the attributes to go right to the very top. At just £15,000 from Watford, his signing was an absolute steal.

Old boys

Vale fans are usually loyal to their more high-profile sales of recent years. Vale old boys include Steve "he should play for England" Guppy at Leicester and Ian "he used to drive a fork lift" Taylor at Aston Villa. Probably the most revered former Valiant was the now-retired Robbie Earle, who was recently voted the best Vale player of all time.

Players hated

Former Stoke striker Mark Stein is probably not the most popular player to visit Vale Park after some penalty antics in a local derby. Swindon defender Sol Davis also deserves all the stick he will get, after nearly ending Michael Walsh's career with a truly awful tackle.

Vale Park

Originally built in the 50s as (I kid you not) the new "Wembley of the North". Unsurprisingly, the club ran out of money before the dream could be realised. The scale of the original idea can still be seen today, thanks to the huge running track that circles the pitch.

Currently, the ground is almost complete. But just like in the 50s, the club has once more run out of money before it could complete the hugely over-ambitious new Lorne Street stand. The half a stand that has been built so far has cost something like £5m and put the club into massive debt in the process.

We could have funded a whole new ground with that amount of money!

Atmosphere

Vale crowds are not renowned for their noise with the honourable exception of our recent trip to Cardiff.

Links

The official club site www.port-vale.co.uk is (unlike some official sites) run by a genuine fan and there is a good relationship between the respective Vale websites. The popular Vale fanzine The Vale Park Beano can be read on www.onevalefan.co.uk whilst Derek, I'm Gutted can be purchased at most games.

webTitle: Camelot boss business woman of the year

fields.headline: Camelot boss business woman of the year
fields.trailText: Camelot chief executive, and former marketer, Dianne Thompson has been named the Veuve Clicquot 'Business Woman of the Year' for 2000, writes Julia Day
fields.body:
Camelot chief executive, and former marketer, Dianne Thompson has been named the Veuve Clicquot 'Business Woman of the Year' for 2000.

Ms Thompson beat 70 nominees to win the award, previously won by Body Shop founder Anita Roddick and head of media group Pearson, Marjorie Scardino.

Starting her career as a marketing trainee at the Co-operative Wholesale Society, Ms Thompson became a lecturer at Manchester Polytechnic and founded her own advertising agency. For five years she was managing director of Sandvik Saws and Tools.

Nine years ago Ms Thompsom became Woolworths director of marketing and then marketing director for the Signet Group.

She joined Camelot in February 1997, was the first female executive director to join the Camelot Board and took over as chief executive after Camelot was finally awarded the second licence in December 2000.

Camelot chairman Sir George Russell CBE said: "The fight Dianne led following The National Lottery Commission's decision last August was not just about keeping Camelot alive and in the race. It was about fairness and justice for our staff, suppliers and shareholders."

Veuve Clicquot managing director John West said: "The panel look for qualities that reflect the character of Madame Clicquot - and felt that Dianne's year showed these many qualities, especially flair, tenacity and leadership, making her the worthy inheritor of the title for the year 2000."

Ms Thompson said: "I hope this accolade goes some way to prove that Camelot is a great business made up of great business people. Although the licence fight catapulted us into the headlines it was our track record as a successful and efficient business that secured our win."

fields.headline: Pluthero launches fresh attack on BT
fields.trailText: 5.45pm: The Freeserve chief has lambasted BT for dragging its feet on the introduction of broadband in the UK, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Freeserve's boss John Pluthero today renewed his attack on BT for dragging its feet on the introduction of broadband in the UK.

He reignited the debate in an online interview on MediaGuardian.co.uk, describing BT as: "appalling - in execution and policy".

He said: "This is extraordinary. While other European telcos are adding 500,000 DSL users a year, BT has given up. We are now officially a third world telecoms country."

Asked if he was still considering taking legal action against BT, he said: "We said we were considering it and we'll take a view after Oftel has reported."

Oftel, the telecoms regulator, has been investigating Freeserve's claims since the start of the year and the industry is now awaiting its findings.

Asked if he supported the idea of an ISP ombudsman to represent the consumer, Mr Pluthero said: "Now the flaky players have exited, or are doing so, we probably don't need one but I would welcome an arbiter of the market."

Meanwhile, Mr Pluthero said Freeserve was forging ahead with a mobile and TV strategy.

"We have distribution on all Cellnet phones and will shortly add Orange, making us the only player to have joint mobile network distribution in the UK.

"On TV, the Bush product [Freeserve has a TV internet site on Bush Internet] is far from half-baked and we will add further similar products this year," he added.

fields.headline: TalkSport nabs soccer rights from Capital
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: Kelvin MacKenzie's TalkSport has snatched the rights to Spurs and Fulham games from arch-rivals Capital, writes Ashley Davies.
02.01.2001: TalkSport revamps programme line-up
fields.body:
TalkSport has snatched the rights to broadcast live commentary of Tottenham Hotspur and Fulham games in London and the southeast from arch rivals Capital Radio.

Kelvin MacKenzie's TalkSport has already taken the rights to Chelsea games from Capital, leaving the London station with coverage of Charlton, Arsenal and West Ham.

"Until now London transmission of Premiership has been the monopoly of Capital," said a TalkSport spokesman.

"There was a risk we would be frozen out entirely but this gives us a handle on Premier League commentary."

Talksport refused to reveal the value of the deal.

Its coverage will kick off at the beginning of next season and the deal is for three years.

The match commentaries will be broadcast on TalkSport's London opt-out service by existing staffers.

"We are pleased and proud to be bringing the best possible live Premier League commentary to the people of London and the southeast, who have not had the service they deserve in the past," said Mr MacKenzie.

webTitle: Disputed rise in independent schools' share of pupils

fields.headline: Rise in independent share disputed
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Independent schools yesterday claimed another rise in numbers, despite government figures showing that their overall share of pupils has remained level.
fields.body:
Independent schools yesterday claimed another rise in numbers, despite government figures showing that their overall share of pupils has remained level.

A survey of member schools by the Independent Schools Information Service (Isis), which covers around 80% of private school places in the UK and Ireland, showed a rise of 6,557 pupils - 1.4% - on last year.

But the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, has reported to the Commons that as the number of school age children rose from 8.19m in England in 1997 to 8.35m in 2000, the share at independent schools had remained steady at 6%.

If sixth form students were taken into account, independent schools accounted for 6.7% of the school population. The government also predicted that an extra 10,000 pupils would go into the independent sector over the next 10 years.

David Woodhead, director of Isis, said independent schools were more popular than ever and disputed the government's figures. He said a 7.5% share was more accurate.

Independent school fees rose by an average of 6.7%.

fields.headline: ITV Sport Channel to get £150m launch
fields.trailText:
5.15pm: Carlton and Granada are planning to invest £150m in launching the ITV Sport Channel pay-TV service, reports Jason Deans.
ITV to launch sports station
25.04.2001: Liddiment steps up in ITV revamp
25.04.2001: ITV centralises web operations
fields.body:
Carlton and Granada are planning to invest more than £150m in launching the ITV Sport Channel pay-TV service.

The money will go on securing sports rights for the channel, including live Champions League, Nationwide League and Worthington Cup football, as well as marketing, distribution and production costs.

ITV Sport Channel is due to launch in August and is expected to be on air from around 5pm to midnight on weekday evenings and for longer on Saturday and Sunday.

The service will be available to subscribers to the ONdigital terrestrial platform, which is to be rebranded as ITV Digital.

"This means that as ITV we can come to the table with very clear free-to-air and subscription sport propositions," said the ITV controller of sport, Brian Barwick, who will have editorial responsibility for the channel.

"We will be able to get the best out of our contracts, our presenters and our rights negotiations.

"I wouldn't underestimate the level of service which is going to be on offer. ITV Sport Channel alongside free-to-air ITV Sport is a considerable step."

The ITV controller of legal and business affairs, Simon Johnson, added that being able to offer viewers and sports rights owners a free-to-air and pay-TV product was "probably unique among European broadcasters. It's a great development," he said.

Mr Johnson said another benefit would be the ability to cross-promote between the main ITV channel and ITV Sport Channel.

"The present regulations allow that, the same as we already do with ITV and ITV2," he added.

"We will be able to drive viewers from free TV to pay, by alerting them to when the next game is coming up on ITV Sport Channel."

Mr Barwick said it was "premature" to be talking about a possible ITV bid for the live football Premier League contract currently held by BSkyB next time it comes up for grabs.

Mr Johnson added ITV's current terrestrial contracts for Premier League highlights, which it inherits from the BBC in August, and live Formula One coverage would be "unaffected" by the launch of ITV Sport Channel.

He also stressed that ITV's position on football World Cup rights in its current row with Kirch would not be changing.

The German media group wants to sell the UK rights to the highest bidder and has threatened to auction them to a pay-TV operator.

"ITV and the BBC are determined to secure the rights to all World Cup games for live, free-to-air broadcast," Mr Johnson said. "That's absolutely unaffected by our plans for ITV Sport Channel."

Mr Barwick would not be drawn on who will be the main faces of the new ITV sports service, apart from Gabby Yorath and Ally McCoist.

But he signalled that sports presenters from the main ITV channel, who include Des Lynam, would be putting in appearances on ITV Sport Channel.

"That's all to be worked through in the next few months," Mr Barwick said. "We will be able to bring people across from ITV, including presenters already working on the sports we will feature on ITV Sport Channel."

In terms of production, the Granada/Carlton joint venture ISN has already secured the major live football contracts for Champions League and Nationwide League coverage, Mr Barwick added.

But he said that there would be opportunities for other companies to secure commissions for ITV Sport Channel shows.

webTitle: An open letter to Robbie Williams

fields.headline: An open letter to Robbie Williams
fields.trailText: Dear Robbie,
fields.body:
Dear Robbie,

We're a bit worried about you.

We all know how the pub conversation goes: "You're a Port Vale fan? Isn't that the club that Robbie Williams supports?"

The answer used to be so easy. To be honest we were delighted that the Vale was "the one" for you. But now?

Well, for a publicity-hungry pop star you seem to have a done a pretty good job of shying away from your association with Port Vale.

Just a few years back, you were opening "PORT VALE" emblazoned guitar cases on TV, wearing Vale shirts at concerts and starring in BBC documentaries on the hallowed Vale Park pitch.

Not any more.

The Millennium stadium's Rock DJ may have had Let Me Entertain You blasting out of the stadium PA system, but there was no evidence that the Ego himself had landed at Cardiff.

We've seen sightings of you at Highbury, at St James' Park and even the Olympic stadium in Munich. But as for Vale Park - not a glimpse.

The onevalefan site has tried to contact you. We thought you may want a chat about the Valiants. We thought we might be able to persuade you to come to a game or to give the club some much needed good publicity. But there's no way through your management entourage.

Have you fallen out of love with us? Has the glamour and bright lights of the Premiership seduced you? Was it all (God forbid) a chance to use an alleged love of a strangely named football club like Port Vale as a chance for cheap publicity? Surely you weren't one of those celebrity football hangers-on?

We're still hoping you haven't abandoned your roots, Robbie. You may not have been at the Millennium Stadium for our greatest game of recent years - our 2-1 LDV Vans Trophy win over Brentford - but we'd all love to see you at the ground soon.

And if you ever fancy a chat about the Vale - we're always available to take that call.

Yours as ever,

Rob Fielding,

Editor - www.onevalefan.co.uk

fields.headline: Freeserve revamp results in staff losses
fields.trailText:
5.15pm: John Pluthero has confirmed there have been redundancies but would not give details of the number, writes Amy Vickers.
How John Pluthero answered your questions
25.04.2001: Wanadoo results disappoint
15.03.2001: Freeserve boss Keeling is casualty of Wanadoo merger
fields.body:
John Pluthero, the chief executive of Freeserve, has admitted the company's recent reorganisation resulted in the departure of several members of staff.

He confirmed there had been redundancies but did not give details of the number of people affected.

"There may be other departures, as there have been in the past. It's a fact of corporate life," he told MediaGuardian.co.uk in a live online interview.

"Freeserve has a deep and capable management team that will continue to serve us well."

The company-wide reorganisation followed Freeserve's acquisition by France Telecom's Wanadoo in December.

The most high-profile casualty so far was the chief operating officer, Frank Keeling.

Mr Keeling was told his role had become superfluous because Mr Pluthero was taking a "more hands-on approach to business strategy" and a number of divisional heads had been appointed.

"It was a shame to lose Frank as his experience was highly valued but that COO role doesn't really exist any longer," said Mr Pluthero.

"Any departures are not a result of downturn but a result of a reorganisation of the business and a new focus on giving our customers what they demand."

Freeserve has also said goodbye to co-founder Mark Danby, who was seconded to a new unit last year to set up the investment arm, ThinkVentures.

Mr Pluthero confirmed ThinkVentures had closed and Mr Danby had moved on to Royal Bank Ventures, an investment arm of the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Mr Pluthero also set the record straight on who conceived Freeserve, after various Dixons employees publicly laid claim to the idea.

"There was no one point and no one person but the defining conversation was between myself and Peter Wilkinson," he said.

fields.headline: Kennedy enters row over government advertising spend
fields.trailText:
5pm: The Lib Dems leader has called for a new system to keep account of the government's advertising spend, reports Claire Cozens.

25.04.2001: Blair accused over advertising spend
Table: top 10 spending UK advertisers
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, has demanded a new regulatory system be set up to keep account of what the government spends on advertising

The call follows follows the revelation that the government was Britain's highest-spending advertiser in the first three months of this year.

Speaking on Radio 4's World at One, Mr Kennedy said the level of spending was "obscene" and called for a system of "independent, outside regulation to keep a check on what the government is spending on your and my behalf as taxpayers".

Figures released today showed the government spent £62.8m in the first quarter of 2001 - almost twice as much as the next highest spender. Consumer giant Unilever spent £34.4m in the same three months.

The news has also sparked criticism from Conservatives, who have accused the government of using taxpayers' money to fund pre-election propaganda.

Ironically, back in 1988 Tony Blair - then a junior opposition spokesman - wrote to the Independent Broadcasting Authority in protest at high levels of advertising spend under the Tories.

"It is no coincidence," he wrote, "that the areas of largest increase in spending are those of most political sensitivity for the government - employment, the DHSS, and the Department of Trade and Industry."

But the cabinet office minister, Ian McCartney, defended the government's advertising campaigns.

"This falls into two categories; those where we have changed the law to give people rights, and you then have to make sure they have knowledge of those rights," he said.

"The second group is public information. For example, we gave a commitment to increase the number of nurses and recruit more police officers, so we are advertising to recruit more nurses, more police officers, and it's working very successfully."

Mr McCartney insisted the timing of these campaigns just before a planned general election was complete coincidence.

He said that there was a difference between the kind of advertising undertaken recently and that used by Tory governments previously.

"The difference is that what we are giving information about is actual rights, not perceived rights, not things that will happen after the next election," he said.

"There is not a single thing that we are advertising in terms of citizens rights that they can't claim now."

fields.headline: Timid debut for BBC Savages
fields.trailText: 5.15pm TV overnights: BBC1's new 9pm sitcom, Savages, came in with a whimper on its first airing last night, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
BBC1's new 9pm sitcom, Savages, came in with a whimper on its first airing last night.

Only 5.6m people, 24% of those watching, tuned in for Simon Nye's new offering.

Over on ITV at the same time, Bad Girls reliably nailed down 8.4m viewers and a 36% audience share.

Earlier on, at 6pm, BBC2's retro science fiction series Stingray came in neck and neck with Channel 4's The Priory.

Both shows pulled in 1.7m viewers and a 9% share.

An audience of 4.8m people saw ITV's Britain's Richest People documentary. It aired at 10.20pm and got a 31% audience share.

C4's Faking It beat BBC2's Happiness at 10pm, although both audiences were small. 1.18m people, 11% of the audience, saw the documentary.

Paul Whitehouse's midlife crisis watched out for 1.5m, an 8% audience share.

webTitle: England World Cup qualifier in Greece faces postponement

fields.headline: England World Cup qualifier in Greece faces postponement
fields.trailText: England's upcoming World Cup qualifier against Greece faces being postponed after Fifa demanded the Greek FA prove its independence from the Greek government by midnight tonight - or face the consequences.
fields.body:
England's upcoming World Cup qualifier against Greece faces being postponed after Fifa demanded the Greek FA prove its independence from the Greek government by midnight tonight - or face the consequences.

Fifa could decide to suspend the Greek FA, a decision that would mean the indefinite postponement of all World Cup qualifiers involving Greece - including England's match in Athens on June 6.

Football's governing body has accused the Athens government of interfering in Greek football, which has been plagued by poor refereeing, match-fixing allegations and dwindling attendances - and demanded legislative changes to enshrine the independence of the Greek FA.

So far the government have refused to budge, with Sports Minister George Floridis claiming it is up to the Greek FA to clear the air with Fifa. "They are members of Fifa, they have to respond to them," he said.

As a result Fifa has now set a deadline for midnight tonight for the government to change the situation.

A Fifa spokesman told Guardian Unlimited: "Today is the deadline for the Greek FA to recover the normal situation and send us documents that show the Greek government's intervention in FA matters has ended.

"If we don't hear anything by midnight tonight we will hold talks tomorrow and make a decision on Friday."

Fifa have already suspended the Guinean FA for refusing to toe their line, and the spokesman warned the Greek FA could be next.

"It's a very serious situation," he said. "I can't speculate on what might happen. But I can assure you that every country is treated the same - whether it's Greece or Guinea."

fields.trailText: The Football League's disciplinary panel are expected to reconvene within the next 10 days after being asked to re-assess allegations of financial irregularities at Chesterfield.
fields.body:
The Football League's disciplinary panel are expected to reconvene within the next 10 days after being asked to re-assess allegations of financial irregularities at Chesterfield.

The League's board of directors yesterday announced they would not to ratify the panel's recommendation to dock the Spireites nine points, claiming the punishment was too lenient.

Football League spokesman John Nagle said today: "The panel will definitely get together at some point before the end of the season."

fields.headline: Children 'drawn into riot'
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Children as young as 11 were drawn into racist rioting in Bradford on Easter Sunday, detectives said yesterday, as they appealed for more witnesses to come forward.
fields.body:
Children as young as 11 were drawn into racist rioting in Bradford on Easter Sunday, detectives said yesterday, as they appealed for more witnesses to come forward.

Specially trained officers are pursuing leads alleging that violence and serious criminal damage was committed by children and teenagers when rumours about a marauding gang of white youths swept the Lidget Green area.

West Yorkshire police have a tally of 96 separate reported crimes, including a vicious attack on a passing driver. Julie Cook, 38, had been visiting relatives in Bradford when a brick was thrown through her windscreen. She left hospital yesterday after eye surgery.

Two pubs were seriously damaged in the four hours of street fighting - "revenge" attacks by Asian youths - triggered when members of a white group made racist comments about a Hindu engagement party. Officers took video film of the fighting.

Three men arrested during the trouble were freed on police bail.

webTitle: Reward offered to catch race attackers

fields.headline: Reward offered to catch race attackers
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A reward was offered yesterday for help in catching a gang of Asian youths suspected of beating up a pensioner in a racist attack.
fields.body:
A reward was offered yesterday for help in catching a gang of Asian youths suspected of beating up a pensioner in a racist attack.

Walter Chamberlain, 76, had a cheek bone broken in the attack on Saturday as he walked home from a rugby match through a predominantly Asian area of Oldham.

Greater Manchester police authority has offered a £10,000 reward, a local business has offered £3,000 and an Asian taxi driver £150 to bring his attackers to justice.

Police believe that three Asian youths were involved and are treating the incident as racially motivated.

Racial tension has been rising in the area and police figures show a record level of racist attacks in Oldham, with more than 60% of the victims being white.

Racial tension has been rising in the area and police figures show a record level of racist attacks in Oldham, with more than 60% of the victims being white. Press Association

fields.headline: France cracks down on 'stock market redundancies'
fields.trailText: In the face of public outcry at a string of layoffs in France by large companies including Marks and Spencer, the French government yesterday announced tough measures to deter companies from mass firings.
fields.body:
In the face of public outcry at a string of layoffs in France by large companies including Marks and Spencer, the French government yesterday announced tough measures to deter companies from mass firings.

The law will double the minimum redundancy pay - at present one tenth of a month's salary per year of service - and force companies to offer staff up to six months of retraining to help them find other work.

Businesses of more than 1,000 employees that shut operations on a particular site will be fined a sum based on the number of staff made redundant unless they help to develop replacement activities. Those that have received state aid will be asked to repay part.

Employees are to be given a greater say in corporate restructuring plans, with management obliged to discuss the "social and local impact" of layoffs and shut-downs with works councils. "We have to give employees the capacity to create new leverage as far as unilateral decisions by company bosses are concerned," said the labour minister, Elisabeth Guigou.

French fury has been roused by the wave of "stock market redundancies" - a French term used to describe layoffs driven by a desire to shore up future profits or defend share prices, rather than by losses - announced by the food group Danone, Marks and Spencer, and Moulinex.

Danone plans to close half its 36 European biscuit factories, including two in France employing 570 workers. M&S is closing its continental operation with the loss of 1,700 jobs in France, and Moulinex is closing three French factories employing 2,900.

Prime minister Jospin's junior coalition partners, the Communists, have proposed an amendment to the bill making mass redundancies by large profit-making companies illegal.

fields.headline: Straw targets 30,000 would-be asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, today vowed to increase the number of asylum seekers who are removed from the UK each year after being refused refugee status.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, today vowed to increase the number of asylum seekers who are removed from the UK each year after being refused refugee status.

His comments came as official figures published today revealed that the government had failed to meet its target of 12,000 last year. However, Mr Straw said: "The target for this year is 30,000." He said the government's new target was backed up by investment in 1,500 extra immigration officers to work as arrest squads. And the Home Office will be using more chartered aircraft to repatriate unsuccessful asylum seekers.

However, Home Office officials later confirmed it will be very difficult to return applicants from Iran and Iraq, who make up a large proportion of the number of asylum applications received in the UK, because direct flights are not possible from British airports.

Mr Straw said that many refugees also leave the country voluntarily after they have exhausted their rights of appeal.

The new target will comprise of 24,000 asylum seekers and 6,000 of their spouses, children and other dependants, he said.

Asked if the target was achievable, the home secretary said: "I think we will get there, but we can never be certain."

About 700 immigration officers have already been trained and are in place to act as arrest teams and they will be joined by 1,500 more, Mr Straw said.

However, he criticised Conservative plans to detain every single asylum seeker in secure camps as "impractical, inhumane and expensive".

Mr Straw said new electronic fingerprinting technology at ports, airports and other centres across the UK have already led to 89 arrests and 44 convictions of bogus applicants.

The latest phase of this technology was being rolled out this week he added.

The home secretary also discussed the possibility of the UK having to change its rules on who qualifies for asylum and who does not under a draft EU directive being published later this year.

It is widely expected that the UK will be required to narrow its definition to exclude people who have been persecuted in non-government-backed incidents.

The UK currently allows asylum on the grounds of rape, domestic violence and other acts not sponsored by other governments for example. Other EU countries do not allow such claims.

"Some European countries have narrower definitions in some respects and some have the same or wider," said Mr Straw. "It's a very varied picture.

"What we think is important is that there should be a level picture so we have similar definitions which apply across Europe.

"What I suspect is that under the EU directive we will have common standards. But I can't say whether ours will go up or down.

"I am sure they will change in some respects but we have to have changes across Europe."

The Home Office also announced today that there was a provisional 2% drop in asylum applications during the financial year 2000/01.

The figure up to the end of March was 74,850 and the backlog of undecided claims was the lowest in the decade.

Figures also revealed the number of asylum applications rose slightly in March, compared with February, but it was still 13% lower than for the same period last year.

Last month, 1,700 people were granted asylum or 9% of the 18,895 decisions made by immigration officials.

But applicants also made a record number of appeals. Nearly 11,000 appeals were submitted and 490 of them were granted asylum by the Immigration Appellate Authority. Interactive guide

fields.headline: Newcastle reject United's £15m for Dyer
fields.trailText: Manchester United look certain to pursue their interest in Newcastle's Kieron Dyer despite having a £15m bid for the player rejected. Barcelona and Juventus are also in the hunt.
fields.body:
Manchester United are contemplating whether to flex their financial muscle again with a bid of around £20m for Kieron Dyer after Newcastle turned down their £15m approach. However, they face competition from abroad after the player's representatives confirmed last night that Barcelona and Juventus had begun preliminary talks about the England midfielder.

Sir Alex Ferguson has identified Dyer as his next priority after concluding the British-record £19m transfer of Ruud van Nistelrooy on Monday and, even though their initial inquiries have been repelled, including a £10m approach last week, the champions have made it clear they are willing to pursue the matter.

Newcastle expect United's chief executive Peter Kenyon to lodge a significantly improved offer in the next few weeks. The north-east club have deliberately leaked details of United's interest to prepare the club's supporters for his possible departure.

Although Bobby Robson, the Newcastle manager, has repeatedly stated his desire to keep Dyer, it seems increasingly likely that the versatile 22-year-old will be allowed to leave after only one season at St James' Park.

The lure of Old Trafford will be enticing but United are concerned that the public knowledge of their intentions could prompt an auction. As well as Barcelona and Juventus, Leeds United have also declared an interest, having twice tried to sign Dyer.

"Kieron is very happy at Newcastle but, if they want to sell him, that is up to them," his agent Jonathan Barnett said last night. "I think every major club in Europe would be interested in a player of his talent."

So far, however, United are the only club to have made a concrete offer. If the Leeds manager David O'Leary is to follow up his interest, a player-plus-cash exchange, possibly involving Michael Bridges and Ian Harte, has been mooted.

The situation is poised delicately because Robson is currently involved in a series of meetings with Newcastle's chairman Freddie Shepherd, the latest taking place on Monday, to discuss the players he wants to bring in over the next few months. These include Vitesse Arnhem's £6m-rated forward Victor Sikora, who is in the Holland squad for tonight's World Cup qualifier against Cyprus in Eindhoven.

Robson has stood by Dyer despite a number of off-the-field problems involving the player, which led to the club ordering him to leave his city-centre flat earlier this season, and the Newcastle manager would vehemently oppose the sale of arguably the club's most valuable asset.

He feels badly let down at the amount of money he has been allowed to spend and any agreement to transfer Dyer would be against the manager's wishes.

Two weeks ago, when Robson was asked about Dyer's availability, he replied: "There is no way I would allow him to go. I want to add to Alan Shearer and Kieron Dyer to make this club stronger and I know for a fact my chairman is in total agreement on this."

However, whether Newcastle United plc, given its financial situation, could resist the opportunity to bank a profit of around £14m on Dyer remains to be seen.

United's interest in Dyer is bound to heighten speculation about the future of David Beckham, though an informed source at Old Trafford emphasised yesterday that, if a deal for the Newcastle player went through, it would have no bearing on the England captain's position at the club.

A predominantly right-sided midfielder, Dyer can also play in central midfield or attack. He made an immediate impact on Tyneside after his £6m move from Ipswich in July 1999 but has been out since February this year after an operation on his shin.

fields.headline: Blair backs beleagured Maff
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today backed the beleaguered Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food following reports it was to be shut down and reconfigured as a Ministry for Rural Affairs.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today backed the beleaguered Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food following reports it was to be shut down and reconfigured as a Ministry for Rural Affairs.

Under pressure from the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, to specify whether he planned to "scrap, reform or change" Maff, Mr Blair dismissed reports of a Whitehall departmental rejig as "nonsense."

The point-blank rebuttal comes after sustained criticism of the department for wavering over a vaccination programme for non-infected cattle, in addition to logistical problems which have seen culled carcasses left rotting in open fields before being disposed of.

The three human infections of foot and mouth have also not reassured the public over Maff's competence, as has concern that the existing policy of burning corpses of cattle may have been responsible for releasing toxins into the air.

Those problems have led to a story in the Times today suggesting that after a general election Maff would be turned into a Ministry for Rural Affairs led by the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, with Maff's responsibility for food production handed over the Department for Trade and Industry.

That would mirror the Ministry for Rural Affairs in Scotland, which is largely perceived to have been a success over its two year lifespan.

However, Mr Blair told the Commons that the concentration of foot and mouth in one area of Scotland was not comparable with the problems faced by Maff south of the border, where the disease is geographically widespread.

In what is expected to be one of the final sessions of prime ministers' questions before the calling of a general election, Mr Blair was also pressed by the leader of the opposition, William Hague, to pledge a veto on any rise in income tax.

Goaded by the accusation the his government had brought in "45 stealth taxes during the lifetime of the parliament", Mr Blair left the question of a 1997-style pledge on income tax hanging, telling MPs they must "wait for the manifesto."
