fields.headline: Paranoid Parenting by  Frank Furedi (I)
fields.standfirst: Making Sense of Parental Paranoia
fields.trailText: Tony is giving up teaching. Although he would not use the words, it was 'parental paranoia' that drove him out of the West Sussex primary school where he had taught for three years. During his teacher training, Tony had anticipated that he might be stretched by the challenge of dealing with rowdy children. But he was not prepared for the task of coping with 'difficult' anxious parents. The most taxing moments of his working life were to be spent dealing with 'worried mums'. He sighs as he tells of the mother who insisted on driving behind her son's coach to France to ensure that he arrived safely. He wearily recalls how a school trip to the seaside, planned for a class of 5-year-olds was cancelled because two parents were concerned that the trip would involve their children in a 45-minute journey in a private car. Would the cars be roadworthy? Who would accompany a child to the lavatory? Who would ensure correct fitting seat belts? Were these normally non-smoking cars, or would the children be made victims of passive smoking? The planned pirate's day on the beach ended up being confined to the school field - sea, sand and adventure confined to their imagination and many of its education aims undermined. Exasperated by 'problems - all in the minds of parents', Tony sought, and found, a career outside teaching.
fields.body:
Tony is giving up teaching. Although he would not use the words, it was 'parental paranoia' that drove him out of the West Sussex primary school where he had taught for three years. During his teacher training, Tony had anticipated that he might be stretched by the challenge of dealing with rowdy children. But he was not prepared for the task of coping with 'difficult' anxious parents. The most taxing moments of his working life were to be spent dealing with 'worried mums'. He sighs as he tells of the mother who insisted on driving behind her son's coach to France to ensure that he arrived safely. He wearily recalls how a school trip to the seaside, planned for a class of 5-year-olds was cancelled because two parents were concerned that the trip would involve their children in a 45-minute journey in a private car. Would the cars be roadworthy? Who would accompany a child to the lavatory? Who would ensure correct fitting seat belts? Were these normally non-smoking cars, or would the children be made victims of passive smoking? The planned pirate's day on the beach ended up being confined to the school field - sea, sand and adventure confined to their imagination and many of its education aims undermined. Exasperated by 'problems - all in the minds of parents', Tony sought, and found, a career outside teaching.

Of course, it is normal for parents to be concerned about the well-being of their children. Parental anxiety is nothing new. A brief inspection of the pages of The Nursery World from the 1920's and 1930's shows that our grandparents were haunted by many of the doubts, worries and preoccupations that torment fathers and mothers today. A frequently revised topic was: 'Is my child's development normal? Child tantrums, shyness, aggression, jealousy, thumb-sucking, nail-biting, refusal to sleep, were regularly raised in letters from concerned parents. Many begged an answer to what the publication's agony aunt called 'a problem as old as parenthood itself - that of how to get to obey us'.

It might seem that not much has changed. But the superficial similarities betray some big differences, in the past, parental anxiety focused on the problems within the family. Infant health - physical, psychological and moral - was an important preoccupation as was preparing children for the outside world - school, career, marriage. And of course, the older generation was often anxious about their children falling in with bad company and generally 'getting up to no good'. But the concerns raised by our grandparents were voiced in a different tone from today.

Reading the worries of parents published in the 1920s, the overall impression is something like this: 'Family life is fine, but there is just this one little thing that we need to sort out.' Today the discussions in parenting magazines suggests that family life is far from fine, that most parents feel out of control and that everything is up for question. Instead of a specific concern, parents seem to be suffering a more general loss of confidence.

The parents who write in magazines today do not give the impression that they are troubled by one aspect of child-rearing. Many seem overwhelmed by the sheer scale of troublesome issues confronting them. These days it seems that every little issue - how to toilet-train a child, when you can leave them home alone, whether to force them to eat their greens - is made into a bigger problem by an overall crisis of parental nerve. This suggests that there must have been some major changes in the way that adults negotiate the task of looking after youngsters. The clearest symptom of this trend is the public panic about child safety.

In recent years, no issue has come under close scrutiny than the question of children's safety. It has become so highly charged that a single incident can spark a major public debate and demands for new regulations. For example, the tragic murder of an English teenage girl while visiting France on an organized school exchange led to a major review of the safety of school trips - despite the fact that the incident was clearly a one-off event. There is no evidence of any increase in attacks on foreign (or French) students in France, and it is unlikely that such an attack will take place again regardless of whether the authorities take new precautionary measures or not. Such measures may make parents feel better, but a murderer intent on getting into a dormitory will probably do so as easily in France as he would in England. Thankfully, such outrages happen rarely - not because of security measures recommended by educational establishments, but because only a tiny number of people are motivated to commit such atrocities. In truth, a 15-year-old girl is probably far safer in a dormitory in St Gerbais than in her 18-year-old boyfriend's Ford Fiesta on the M25.

Public concern with safety has reached obsessive proportions. The remote possibility that children might choke on small toys in packets of cereals, chocolates and crisps has provoked demands to ban them. There is no evidence that any child has ever choked to death - but the theoretical possibility that one just might do so one day in undeniable, and that is sufficient to justify the call for a ban. Baby walkers, which have been used for years to allow infants to whiz about before they can walk alone, have been condemned because of the possibility that children may topple over or fall down the stairs. Admittedly this danger is more 'real' than that of death by Pokemon-card ingestion, but it is still triggered by the potential risk that something might happen, and not by specific evidence that it has.

Once in place, parental paranoia easily attaches itself to any new experience concerning children. Take in vitro fertilization (IVF) - for many the only root to parenthood. Rather than celebrating the potential of IVF to cerate wanted children, researches have recently warned about hypothetical dangers to the children being given life. There have been warnings that IVF could induce changes in children's genetic make-up and impair their mental development. There has been speculation about whether sperm that have to be assisted to fertilize an egg will produce babies as healthy as sperm that can swim on their own. Psychologists muse about whether people who become parents by artificial means after years of infertility will be able to relate, in an emotionally stable manner, to their much-wanted children. It has even been suggested that IVF children will be loved too much and may not be able to live up to their parents' hopes for them. It is only a matter of time before the fertile imagination succeeds in turning IVF into a child safety issue.

The internet has a remarkable potential to enhance young people's lives by providing educational opportunities. Yet it is widely seen as another new technology that poses new dangers to children. Much of the discussion about the World Wide Web has focused on how to protect young people from the perils, to prevent innocents stumbling across 'adult' sites or into the clutches of paedophiles. 'The Internet can be a big and dangerous place for children, but for the price of a phone call, it needn't be', promises a newspaper advertisement for an Internet provider specializing in protecting children in cyberspace. Such manipulative marketing schemes are confident that they can convert parental paranoia into hard cash.

Sadly, virtual reality provides infinite space for the exercise of the anxious imagination, an unknown world where our fear of invisible strangers can run riot. Since children are often more adept at negotiating the net, parental control is forced to confront uncomfortable new challenges. 'You don't know what's out there', a group of fathers confided in me. One raised the spectre of paedophile rings lurking in the shadows online, ready to pounce on his unsuspecting teenagers by e-mail. Nobody I talked to had actually heard of any child being damaged, but nevertheless they regarded the Internet as a really big problem. As one parents' guide to the Internet warns: 'You might think you have taken adequate steps to protect your child, but please be aware that a determined child might nonetheless be able to circumvent any protective software or security measure. And apparently there are other risks to worry about. A London conference on parenting in April 2000 was informed by Dr Jane Healy, and American educational psychologist, that computers can also damage children's brain development.

Old-fashioned television is often indicted for its negative impact on children. Parents complain that television is teaching their children to be violent shopaholics. They protest that video games distract children form reading or riding a bike. Even parents who rely on the VCR to keep their children busy feel guilty about their pragmatic embrace of the electronic baby-sitter. The experts encourage these concerns. One American study warns that the impact of the media on children 'should be eliciting serious concern, not just from parents and educators but from physicians, public health advocates, and politicians as well'. Parents are encouraged to blame television because, in a world where they already feel pretty powerless, yet another outside influence on their children is experienced as a threat to their authority.

Parents mistrust the Internet and television because of a more general unease about having to cope with external influences that bear upon their children. Many of these influences - television advertising, consumerism, the Internet - are portrayed as part of a complex new world that is causing parental insecurity. But adult over-reaction to new technology is a symptom, and not the cause of the problem. Many parents now feel so insecure and fearful of what they do not understand that virtually anything can be turned into a potential childcare crisis.

Fear of children's safety has come to dominate the parenting landscape. In 1998 the advocacy group Families for Freedom interviewed 200 parents. The results make frightening reading. Most of these parents paint a picture of a world that is hostile territory for their children. They routinely use words like 'scared' and 'frightened' to describe their feelings about their children, particularly where they are outdoors. When the marketing organization System Three surveyed public opinion on the safety of children in Scotland for the BBC in 1998, the results suggested an overwhelming sense that children were far less safe than 20 years ago. Although the incidence of child murder by a stranger in Scotland is very low and has shown no change in the past 20 years, 76 per cent of respondents thought that there had been an increase in such tragedies, while 38 per cent believed that the increase had been 'dramatic'. A large majority - 83 per cent - also thought that more children were now being knocked down by traffic on the roads of Scotland. In fact the incidence of road injuries to children had decreased by 60 per cent during the previous 20 years. The gap between adult perceptions and the reality of the risks faced by children is confirmed by other studies in the Anglo-American world. A survey of US paediatricians carried out in 1995 claimed that parental anxieties tended to be significantly out of proportion to many real risks. The discrepancy between actual and imagined risks was particularly striking in relation to the dramatic issues of child welfare, such as abduction, environmental poisons and cancer.

A culture of fear has led parents to restrict their children's independent outdoor activities. In 1971, eight out of ten 8-year-olds were allowed to walk to school alone. Now it is fewer than one in ten. At age II almost every child used to walk, now it is down to 55 per cent and falling. A report published by the Children's Play Council in 1997 argued that children had become virtual prisoners in their own homes.

Paranoid parenting does not only restrict children's freedom to play. It also diminishes the creative aspect of play. There is considerable evidence that children are more creative when their parents are not around to monitor their behaviour. A study by Dale Grubb and Alicia Snyder concludes that adult supervision turns play into a structured activity and that this weakens youngsters' drive to experiment. Unfortunately, the concept of unsupervised children's activity - what used to be called play - is now defined by child professionals as a risk. Restricting children's outdoor activity has predictable consequences for their development, and a sedentary lifestyle is inevitably bad for their health. Research has linked the decline in British children's fitness to the decrease in the amount of time they spend walking and cycling. The First National Travel Survey reported a fall of about 20 per cent in the annual distance walked and 27 per cent in the distance cycled by children between 1985 and 1993. An average British schoolgirl now walks for less than seven minutes a day. Deprived of the opportunity to burn calories by racing around outside, children grow fat. A study published in the British Medical Journal in September found an alarming proportion of pre-school children to be overweight and even obese. Among those aged 2, 15.8 per cent were considered overweight and 6 per cent obese. By the time they reached 5, 18.7 were deemed overweight and 7.2 per cent obese.

A study published in the British Medical Journal in September found an alarming proportion of pre-school children to be overweight and even obese. Among those aged 2, 15.8 per cent were considered overweight and 6 per cent obese. By the time they reached 5, 18.7 were deemed overweight and 7.2 per cent obese. Continue

webTitle: 'He was the voice of unpretentious good taste and common sense'

fields.headline: 'He was the voice of unpretentious good taste and common sense'
fields.standfirst: Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw pays tribute to Barry Norman, while Derek Malcolm bemoans the state of today's cinema.
fields.trailText: Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw pays tribute to Barry Norman
fields.body:
Memories are short in the media, and for many, the news that Barry Norman is about to quit his Film Review programme on the Sky Premier cable channel is like hearing James Callaghan announce from the House of Lords that he is quitting politics.

But for 26 years, from 1972 to 1998, as presenter of the BBC's weekly film slot, Barry Norman was perhaps the nation's best-known film critic - rumpled, genial, avuncular, with bags under his eyes which bespoke a hard evening's viewing, and which women viewers were alleged to find sexy. The programme went through a phase of trying out alternative presenters in the 70s: including Iain Johnstone and a squeaky-voiced young Tina Brown - but only Barry had the necessary sang-froid.

He became an institution, despite the graveyard slot in which that programme was (and often still is) scheduled - acquiring, like all legends, a catchphrase that he never actually said: "And why not?".

Then in 1998, during a spasm in which the BBC lost other big names like Desmond Lynam and Frank Skinner, Barry said he was leaving for a better offer at Sky because the modern corporation did not value him enough - a slight display of grumpiness which perhaps prefigures his bowing out now.

Barry's style now looks very sedate compared to the intense young guys and gorgeous babes doing film shows - and certainly compared to Jonathan Ross's dazzling enthusiasm and connoisseurship.

He hails from an era when his BBC show was virtually the only outlet for mainstream cinema comment: before the era of subscription movie channels and the internet. He was the voice of unpretentious good taste and common sense. He reviewed what was on at the multiplex, guiding viewers to what they were actually likely to enjoy and be able to see locally.

The format of his show was sometimes very placid, especially time-consuming features like plodding through the American top ten box office. But Barry's interviews were models of easy-going charm, especially his classic interview with Michelle Pfeiffer in which Barry, endearingly, made no secret of his crush on Michelle, and we all knew how he felt.

But he gave some tough questions to Robert de Niro which famously resulted in an off-camera nose-to-nose aggressive encounter. (Let's see the young whippersnappers stand up to Travis Bickle!) I remember his breezy, feelgood encounter with Steven Soderbergh, amiably riding around Cannes with him in a car with when Soderbergh had just won the Palme d'Or for sex, lies and videotape.

Now Barry is quitting, citing the dumbing-down of the movies; it's a perennial complaint. Perhaps he's just had enough. Barry Norman did the film world a favour in leading the complaints about people talking during the movie, a sin which many chains now explicitly forbid before the film starts. And he always had a buoyant, infectious love of cinema. Well done, Mr Norman!

 Derek Malcolm bemoans the state of today's cinema.

webTitle: 'At least 60 per cent of what's on offer in British cinemas is total dross'

fields.headline: 'At least 60 per cent of what's on offer in British cinemas is total dross'
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm reckons his fellow critic was spot on, and bemoans the lack of quality cinema available today, while Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw pays tribute to Barry Norman, "the voice of unpretentious good taste and common sense".
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm reckons his fellow critic was spot on, and bemoans the lack of quality cinema available today
fields.body:
Barry Norman, by some way the highest paid and best-known film critic in the UK, will find it relatively easy to retire now and indulge himself by thinking that things ain't what they used to be in the world of reviewing. Financially he probably could have retired from weekly reviewing even before taking Sky's generous bait some two years ago.

Nevertheless, things clearly aren't what they were. He's right in decrying present-day Hollywood's obsession with comic book adaptations, or at least movies which have very little relevance to anyone over the age of 25, and no doubt he would also be aware that the rest of the world hasn't exactly covered itself in glory over the last decade or so either.

Where, for instance, are the equivalents of European and Russian masters like Bergman, Fellini (pictured, scene from La Dolce Vita), Tarkovsky, Truffaut and Fassbinder now? Only Asia seems to be coming up trumps these days, and films from there seldom get much time on the airwaves of Sky, since they are - Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon excepted - firmly relegated to the art houses by reason of their sub-titles.

Besides that, television is scarcely going upmarket where films are concerned and there's palpably a limit any self-respecting critic can contemplate when endlessly discussing star vehicles made for teenagers, or the stars themselves whose publicity is manipulated by PRs as never before.

No doubt Norman will continue to work, since he's scarcely gaga with age. But he will be relieved not to have to see quite so many awful movies as he has done in the last few years. By my reckoning, at least 60 per cent of what's on offer in British cinemas is more or less total dross. Swimming through that week after week is enough to soften the brain and harden the heart. It's not as much fun as it used to be indeed. He'll see the best and desert the worst. Meanwhile one hopes his successor isn't a weather girl pressed into service.....

 Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw pays tribute to Barry Norman, "the voice of unpretentious good taste and common sense".

fields.headline: Guardian readers' moral dilemmas over the census
fields.trailText: Perhaps you could tell the whole story (Callers to census hotline cut short, April 24) instead of the usual journalistic spin that implies that we could do better. As a census district manager I get a daily printout of the calls that apparently require action for my area.
fields.body:
Perhaps you could tell the whole story (Callers to census hotline cut short, April 24) instead of the usual journalistic spin that implies that we could do better. As a census district manager I get a daily printout of the calls that apparently require action for my area.

In the first week of enumeration I had three demanding to know why they'd not had a form yet. Today I got one that said an occupant was going to be away till the end of May... so post the form early, and join the 1,000 or so that have already been posted back in my area, despite instructions to wait!

Out of 10 calls so far, only four have required action. If this is the general experience, no wonder the lines are not holding out. When all else fails, read the instructions; if you give them a phone number they'll only call it. Please withhold my name: I still want to get paid.
Name and address supplied

 Unlike Geoff Mason (Letters, April 23), we had a census form rather than a note put through the door. If it is apparently acceptable merely to deliver these, why not use the Royal Mail? As least our postman would have delivered it to the correct house.
Tom Locke
Burntisland, Fife

 I have been asked by the Registrar General to answer the question: "What is your ethnic group?" and threatened with a fine if I fail to answer. I am afraid that I must incur the possibility of this fine.

What the question actually asks me to do is to identify with a group based upon skin colour. I refuse to do this because I do not think that my skin colour of itself makes me a member of an ethnic group. If my skin colour happens to be black, I may not say that my primary ethnic identification is with my Britishness rather than with my skin colour. In all conscience, as one who has been a professor of sociology and ethnic relations for some 50 years, I feel that it is my duty to indicate that this census has a political purpose and is not simply an objective fact-gathering exercise.
John Rex
University of Warwick
ersas@dredd.csv.warwick.ac.uk

 And what about the census question on health? "Getting a picture of people's health helps your health authority plan the right services for your area". The only question on health asks: "Over the past 12 months would you say your health has been: Good; Fairly good; Not good?"

How's that going to tell my health authority how many hip replacements and ingrowing toenail operations it's going to have to do?
Margaret Wilkinson
Leeds

 There appears to be a question missing on my census form: Are you a pain in the arse Guardian reader who will nit-pick and have moral dilemmas over every single bloody word in this document? Yes/No
Tim Blacklock
Sheffield
tim@blacklock.supanet.com

fields.headline: Monkey goes to the Princess Margaret Awards
fields.standfirst: They were inspired by Paul McCartney's PR, Geoff Baker, who once 'revealed' that Princess Margaret was to appear in the original series of Crossroads. Ancient history now and former hack Baker is long gone from the Daily Star, but his legacy lives on. Last night's Princess Margaret Awards honour the men and women behind Fleet Street's finest fiction. So if you're a celebrity and you have been 'misquoted' or even 'quoted' you can take some solace in the fact that at least once a year journalists own up to it
fields.trailText: Monkey reports from a night out at 'Fleet Street's Oscars' which saw hacks vie for awards including 'best showbiz vendetta' and 'bitchiest hatchet job'.
fields.body:
Sugar Reef last night opened its doors to the most important event in the Fleet Street calendar.

With so many media awards pageants, it's easy to become jaded by fading glitter.

But the Princess Margarets pay homage to journalism at its finest. Here the unsung footsoldiers of Britain's newspaper offices finally reap the rewards of their labours.

Not for them the hollow glory of the Press Awards, the masonic backslapping of the Baftas. Here the mercenaries of truth are rewarded for their daily vigil against the creeping pressures of deadlines and the insidious strictures of the Press Complaints Commission.

The pinnacle of the evening was watching two masters of their craft, Mirror editor-in-chief Piers Morgan and his most loyal disciple, Sunday People editor and professional Yorkshire lad, Neil Wallis, exchanging lifetime achievement awards.

Imagine Monkey's pride to see Mirror showbusiness deputy ed Alun Palmer and News of the World's Lee Harpin finally rewarded for services to shorthand in the Verbatim Quotes Award.

Harpin eventually took the gong for his extraordinary recall of an "interview" with Martine McCutcheon. But there were mutterings that the award should have gone to Palmer for his amazing empathy with Samantha Janus in the black arts of childcare.

Palmer scooped the world with his lengthy and in-depth interview with the former Liverpool One.

'This hasn't come as that much of a shock to me," Janus told Palmer.

Indeed Janus confided lots, lots more. "Isn't he absolutely gorgeous?" she said of her babe. "I can't believe how much I love this person."

That was, of course, exclusive, - ie nobody else at the press conference heard it.

And who could forget Lee Harpin's recreation of moments of passion between actress Samantha Morton and the Cops actor Jack Marsden.

"Breathless groans of raw passion echoed around the cinema as up on the screen stunning young actress Samantha Morton and tough guy Jack Marsden writhed in naked ecstasy.

"And amid the darkness of the spellbound West End premiere audience the sexual heat was also rising.

"Former Band of Gold stars Sam and Jack were there as honoured guests watching themselves play a nymphomaniac and her prey in steamy cult movie Under the Skin. As their love scene reached its climax the two began exchanging drooling sidelong glances in the flickering darkness of the auditorium."

The Mail's showbusiness supremo, Alison Boshoff, was rewarded for her sensitive handling of the subject of female body image, with her moving tributes to those feminist icons, Vanessa Feltz and Geri Halliwell and Mel C, whom she dubbed Beefy Spice.

The Sunday People's Sean Hoare picked up the overall Princess Margaret award for his exclusive revelation that David and Victoria Beckham plan to buy an "idyllic £6m private island off the coast of Essex".

The Spice Island exclusive was roundly applauded as brilliant fiction.

And the Mirror's 3AM girls collected the Matchmaker of the Year award for "Billie to wed Chris Evans".

Super columnist Sue Carroll and her younger rival Christine Smith of the Mirror toughed it out for the award for bitchiest hatchet job.

But the clear winner in the "phantom pregnancy" stakes was Sean O'Brien for his "exclusive" revelation of the imminent pregnancy of Zoe Ball. He told the world she was with child in February - a full 11 months before she gave birth in December. It was enough to earn him the "One-day-it-will-happen or celebrity-set-to-die award".

The Daily Star's Ben Todd wiped the floor with the People's Sean O'Brien, Screws columnist Rav Singh and Bizarre in the "Sources Close to Deadline Award", with 30% of his stories featuring "close friends" and "insiders" compared with O'Brien's 19%, Singh's 20% and Bizarre's paltry 12%.

The only sour note to an otherwise glorious evening was compere Matthew Wright's threat to reveal the details of former boss Piers Morgan's love life.

Just why was he sitting at the Sun's table?

But perhaps the People's Mr Wallis, himself a member of the Press Complaints Commission, put it best when he described the awards as the real Oscars of Fleet Street.

webTitle: US moves to tackle online fraud

fields.headline: US moves to tackle online fraud
fields.trailText: The US government has launched an international database to protect consumers from online fraud, allowing surfers from 13 countries to file e-commerce complaints at one place.
fields.body:
The US government has launched an international database to protect consumers from online fraud, allowing surfers from 13 countries to file e-commerce complaints at one place.

The site - Econsumer
- is run by the federal trade commission (FTC) and will take in confidential fraud information gathered by law enforcement officials across the globe. An FTC spokeswoman said that at the moment there is no systematic way to investigate cross-border internet scams.

Econsumer offers information about scams on the net and a place for consumers to file specific complaints. The FTC hopes the database will help participating countries crack down of fraudsters who often operate across international boundaries.

The initiative is an extension of the FTC's Consumer Sentinel database, which covers all types of fraud, but only in English. The Econsumer site operates in English, French, German and Spanish.

A notice on the site encourages users to share their experiences of online fraud: "Because the internet marketplace is a borderless one, sharing your complaint with government agencies in different countries will help keep the internet safe. It will also help prevent others from experiencing the problem you did."

The UK has joined Australia, Canada, Denmark, Finland, Hungary, Mexico, New Zealand, Norway, South Korea, Sweden and Switzerland in signing up to the scheme.

FTC
Consumer Sentinel
Office of fair trading

fields.headline: Express threatened with industrial action
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: NUJ members will be balloted next week following a breakdown in talks with the management, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Desmond and Hollinger settle dispute
11.04.2001: Associate editor quits Express
11.03.2001: Express swamped with redundancy requests
fields.body:
Journalists at the Express will be balloted for strike action early next week following a breakdown in talks between management and the NUJ over terms and conditions.

And the union is to consider writing to management at the paper to ask for the editorial board to be suspended, following fresh allegations of editorial interference.

Earlier this week, representatives of the NUJ walked out of the meeting with the newspaper's departing managing editor, Lindsay Cook, the deputy managing editor, Alex Bannister, and the legal representative, Naomi Hirans.

The NUJ's newspaper organiser, Jeremy Dear, told MediaGuardian.co.uk talks had broken down after the Express failed to address a series of demands made by the union.

Mr Dear said Express Newspapers management had failed to provide answers to a series of questions.

The union had asked for the current redundancy terms to be extended beyond their December deadline.

The terms provide for as much as 20 times the statutory redundancy payment and Express Newspapers wants to cut this back.

The union called for guarantees that staff would be given Express Newspapers contracts as opposed to Northern & Shell contracts, which offer poorer holiday and sick pay terms.

The NUJ also wants Express Newspapers to provide some sort of remuneration for staff who remain at the paper after the departure of so many of their colleagues.

The union also wants details of how the redundancies will affect the newspaper's Scottish offices.

"We asked them to provide recognition that people were doing extra work and should be compensated accordingly," Mr Dear.

Over the course of the past few weeks, more than 130 staff have volunteered for fast-track redundancy.

The most recent high-profile journalist to leave the paper is Nigel Billen, the Saturday features editor, who will leave the paper at the end of April.

Meanwhile, the NUJ is "strongly considering" writing to Express Newspapers to ask for the dissolution of the editorial board, which comprises Arthur Davidson, Jonathan Holborow and Louise Chase.

Insiders claim Express owner Richard Desmond has continued to interfere with editorial policy making, particularly on the business pages.

It is claimed he asked business journalists on the Sunday Express to run two negative pieces about the Telegraph Group and Emap and a positive piece on Mohamed Al Fayed.

An Express Newspapers spokesman said: "We have a full consultation period of 90 days. Redundancy terms are far superior to the legal minimum."

He added the Express Newspapers editorial board had been appointed for a two-year term.

fields.headline: The whole kit and kaboodle
fields.standfirst: Your football questions answered every Wednesday. Email the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to help
fields.trailText: NOW YOU CAN PUT YOUR SHIRT ON IT
fields.body:
NOW YOU CAN PUT YOUR SHIRT ON IT

Last week, we chopped down the tall tale that Notts County don't have to wear an away kit because they were the first team in the football league, before stuffing it into a large bag marked "completely untrue". But that hasn't stopped some of you from claiming that this special dispensation refers to other league clubs.

"It's actually Preston North End who aren't required to wear away strips by virtue of them being the first double winners," ventures Henke Larsson., while Mad Dan Eccles reckons: "Reading don't have to because of being in Royal Berkshire (or something like that)."

Well, you're both wrong. John Booth, the Preston press officer, says: "It's a load of rubbish. We're governed by the same Football League rulebook as everyone else." While his counterpart at Reading, Craig Mortimer, says much the same thing. "I've heard of this before, but while I haven't spoken to the Football League about it, I doubt very much whether they'd allow us to play all our matches in our home kit." So now you know.

A EUROPEAN FIRST

"Can you tell me the name of the first British club to play in the European Cup? I know that Chelsea didn't when they were English Champions in 1956, but don't know who was," writes Jon White.

The first British club to play in European competition was Hibernian, who reached the semi-finals in 1955 thanks to a forward line known as The Famous Five: Gordon Smith, Bobby Johnstone, Lawrie Reilly, Eddie Turnbull and Willie Ormond.

The first round saw them beat German champions Rot-Weiss Essen 5-1 over two legs. They eased past Swedish champions Djurgaardens in the quarter-finals 4-1 on aggregate. But their run came to an abrupt end in the semis when eventual runners-up Stade de Reims triumphed 3-0 over the two matches.

The first English side to play in the tournament were Manchester United, Matt Busby telling the Football League where to stick the pressure that had seen Chelsea opt out of the tournament the year before.

Their first tie saw them dispose of Belgian champs Anderlecht by a massive 12-0. But, like Hibs before them, their first punt in Europe saw them bow out in the semis, when the unstoppable Real Madrid of Puskas and Di Stefano saw them off by five goals to three.

ENGLAND'S 1970 WORLD CUP SQUAD - THE UNLUCKY MEN

David Glass asks: "Can anyone tell me who England's third keeper was in the 1970 Mexico World Cup Squad after Gordon Banks and Peter Bonetti?"

Alex Stepney, the Manchester United goalkeeper who once shouted so hard at his defence that he dislocated his jaw, is your man.

Stepney was one of only four members of Sir Alf's greatest-ever World Cup squad not to play in the tournament. The other players who may as well have stayed Back Home were Emlyn Hughes, Nobby Stiles and Everton defender Tommy Wright.

WHERE DOES THE COUNTY IN STOCKPORT COUNTY COME FROM?

"Why are Stockport County called county? My mate who's a Stockport fan hasn't got a clue," says Nick.

As we all know, Stockport isn't a county, but a suburb of Greater Manchester. But it wasn't always that way. Back in the grimy old days of 1889, Stockport was accorded county borough status, so when a local football team formed the following year, it seemed completely logical to call themselves Stockport County.

Of course, the decision made a bit less sense in 1974, when Stockport ceased to be a county. But despite floating the idea of becoming known as Manchester South FC, they decided to keep their name. And long may it continue.

CAN YOU HELP?

"I have heard that only three players have scored 30 league goals against Liverpool - Dixie Dean, Jimmy Greaves and the classic Emlyn Hughes bringing up the rear with an astounding 30 own goals. Is this true?" asks John Ames.

"Can you tell me who scored the last First Division goal of the 1991/92 season?" asks Sue Neil.

"Everyone remembers that Steve Bull played for England despite not playing in the top league," remembers David Cassidy. "But I'd like to know which is the lowest division a player has ever been selected from to represent a) England and b) a top ranking international side."

Your football questions are answered every Wednesday. Email the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to help.

fields.headline: Regulation to increase for charities
fields.trailText: Charity leaders have been warned that they face greater regulation and legislation over the next 12 months.
fields.body:
Charity leaders have been warned that they face greater regulation and legislation over the next 12 months.

Legal expert Stephen Lloyd, of Bates Wells and Braithwaite, told delegates at Charityfair that the charity commission was set to become an "increasingly forceful legislator". The government's regulator had received a 20% increase in funding and would be increasing its investigations of charities by 25%.

"The focus will be on larger charities and allaying the public's concerns about fundraising costs," Mr Lloyd said. He predicted that the commission would continue to demand greater accountability from charities.

Reviewing key regulatory developments over the past year, Mr Lloyd pointed to a plethora of consultations and guidance issued by the charity commission, including guidance on annual returns, beneficiaries who become trustees and resolving disputes.

The consultation on whether the promotion of sport should have charitable status ends this week. This follows another consultation on whether community development can be recognised as a charitable purpose - this has now been agreed.

In what could be a major change to the regulation of charities, Mr Lloyd urged delegates to respond to a consultation initiated by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations about charities having to prove public benefit in order to maintain charitable status. If implemented by the charity commission this could have a major impact on private schools and hospitals that currently enjoy charitable status. The deadline for feedback is July 31.

Mr Lloyd acknowledged it was a tough job for trustees of charities who volunteer their time but have had to keep up with a "flood" of legislation under the Labour government. This included the Trustee Act, Freedom of Information Act and the Protection of Children Act as well as the tax changes brought in last year.

He predicted this flood would continue and that the charity commission would monitor charity accounts more closely. The government's expectations of a growth in volunteering would bring more regulation and there would be more scrutiny of fundraising practices, particularly face to face fundraising on the streets.

fields.headline: Marketing
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 26
fields.trailText: April 26: A lobby group set up by Europe's top football clubs is in talks about a brand identity project.
fields.body:
G14, the lobby group set up by Europe's top football clubs, is in talks with agencies about a brand identity project that could see the clubs attempt the formation of a European super league.

Reuters is to launch an internet cafe brand called Refresh, and is in talks with agencies about a marketing campaign.

Unilever Bestfoods has handed the international advertising account for Italian olive oil brand Bertolli to Bogle Bartle Hegarty.

ITV could call a full-scale review of its advertising as it puts the finishing touches to its plans to create a mega-brand including ONdigital, sports and children's channels and ITV.com.

Blockbuster has appointed former Mothercare marketing chief, Stephen Foulser, as its third UK marketing director in less than a year.

Trish Wadley, the marketing director of The Independent and The Independent on Sunday has resigned suddenly after just six months in the job.

Diageo has created a text-messaging service called Nightfly which brands can use to target the youth market.

Bass Brewers is planning to double its TV adspend for Carling this year and treble it next year as compensation for the end of its Premier League football sponsorship.

fields.headline: Marketing Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 26
fields.trailText: April 26: Burger King is considering a shake-up of its international marketing operations.
fields.body:
Burger King is considering a shake-up of its international marketing operations following the appointment of Chris Clouser, the global chief marketing officer and executive vice president.

Motorsport boss Murray Soanes claims his livelihood is on the line because of a bitter feud between two sponsorship agencies, Octagon and IMG.

Psion marketing director, Alasdair Seton-Marsden, has been made redundant as part of a £11m restructure which has resulted in 200 job losses at the company's London and Milton Keynes offices.

Coca-Cola has launched a major advertising campaign to promote some of its major soft drinks brands.

AKQA, a leading web agency, has laid off 36 staff at its San Francisco office.

Pret a Manger is seeking it first dedicated head of UK marketing as the sandwich and coffee shop expands overseas.

Sainsbury's, the supermarket chain, is strengthening its ties with TV chef Jamie Oliver with the launch of an extensive range of own-brand fresh herbs.

Tiny Computers has handled Coltas, the Glasgow-based advertising agency, its UK creative account worth about £40m.

The BBC has issued a tender for the £10m above-the-line and £30m below-the-line advertising business associated with the TV licence fee.

The ITV network marketing and commercial director, John Hardie, will be expanding his responsibility to take on the marketing of Ondigital.

Capital Radio has started the search for a new agency to handle its £5m advertising business.

fields.headline: A 21st century Bond
fields.standfirst: Following yesterday's news that Gerard Butler is the latest young actor 'hotly tipped' to be the next James Bond when Irish actor Pierce Brosnan hangs up his tuxedo, Emma Yates takes a closer look at some of those rumoured to be in the running for the coveted role of Britain's favourite spy
fields.trailText: With yesterday's news that Gerard Butler is the latest young actor 'hotly tipped' to be the next James Bond when Irish actor Pierce Brosnan hangs up his tuxedo, Emma Yates takes a closer look at some of those rumoured to be in the running for the coveted role of Britain's favourite spy
fields.body:
Bond writer Ian Fleming was very clear what his British secret agent creation looked like. His Bond was:"6'2" tall, 167 pounds, slim build, blue eyes, black hair, scar down right cheek, straight nose, cruel mouth, firm jawline, flecks of grey hair, and tanned." For many others, James Bond will always be Sean Connery, although there are many who will argue in favour of Brosnan's turn as the suave spy. It is seems that Brosnan's next Bond, the 20th in the franchise, is to be his last, and speculation is rife as to who will be chosen to replace him. Ranging from the sublime to the ridiculous, we survey the possible candidates.

Greg Wise
Way back in 1999, Wise, he of Sense and Sensibility and Emma Thompson's other half fame was rumoured to be the main contender. "It would be great to do it," he said at the time "The producers saw me after Timothy Dalton left, but I had these very unsexy sideburns for some period thing, which spoilt my chances."

Robbie Williams
The Robster threw his hat into the ring back in November 1999 when a 'source' close to the singer told the Sunday Times that he was willing to take extensive acting lessons and give up his music career for the chance of winning the role. However the 26-year-old's dreams will have been dashed yesterday when the casting director for the world famous series told internet radio station netfm.com "Robbie Williams, bless him - I don't think is quite what we're looking for."

Rupert Everett
Madonna's best mate and longtime LA resident Everett announced his interest in the role last year in typical style: "I want to be James Bond". He probably didn't help his chances when he criticised current Bond, Brosnan claiming, "He's a shop girl, someone you'd see in a department store. He looks like James Bond's florist. He's just not ruthless enough." Everett's well-known homosexuality would add an interesting dimension to Bond's famous womanising ways... alternatively the producers might take the opportunity to well and truly bring Bond into the 21st century.

Ioan Gruffudd
The first Welsh Bond? The 26-year-old heartthrob, best known for his role in the BBC's Hornblower, was recently mooted as a future 007, but claimed "It's all hearsay. I would love to do it, though. I'd absolutely love it - I'd be in there like a shot. "Maybe we could go back in time a bit, back to his young life, back to his SAS training." His recent turn as a drippy boy scout and friend of all dumb animals in 102 Dalmatians can not have helped his prospects.

Catherine Zeta-Jones
More Jane than James, reports earlier this year claimed that the 31-year-old actress had been screen-tested for the role and was the number one choice. Studio executives were reported to have enthused: "She is feisty, independent and beautiful. A deadly combination for a glamorous spy. Schedule permitting, she's our girl."

Russell Crowe
The highest profile of the candidates, Crowe's recent Oscar win perhaps makes him too big a star for the role. His antipodean roots could also be a problem (George Lazenby anyone?). John Glen, the man who has directed five of the Bond movies, reportedly believes that Crowe is the 'only man' who could take over the licence to kill. "I see the Bond movies going on for another 20 years and I can't think of anyone better than Russell to fill his shoes."

Colin Firth
Currently wowing cinema audiences as the mean and moody hero of Bridget Jones's Diary, Firth is reportedly 'desperate' to play 007, admitting he would jump at the chance to replace Brosnan. "I'd go for it, absolutely! I'd love the idea," he told reporters.

Cuba Gooding Jr
The first potential black Bond has got the thumbs up from Roger Moore who believes the Jerry Maguire star would be perfect for the role.

Martin Kemp
The Eastenders actor and ex Spandau Ballet member, who had his screen debut playing Reggie Cray, was rumoured earlier this year to be under consideration.

Andrew Collins, writing in the Observer in July 1999, came up with some interesting options for a 21st century Bond. "Ewan McGregor will be 31 by then - close to Bond's age in the books - and with the Scots heritage that served Connery so well, he has to be any producer's first choice... McGregor's co-star from Trainspotting, Jonny Lee Miller, does an impeccable Connery impression.

"Leonardo DiCaprio would, of course, be dreadful in the role, but we have to go through the motions (and he does satisfy the 'piece of meat' test). A far more interesting choice would be Ben Chaplin: English, good-looking and superb in an action role in The Thin Red Line. Hugh Grant is too well-established this time around, but the man who stole Notting Hill from under his nose, Rhys Ifans, would make a magnificent Welsh superspy (Remember, Timothy Dalton's from Colwyn Bay). It depends how far off-piste the Bond franchise wishes to go. Will Smith can handle gun-totin' action, wise-ass humour and bedroom duty, plus he'll sing the theme tune. Mind you, dear old Ian Fleming would spin in his colonial grave.

"Maybe after 40 years, it really is time for a change. M is already a woman (Judi Dench), so why not her top double-O agent? You must admit, Gwyneth Paltrow has the English public school accent down to a tee."

So who do you think would be the best Bond? Vote below for who you think could handle the Walther PPK with sufficient aplomb, or send us your suggestions for other actors you think should be considered.

fields.headline: Graffiti
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair has vowed to make graffiti artists clean up after themselves. Here are the best sites on the evil spray can menace
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has vowed to make graffiti artists clean up after themselves. Here are the best sites on the evil spray can menace.
fields.body:
1. Tony Blair has pledged to clean up Britain's urban streets by making graffiti artists clean up after their spray cans.

2. But not everyone agrees that graffiti - or the graff scene to those in the know - is an urban evil.

3. It all depends on your definition.

4. Graffiti isn't just a modern problem. It's been around since ancient times. But it wasn't until the 1960s that it took on its modern connotations as political statement, gang identifier and the scourge of city councils everywhere.

5. Graffiti has undergone an image change in the last few years: some of its finest practitioners have become celebrities.

6. It has had a film, a three-dimensional drawing program and even a Louis Vuitton bag named after it.

7. But is it art or vandalism?

8. There's big money at stake, whatever your view. A whole industry has been built up around its removal, but many businesses are also cashing in on graffiti's street cred.

9. But many graffiti artists prefer to stay out of the limelight, using an array of zines to compare notes on their pursuits.

10. The prime minister's latest initiative is likely to stoke the raging debate. But as long as there is a convenient train or wall, graffiti looks set to stay.

A calf which has been found alive under a pile of animal carcases five days after they were incinerated may have escaped the foot and mouth cull.

It is thought the white heifer Phoenix was not spotted by slaughtermen, who were administering lethal injections to the herd, as she was standing under her mother.

The workers destroyed all the other animals at Michaela Board's farm in Membury, East Devon.

Now Mrs Board, whose farm borders another which has the disease, is pleading with officials to allow Phoenix to remain alive.

The calf shows no signs of foot and mouth disease.

"The calf was found when groundsmen came to disinfect carcasses," Ms Board said. "She was lying next to her mum."

Mrs Board who runs the farm with her husband Philip, says the calf must have survived by living off straw that was in the barn.

The farmer has bottle fed Phoenix who is slowly recovering from the ordeal.

"She has been out playing with dogs and is feeding very well," she said.

"The vets have checked her out and will be back later in the week. I'm hopeful she is going to make it."

A Ministry of Agriculture official confirmed blood samples have been taken from the calf.

Tests take several days and if Phoenix is cleared the ministry could exempt her from the cull under "exceptional" circumstances.

fields.headline: Desmond and Hollinger shake on debt dispute
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Richard Desmond has settled his dispute with the Telegraph group over multimillion-pound debts, writes Ashley Davies.
06.04.2001: Westferry dispute hots up
05.04.2001: Desmond in crunch talks with Hollinger
23.02.2001: Desmond at loggerheads with Telegraph
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
The Express newspapers owner, Richard Desmond, has settled his dispute with the Telegraph group over multimillion-pound debts.

Northern & Shell has agreed to pay Hollinger the £3m it owes in unpaid printing bills.

In exchange, Hollinger has agreed to pay Northern & Shell an £11m Westferry dividend. A sum of £8m has already been paid and the remainder is to be handed over during the next year.

The deal follows a bitter and protracted row over printing bills and dividend payouts at the Westferry printing plant, jointly owned by Desmond's holding company, Northern & Shell, and Daily Telegraph owner Hollinger.

"The payment of these moneys represents a victory for common sense and for Northern & Shell," said a Northern & Shell spokesman.

But the dispute over the ownership of Westferry drags on. Hollinger has exercised an option to buy out Northern & Shell but neither party can agree on a price.

Desmond wants at least £70m for his share but Hollinger has refused, branding the demands excessive.

The continuing dispute over the valuation of Mr Desmond's stake will now go to arbitration.

fields.headline: Breaking the asylum deadlock
fields.standfirst:
Creative solutions are needed to escape the inertia of political debate on the asylum issue, says home affairs editor Alan Travis

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Creative solutions are needed to escape the inertia of political debate on the asylum issue, says home affairs editor Alan Travis.
fields.body:
The party political debate over asylum seekers just keeps going round and round in circles. "They are too many economic migrants abusing the asylum system. We should lock them all up. That'll deter all but the genuine refugees," say the Conservatives. "That'll be too expensive and inhumane," reply Labour. "We need to be tougher on ensuring that illegal entrants can't get into the country. Let's have more x-ray machines and sniffer dogs."

But behind the party political dogfight lies a more complicated debate. One reason why asylum has shot to the top of the political agenda in this election campaign is because the system completely broke down over the last three years. The backlog rose to more than 100,000 cases as some asylum seekers waited more than three years for a decision. They started to put local authority services in the south-east under strain. The system is now recovering: some £800m has been pumped in and thousands more immigration staff recruited and the backlog has been cut to below 50,000. The average wait has come to down to 14 months.

But if the main injustice - the long wait for an asylum decision - is being partly tackled, there are still major flaws in the system. Decisions are not fair. More than 30% of cases are being refused on non-compliance grounds because somebody failed to return their form on time. That can't be right. The voucher system is degrading and has not worked as a deterrent; it should be scrapped.

However, the main question remains how to open a legal door to Britain for economic migrants so they don't have to risk dying in the back of a lorry. Europe has an ageing population and our booming economy means we are developing serious skill shortages. It is time we adopted a kind US or Canadian "green card" system which would enable those we need to come to Britain. A lottery would probably be the fairest system. Certainly, that's the kind of creative thinking we need from our major political parties.

webTitle: Neville has fine reduced - but ban will stand

fields.headline: Neville has fine reduced - but ban will stand
fields.trailText: Manchester United's Gary Neville has had a fine of £30,000 for using foul and abusive language towards a match official reduced to £7,000 on appeal - but his two-game ban will stand.
fields.body:
Manchester United's Gary Neville has had a fine of £30,000 for using foul and abusive language towards a match official reduced to £7,000 on appeal - but his two-game ban will stand.

The Football Association's independent appeal board agreed that the £30,000 fine was too high.

Neville, who arrived at the hearing on crutches because of a knee injury, was charged with misconduct following United's FA Cup defeat at home to the Hammers on January 28.

The ban comes into effect on Monday and he will be suspended for the home match against Derby on Saturday week and the trip to Southampton on May 13.

However, Neville looked set to miss the games anyway after picking up the injury during training this week.

Neville was satisfied with the outcome of the appeal and he said: "They have reduced the fine from £30,000 to £7,000 and decided to keep the ban of two games.

"I think we're happy that we have had a fair and full hearing.

"We just wanted a fair hearing and we believe we got that and in terms of reductions I think we can say we are happy with what we have achieved."

Paul Newman, the FA's head of communications, claimed the three-man appeal board felt the £30,000 fine was too high.

Newman said: "The feeling was that the original fine was disproportionate and the panel took into consideration his good disciplinary record, not just over one season but a number of seasons.

"At the end of the day it was an offence involving offensive language towards a match official and the feeling of the panel was a two-match ban was the most appropriate penalty but that the fine was too high."

England defender Neville made his outburst at an assistant referee in the tunnel at Old Trafford at the end of United's 1-0 FA Cup defeat against West Ham at the end of January.

webTitle: England fan loses appeal on Brussels violence

fields.headline: England fan loses appeal on Brussels violence
fields.trailText: An England football fan today lost his appeal against a conviction for assaulting Brussels police during Euro 2000, but vowed to fight on and clear his name.
fields.body:
An England football fan today lost his appeal against a conviction for assaulting Brussels police during Euro 2000, but vowed to fight on and clear his name.

Mark Forrester, 34, said he had been made a scapegoat by a corrupt Belgian justice system. "I am shocked but not surprised. This should have been over today. Instead we are just entering another stage of the battle. But I am really confident I will prove my innocence in the end."

He said his lawyer is planning to take the case to the highest appeal court in Belgium - the equivalent of the House of Lords - and then on to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

Mr Forrester, an Aston Villa fan, was speaking after a Brussels appeal court judge today backed the evidence of the only witness at the original trial - a Belgian police hooligan "spotter" - and rejected video footage produced at the appeal hearing last month.

Now his hopes rest on British police video footage of the incident, film it is claimed the Belgian police knew about but refused to accept from the UK authorities.

At the original trial last June, days after rioting in central Brussels, the police "spotter" said that Mr Forrester deliberately orchestrated trouble, attacking five officers on the eve of the England-Germany match.

No defence evidence was allowed - because Mr Forrester was tried under controversial "fast track" legal procedures introduced specifically to deal with the expected backlog of riot cases during Euro 2000 .

Mr Forrester was given a one-year jail sentence, half of it suspended for three years. The trial judge said there was proof that Forrester had been "provocative and aggressive". But the video footage shown at Mr Forrester's insistence during the appeal hearing last month revealed no sign of him being a rioting ringleader. It caught him on the fringe of trouble which flared in Brussels.

After it was shown, the public prosecutor expressed doubt about the conviction and sentence, saying the case was not suitable for the "fast track" approach.

Today the appeal court judges announced that they were still upholding the sentence and conviction, describing the police evidence as "objective". They pointed out that although the video did not "one hundred per cent" prove that Mr Forrester was involved in rioting, it failed to show conclusively that he was not.

Afterwards Mr Forrester's lawyer, Jan Fermon, said the rule of law had been turned upside down and an appeal would be lodged within 15 days. The normal procedure, he said, was for the prosecution to prove guilt and not for the defence to prove innocence.

Mr Forrester said: "Anyone with any common sense could see that there is no evidence against me. The video shown in court clearly demonstrated that I was doing nothing wrong. Now we have more ammunition in the form of a British police video - which the Belgian police refused to look at - and we will use it in the next stage of the legal battle.

"It shows the entire arrest sequence that night in Brussels and it proves I did nothing. The Belgian police spotter was not just mistaken, he was lying. There is a conspiracy and I am the scapegoat."

fields.headline: Dyke awaits apology from politicians
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: The director-general wants politicians to admit he was right to move the BBC evening news to 10pm, writes Jason Deans.
20.03.2001: BBC regains ground in news war
Special report: the BBC
Special report: battle of the bulletins
fields.body:
The BBC director-general, Greg Dyke, said today he was waiting for an apology from politicians who criticised his decision to move the BBC1 evening news to 10pm.

Mr Dyke, in a speech to the Institute of Directors, said the BBC had been attacked for moving the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm too quickly.

He said six months after the move ratings for the Ten O'Clock News were up compared with those of the old 9pm bulletin.

"I'm still waiting for the politicians who criticised our decision to move the news to ring and say 'you were right, we were wrong'," he said.

Mr Dyke also admitted he thought the BBC was taking a risk by planning to launch digital channels but said it was a risk worth taking.

"There is, I believe, a real danger that publicly funded organisations err on the side of conservatism and do not take the calculated risks they ought to if they want to improve the services they deliver to the public," he said.

"They fear public and press criticism if the decision turns out to be the wrong one, whereas the reward for taking the right decision is usually silence."

The BBC's plans to spend more on BBC1 drama, sport and regional broadcasting and to launch digital channels later this year were aimed at convincing licence fee payers the BBC remained relevant in a digital world, said Mr Dyke.

"Our plans for improving our existing services and starting a limited number of new services mean spending money we are not certain we have got.

"It means assuming we will hit our overhead savings targets. By going ahead now we are undoubtedly taking a risk. It could rebound on us.

"But if the BBC is to be special in the new media age - just as it has been special for the past 70 years - then it is a risk work taking and one we will take."

fields.headline: Wanadoo results disappoint
fields.standfirst: Quiz Freeserve boss John Pluthero now
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: Wanadoo, the French owner of Freeserve, today posted lower than expected first quarter revenues, writes Amy Vickers.
Quiz Freeserve boss John Pluthero now
fields.body:
Wanadoo, the French owner of Freeserve, posted lower than expected first quarter revenues this morning.

Total revenues came in at £195.5m, of which internet access revenues accounted for £82.5m and directories £113m. No comparative first quarter figures were given.

Lower than forecast internet revenues were attributed to the longer than expected consolidation of Freeserve, which slowed growth.

Revenues from its portal business fell to £9.8m from £22.7m in the fourth quarter, owing to a slowdown in the online advertising market.

City reaction was mixed. Some analysts applauded the business, heralding Wanadoo as a strong player in the European ISP sector.

Others said it still needed time to get its house in order and flesh out its pan-European growth strategy.

Wanadoo aims to have signed up 10m subscribers in Europe by 2003 and to be one of the region's top three ISPs.

Currently, it has a subscriber base of 4.94m and pulls in more than 1.1bn page impressions per month.

Wanadoo's acquisition of Freeserve in December along with Spain's Indice Multimedia more than doubled the company's subscribers figures.

Freeserve customers accounted for 2.15m of the rise, although no separate revenue figures were reported for Freeserve.

webTitle: Halifax and Bank of Scotland discuss surprise merger

fields.headline: Halifax and Bank of Scotland discuss surprise merger
fields.trailText: Mortgage bank Halifax and the Bank of Scotland surprised the City today by announcing they have begun merger talks to create a £28bn banking giant.
fields.body:
Mortgage bank Halifax and the Bank of Scotland surprised the City today by announcing they have begun merger talks to create a £28bn banking giant.

The proposed move would produce one of Britain's biggest banks, with 57,000 staff and more than 1,000 branches.

The merged banks could benefit customers by posing a threat to the traditional domination of Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds TSB and Royal Bank of Scotland. The office of fair trading has been concerned about the "Big Four's" domination of the small business banking and current account markets.

Prior to today's announcement, the Edinburgh-based Bank of Scotland (BoS) had already failed twice in merger attempts with Abbey National and NatWest.

Shares in both companies rose around 6% today as the City appeared to welcome the proposed deal. The move is described as a "merger of equals", although Halifax would be the larger partner with 37,000 employees and a market value of around £18bn. BoS has some 20,000 staff and is valued at more than £10bn.

A merger would help the Halifax strengthen areas away from the mortgage market, while BoS would get a stronger influence outside Scotland.

Details of the proposed merger are sketchy, although the news will raise concerns about the security of thousands of banking jobs. While there is little overlap in terms of branch locations, the enlarged bank will need to decide where to have its head office.

Bill Furness, chief executive of the Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce, said: "Clearly we are concerned about what will happen to jobs, particularly in Scotland, and whether there will be an overlap between branches."

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "We will be monitoring the situation and talking to management to ensure that the workforce is not adversely affected."

News of the merger comes just weeks after Lloyds tabled a £19bn bid for Abbey National.

The office of fair trading has been concerned about the "Big Four's" domination of the small business banking and current account markets. Prior to today's announcement, the Edinburgh-based Bank of Scotland (BoS) had already failed twice in merger attempts with Abbey National and NatWest. Shares in both companies rose around 6% today as the City appeared to welcome the proposed deal. The move is described as a "merger of equals", although Halifax would be the larger partner with 37,000 employees and a market value of around £18bn. BoS has some 20,000 staff and is valued at more than £10bn. A merger would help the Halifax strengthen areas away from the mortgage market, while BoS would get a stronger influence outside Scotland. Details of the proposed merger are sketchy, although the news will raise concerns about the security of thousands of banking jobs. While there is little overlap in terms of branch locations, the enlarged bank will need to decide where to have its head office. Bill Furness, chief executive of the Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce, said: "Clearly we are concerned about what will happen to jobs, particularly in Scotland, and whether there will be an overlap between branches." John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "We will be monitoring the situation and talking to management to ensure that the workforce is not adversely affected." News of the merger comes just weeks after Lloyds tabled a £19bn bid for Abbey National. fields.headline: Tug-of-war goes nowhere
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: It was another day of stalemate for traders yesterday, with selling of hi-tech issues all but cancelled out by buying of banking stocks and shares going almost nowhere as a result.
fields.body:
It was another day of stalemate for traders yesterday, with selling of hi-tech issues all but cancelled out by buying of banking stocks and shares going almost nowhere as a result.

There was a lack of fresh stories, with Vodafone, down 6.25p to 214.75p, the only real talking point after Deutsche Bank, which has been among the company's biggest supporters, told its clients that Orange is a better short-term bet.

According to Deutsche, Orange has no exposure to the slowing US economy, unlike Vodafone, while the risks to its forecasts are lower and it has a smaller stock overhang issue.

The final scores showed the FTSE 100 index down 31 points at 5,840.3, with Vodafone, due to its huge index weighting, doing most of the damage. Turnover was an unremarkable 1.8bn shares.

After last week's run-up, the market appears to be stuck in no man's land - lacking the confidence to push higher but at the same time proving fairly resilient to the tide of poor corporate news that keeps rolling in from the other side of the Atlantic.

"We have had the rise, we have had the profit taking, the question is where do we go from here? I can see this market trading in a narrow range for the next few weeks," said one market maker.

Bleak results from US fibre-optic company JDS Uniphase and telecoms equipment maker Lucent pulled the rug from under the tech sector, with those companies in related sectors worst hit by the news.

Bookham Technology, which makes optical components, slipped 12.5p to 300p ahead of today's first-quarter figures, while telecoms testing firm Spirent dropped 19p to 400p and equipment maker Marconi shed 13.5p to 338p.

That said, software stocks were also weak. Logica was marked 64p lower at 771p, while Sage shed 21p to 260p, and CMG gave up 15p to 329p.

The FTSE Techmark 100 finished the day 34.52 points lower at 1,928.18. Other fallers included venture capital group 3i, off 72p at £12.03, as UBS Warburg lowered its rating to "hold" from "buy" on the grounds that the stock is now up with events, and Reuters down 65p to 910p, after strong first-quarter figures were overshadowed by cautious comments on prospects for the second half.

The banking sector propped the market up. Halifax added 9p to 738p after JP Morgan upgraded the stock to "buy". Despite the strong performance of the shares this year, JP Morgan thinks Halifax is undervalued by 20%.

Royal Bank of Scotland gained 9p to £16.42, and Bank of Scotland rose 4p to 742p, as HSBC Securities turned buyer ahead of next week's full-year results. HSBC analyst Michael Lever expects the figures to beat City expectations.

Telecoms group Cable & Wireless made a late surge, rising 10.5p to 490p on vague chatter of a bid approach.

Lower down, the FTSE 250 index closed 5.6 points better at 6,317, with discount retailer Matalan improving 14p to 532p after Goldman Sachs added the stock to its "recommended list" of preferred stocks.

After its profits warning earlier in the year, Goldman reckons the Matalan growth story is back on track.

Sports and advertising company Sportsworld Media finished top of the mid-cap pile, rising 35p to 337.5p, after a line of stock - about 1m shares - that had been overhanging the market was finally cleared.

In the smaller companies world, Chapelthorpe, the wall coverings and umbrella frame specialist, climbed 2.5p to 13.75p, after a seller found a home for 5m shares.

According to market gossips the buyer was a company director who might use the shares as the platform to launch a bid. Back in March, Chapelthorpe's chief executive, Brian Leckie, had a 32.5p per share offer rejected by the company's independent directors.

fields.headline: Leeds complete Keane signing
fields.trailText: Leeds have completed the £12m signing of Robbie Keane from Internazionale.
fields.body:
Leeds have completed the £12m signing of Robbie Keane from Internazionale.

The move was expected to be finalised this summer, but today Keane signed a five-year deal ahead of schedule.

Leeds spent £1m to take Keane on loan in December, and they will pay Inter the rest of the 11m fee over the next three years in instalments.

"The funds are in place and are part of a three-year deal," club chairman Peter Ridsdale told the Yorkshire Post. "The deal to make Robbie's transfer permanent has been agreed with Inter Milan.

"The money for the transfer fee of £11m has already been covered by guarantee. This means that we are not trying to sell players in the summer merely to find the money to pay for Robbie Keane, because that deal is done and, with it being a foreign transfer, we can pay the balance over a three-and-a-half year period."

fields.headline: ITV to launch sports station
fields.trailText: 1pm The new ITV Sport Channel will offer more than 150 live football matches a year, writes Jason Deans
fields.body:
The new ITV Sport Channel will offer more than 150 live football matches a year, including Champions League, Nationwide League and Worthington Cup action.

The service, which is to be under the editorial control of the ITV controller of sport, Brian Barwick, is being pitched by owners Carlton and Granada as "the first ever sports offering to break the Sky stranglehold on how Britons watch premium sport".

"We are about to enter a unique integration of free-to-air and premium sports television which will allow us to play to our maximum strengths and the viewer will be the winner," said Mr Barwick.

"The channel will be 'football rich' with live football at its very core."

ITV Sport Channel, which is effectively the rebranded sports channel ONdigital was already planning to launch, is due to launch at the start of the next football season in August.

The ONdigital director of programmes, Nick Atkins, will have day-to-day control over the channel.

ITV Sport Channel will offer live Champions League games on Tuesday and Wednesday nights on 17 weeks of the year.

The service will also carry 80 live Nationwide League matches on Thursdays and Sundays throughout the domestic UK football season between August and May.

In addition, ITV Sport Channel will televise 15 Worthington Cup ties live on weekday evenings each season.

Other sports featured on the channel will include World Championship boxing, ATP Master tennis and Champions Cup snooker.

ITV Sport Channel will have a Saturday evening Nationwide League first division highlights show, with a separate highlights programme for the second and third Divisions.

It will also carry Champions League highlights and feature-led programming.

fields.headline: Asylum applications rise by 5%
fields.trailText: The number of asylum applications in the UK rose by 5% last month, the Home Office said today.
fields.body:
The number of asylum applications in the UK rose by 5% last month, the Home Office said today.

But the figure was still 13% lower than for the same period last year. Immigration officials received 5,815 applications during March, compared with 5,520 in February.

The figures were published on the day the home secretary, Jack Straw, was carrying out two public engagements highlighting the asylum issue. Earlier today the row on race policy between Labour and the Conservatives deepened when Mr Straw said he "greatly regretted" shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe's claim that Britain was a "soft touch" for refugees.

He warned the debate on immigration should be divorced from racial overtones - while she responded by saying that she was not talking about race, but about "the inadequacy of our asylum procedures".

Today's figures showed that the number of initial decisions made by immigration officers was the highest ever at 18,895. This figure included many from the backlog of applications, which stood at nearly 50,000 in February and is now just over 36,000. Last month, 1,700 people (9% of the decisions made) were granted asylum.

There was also a record number of appeals by refugees who had been denied asylum. Nearly 11,000 appeals were submitted, and 490 of them were granted asylum by the immigration appellate authority.

Last year, there was an average of 6,335 applications a month, leading to a record number of 76,040 over the year. So far this year, there has been an average of 5,905 applications a month, which is 6% lower than for the same period in 2000.

The actual number of asylum seekers is much higher than the figures used by the Home Office, which do not include spouses, children or other dependants who arrive in the UK with the person seeking asylum.
