fields.headline: Blair accused over advertising spend
fields.standfirst: Click here to see the 10 top-spending advertisers
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: The government stands accused of 'abusing' taxpayers after spending £62.8m on advertising in three months, writes Julia Day.
Table: 10 highest spending UK advertisers

17.04.2001: Government is top UK advertiser
fields.body:
Tony Blair was today plunged into a bitter row after it emerged that the government is now spending more than Unilever and Procter & Gamble on advertising.

The prime minister was accused of "abusing" taxpayers' money by pumping millions into unnecessary campaigns on everything from benefit fraud to police recruitment.

"I'm afraid it's a common pattern of a government which is more concerned with spin than it is about delivery," said Andrew Lansley, the Conservative spokesman on cabinet office issues.

According to research consultants AC Nielsen, the government's spending on advertising has rocketed to a collossal £62.8m over the past three months.

In February alone it spent £16.5m - more than supermarket Asda spends on its products in an entire year.

The government's advertising spend rocketed to £30.2m in March - almost three times as much as Coca-Cola spends on advertising Coke in a year.

The figures mean the government is by far the country's biggest advertiser, outspending even the world's biggest advertisers, Unilever and Procter & Gamble.

The Conservative party has attacked the scale of the government's spend on advertising as an abuse of the taxpayer.

"The amount that is being spent on advertising by the government ahead of an election has risen dramatically," said Mr Lansley.

"For example, the DTI used to spend £1-2m a year. In the last financial year it went to £13m. The DSS went up to £11m from just under £3m.

"This is simply a way in which the government tries to disguise its failure to deliver."

By comparison, Unilever, whose brands include Pot Noodles, Chicken Tonight and Flora, spent £34.3m over the same period.

The money has been spent on a wide variety of public service advertising.

A £2.5m Department of Trade and Industry campaign encouraged workers to take their annual paid leave, while £3.5m was spent on a social security department campaign to tackle benefit fraud.

fields.headline: Polls in full
fields.standfirst: This week's Guardian/ICM poll reveals the public mood is turning against the Conservative party. The Guardian's home affairs editor analyses the trends.
fields.trailText: The sharp fall in William Hagues popularity amongst Tory voters - down from 60% to only 49% - revealed in this months Guardian/ICM opinion poll is a good guide to the scale of the problems facing the Tory Party leader.
fields.body:
The sharp fall in William Hagues popularity amongst Tory voters - down from 60% to only 49% - revealed in this months Guardian/ICM opinion poll is a good guide to the scale of the problems facing the Tory Party leader.

The monthly poll findings show that the Tories have failed to make any political capital out of the farming crisis and the row over race has only served to make them look like a party out of control. The more Tory voters desert Hague the more his nearest rivals for the leadership, Widdicombe and Portillo, prepare for the opportunity that post-election defeat will present them.

The weakness of Hagues current position contrasts sharply with that enjoyed by Tony Blair who, on these findings, must be regarded as the only credible party leader in the game. Labour is emerging almost completely politically unscathed from the continuing foot and mouth crisis. It still enjoys a 14 point lead over the Conservatives with a share of the vote which would translate into a Commons majority of 165 if the general election were held tomorrow. In sharp contrast to Hagues falling popularity amongst Tory voters, some 82% of Labour voters believe Tony Blair makes the best prime minister.

fields.headline: Motorola refuses to relent
fields.standfirst: Labour's plea to spare plant is rejected
fields.trailText: Motorola is to close its mobile phone factory in Bathgate in Scotland with the loss of more than 3,000 jobs, write Kirsty Scott and Jane Martinson.
fields.byline: Kirsty Scott  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Motorola confirmed yesterday that it is to close its mobile phone factory in Bathgate in Scotland with the loss of more than 3,000 jobs.

Workers at the West Lothian plant, the biggest manufacturing facility in Scotland, were told the news at company meetings yesterday morning.

The closure, which has been blamed on trading losses and overcapacity in the mobile handset market, will be phased over four to six months and comes despite high-profile political intervention. The company last night agreed to pay back some £17m in grants it had received in recent years.

On the same day, JDS Uniphase, the manufacturer of fibre-optic equipment, said it would cut 5,000 jobs, 20% of its workforce, to cut costs because of falling demand.

Lucent, the telecom equipment manufacturer, announced a second-quarter loss of $3.7bn yesterday after spending $2.7bn on restructuring charges and suffering a sharp slowdown in demand.

Tony Blair, who had spoken to Motorola management in an effort to save the plant, said the news was a "bitter blow".

Foreign secretary Robin Cook said Motorola had created a "human tragedy" and he was bitterly disappointed that the firm did not listen to the case for keeping Bathgate open.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, promised "direct and immediate" government support to find jobs for those affected.

Ministers at Westminster and Holyrood had hoped to persuade the company to retain the Bathgate facility after last month's announcement that 7,000 jobs would be cut from the global workforce. However, a decision was taken at the weekend to retain the company's plant in Flensburg, Germany, and close Bathgate.

Danny Carrigan, Scottish regional secretary of the AEEU engineering union, said: "Motorola has given the workforce and the community a kick in the teeth. The whole Bathgate community depends on that plant and the area will now be destroyed. We've worked hard to prevent this decision but Motorola has pulled the rug from under our feet."

Motorola said it had come to the decision after long and complex deliberations. "As you would expect, Motorola is committed to providing a full range of support services to its employees throughout the coming weeks as it continues to discuss the proposal with the elected employee consultation forum."

The shadow trade and industry secretary, David Heathcote-Amory, said: "High-profile political intervention has come to nothing and has failed to save a single job. The job losses at Motorola come on top of 350,000 already lost during a period of manufacturing decline since the last general election. The government has persistently ignored the problems of the manufacturing industry and has piled on extra regulations and taxes."

The Scottish enterprise minister, Wendy Alexander, said she had instructed officials to recover £16.75m in regional assistance paid to the Bathgate plant over the past six years.

Jozef Straus, chief executive of Canada's JDS Uniphase, said the outlook was too murky to predict an upturn later this year. Yesterday's restructuring "reflects the current situation in the market."

Other companies to issue poor results yesterday included Agere Systems, the semiconductor business recently spun off from Lucent, and AT&T, Lucent's largest customer.

webTitle: No 10 demands cash back as Motorola sacks 3,000

fields.headline: No 10 demands cash back as Motorola sacks 3,000
fields.trailText: The government last night demanded Motorola repay the bulk of £20m worth of state aid after its decision to close its plant at Bathgate in Scotland, write Michael White, Larry Elliott and Mark Milner.
fields.byline: Michael White, Larry Elliott  and Mark Milner
fields.body:
The government last night demanded Motorola repay the bulk of £20m worth of state aid after the US mobile phone giant said it is to close its plant at Bathgate in Scotland with the loss of more than 3,000 jobs.

Opposition parties seized on the latest blow to Britain's manufacturing base to launch a pre-election strike against Labour's handling of the economy, on the day when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, proclaimed Britain's new found strength to ride out global economic turbulence.

Motorola's decision, blamed on disappointing demand for mobile phones worldwide, was described by Tony Blair as a "bitter blow". A spokesman for the prime minister said the company would be required to repay £16.5m of regional selective assistance.

The closure announcement was a personal setback for Mr Blair, Mr Brown and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who had intervened in an attempt to keep the plant open.

Their failure to change Motorola's mind was criticised by the shadow trade secretary, David Heathcoat-Amory, who said: "High profile political intervention has come to nothing and failed to save a single job.

"Having undermined manufacturing competitiveness for four years, the government is in no position to launch last-ditch survival initiatives. The losses at Motorola are further testament to its failed economic policy."

MPs were angry at the lack of a government statement, though Tam Dalyell, in whose Linlithgow constituency the Bathgate plant lies, warned against alienating the US owners. "Motorola is still the biggest private employeer in Scotland. They are not a fly-by-night company," he said.

The move comes at a dangerous time for Labour in its Scottish heartlands, weeks before a probable general election where core voters may not need much persuasion to stay at home or register protest votes with the Scottish National party, which denounced the closure last night.

The Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, said: "Britain is losing jobs, investment and world market share yet the government remains complacent about the exchange rate.

"The chancellor continues to ignore the overvaluation of the pound and the resulting problems facing British farmers, manufacturers and the tourism industry."

With the International Monetary Fund set this week to forecast only a modest slowdown in the UK economy this year, Mr Brown was cautiously optimistic about the outlook, adding: "We are on course to deliver stability and sustained growth."

On Motorola he admitted it was "an extremely difficult time for individuals and communities when jobs are lost as industries restructure in the face of change. It is even more frustrating when these losses arise because of global managerial decisions based on financial problems in one sector despite the high productivity performance of the British employees".

Mr Brown, underlining the reasons for his keenness to fight the election as soon as possible, acknowledged the global economic environment was "more challenging". He added: "We know that in today's world of instantaneous global markets, instability anywhere has repercussions everywhere."

However his Tory predecessor, Kenneth Clarke, accused him of underplaying the dangers. "Now a marked worldwide slowdown is going on and Gordon has at last noticed that the economic cycle has not been abolished, and I think he is being very complacent about the outlook," he told BBC Radio.

The Swiss business school, IMD, yesterday demoted the UK to the second rank of countries in its annual world competitiveness league table. Based on economic data and surveys of executives, the survey ranked the UK at number 19, behind the likes of Taiwan, Belgium, Israel and Iceland. The US, which is on the brink of recession, was ranked the most competitive country.

fields.headline: Scots defend higher public spending
fields.trailText: Senior politicians north of the border yesterday defended higher public spending in key areas as pressure grew for a review of the Whitehall formula which gives Scotland more money than the English regions.
fields.body:
Senior politicians north of the border yesterday defended higher public spending in key areas as pressure grew for a review of the Whitehall formula which gives Scotland more money than the English regions.

With the government facing a backlash against suggestions from John Prescott and other ministers that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland could lose their favoured status after the election, the Scottish National Party - the main opposition in the Edinburgh parliament - said spending was higher for a variety of reasons outside the area of the formula.

It called for the parliament to be given new powers to raise money and take its own spending decisions outside the Whitehall financial straitjacket. At present, the Edinburgh parliament can only "vary" tax by up to 3p in the pound on the basic rate of income tax, raising at most around £700m, or 3%of the total budget.

Andrew Wilson, Scotland's shadow finance minister, said services such as education were often better because council tax levels were higher in Scotland, thus providing more cash for schools. Scotland was also committed to higher spending in other areas, such as water distribution, because - unlike England and Wales - it had chosen not to privatise some essential services and consequently needed more money from the public purse. Public spending per head in Scotland remains 23% above the English average, while Northern Ireland and Wales are 39% and 18% above respectively.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Prescott signalled that a forthcoming review of local government finance will include a detailed examination of funding throughout the UK. He said that the formula, devised by Lord (Joel) Barnett when he was Treasury chief secretary in the 1970s was certainly not "written in stone".

Yesterday a spokesman for the prime minister sought to play down the suggestion that the Barnett formula was to be revised radically. "Our spending plans have been agreed for the years until 2004 and that includes plans for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland." Mr Prescott's Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions said there were no plans "at present" to review the formula.

webTitle: What does Labour plan for a second term?

fields.headline: What does Labour plan for a second term?
fields.trailText: Health secretary Alan Milburn is today unveiling Labour's second-term plans for health.
fields.body:
Health secretary Alan Milburn is today unveiling Labour's second-term plans for health.

For a preview of the speech, which is expected to pledge a massive cutback in NHS bureaucracy and a switch of resources to frontline staff, log on to:

http://www.societytheguardian.com

And watch out for updates throughout the day

Also making headlines today:

Housing: Owning cheaper than social rents

Owner occupation is cheaper than renting "affordable" homes from housing associations across much of the country, according to unpublished research.

For the full story, as well as analysis on where it's cheaper to buy and why homes are left empty, log on to:

http://www.societytheguardian.com/housing

Health: GPs' threat to go private 'would cost NHS £5bn'

At least an extra £5bn of public and private money would have to be spent to maintain current primary care services if family doctors resigned en masse from the NHS in protest against excessive workloads, leading health analysts have claimed.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/NHSstaff

Regional government: Scots defend high public spending

Senior politicians north of the border have defended higher public spending in key areas.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/regionalgovernment

Health: Publicity for 'top' hospitals backfires

The latest attempt to publicise NHS performance has backfired after the promoters of a "40 top hospitals" list refused to name the poor-performing hospitals who failed to make the grade.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health

Local government: Last orders on modernisation consultation

The government wants to modernise councils and the public must get involved. But how aware is the public on the changes and does it even care? Mori's Colin Wilby investigates.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/modlocalgov

Plus:

Don't forget tomorrow's online chat with housing minister Nick Raynsford. Post your own question or find out what our other talkers are asking:

http://talk.societytheguardian.com/WebX?13@@.ee81dbe/0

In the practice section, find out how collaboration between a charity and a London borough is bringing a range of child care services to more than 600 families a week:

http://www.societytheguardian.com/practice

Catch up with all the news and features from this week's Society Guardian supplement at:

http://www.societytheguardian.com/societyguardian/

webTitle: Joined-up working creates a family one-stop shop

fields.headline: Joined-up working creates a family one-stop shop
fields.standfirst: Collaboration between a charity and a London borough is bringing a range of child care services to more than 600 families a week. David Mitchell reports
fields.trailText: Collaboration between a charity and a London borough is bringing a range of child care services to more than 600 families a week. David Mitchell reports.
fields.body:
An innovative "one-stop shop" that caters for children and families in one of the most deprived areas of London could be the shape of things to come, according to a new report.

The Coram Community Campus combines two nurseries, a parents centre, a special needs charity for disabled children, two homelessness projects and a school for children with autism. Services are provided by Camden's education department, social services department and the local community health trust.

Situated in a leafy three-and-a-half acre site on the edge of the bustling King's Cross area, it has been operating since 1998 and provides a range of services to more than 600 families a week.

The idea is the brainchild of the child care charity Coram Family, formerly the Thomas Coram Foundation, that owns the site. While multi-agency working is not new, the campus attempts to bring mainstream statutory and voluntary agency services more closely together in an integrated network.

A two-year study funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation has found that although most families tended to use only one provider, many were able to gain access to several services or activities through that provider.

"Over time, the movement between services was increasing as staff gained confidence in making referrals and families themselves became more aware of what was on offer. Whatever their take-up, users were extremely positive about the quality of services. They valued the support and felt services had made a real difference in their lives," it says.

The partnership with local authority services produced mixed results. But the most outstanding success was the setting up of a well-established child psychology service on the site, where parents could get help with serious problems or seek reassurance about their children's development.

The researchers recognise that creating a multi-agency network is in itself a significant achievement, and there is a commitment and belief that it can be achieved, but it is not quite there yet.

"It has yet to reach its full potential in terms of becoming more than the sum of its parts. Services are beginning to learn from each other, to share skills and to enjoy a cross-fertilisation of ideas, but the process needs time to develop further," they conclude.

"However, the general concept of services working in collaboration, linked by a common value base, with some kind of overall coordination, is one which might be reworked more widely to fit different situations, drawing on particular aspects of the campus multi-agency network model."

Dr Gillian Pugh, chief executive of Coram Family, said that while projects appreciate the need to offer more joined-up services, there is always a degree of suspicion they might be losing their individual patches.

"But as people get to know each other better, collaboration and joint working gets better, and the fact that we are all operating on the same site means there are more opportunities for meeting, discussing referrals and providing support for one another," she said.

"Being part of the same exciting place rubs off. The front door may be the nursery, but it is actually the parents who could do with support by providing access to classes or training, or advising them on which groups to join.

"It is definitely a model for the future. It has always been our intention to develop other potential partnerships in other areas and we are now in the planning stages with three other local authorities to see whether we can provide consultancy and support to set up similar schemes."

Teresa Smith, head of social policy and social work at Oxford University, and an adviser to the project, said the campus was an up to date version of an idea that went back a long way, with various experiments over the past century.

"The degree of commitment and the size of the enterprise is new. It is also exciting in the way that it brings together high quality education with day care and a range of other services for parents with more specialist needs," she said.

Dr Valerie Wigfall, research officer at London University's Institute of Education and co-author of the study, said that when they first arrived individual projects were apprehensive that the campus's "grand ideas" were not in their interests.

"Now that fear and anxiety has gone and they are beginning to see that it can work and it is not a threat to them. A balance has been struck between staying independent and working together," she said.

"There is huge potential here. When you get people together on a site like this, it is such an inspiring sort of place when people can learn what their true potential is. It is the way of the future and it is a very exciting one."

webTitle: Ulster infiltration unit remains under wraps

fields.headline: Ulster infiltration unit remains under wraps
fields.standfirst:
What role did the FRU play in infiltrating Northern Irish terrorism? The government seems keen to muffle the truth, writes John O'Farrell

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: What role did the FRU play in infiltrating Northern Irish terrorism? The government seems keen to muffle the truth, writes John O'Farrell.
fields.body:
At tea time yesterday, solicitors representing Geoff Hoon, the Secretary of State for Defence, succeeded in getting Justice Kerr of the high court of Belfast to impose an injunction preventing Ulster Television from broadcasting a documentary about a British army agent who infiltrated the IRA.

As the crown's counsel was pitching his "national security" defence to the Judge, UTV's evening news was broadcasting a "teaser", detailing some of the allegations made in the programme. Readers of the late edition of the Belfast Telegraph had already seen the headline: "Agent who infiltrated Provos admits involvement in killings."

The story is a dramatic one. According to the Belfast Telegraph, the ex-Royal Irish Rangers soldier, "named only as Kevin", claimed he earned the trust of the IRA after four years of armed robberies, before graduating to making bombs which killed fellow British soldiers and RUC officers in the late 80s and early 90s.

"How can I be a terrorist and not be a terrorist?", he asks. "I had to be an IRA man, not just pretend to be one; I had to be one." What makes his allegations explosive is his claim that he tipped off his military intelligence handlers of impending bombs which were then not stopped, such as the massive explosion which ripped the heart out of Portadown in 1993.

Unsurprisingly, unionist politicans interviewed for the programme are livid. The DUP are calling for an independent inquiry into the allegations and UUP MP Jeffrey Donaldson is quoted in the Belfast Telegraph as saying: "People will want to know - were innocent lives lost because people in the military intelligence failed to act on information that was available to them, that might have prevented murder?"

Those quotes and charges did not go out on air after the 10 o'clock ITN news. Nor did any opinions from any of the programme makers on UTV Insight, the station's weekly currrent affairs slot, which instead broadcast a documentary about surgical concerns inside the local NHS.

The injunction so restrained UTV staff that the station was limited to issuing a terse statement asserting that "UTV will contest this order and we intend to show the programme at the earliest possible date."

The high court order restrains UTV from issuing "any information which identifies any former member, any former informant or any former agent of the Forces Research Unit (thereafter 'The Unit')."UTV are also barred from broadcasting or discussing "any information about the methods of operation, operational techniques or tradecraft of The Unit."

There are two interesting points about that section of Justice Kerr's judgement. Firstly, it is possibly the first admission that the FRU actually existed. It used to operate in a similar limbo to MI6, which did not officially exist until the late 80s. Second, the FRU are not mentioned in the programme, not once.

The existence of the FRU, whose initials were long familiar to Northern Irish ears, was so blurred that guessing the meaning of the three letters was a parlour game among the local political/security complex. Did the "R" stand for "reconnisance? And what was it up to anyway?

The FRU emerged in the mid 80s after a succession of attempts by the British army to contain the IRA through infiltration and observation. The Unit supplanted the efforts of the SAS and the undercover section of the British army, the 14th intelligence unit, recently given the Peter Taylor treatment in a BBC series shown last year.

The FRU were different. They avoided the absurd theatrics of the 14th, such as teaching English squaddies Belfast accents and sending them into west Belfast as commercial salesmen or, in one famous case, setting up a door-to-door laundry service. They also avoided the gung-ho machismo of the SAS or the preferred method of the RUC special branch, recruiting informers from local petty criminals and paying them the biblically loaded fee of £30 per name.

The FRU wanted people inside the paramilitaries, and it is those people who are talking. The first to "out" the existence of the FRU was Brian Nelson, an ex-serviceman persuaded by the FRU to join the UDA. Nelson was from an impeccable Ulster protestant background and his military experience was valued by the loyalist organisation. By the late 80s, Nelson was the intelligence officer for the UDA's Shankill brigade. It is claimed that Nelson was getting "accurate" information about provos which improved the "targetting" of the UDA's hit squads, previously happy to stiff any "fenian".

Among the names given by Nelson for the UDA's attention was the nationalist solicitor Pat Finucane, shot dead in front of his family in February 1989. Afterwards, Nelson claimed he warned his handlers that Finucane was in danger and that nothing was done to prevent the assassination.

Republicans read that story in reverse. They see people like Nelson as proof that the FRU treated loyalist paramilitaries as state-sanctioned death squads, by passing state information to killers. The UDA were, republicans repeatedly assert, violent proxies for the British government who were unable or unwilling to let the courts and the justice system deal justice to provos, or those accused of giving quarter to them.

A full public inquiry into the Finucane murder and the role of the intelligence services was a core demand of both Sinn Fein and the SDLP during the recent wrangling with the government over whether nationalists would accept the new police service for Northern Ireland.

The foremost failure of the FRU lay in its obsessive secrecy. It did not cooperate with any of the other branches of the security system and therefore was not aware that the quartermaster of Nelson's UDA brigade was working for RUC special branch.

Nor did Nelson know that when he provided information about a leading IRA figure in west Belfast, that the latter too was in the pay of the FRU. When Nelson told his handlers about the intended "targetting" of the IRA man, he was urgently ordered to find another target.

"Steak Knife" was too valuable to the FRU to be allowed die, and so, a completely innocent catholic, Francisco Noterantonio, was shot dead by UDA killers, believing that this 66-year-old retired taxi-driver was a big-time provo.

In recent months, gagging orders have been served on the Sunday Times, Sunday Herald and Sunday People, who fought a long court battle before publishing the "Steak Knife" revelations.

Today, UTV will start a similar battle in the Belfast courts. Even then, in the event of showing even an amended programme, they may face the part of last evening's injunction which compels them to "facilitate a viewing for the secretary of state." And if Geoff Hoon does not like way he sees, then we may not see it either. Which will facilitate more allegations about the FRU and its "tradecraft". Or is there really something to hide?

 John O'Farrell is a correspondent for the Guardian and the Observer and is managing editor of Fortnight magazine.

The high court order restrains UTV from issuing "any information which identifies any former member, any former informant or any former agent of the Forces Research Unit (thereafter 'The Unit')."UTV are also barred from broadcasting or discussing "any information about the methods of operation, operational techniques or tradecraft of The Unit." There are two interesting points about that section of Justice Kerr's judgement. Firstly, it is possibly the first admission that the FRU actually existed. It used to operate in a similar limbo to MI6, which did not officially exist until the late 80s. Second, the FRU are not mentioned in the programme, not once. The existence of the FRU, whose initials were long familiar to Northern Irish ears, was so blurred that guessing the meaning of the three letters was a parlour game among the local political/security complex. Did the "R" stand for "reconnisance? And what was it up to anyway? The FRU emerged in the mid 80s after a succession of attempts by the British army to contain the IRA through infiltration and observation. The Unit supplanted the efforts of the SAS and the undercover section of the British army, the 14th intelligence unit, recently given the Peter Taylor treatment in a BBC series shown last year. The FRU were different. They avoided the absurd theatrics of the 14th, such as teaching English squaddies Belfast accents and sending them into west Belfast as commercial salesmen or, in one famous case, setting up a door-to-door laundry service. They also avoided the gung-ho machismo of the SAS or the preferred method of the RUC special branch, recruiting informers from local petty criminals and paying them the biblically loaded fee of £30 per name. The FRU wanted people inside the paramilitaries, and it is those people who are talking. The first to "out" the existence of the FRU was Brian Nelson, an ex-serviceman persuaded by the FRU to join the UDA. Nelson was from an impeccable Ulster protestant background and his military experience was valued by the loyalist organisation. By the late 80s, Nelson was the intelligence officer for the UDA's Shankill brigade. It is claimed that Nelson was getting "accurate" information about provos which improved the "targetting" of the UDA's hit squads, previously happy to stiff any "fenian". Among the names given by Nelson for the UDA's attention was the nationalist solicitor Pat Finucane, shot dead in front of his family in February 1989. Afterwards, Nelson claimed he warned his handlers that Finucane was in danger and that nothing was done to prevent the assassination. Republicans read that story in reverse. They see people like Nelson as proof that the FRU treated loyalist paramilitaries as state-sanctioned death squads, by passing state information to killers. The UDA were, republicans repeatedly assert, violent proxies for the British government who were unable or unwilling to let the courts and the justice system deal justice to provos, or those accused of giving quarter to them. A full public inquiry into the Finucane murder and the role of the intelligence services was a core demand of both Sinn Fein and the SDLP during the recent wrangling with the government over whether nationalists would accept the new police service for Northern Ireland. The foremost failure of the FRU lay in its obsessive secrecy. It did not cooperate with any of the other branches of the security system and therefore was not aware that the quartermaster of Nelson's UDA brigade was working for RUC special branch. Nor did Nelson know that when he provided information about a leading IRA figure in west Belfast, that the latter too was in the pay of the FRU. When Nelson told his handlers about the intended "targetting" of the IRA man, he was urgently ordered to find another target. "Steak Knife" was too valuable to the FRU to be allowed die, and so, a completely innocent catholic, Francisco Noterantonio, was shot dead by UDA killers, believing that this 66-year-old retired taxi-driver was a big-time provo. In recent months, gagging orders have been served on the Sunday Times, Sunday Herald and Sunday People, who fought a long court battle before publishing the "Steak Knife" revelations. Today, UTV will start a similar battle in the Belfast courts. Even then, in the event of showing even an amended programme, they may face the part of last evening's injunction which compels them to "facilitate a viewing for the secretary of state." And if Geoff Hoon does not like way he sees, then we may not see it either. Which will facilitate more allegations about the FRU and its "tradecraft". Or is there really something to hide?  John O'Farrell is a correspondent for the Guardian and the Observer and is managing editor of Fortnight magazine. fields.headline: MoD blocks TV show on IRA double agent
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland

Background: who are the FRU?
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence last night stopped Ulster TV showing a controversial documentary about a double agent, writes Rosie Cowan.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence last night stopped Ulster Television showing a documentary in which an ex-soldier claims his military chiefs knew he helped murder members of the security forces while working as a double agent in the IRA.

The MoD obtained a high court order banning the Insight investigation into covert military intelligence operations in Northern Ireland just four hours before it was due to be broadcast. UTV refused to comment on the injunction or the programme, but Rob Morrison, head of news and current affairs, said the channel would contest the ban and remained intent on screening the documentary as soon as possible.

UTV has been prevented from disclosing details about the methods of military intelligence. It is understood the programme features an interview with a former Royal Irish Ranger, named only as Kevin, who alleges his British handlers were aware that he took part in terrorist bombings in the 1980s and early 1990s, including the 1993 blast which decimated Portadown centre.

Kevin says: "I had to be an IRA man, not just pretend to be one. Yes, certain lives were lost. I know a lot of lives were saved, that's all I can say."

He claims he had to commit armed robberies for four years before the Provisionals accepted him. He says he worked as a double agent until the second IRA ceasefire in 1997 when the republican paramilitaries discovered he was an informer and he received death threats.

He says he has been interviewed by the team, headed by Metropolitan police chief Sir John Stevens, which is investigating allegations of collusion between the security forces and loyalist paramilitaries.

An MoD spokesman said: "An order was made but because we understand UTV will be contesting it we cannot comment."

fields.headline: Estrada held on corruption charges
fields.trailText: The toppled Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, was today arrested on corruption charges which allegedly involved procuring himself almost £60m.
fields.body:
The toppled Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, was today arrested on corruption charges which allegedly involved procuring himself almost £60m.

After weeks of legal wrangling and a last-minute flurry of moves aimed at keeping him out of jail, Mr Estrada was escorted from his home in Manila's opulent Greenhills district.

The scene seemed on the verge of erupting into violence as a tense standoff developed between thousands of his backers and riot police. Vowing to block his arrest or go to jail with him, the crowd pelted police with stones.

To clear a path along the narrow streets to his house, riot police used truncheons and plastic shields to disperse angry Estrada supporters as a police helicopter hovered low overhead.

"We will not even allow him to surrender. We are ready to die for him," said Jojo Ibay, a 38-year-old supporter who had been outside Mr Estrada's house for three days.

Hundreds more Estrada supporters rallied outside the anti-graft court grounds near demonstrations organised by his opponents. Some wore T-shirts marked "Pro-God, Pro-Constitution," a reference to Estrada's claim that his ouster was unconstitutional.

But under the brutal midday sun, police were forced to climb over the fence of the Estrada to unlock the gate so they could deliver the warrant.

The former action film star was then driven about two miles to Camp Crame, the main police camp, where a special cell has been prepared for him.

Hours earlier, the chief anti-graft court, the Sandiganbayan, ordered Mr Estrada's arrest for the non-bailable offence of plunder. The most serious charge in an eight-count indictment carries the death penalty, although it is considered highly unlikely to be imposed if Mr Estrada is tried and convicted

Mr Estrada continued to defiantly maintain his innocence and insist he never gave up the presidency. He is the first Philippine leader to be arrested on corruption charges.

After the arrest, Mr Estrada's lawyer, Raymond Fortun, said he had asked for at least three hours' notice of a warrant to give the former president time to take a bath, pack his clothes and say goodbye to loved ones.

Mr Estrada, who left the presidential palace on January 20 amid mass street protests demanding he resign over alleged corruption, claimed he is confident he will beat the case against him and berated the government for harassing him and his family.

"I will face and answer all the charges against me. I believe that in the end truth will triumph and that our constitution will prevail," Mr Estrada said in a taped message broadcast by DZRH radio.

He also reiterated his claim that he left the palace only to avoid bloodshed and was technically on leave.

"I stand firm that the assumption to power of the new administration is against the constitution," he said.

On April 4, he was indicted for allegedly pocketing £57m in kickbacks and payoffs during 31 months in office.

His indictment came after the supreme court unanimously rejected his appeals of a ruling that stripped away his presidential immunity.

fields.headline: Thatcher caught in the spotlight
fields.standfirst: The Californian blackout crisis has been traced all the way back to our very own Margaret Thatcher, reports Duncan Campbell.
fields.trailText: The Californian blackout crisis has been traced all the way back to our very own Margaret Thatcher, reports Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
Baroness Thatcher does not register on the radar in the United States very often these days and when she does it is usually as a speaker at one of those business seminars where the once-powerful deliver a few homilies and pick up a fat cheque; much like 60s rock bands playing their greatest hits in holiday camps.

But now she has surfaced in a spectacular way: accused of being responsible for the energy crisis in California that has blacked out the state, bankrupted a utility company and sent the price of electricity rocketing. Leading Democrats in the state are now suggesting that the Baroness should carry some of the blame for the calamity.

Earlier this month Pacific Gas & Electric, California's largest utility, filed for bankruptcy with its debts approaching $9bn [£6.2bn]. It had been announced the previous day that 34 days of blackouts should be expected in California this summer. Electricity consumers have been told that their bills will be rising by up to 46%. The series of disasters are seen as the result of the state's adoption of a deregulated electricity system. So where does Baroness Thatcher fit in?

The story goes back to 1994 when the then governor of California, Republican Pete Wilson, gave the task of thinking about deregulation to a contracts law professor called Daniel Fessler, who was appointed head of the public utilities commission (PUC). Fessler, then attached to the University of California, Davis, was a committed free marketeer. Like Wilson, who had aspirations to the presidency at the time, he was an admirer of Baroness Thatcher and her economic policies.

In 1994, a trip to London was organised by a conservative business organisation called California Council for Environmental and Economic Balance. On the trip were senior executives from Edison, Pacific Gas & Electric and the PUC, which oversees energy in the state. Also attending were senior political figures The party were put up in a hotel in Mayfair and a round of meetings was arranged for them including a chance to meet "ranking Thatcherites". The junket went unreported in the California press.

"The usually aloof Fessler was especially taken with his meeting with Stephen Littlechild [then head of the office of electricity regulation]," according to Bill Bradley, a leading California politcial analyst who has published a report on the genesis of the state's power crisis in the LA Weekly. On his return from the trip, Fessler proceeded energetically with the plans for deregulation. In a Republican-controlled state assembly the electricity industry in the state was deregulated in 1996.

Bill Bradley ascribes California's decision to the effect of the London trip and to the admiration Pete Wilson and Daniel Fessler felt for Baroness Thatcher: "Lady Thatcher was venerated by conservative free marketeers... after all, she broke the back of the labour unions in Britain. She also privatised and deregulated Britain's electric power market."

"That trip led to California adopting Maggie Thatcher's 'mad cow' deregulation theory," said Bob Mulholland, the campaign adviser to California's Democratic party yesterday. Mulholland has now written to a leading Republican politician on the trip, asking for details of the hospitality received and whether the party met Baroness Thatcher. Mulholland accuses those who returned from the London trip of uncritically adopting Baroness Thatcher's policies.

Contacted in San Francisco where he now works for a large law firm, Mr Fessler said that Baroness Thatcher had "done interesting and innovative things to deal with the economy in the United Kingdom". He added that while he admired Baroness Thatcher, he also admired Winston Churchill and Tony Blair and said that the deregulation model had come as much from Chile as the UK.

But it is reassuring to think that with so much being imported from the US to the UK there is some traffic in the other direction - even if it comes in the form of rolling blackouts.

fields.headline: An audience with Mandela
fields.standfirst: If it's not pop stars or supermodels, it's defeated heavyweight champs. There is no telling who will turn up next at Nelson Mandela's door, says  Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: If it's not pop stars or supermodels, it's defeated heavyweight champs. There is no telling who will turn up next at Nelson Mandela's door, says Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
Lennox Lewis lost the fight but still got the prize yearned for by those of note who travel to South Africa - a pilgrimage to Nelson Mandela's door.

Plenty have been there before: Castro and Clinton, Michael Jackson and the Spice Girls, Princess Diana and her husband (although not together). But an audience with Mandela is as individual as it appears to be spiritual for those who long to meet the great man.

Mandela, an amateur boxer in his youth, told Lewis he had studied Sunday morning's fight and where he had gone wrong. By the end, Lewis's morose expression gave way to a grin. The old Madiba magic worked again.

Mandela sees it as part of his duty to his country to reward those who bring their sporting prowess, musical talents or political influence to South Africa. But he is quietly flattered at the awe in which these lesser gods clearly hold him. And he is particularly fond of the more shapely visitors.

Political giants cross his doorstep, but never quite measure up. Fidel Castro and Muammar Gadafy are more popular in South Africa as backers of the liberation movement than in most other countries. But when Castro met Mandela, the gulf between two contemporary revolutionaries against the legacy of imperialism was glaring.

Mandela took Clinton to his old Robben Island prison cell. The American president's renowned verbal skills almost deserted him.

An endless stream of entertainers consider themselves deserving of an audience. The Spice Girls were a big hit in 1997. The group was in South Africa at the behest of Prince Charles for a concert in aid of a charity founded by Mandela.

As the prince stood gormlessly on the sidelines, one of the Girls, Geri "Ginger" Spice, announced to the world's greatest living icon: "You're as young as the girl you feel - and I'm 25."

Mandela had not failed to notice. He barely conceals his delight in the company of the likes Naomi Campbell, although he usually reserves the more personal comments for private discussions.

And he endures the most crass misconceptions. Mel B drew parallels between "girl power" and the struggle against apartheid.

"Some people found that a little, er, not arrogant, but it's all relative. Everyone has their fight for freedom and this is our little quest," she said later. Mandela knew how to put the Spice Girls in their place.

"They are my heroes," he told reporters. "I don't want to be emotional, but this is one of the greatest moments of my life."

Mel C showed due respect by "nicking some of Nelson's bog-roll for a souvenir".

At least the Spice Girls gave the octogenarian statesman a laugh. Michael Jackson arrived unannounced on Mandela's birthday - disrupting a family celebration - and threatened to involve himself in the great man's charity for children. Mandela's renowned grace in dealing with less conventional people was clearly tested by Jacko.

Some visitors lose their perspective. Morgan Freeman, who played Mandela in a film about his trial, said that having met the great man he now understood the awe felt by ordinary people in encountering actors such as himself.

Whoopi Goldberg won Mandela's respect for her sensitivity to the complexity of South Africa's problems. Spike Lee failed to understand the essence of Madiba's message and refused to be interviewed by white reporters after meeting the man.

But possibly the most bizarre encounter of all was with the BBC's Ground Force crew. South Africans never really understood why a television station flew a bunch of gardeners half way across the globe to do up a patch of barren, rocky ground in a Transkei village. They concluded the whole charade was further evidence of the peculiar effect Madiba has on foreigners.

"It will be completely out of his mind that someone from England would fly over and spend many days and hours doing this," said Alan Titchmarsh, one of Ground Force's co-presenters. That much was true.

Mandela studied his garden and then turned to Ground Force's famously buxom other presenter, Charlie Dimmock, and told her that she looked like a Spice Girl.

fields.headline: Prices edging out of reach
fields.standfirst: Advice bank: homebuyers' timetable
fields.trailText: Many young, first-time buyers in the south of England are being priced out of the residential property market, as Carla Moore reports.
fields.body:
Many young, first-time buyers in the south of England are being priced out of the residential property market.

Despite the fact the Bank of England's base rate is now at a low of 5.5%, first-time buyers are being forced to look further afield when it comes to investing in their dream home.

National Association of Estate Agents (NAEA) chief executive Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy urges those wanting to take the plunge into home ownership to "lower their sights".

"First-time buyers chasing higher prices in the south of England and any other busy regions must be prepared to be flexible on their requirements," Mr Dunsmore-Hardy says.

"They must be prepared to look at cheaper areas - even if it means travelling a bit further and settling for something that may be a bit further down on the rungs of the ladder. To move up, you sometimes have to move on," he says.

Mr Dunsmore-Hardy says first-time buyers should be careful not to over-extend themselves and borrow more than they can repay.

"Rather than getting in over your head, I would advise those wanting to invest, for the first time, in the property market, to perhaps look at properties that may require a bit of work on them. In this way, there may be better opportunities for investment," Mr Dunsmore-Hardy says.

"I would also suggest people look at their repayments rationally, as many people do not factor in things such as new furniture, credit card bills and shopping," he says.

Mr Dunsmore-Hardy adds that he expects the current burst of activity to slow down and stabilise soon.

"We have seen, periodically, evidence of prices rationalising in some of the more popular areas and this comes down to basic questions of affordability. People's pockets are only so deep and we are not anticipating that we are going to see increases running as high as they were last year or the year before," Mr Dunsmore-Hardy says.

"We will soon see prices more restrained and although we might get periods of prices edging forward, that will be coupled with the traditional buying season of spring. Prices, year on year, are only rising at 7 to 8%, which we believe is fairly contained. But certainly, it's natural that prices will edge forwards especially in the most sought after areas," he says.

In its Residential Property Review for the first quarter of 2001, the Portman Building Society points to the south of England as being one of the country's main housing hot spots.

The review states that the residential property market in this region is seeing prices edging upwards, fuelling a shortage of available property in the area. But it also explains that a significant number of house hunters are looking for properties to buy before marketing their own houses, adding to the problem of demand exceeding supply.

Group communications manager John Gully acknowledges that the latest interest rate reduction might serve to motivate first-time buyers to take the plunge but he, too, warns against "getting too excited".

"The danger is that while rates are low, people might bask in the fact that they have a disposable income. But if, for whatever reason, we had a return of rates of interest of up to 8 or 9 %, then, for some people, the difference in mortgage payments could be such that they will find themselves in difficulty," Mr Gully says.

The Portman property review reflects the state of the busy market with geographical examples. It includes a round-up of:

 London and Southeast - where a one-bedroom house in Royston, Hertfordshire, is selling for about £120,000;
 Southern England - where a two-bedroom semi in Bournemouth is selling for about £111,000 and older semis sell for about £102,500;
 Southwest England - where a semi detached house in Plympton, near Plymouth, is now being sold for just over £90,000 (Before Christmas they were fetching about £77,000);
 The Thames Valley - where, with the "rampant inflation" buyers will be lucky to find anything under £100,000;

 The Midlands - where a 1940s semi-detached in need of refurbishment is selling for about £72,000.

Given the significant number of house hunters looking for properties in Southern England, Mr Gully advises first home buyers to consider the lure of the West country.

But he also says the real problem for first homebuyers is, primarily, whether or not they have sufficient income to service the borrowing they are looking for, and not whether they are able to buy their dream home in Bournemouth.

He says while it's rare for 100% mortgages to be available, borrowers still have to find at least five to 10% minimum as deposit.

"Typically, if a first home buyer was looking to buy at £100,000 and they had a 5% deposit, they'd be looking at a mortgage of £95,000 which means they need an income of £30,000. When you do the figures and equate the required income, you realise that many first homebuyers are in their early 20s, and the equation starts to break down. There are really not many 20-year-olds earning that amount of money or who could support the repayments," Mr Gully says.

Mr Gully says that although lenders are keen for first-time buyers' business, he believes they also have a responsibility to the borrowers. He adds that the number of customers who fail to meet their repayments is miniscule.

"As far as Portman is concerned, we have somewhere in the region of 90,000 borrowers and we currently have somewhere in the region of just 24 properties that are in possession because they haven't been able to sustain payments. As for the arrears scenario, we have less than one per cent of mortgage balances in arrears," he says.

"We, like many lenders, learnt a salutory lesson in the collapse of the early 90s when people over-extended themselves and then the levels of interest went back to being famously high [at 13 or 14%]. Lenders have a duty to be responsible to their borrowers. We would rather lose the borrower by refusing to give them five times' their income. Why? Because it wouldn't be good for us and it wouldn't be good for them," he says.

As for predicting trends in the property market this year, Mr Gully says while he, too, sees the situation stabilising, he is constantly surprised at what people are actually prepared to pay.

'I live in Bournemouth and each weekend we get a free property supplement and I browse through it and each week have a sharp intake of breath when I look at these properties and see what they are asking and see what they are getting.

"Vendors are definitely testing the values a little bit by putting them on at fairly high prices I just don't know how long that can last," he says.

If you are buying your first home, the good news is that lenders are desperate to woo you, certain that once they offer you a mortgage you will remain a faithful customer.

But the bad news is that buying your first home can be even more expensive than first anticipated. According to HSBC, a third of new home owners don't budget enough money when buying their first home.

With Halifax, those with a minimum income of £100,000 can borrow 4.25 times their income as long as they also get a good credit score.

Woolwich lends up to four times income and Abbey National up to 4.2 times, but taking credit scoring into account.

webTitle: Blair 'to replace Maff with new department'

fields.headline: Blair 'to replace Maff with new department'
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, is planning to replace the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) with a new department of rural affairs to fundamentally reform farming, according to newspaper reports today.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, is planning to replace the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) with a new department of rural affairs to fundamentally reform farming, according to newspaper reports today.

Maff has been criticised over its handling of the crisis and for promoting a system of intensive farming that many blame for the disease's rapid spread.

A reform of the European Union's common agricultural policy, which may be possible with Germany's support for environmentally friendly farming methods, would also remove the subsidies that Maff administers based on the number of animals in a farmer's herd.

The environmentally sensitive alternative places greater emphasis on farmers' role as managers of the land. The Prince of Wales, who is currently visiting Canada, wrote yesterday in the country's Globe and Mail newspaper that repeated farming crises may be a "consequence of the belief by some that, somehow, the quality of our sustenance can in some way be divorced from the well-being of our natural surroundings.

"For as long as we care about our sense of identity and spiritual well-being, I believe we have to ensure that the farmer, who has always brought meat and drink to our table, is able to continue his duty as provider and, equally importantly, as custodian of the countryside," he argued.

Tourism ministers from England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland are today meeting in Glasgow to discuss the economic fallout from the crisis in their industry.

Top of the agenda is expected to be calls for the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to give extra resources to hotel and catering firms.

webTitle: Vaccine policy risks lives, claim Tories

fields.headline: Vaccine policy risks lives, claim Tories
fields.trailText: The Conservatives launched a stinging attack on the government yesterday, accusing it of endangering the lives of young children by refusing to fund single doses of measles vaccination.
fields.body:
The Conservatives launched a stinging attack on the government yesterday, accusing it of endangering the lives of young children by refusing to fund single doses of measles vaccination.

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said that children would die and would be left disabled because of the government's insistence that children must have the combined MMR vaccination for measles, mumps and rubella.

Inoculation rates have fallen sharply in recent months because of parental fears that the MMR vaccine could be linked to bowel disease and autism in certain susceptible children. Some parents have resorted to taking their children to France for a single dose measles vaccine.

Dr Fox, a former GP, said yesterday that a Tory government would fund single dose vaccines to increase the inoculation rate. "We will be less doctrinaire and more pragmatic," he said. "Otherwise children are going to die and are going to be disabled. That is not an acceptable price for an absolutist political position. If inoculation rates continue to fall, as they have been, we would have to see whether we should make single dose vaccines available in certain areas to certain groups to get inncolulation rates up," the shadow health secretary said.

"A single dose vaccine is not as good as the MMR - it therefore only has a place where you have no alternative to raise inoculation rates. What we cannot do is say that irrespective of inoculation rates we will not re-evaluate the policy."

Dr Fox's intervention, which was condemned by the government last night as "irresponsible", comes in the wake of a dramatic fall in the MMR inoculation rates. Vaccination rates have dropped to 75% in some areas - notably parts of London - which is well below the 95% rate recommended by the World Health Organisation to stave off outbreaks.

The Department of Health launched a £3m campaign earlier this year to persuade parents that the MMR vaccination is the safest way of protecting their children. The MMR jab is given to babies at 18 months and is followed by a pre-school booster.

The controversy resurfaced in January when Andrew Wakefield, a consultant gastroenterologist who raised questions about the MMR jab in 1998, questioned the clinical trials which assessed the safety of the vaccine before it was introduced in Britain in 1988.

Dr Wakefield's concerns have been dismissed by the government as "bad science".

The government last night reacted furiously to Dr Fox's intervention. A Department of Health source said that doctors were free to provide single dose vaccines, although resources are directed towards funding the MMR jab.

"It is a great shame that Liam Fox has decided to turn what is a difficult decision for many parents into a party political football," the source said. "The key thing is that MMR is the safest vaccine."

Dr Fox also rounded on the government for failing to tackle the threat posed by HIV. He warned that the government's "failure" to give priority to HIV would place Britain "smack bang on course for a large epidemic. HIV should be given more priority than telling people to eat vegetables", he said.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 65: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 65: The crisis appears on the front pages with reports on the human victims and the plight of Phoenix the calf.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
Daily Express
The paper splashes on the fact that the disease we were told never spreads to people has now claimed three human victims. Does the government have any idea how to end this horror, the paper asks. The Mirror
The Mirror also gives front page coverage to the "foot and mouth hell" story of Paul Stamper, the first of three men suspected of contracting the disease. "I was picking up a carcass from a farm and it exploded into my face," he told the Mirror. "Some of the juices went into my mouth and I swallowed them." The Times
The paper also runs a foot and mouth lead story. It reports Tony Blair has decided to replace Maff with a department of rural affairs, headed by a senior cabinet minister with a brief to reform farming fundamentally. The Daily Telegraph
The paper carries a front page picture story about Phoenix, a healthy young calf found alive after it had lain beneath its dead mother for six days at a farm in Devon. But a Maff spokesman says: "Phoenix has to die."

webTitle: PCC backs complaint against Sunday Mirror

fields.headline: PCC backs complaint against Sunday Mirror
fields.trailText: 11.30am: The PCC has upheld a complaint against the Sunday Mirror for publishing the address of Elton John's former wife. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Press Complaints Commission has upheld a complaint against the Sunday Mirror for publishing the address of the former wife of Elton John, Renate Blauel.

But the PCC rejected complaints from Ms Blauel that the article, headlined "Sad, lonely life of the woman who loved and lost Elton John", represented an invasion of her privacy, harassment and misrepresentation.

The article, published in June 2000, compared Ms Blauel's current lifestyle with her experiences with her former husband, and was accompanied by photographs of Ms Blauel in a petrol station forecourt.

The commission rejected complaints that Ms Blauel had "a reasonable expectation of privacy" in the petrol forecourt.

It failed to find evidence of harrassment by Sunday Mirror journalists and ruled that while the complainant may have been insulted by the tone of the article, this was a matter of "editorial comment".

The adjudication stated: "It is not the commission's job either to restrict this right or to afford individuals a veto over future publicity."

It noted that the article had not published any details that could be considered to concern Ms Blauel's private life.

fields.headline: ONdigital trims subscriber forecasts
fields.trailText:
11.30am: ONdigital has cut its subscriber projections from 2m by early 2003 to 1.7m in 2003-4, writes Jason Deans.
24.04.2001: Government boosts digital signal

02.04.2001: ONdigital set for rebranding

17.01.2001: ONdigital passes magic million mark
fields.body:
ONdigital, the Carlton/Granada pay-TV operation that is to be rebranded ITV Digital, has cut its subscriber projections from 2m by early 2003 to 1.7m in 2003-4.

In January Stuart Prebble, the ONdigital chief executive named today as ITV chief executive, said the pay-TV business would break even at 2m subscribers "around the end of 2002 or the beginning of 2003".

Now Carlton and Granada are saying ITV Digital is working towards "planned break-even in 2003-4 with 1.7m subscribers".

"ITV Digital's strategy is to improve customer loyalty, increase revenue per subscriber and reduce acquisition costs," the two companies said.

fields.headline: Wednesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours drive the ball so far they're ruining golf
fields.trailText: No doubt what the most surprising rumour of the day is. According to Planet Football, "speculation is rife that Dick Advocaat will quit Rangers in the summer and George Graham will take charge". The website even claims that Rangers chairman David Murray has already held talks with the former Arsenal, Leeds and Spurs boss.
fields.body:
No doubt what the most surprising rumour of the day is. According to Planet Football, "speculation is rife that Dick Advocaat will quit Rangers in the summer and George Graham will take charge". The website even claims that Rangers chairman David Murray has already held talks with the former Arsenal, Leeds and Spurs boss.

Juventus will offer Arsenal £13m and David Trezeguet for Patrick Vieira, according to the Star. The paper reckons that with the "Dutch schemer Edgar Davids failing a drugs test", Juve are more desperate than ever to sign Vieira.

Barcelona are so keen to sign Arsene Wenger as their new manager they are prepared to wait a year for him, reports the Express. Apparently, Barca will appoint a caretaker-manager until June 2002 - the date Wenger's contract with Arsenal runs out.

Meanwhile, the Sun reports that Arsenal are hoping to bring back Emmanuel Petit to Highbury, possibly in a swap deal for Kanu. However, the paper admits that "the Gunners may be reluctant to part with Kanu", which could allow Spurs to "hijack" the Petit deal and buy the French international themselves.

Speaking of returning footballers, the Sun reckons that John Gregory wants Dwight Yorke back at Aston Villa. Gregory is prepared is offer £10m for the United striker - and could finance the deal by selling Dion Dublin, Julian Joachim and David Ginola.

Gianluca Vialli is not about to be unveiled as Watford's new manager. According to Vialli's agent Athole Still: "Gianluca only came back from holiday on Sunday evening and, as far as I am concerned, he has not been in talks with any clubs. If he was in talks with anyone I know that I would have been involved in some way and I haven't spoken to anybody as yet."

Mark Viduka will not be going to AC Milan in a £20m deal, according to Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale. He said: "This is Mark's first season with us, he's still got another four years on his contract and as far as I'm aware he's happy at Leeds."

Manchester United eat your heart out. Real Madrid are planning to spend big again this summer with Andrei Shevchenko, Lilian Thuram and Zinedine Zidane all on the club's shopping list. Planet Football speculates that Shevchenko is Real's top target - and that Milan could be offered Guti and Michel Salgado in part-exchange. Meanwhile, Claude Makelele could form part of a player plus cash deal for Zidane, and Thuram could also be heading to the Bernabeu if Madrid stump up the £26m fee being demanded by Parma.

webTitle: The Guardian consumer champions round-up of the year

fields.headline: Annas Oscars
fields.standfirst: The Guardian consumer champions round-up of the year
fields.trailText: The Guardian consumer champions round-up of the year.
fields.body:
And so a third glorious year has passed since we volunteered to listen to the lamentations that drive your friends away. No one is more intimate than we with the mischievousness of your zip drives, the difficulty of disposing of those green shield stamps and the damage to your Christmas turkeys membrane. We have investigated the high cost of dying in Sunderland and transatlantic gold bullion fraud. We have squared up to the might of ntl and stooped to deal with double-glazing lowlife.

The postbag shows that you are a millennial crowd struggling to master digital wizardry and the highways of cyberspace. This year nearly as many of you have burnt your fingers through cybershopping as through mail order, and for the first time your rage against mobile phone providers almost equals your loathing of the landline giants. That other life-enhancing innovation, the computer, lurks in second place after telecoms, as your favourite dinner party rant and Time Computers has the honour of a mention in half of that correspondence.

As usual, it is not the idiosyncratic quality of your gadgets that inflames you so much as the lost hours of exposure to Peer Gynt on the end of a helpline, the vanished call-out engineers and the promised return calls that never return.

There are some intriguing changes from last year: airlines that lose your luggage, sell off your seat and de-schedule your flight route have now eclipsed your previous bogeymen, the utilities companies. Of those, the breathtakingly blithe Ryanair is your least loved, notching up a quarter of such complaints for crimes such as a refusal to accept responsibility for damage to luggage with wheels or handles (ie most suitcases).

Internet service providers and their inability to provide internet service scored exactly the same tally, largely thanks to the efforts of ntl which accounted for three quarters of the total, and those unmetered access pioneers who were, in their words, swamped by their own success.

The surprise is that the antics of the train operating companies bother you so little, despite the fact that some have charged you up to five times more (by withdrawing discounted tickets) for journeys that took five times longer during the post-Hatfield crisis. Presumably experience has taught you that tantrums will not make a jot of difference to their contempt for you.

May we take this opportunity to congratulate Virgin Trains which, with its serene disregard for customer care, caused half our rail moans and secured a position as fourth most-complained about company this last year.

Finally, for the second year running we should make a special mention of Dixons and Ikea whose efforts dont yet merit a prize, but thats not for want of trying.

What, one might ask, is their magic? Each time you go back for more and each time run sobbingly into our consoling arms. Weep not, we are always there for you, fearless in our pursuit of righteousness and tireless in trumpeting our triumphs.

The prizes will remind you how you need us, for your worst nightmares are likely to come true once you venture down the high street.

The awards

One you most love to hate

To British Gas: you did your best, as usual, but for the second time you have been outshone. Last year, the winner was Cable and Wireless Communications. Is it a sinister coincidence that this year it is ntl, which has since taken over our old enemy? Its much-vaunted free internet disc seemed too good to be true  and it was. Some of you were still waiting for it six months after the delivery date and many who saw sight of it couldnt get it to work. Descriptions of the hours spent on its helpless helplines accounted for nearly 10% of our entire post bag.

Most prolific newcomer

The spotlight falls on EasyRentacar, which confounded its rivals with its extraordinarily low prices. Before long, its hidden income became apparent. So many customers had £100 for unexplained damage removed from their account after returning their cars that the office of fair trading launched an investigation. Interestingly, the company returned the money to all the customers who complained to Consumer.

Biggest climb down

Last year, Virgin Holidays won  this time it is Virgin Trains. Consumer contacted the company after a readers train fare was increased by 520% because of "heavy demand by business travellers" on a half-empty service. The day after our fax, Virgin decided the demand was not so heavy after all and restored the old fare. Five weeks later the cost had crept back up. Virgin, when cornered, muttered about "heavy demand by business travellers", who must have all read the Guardian and rushed to take advantage of a hitherto neglected ticket.

Canniest business strategy

A new prize, to pay tribute to Connex. One reader was dumped at Victoria, miles beyond her destination, after her train missed out her stop. Connex explained that late-running services may make up for lost time (and therefore, presumably, save face in the companys performance record) by running non-stop to the terminus. Words of comfort at least from the rail passenger council, which promised we wouldnt be charged a penalty fee for overshooting our destination in such cases.

Most blase opt-out

Lets hear it for that toothy tiger Oftel, ever valiant in its regulation of telecoms companies. "Licences are not dependent on standards of services because competition is the best regulator," it told us last June when asked about a poor-quality provider. "Its not for us to try to run companies, although we might have an informal word with them."

Tardiest service

Achieved by an Essex firm, Bryco Glaze, which had still not fulfilled a double-glazing order 13 months later. When our reader tried to cancel, the company threatened to hold on to his deposit. Nor was it chastened when it replied (10 weeks later) to Consumers overtures. The customer, it said, was being unreasonable in not giving it more time to chase vital parts.

Most effective vanishing act

Jointly won by the international removals company Cargo Forwarding, which disappeared leaving scores of customers belongings stranded across the globe, and First Point International, which claimed to procure visas for would-be emigrants to the US. Cargo Forwarding had once before gone into liquidation, losing some customers their possessions, and is presently launching a third incarnation, CFI Movers. First Point, whose activities left scores of customers out of pocket, is now reinvented as Visaplus and, according to trading standards, there are still no guarantees that customers will get the visa they are paying several thousand pounds for.

Most constructive excuse

Step forward those familiar faces at Time Computers who collected a readers faulty computer then lost it. He discovered that its finance company could not cancel its credit agreement until it had heard from Time and Time refused to get in touch until it had examined the computer. Which it had lost.

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

webTitle: Charity Awards 2001 - you've got to be in it to win it

fields.headline: Take the challenge
fields.standfirst: Charity Awards 2001 - you've got to be in it to win it
fields.trailText: Charity Awards 2001 - you've got to be in it to win it
fields.body:
Every week, some 20 new charities are registered in Britain. It's the same story, month in, month out: good ideas dreamed up by altruistic people are born as fledgling good causes.

Sadly, some perish quickly; others grow for a while, then give up their independent existence and link with another charity doing similar work.

Many of the newer, smaller charities are still doing well after 20 or 30 years because they have accurately targeted their user groups - and donors. But the ones doing best of all owe their vigour to their novel approach. They were conceived as innovative projects - and now their ideas are being adopted for use by other causes and communities.

It's this accent on innovation which the judges of this year's Guardian charity awards will be on the lookout for - along with, of course, a stand-out contribution a charity makes to the social welfare of the community in which works.

Five winners will each receive a cheque for £5,000 from Sainsbury's - the Guardian's new partner in this, the ninth year of the awards. The prestige and publicity which the five receive is a bonus that brings the charities a higher national profile and grants from other sources.

That's a point made by Alan Hatton-Yeo, director of one of last year's winners, the Beth Johnson Foundation, whose thoughtful idea has been to get old people to mentor schoolchildren in classrooms. Publicity about the award led to a cheque from the lottery charities board for £188,000 enabling the Stoke-on-Trent-based charity to study how this concept could be more widely applied.

And even if our awards don't generate cheques, they are an important booster for unsung employees of any organisation.

Benita Refson, director of Place 2 Be, providing emotional and therapeutic support for children in schools in the south-east, says that the award helped to get them better known; and its funders had the satisfaction of seeing a cause they had been supporting get national recognition.

"We were very excited by [the award]. It had a terrific effect on the morale of the organisation."

The batch of prize winners last time round showed the resourcefulness of voluntary organisations. There was the Shape Ticket Scheme, which allows disabled and older people get to arts venues through cheap tickets and user-friendly venues.

Another was simplicity itself - the Phoenix Community Scheme in Newtown, Powys, which runs a warehouse of discarded and donated furniture and household items for needy families in mid-Wales.

Will this year's entrants come up with even better schemes? They may well do so. And some of the 1,000 or more runners from previous years may be trying their luck again.

Charities that have been registered for at least two years are eligible. They should have an income of between £5,000 and £1m, and must submit the last set of financial accounts, together with a statement (500 words maximum) saying why it should get an award.

The closing date for entries is Friday, June 29. The winners, who will be honoured at a reception in London on Friday, October 12, will be chosen by a panel chaired by Simon Armson, chief executive of the Samaritans; along with Naomi Eisenstadt, chief executive of Sure Start; Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council; Jan Shawe, director of corporate relations at Sainsbury's; and David Brindle, editor of Guardian Society.

For an entry form tel: 020-7713 4961. Copies may also be downloaded from the Guardian Society website.
