fields.headline: Edinburgh TV festival launches fast-track scheme
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: The Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival has kicked off the search for applicants for its TV25 fast-track scheme, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
The Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival has kicked off the search for applicants for its TV25 fast-track scheme.

TV25 offers 22 to 29-year-olds a series of masterclasses, executive breakfasts, career direction, programme-making skills classes and access to the festival.

Applicants need to have been working in television for between two and four years. They can be working in a wide range of broadcasting roles, including researchers, producers, directors, writers, marketeers and new media creators.

Now in its seventh year, TV25 is well-known as a forum for making contacts. Being granted one of the 25 places is considered a prestigious entry on your CV.

"This is the a chance for the industry to meet the Greg Dykes and Dawn Aireys of tomorrow," said a spokeswoman.

"They get to pitch to controllers - something that is virtually impossible for people starting out."

Previous masterclasses have been given by the BBC director-general, Greg Dyke, and the Channel 5 chief executive, Dawn Airey.

The person giving this year's masterclass has yet to be confirmed. TV25 is being produced by Anne Mensah, a producer at the BBC Fiction Lab.

Click here to apply for a place on TV25

fields.headline: ITV centralises web operations
fields.trailText:
11am: ITV has unveiled its most ambitious internet strategy to date by pooling its companies' internet resources. By Amy Vickers.
29.01.2001: Granada and Carlton bury hatchet over ITV website
03.04.2001: Granada wins custody of ITV.com
fields.body:
ITV has unveiled its most ambitious internet strategy to date by creating a single home for the ITV companies to pool their internet resources.

ITV.com, when it launches at the end of the year, will bring together existing Carlton and Granada websites such as Coronationstreet.co.uk, Emmerdale.co.uk and Crossroadshotel.co.uk, as well as the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? game which has recently been launched on ITV.co.uk.

The planned portal will also feature celebrity chats, audio and video streaming, text messaging services, chat rooms, consumer polls and the ubiquitous listings information.

The network wants to build ITV.com into one of the UK's top 10 entertainment sites and claims it is already well on the way to achieving this, after having notched up more than 45m page impressions since launching the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? internet game three weeks ago.

ITV.com will sit under the control of the new ITV boss, Stuart Prebble, although it is unclear at this stage who will effectively run the pooled internet operation.

Granada Media and Carlton Communications, the two largest ITV companies, have until now pursued their own separate internet strategies.

While Carlton focused on developing a number of strong web brands - Jamba, Popcorn and SimplyFood and now Carlton.com - Granada went cold on internet brand G-wizz almost immediately after it was launched, finally shutting the site down at the end of March.

Since then, Granada has established Granada Broadband to develop programme-related websites.

However, both parties have been talking about creating a single, focused ITV website for some time.

The idea for ITV.com was first discussed by the Carlton Communications chairman, Michael Green, in June last year despite not owning the domain name at that time.

Mr Green admitted the ITV companies were lagging behind the BBC in the online arena.

ITV managed to gain custody of the ITV.com domain name for £100,000 from an executive who had registered the name in 1994.

ITV.com, when it launches at the end of the year, will bring together existing Carlton and Granada websites such as Coronationstreet.co.uk, Emmerdale.co.uk and Crossroadshotel.co.uk, as well as the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? game which has recently been launched on ITV.co.uk. The planned portal will also feature celebrity chats, audio and video streaming, text messaging services, chat rooms, consumer polls and the ubiquitous listings information. The network wants to build ITV.com into one of the UK's top 10 entertainment sites and claims it is already well on the way to achieving this, after having notched up more than 45m page impressions since launching the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? internet game three weeks ago. ITV.com will sit under the control of the new ITV boss, Stuart Prebble, although it is unclear at this stage who will effectively run the pooled internet operation. Granada Media and Carlton Communications, the two largest ITV companies, have until now pursued their own separate internet strategies. While Carlton focused on developing a number of strong web brands - Jamba, Popcorn and SimplyFood and now Carlton.com - Granada went cold on internet brand G-wizz almost immediately after it was launched, finally shutting the site down at the end of March. Since then, Granada has established Granada Broadband to develop programme-related websites. However, both parties have been talking about creating a single, focused ITV website for some time. The idea for ITV.com was first discussed by the Carlton Communications chairman, Michael Green, in June last year despite not owning the domain name at that time. Mr Green admitted the ITV companies were lagging behind the BBC in the online arena. ITV managed to gain custody of the ITV.com domain name for £100,000 from an executive who had registered the name in 1994. webTitle: Isle of Man cancels TT races in foot and mouth fear

fields.headline: Disease risk sees off TT races
fields.standfirst:
Isle of Man suffers tourism blow as sporting event is called off

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A top international motor sport event was cancelled yesterday due to fears over foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
A top international motor sport event was cancelled yesterday due to fears over foot and mouth disease.

The Isle of Man TT races, due to take place from May 26 to June 8, have in the past attracted up to 40,000 motorbike enthusiasts and are worth between £5m and £7m to the island's economy. But this is more than counterbalanced by the threat to that economy if there were an outbreak of foot and mouth. All its 250,000 animals would have to be slaughtered, which would cost £50m.

Geoff le Page, director of tourism, said the decision to cancel had been a difficult one because tourism and agriculture were interlinked.

A programme of extra precautions was put forward by the Department of Trade and Tourism, but the council of ministers decided that the races would constitute a significant risk to animal health and the agricultural industry.

Although the island is still welcoming tourists, the TT races were a particular threat because of the number of spectators on farmland and lanes.

"The big debate has been to look at what precautions can be put in place," said Mr Le Page. "Other avenues have been explored, such as putting grandstands up. But it is a 37.5 mile race and most of it is run on farmland."

It was considered impractical to restrict spectator movements, and disinfecting the thousands of motorists who might have travelled from infected areas was too big a task.

The Tynwald chief minister, Donald Gelling, said: "We hope people will understand that the alternative was to take an extra risk, against advice, of introducing a terrible disease which could devastate the Manx countryside and cause long-term damage to tourism as well as to agriculture.

"Our priority must now be to help this important sector at this difficult time and to ask the fans to look forward to a special TT festival in 2002."

The loss of business to the island will have to be addressed. The Treasury and Department of Tourism and Leisure are looking at ways of easing hardship and cash flow difficulties.

fields.headline: Getting away with murder
fields.standfirst:
The War Crimes Act has produced a pathetic single conviction

Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: Why, after a decade of effort since the passage of the War Crimes Act and the millions expended on investigations and legal preparation, have there been only two prosecutions and just one conviction in England and none in Scotland?
fields.body:
In a report on the prosecution of Nazi war criminals around the world, the Simon Wiesenthal Centre has accused England of "minimal success" and classified Scotland as guilty of "insufficient and/or unsuccessful effort". The report singled out the lack of Scottish action against Anton Gecas, accused of complicity in war crimes in Lithuania and Belarus in 1941-2. Overall, Britain was ranked alongside Argentina and Croatia.

Yet Lord Janner, secretary of the All-Party Parliamentary War Crimes Group, dismissed the centre's league table of success as "ludicrous". He said that any assessment had to heed the commitment to seek prosecutions, not just the results, and take into account "the circumstances". So why, after a decade of effort since the passage of the War Crimes Act and the millions expended on investigations and legal preparation, have there been only two prosecutions and just one conviction in England and none in Scotland?

Despite overwhelming evidence that Britain harbours Nazi collaborators, a significant section of political and legal opinion has stubbornly opposed bringing them to justice. In June 1992 and again in November 1994, peers led by Lord Campbell of Alloway passed legislation designed to nullify the act, even though it had been passed by substantial majorities. This legislation perished in the Commons, but it sent a message to law officers that their influential senior colleagues reviled war crimes prosecutions.

Hostile scrutiny obliged the police war crimes units in Scotland and England to be ultra cautious. The cases were complex enough and required enormous diligence, but the units wasted valuable time reviewing the research of the government's own inquiry published in July 1989. The police were undoubtedly committed but they made some terrible blunders. The Met unit squandered 18 months attempting to trace Szymon Serafinowicz, a collaborationist police chief who was the first suspect to be arrested, because his name was misspelled on their lists - even though the correct version was in the phone book. They repeated the same mistake with Anton Sawoniuk, accused of committing atrocities in 1942-3.

The Scottish unit failed to interview any of a dozen men living in England who had served with Gecas. Since they risked self-incrimination it was essential to give the men immunity, but the Met refused to exempt them from prosecution claiming that it had them in its sights. Without a guarantee the men would never tell what they knew and the Scottish investigation bypassed them. But the Met never acted against any of the former collaborators and it later transpired that there was no intention to do so.

Although the War Crimes Act was intended to apply to anyone suspected of "grave violations of the laws and customs of war committed in German held territory during the second world war", in practice it was modified to restrict its scope dramatically. At a press conference in March 1999, following the conviction of Sawoniuk, a spokesman for the Met explained the criteria for the prosecution. In addition to safe identification and solid eye-witnesses, "proof that the defendant was in a position of command, responsibility [was] also an important factor in deciding on the defendant's culpability". Sawoniuk met this standard, but others who were equally as guilty of mass murder did not. The exclusion of those who were not officers indicates that a decision was quietly made by law officers, presumably in concert with the Home Office, to ignore so-called "small fry" no matter how bloody their hands. There is also a persistent suspicion that some of the suspects were shielded because of their prior contribution to military intelligence based on their knowledge of eastern Europe. Gecas almost certainly had links with MI6 after he came to this country.

Since 1993, several suspects have been named against whom no action has been taken beyond preliminary investigations. In some cases it was decided that a prosecution was unlikely to succeed for lack or reliable and credible evidence. This is frustrating, but understandable and laudable in a country which values safe justice. But by requiring prosecutions for murder, rather than denaturalisation and deportation, the War Crimes Act set an almost impossibly high threshold of evidence.

Jack Straw's hesitant response to the discovery of Konrad Kalejs, a Latvian war crimes suspect, in an old people's home in December 1999 underlined fears that lack of evidence was not unrelated to absence of political will. Until there is a full inquiry into why Clement Attlee's postwar Labour government allowed so many Nazi collaborators to enter and reside in the UK with impunity, there will be a nagging feeling that old Labour let them in and New Labour let them off.

 Justice Delayed: How Britain Became a Refuge For Nazi War Criminals, by David Cesarani, is published by Phoenix Press.

fields.headline: Ends and means tests
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: A prime minister who talks about "ending the something for nothing society" cannot expect to recapture welfare's popularity
fields.body:
Is there no justice in politics? A new government moves in and recognises that as well as those in poverty - whose numbers had increased threefold under its predecessors - other people need help too. All families with children had lost out compared to childless couples. Similarly, pensioners just above the poverty line needed help as well as the 2m below. Under Labour's new strategy, 14% more families and 20% more pensioners will get it.

The response last week when researchers in the Commons library tabulated these achievements must have been disheartening for ministers seeking to make welfare more popular.

"More families draw welfare" (Telegraph). "Means testing surge on cards" (Express). "The welfare explosion" (Mail). Michael Portillo, who helped the Tory party push up means-tested benefits from 16% of all social security in 1979 to 34% in 1998, discovered a sudden antipathy to income-related benefits. He scornfully condemned the Labour strategy as "welfare creep - a steady increase in the number of people caught in social security".

According to Labour, means-tested benefits as a proportion of social security spending have actually declined. But this is smoke and mirrors. It does not include Labour's tax credit schemes funded by the inland revenue rather than social security.

It is tax credits which have meant that 38% of all households by 2003, compared with 24% in 1999, will be supported by income-related benefits. Support for pensioners will rise even more dramatically - from 37% to 57% in the same period. A person from Mars might have expected widespread approval of this move. But this ignores a deeply ingrained hostility to means tests in the UK.

What Labour has done is strategically right. By targeting its resources it has been able to make dramatic improvements: 2m poor pensioners £800 a year better off; recently retired couples £1,400 ahead; poor families £3,000 better off. Spread to all, these benefits would shrink to a fraction.

Where ministers have failed is in selling their reforms. This is partly because of their own negative messages. A prime minister who talks about "ending the something for nothing society" cannot expect to recapture welfare's popularity. Worse still, incremental reform has produced a highly complex system. Labour has moved social security towards an Australian model - with one major difference: special benefits for a middle band. In Australia, the poor and middle band enjoy the same generous benefits. They are affordable because they are withdrawn from the better-off. That is the right end of the income scale to apply means tests.

fields.headline: Presidency of dunces
fields.standfirst:
One hundred days in office and what does George Bush have to show for it? It is a sorry record for America

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: One hundred days in office and what does George Bush have to show for it? It is a sorry record for America.
fields.body:
Is this real life or is it cruel satire? The scene is the Oval Office. The time is early April 2001. The United States and China are locked in a stand-off with 24 American aircrew held captive, their spy plane downed. Behind the desk is President George W Bush, grilling his aides on this complex diplomatic confrontation. Just as John F Kennedy interrogated his advisers during the Cuban missile crisis, so it falls to Bush to put the single question that might get to the heart of this superpower showdown.

So what does Bush ask? "Do the members of the crew have Bibles? Why don't they have Bibles? Can we get them Bibles? Would they like Bibles?" Then the president remembers a strategic factor even more crucial. "Are they getting any exercise?" Do the captive US personnel have access to exercise equipment? Is there a Stairmaster on Hainan Island?

OK, maybe the last bit is an embellishment but the rest is George W Bush in his own words, helpfully provided by the White House as proof of his deep engagement in the China crisis. You and I may think this transcript has the reverse effect - confirming the satirists' caricature of Bush as a know-nothing, fundamentalist fitness freak - but the Bushies released it to prove how presidential their man has become. "He's very curious, and so he asked a lot of questions," gushed an irony-proof Karen Hughes, Bush's press secretary.

There'll be more boasting this week as Bush the Younger heads towards his 100th day in office on Sunday. Ever since Franklin D Roosevelt used his first 100 days to rush through the New Deal, this Napoleonic marker has been the occasion for an interim report on the new president. So what should we make of the new man - and is there a lesson there for us?

Yes, he has proved as verbally challenged as we expected. The list of Bushisms grows daily, a classic added after the president refused to answer reporters' questions at the Quebec Summit of the Americas, "Neither in French nor in English nor in Mexican."

But the key expectation has proved spectacularly false. The savants told us there was little to choose between Gore, a Clintonite New Democrat, and Bush, a self-styled "compassionate conservative". Both were huddling in the soft centre: Tweedledum and Tweedledee. Whoever won, little would change.

Well, no one's saying that now. For the promise that this would be a Republican Lite administration has proved naive, if not positively deceitful. Instead, in 100 short days, we have seen the Bush regime establish itself as the most brazenly rightwing of modern times. As the ecstatic head of the ultra-conservative Heritage Foundation enthuses, the new crowd are "more Reaganite than the Reagan administration".

At least you cannot fault their energy. In little over three months they have notched up a roll-call of policy atrocities that will keep US pressure groups busy for years. Pick your subject. Women's rights? Bush used the very first day of his presidency to block aid to any international group that promotes or offers abortion, even in developing countries where that help is vital. Children? He proposed saving money by slashing programmes designed to fight child abuse.

But let's not forget the area where Bush has made his strongest mark: the environment. Since January he has trashed the Kyoto protocol, broken his promise to reduce carbon emissions, proposed drilling in America's last wilderness, the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, called for more nuclear power plants and "delayed" a demand that the utilities reduce the amount of arsenic in drinking water. The Bushies are backpedalling now, but their message could not have been clearer: the planet is not safe in their hands.

In international affairs, a retro brand of hawkery has become the defining philosophy of a president who promised a "humble foreign policy". Not content with reviving the cold war with Russia and triggering a new one with China (though yesterday's compromise on arms sales to Taiwan may be enough to prevent relations souring further), Bush scuppered the growing reconciliation between the two Koreas. That way he can still cite the "rogue state" of North Korea as the excuse for his ludicrous Son of Star Wars scheme.

Meanwhile, the closest thing we have to a policy crusade is Bush's drive for a $1.6 trillion tax cut - 43% of which will go to the richest 1% in America: billionaires who don't need, and don't even want, the cash.

It is an appalling record, assembled in less than 14 weeks. What it amounts to is the wish list of the wealth wing of the Republican party, granted in full. Big business does not just have influence over this administration - it is this administration. Look at the multimillionaires around the cabinet table. Scan the resumes: chief of staff Andrew Card is the former top lobbyist of General Motors; national security adviser Condoleezza Rice has a Chevron oil tanker named after her. It's no surprise this lot are making life easier for corporate power. Despite the window-dressing, which allowed compassionate W to present his cabinet as a "diverse" mix from across America, this is the boardroom presidency.

Is there a lesson from this three-month, crash course in Bushism? You bet. First, the right are serious about power. Many expected Bush to clip his wings, to govern from the centre, in deference to his lack of a national mandate. But that's not how the right works. It thinks power belongs to it, as a law of nature - and when its got power, it uses it. It's only the centre-left that is scared of its own shadow, too frightened to act even when it's won by a landslide.

Second, progressives must never again be deluded into thinking there is no difference between us and our enemy. The right may pretend it has changed, but it will be just that: a pretence. "Forgive me, Al Gore," pleaded one liberal US columnist, recanting her previous line that Democrats and Republicans were as bad as each other. She's now seen that Democrats may be bad - but Republicans are worse.

So what might be a practical response? How about the left resolve to pursue power as deliberately as our adversaries? In the United States, that would mean no repeat of the 2000 split which saw Ralph Nader win votes that might otherwise have gone to Gore. Third parties make sense in parliamentary systems - and Nader's Greens should compete for congressional seats - but not in presidential races, where there is but a single prize at stake. There can be only one president: next time the left have to unite behind one candidate.

In Britain, unity may well take the opposite form. Progressives lost four successive elections here because the anti-Tory vote was split between Labour and Lib Dems. Tactical voting in 1997 finally found a way around the problem, with supporters of the two parties effectively swapping their votes. Now there are moves, led by Billy Bragg and others, to formalise that process. Good luck to them. Should there be any doubt about motive, we need only cast a glance across the Atlantic. For that is what happens when the left forgets its enemy.

For the promise that this would be a Republican Lite administration has proved naive, if not positively deceitful. Instead, in 100 short days, we have seen the Bush regime establish itself as the most brazenly rightwing of modern times. As the ecstatic head of the ultra-conservative Heritage Foundation enthuses, the new crowd are "more Reaganite than the Reagan administration". At least you cannot fault their energy. In little over three months they have notched up a roll-call of policy atrocities that will keep US pressure groups busy for years. Pick your subject. Women's rights? Bush used the very first day of his presidency to block aid to any international group that promotes or offers abortion, even in developing countries where that help is vital. Children? He proposed saving money by slashing programmes designed to fight child abuse. But let's not forget the area where Bush has made his strongest mark: the environment. Since January he has trashed the Kyoto protocol, broken his promise to reduce carbon emissions, proposed drilling in America's last wilderness, the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, called for more nuclear power plants and "delayed" a demand that the utilities reduce the amount of arsenic in drinking water. The Bushies are backpedalling now, but their message could not have been clearer: the planet is not safe in their hands. In international affairs, a retro brand of hawkery has become the defining philosophy of a president who promised a "humble foreign policy". Not content with reviving the cold war with Russia and triggering a new one with China (though yesterday's compromise on arms sales to Taiwan may be enough to prevent relations souring further), Bush scuppered the growing reconciliation between the two Koreas. That way he can still cite the "rogue state" of North Korea as the excuse for his ludicrous Son of Star Wars scheme. Meanwhile, the closest thing we have to a policy crusade is Bush's drive for a $1.6 trillion tax cut - 43% of which will go to the richest 1% in America: billionaires who don't need, and don't even want, the cash. It is an appalling record, assembled in less than 14 weeks. What it amounts to is the wish list of the wealth wing of the Republican party, granted in full. Big business does not just have influence over this administration - it is this administration. Look at the multimillionaires around the cabinet table. Scan the resumes: chief of staff Andrew Card is the former top lobbyist of General Motors; national security adviser Condoleezza Rice has a Chevron oil tanker named after her. It's no surprise this lot are making life easier for corporate power. Despite the window-dressing, which allowed compassionate W to present his cabinet as a "diverse" mix from across America, this is the boardroom presidency. Is there a lesson from this three-month, crash course in Bushism? You bet. First, the right are serious about power. Many expected Bush to clip his wings, to govern from the centre, in deference to his lack of a national mandate. But that's not how the right works. It thinks power belongs to it, as a law of nature - and when its got power, it uses it. It's only the centre-left that is scared of its own shadow, too frightened to act even when it's won by a landslide. Second, progressives must never again be deluded into thinking there is no difference between us and our enemy. The right may pretend it has changed, but it will be just that: a pretence. "Forgive me, Al Gore," pleaded one liberal US columnist, recanting her previous line that Democrats and Republicans were as bad as each other. She's now seen that Democrats may be bad - but Republicans are worse. So what might be a practical response? How about the left resolve to pursue power as deliberately as our adversaries? In the United States, that would mean no repeat of the 2000 split which saw Ralph Nader win votes that might otherwise have gone to Gore. Third parties make sense in parliamentary systems - and Nader's Greens should compete for congressional seats - but not in presidential races, where there is but a single prize at stake. There can be only one president: next time the left have to unite behind one candidate. In Britain, unity may well take the opposite form. Progressives lost four successive elections here because the anti-Tory vote was split between Labour and Lib Dems. Tactical voting in 1997 finally found a way around the problem, with supporters of the two parties effectively swapping their votes. Now there are moves, led by Billy Bragg and others, to formalise that process. Good luck to them. Should there be any doubt about motive, we need only cast a glance across the Atlantic. For that is what happens when the left forgets its enemy. jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com Talk about it Calling Americans: What do you think of your president? Interactive guide By George! fields.headline: Inequitable and unfair
fields.standfirst: UK's public spending must be reformed
fields.trailText: Leader: UK's public spending must be reformed.
fields.body:
The editor of the Berwick-upon-Tweed's local newspaper summed it up succinctly: "Berwick is out on a limb. We feel we won't get a fair deal from Westminster. Cross the border and you instantly see the difference." As our regional affairs editor reported yesterday, a small but growing number of people are doing more than noting the difference - they are crossing the border to gain access to better hospitals and schools.

For years public service reformers in England have pointed to Scotland in support of their argument for higher public expenditure on health and education services. Why does Scotland have less private medicine than England? Because access to good hospitals is so much easier. Why will Scotland be better able to ride the teacher shortage? Because it has recently concluded a three-year 23% pay rise for teachers that includes a 35-hour week, one third of which is reserved for class preparation and marking work.

How can Scotland afford these expenditures? Because under the current out-dated funding formula, it receives 23% more per head than the English average - with Wales getting 18% more and Northern Ireland, with its security problems, an extra 39%. England's deprived regions have been calling for a reform of the formula for years.

The formula was devised in the late 1970s by Joel (now Lord) Barnett, Labour's chief secretary at the Treasury when Scotland was considerably less well off than it is today. Even Lord Barnett believes it now needs reformulating. As he explained last year, it was "intended as a stopgap until a needs-based system came into operation. In fact no such change to take account of needs has been made". The Treasury select committee, which investigated the system in 1997, was even more scathing, criticising successive governments for not studying the appropriateness of the formula.

Ironically, if ever there was a government that should have reformed the system it is the current Labour government, with a prime minister and five cabinet ministers in the last four years drawn from the north-east. Devastated by de-industrialisation, no other region suffers quite so badly. The north-east may have the second highest unemployment rate and the highest proportion of people on welfare, but it still sees its richer neighbour, Scotland, receiving 16% more funds per head, even though it is 20% richer. But change is in the air.

Our regional affairs editor yesterday reported John Prescott, deputy prime minister, signalling that the review of local government finance in the new parliament would include a detailed examination of funding throughout the UK. There was some rowing back yesterday, but there should not be. There would be "blood on the carpet", but that is the only way reform could be pushed through. The reason why there has been no reform until now, lives on: the fear of provoking a tartan revolt and increasing support for the nationalist parties. But the mood among the ministers and Labour MPs representing England's depressed regions, has also changed.

The recently revised index of English regional deprivation shows how difficult it is to reach an agreed formula. Ideally, the needs-based analysis should be done by an independent board. Labour must produce a fairer and more equitable system. But it must also produce more public spending. A report from the Treasury earlier this month confirmed that in the first four years of the Blair government, public spending as a proportion of GDP was the lowest for 37 years. Don't rob Scotland and Wales: give England more.

webTitle: Robert Downey Jr fired after arrest

fields.headline: Robert Downey Jr fired after arrest
fields.trailText: Robert Downey Jr, whose career has been blighted by his addiction to drugs, has been dropped from Ally McBeal, after being arrested early yesterday for allegedly taking an unknown "stimulant"
fields.body:
Robert Downey Jr, whose career has been blighted by his addiction to drugs, has been dropped from Ally McBeal. Downey Jr, 36, was arrested early yesterday for allegedly taking an unknown "stimulant" and has now been fired from the hit TV series.

Ananova reports, that David E Kelly, the producer of Ally McBeal, has released a statement saying that Downey was being dropped from any more episodes. Kelly had been supportive of the wayward star, even signing him to more episodes after the actor's arrest last November on more drug charges.

Downey Jr, who won a Golden Globe for his role as Calista Flockhart's boyfriend in the TV show, spent a year in prison for cocaine possession and faces another possible spell inside following on from last November's arrest.

webTitle: G2: Len Cook, the census mastermind

fields.headline: In for the count
fields.standfirst: Len Cook is the number cruncher masterminding the census. He tells  Paul Kelso why it's so vital - and why he won't be classing Jedi as a religion
fields.trailText: Len Cook is the number cruncher masterminding the census. He tells Paul Kelso why it's so vital - and why he won't be classing Jedi as a religion.
fields.body:
Len Cook knows where you live, but wants to know more. Who you live with, for instance, and whether you share a bathroom with them. He is also interested in where you come from, how you get to work and to which gods you pray. If he sounds nosy, forgive him - it's his job. Cook is the registrar general for England and Wales, the man with overall responsibility for the 2001 census, and if you haven't received a letter from him yet, you soon will.

You will find his signature at the bottom of the census form delivered in a bright yellow envelope to your home (and 24m others). This Sunday, you are required by law to answer the 40-plus questions on the form and return it. Then, when the answers have been counted, collated, verified and compared, Cook will have a snapshot of how we live our lives at the turn of the 21st century.

Much rests on what the census - conducted every 10 years - reveals. Local and national government spending plans are governed by the demographic secrets it gives up; bypasses and railways, schools and hospitals, factories and sports centres will be built or left on the drawing board depending on the boxes you tick.

Cook is looking forward to the challenge. He beat an international field of candidates to become head of national statistics last May, having previously held the post in his native New Zealand. With a census every five years at home he is experienced, but has never conducted an exercise on this scale. "The UK is one of the largest and most sophisticated census operations in the world, including the USA. It's a huge task," he says.

More than 70,000 enumerators have been hired to distribute 24m forms (in 28 different languages, plus Braille), and even using computers it will take seven months to process the details. The results concerning age, sex and marital status will be published in the summer of next year, but the full results will not be available until August 2003. By then preparation for the 2011 census will be under way.

Cook, a compact, moustachioed man with social skills and energy levels you might not associate with a number cruncher, readily shoulders the responsibility that goes with having his signature on every form. "The other day I was the first in and I picked up this ringing phone and there was a lady complaining about the help desk here, so I answered her questions and put her straight. Having the signature there means I have to be available when people find things that are complicated."

Cook has had other problems to deal with. The whole project was briefly threatened by the foot and mouth epidemic, and given the controversy of the ethnicity question, it's a small miracle that only the Welsh were inflamed by the absence of a specific box to tick.

The religion question, meanwhile, has provided one of the lighter moments of the exercise. A web campaign launched in New Zealand has been urging the agnostic to put "Jedi" in the space reserved for other religions. If more than 10,000 people do so, runs the rumour, the 2011 census will have to include Jedi as an official religion alongside Buddhism and Christianity. Unfortunately for Star Wars buffs, Cook says this will not be the case. "These sort of dilemmas arise all the time when you're asking people about their lives. It's rather like peeling an onion; once you sort out one question another crops up. The challenge is to keep finding useful solutions."

He can hardly contain his enthusiasm for the revelatory power of his craft, and shows a sharp sense of humour at the suggestion that it is, well, a touch dull: "Oh yes, I really wanted to be an accountant but I didn't have the charisma, so I went for statistician instead," he cracks. In fact Cook, 53, was interested in maths at school, but as he progressed he realised the pure discipline was not for him. His interest in economics then fired him towards statistics, what he calls the art of "measuring the unmeasurable".

To dismiss statisticians as bean counters is to misunderstand the role. It's not the number of beans that count, it's what they tell you about bean-related trends: "What we do is develop a model of how something might work in theory - say the level of consumption, of investment or of inflation - and then work out ways of measuring them in practice," Cook says.

"These concepts are not easily measurable. With inflation, for instance, we have to take a list of goods from a number of outlets, find out what they cost and average them to arrive at an index that is useful. That sounds simple but the question of arriving at the average and the index is crucial, and difficult. It's not the counting that's important, it's how you use those numbers."

These numbers have great power, and the consequences of mistakes are huge; the office for national statistics is blamed for failing to spot the Lawson boom in the 80s which led to interest rates of 15%; and Cook's predecessor left after mistakenly predicting that earnings were to soar, which caused jitters in Threadneedle Street.

"What is so exciting and so challenging is to show what the figures reveal about this country. Take population. In the next 30 years it's not really going to grow that much, but underlying that will be huge shifts in the age of the workforce, and issues relating to the fertility of British women. The mean age of women when they have children is going up towards 29, while the baby-boomers in the workplace are getting ever older. This has implications because of the greater reliance on technology and new skills at work. But the bigger question is, was the baby boom the blip, rather than a 'natural' trend?"

But while such weighty issues engage Cook's attention at the office, he unwinds with regular fishing trips. A keen angler, he tries to get home to New Zealand at least once a year. But even when he is relaxing on the riverbank, rod in hand, the statistician's mind still whirs: "I always try to guess the weight of a fish. Also, one of my very good friends is a fishing writer, and he logs all his catches, size, weight, weather, everything. So I've been looking at the things that influence trout catches in New Zealand waters. Was it a nymph or a fly, what time was it caught, what was the weather, was the water still or flowing?" He pauses. "I guess you would have to say I'm a congenital measurer."

fields.headline: Labour's NHS power shift
fields.trailText: A massive cutback in NHS bureaucracy and a switch of resources to frontline staff, giving more power to disgruntled GPs and consultants, is to be unveiled today as the keynote of Labour's second-term plans for health.
fields.body:
A massive cutback in NHS bureaucracy and a switch of resources to frontline staff, giving more power to disgruntled GPs and consultants, is to be unveiled today as the keynote of Labour's second-term plans for health.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will present the reforms as "shifting the centre of gravity in the NHS from Whitehall to frontline services". The changes will "liberate local services," he will claim.

Speaking in advance of a speech to launch the NHS Modernisation Agency, Mr Milburn said: "Public service reform, whether it is in health, education [or] local government, has got to be the driving force of any Labour second term. There is a huge amount of catching up to do in the reform of the public services, including the NHS."

He will announce plans to cut the number of health authorities in England from 99 to 30, as well as abolish the current 10 regional offices.

Financial muscle in the health service will pass to local primary care trusts which will decide how much money to divide between GP surgeries, local hospitals and other local services. By 2004, the trusts will be responsible for allocating 75% of an NHS budget that will have increased to £57bn.

The new approach may appeal to hospital managers and doctors who have become increasingly frustrated over the past four years by growing control from the centre. Mr Milburn will say the time has come for more authority to pass to the front line.

He said it was not surprising that the British Medical Association had criticised the government. It was doing its job as a trade union during the first big renegotiation of the doctors' contract for 50 years. But reform would go ahead and the doctors would feel the benefit of being freed from the frustrations they were feeling.

He said the new-style merged health authorities would no longer have hands-on responsibility for allocating money. "Local services will be controlled much more by local front staff in the primary care trusts and NHS trusts". The new health authorities will hold the system to account.

The merger of English health authorities will be implemented by 2004. Regional offices will be abolished by the end of the next parliament, although regional directors with small staffs will continue to oversee local performance.

Mr Milburn predicted that he would be able to cut the number of staff in the regional offices from 1,000 to 500. The merger and changed role of the health authorities would also see staff cutbacks, he said.

He wants to reduce the size of the Department of Health in Whitehall and focus its role on monitoring the delivery of policy, progress-chasing and ending bottlenecks.

He will also confirm the abolition of the NHS executive.

The aim he said will be to ensure that 75% of the£57bn NHS budget in 2003-4 will be handled by local primary care trusts. In 1997 the proportion of the budget controlled by GP fundholders was 15%. He compared the drive to devolve budgets to local health services to the shift in the control of resources to schools from local education authorities.

"The reduction in bureaucracy is designed to give more control to primary care groups to purchase services from local NHS trusts. The chief executives of the trusts have complained about day-to-day interference so they cannot get on with the job of delivering the NHS plan. The new flatter structure is going to liberate local services.

"In too many cases the local health authorities have been refusing to let go of the purse strings, and in some cases they have refused to let go of the contents of the purses. Not surprisingly, some doctors and nurses have felt disempowered by that process. That cannot go on.

"Inevitably the NHS plan was centrally driven, but if we are going to deliver radical public services reform and ask NHS staff to be ambassadors for better public service, frontline staff have to be the architects of change," the health secretary said.

He will also announce a shake-up of cancer services so that leading doctors and nurses are given control of cancer budgets spanning everything from prevention to treatment. He will invite bids from local clinicians. "Over time we can get to a position whereby cancer doctors and nurses are in control of the whole budget for NHS cancer care," he said.

He will announce that in the summer he will ask senior managers to work with local staff to identify obstacles to implementing the plan. The outcome will influence annual cash grants to hospital trusts and care groups next spring.

Mr Mllburn is taking a risk with his proposals since he is already facing a rebellion from doctors over their new contract, as well as from consultants on the amount of time they must devote to the NHS.

He admitted: "It is not surprising there is an element of change fatigue in the NHS. Nonetheless my message is that reform must happen."

He also claimed that a Labour general election victory will for the first time in decades give a centre-left party a mandate to tackle the legacy of public under-investment.

He will also announce a shake-up of cancer services so that leading doctors and nurses are given control of cancer budgets spanning everything from prevention to treatment. He will invite bids from local clinicians. "Over time we can get to a position whereby cancer doctors and nurses are in control of the whole budget for NHS cancer care," he said. He will announce that in the summer he will ask senior managers to work with local staff to identify obstacles to implementing the plan. The outcome will influence annual cash grants to hospital trusts and care groups next spring. Mr Mllburn is taking a risk with his proposals since he is already facing a rebellion from doctors over their new contract, as well as from consultants on the amount of time they must devote to the NHS. He admitted: "It is not surprising there is an element of change fatigue in the NHS. Nonetheless my message is that reform must happen." He also claimed that a Labour general election victory will for the first time in decades give a centre-left party a mandate to tackle the legacy of public under-investment.

fields.headline: Haider rhetoric 'trivialises' Nazism
fields.standfirst: Linguists say the far right politician uses distortion, diversion and humour to push his agenda, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Linguists say the far right politician uses distortion, diversion and humour to push his agenda in Austria, writes Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
An Austrian appeal court ruled at the end of last week that the far right politician Jörg Haider had made comments which trivialised the crimes of the Third Reich.

The judgment was a victory for political scientist Anton Pelinka of Innsbruck university. In a television interview Prof Pelinka had referred to a statement by Haider that concentration camps were "punishment centres", saying that Haider had played down the horrors of Nazi rule.

Haider's lawyer and now the country's controversial justice minister, Dieter Bohmdörfer brought the case against Prof Pelinka, one of hundreds that the litigious populist has launched against his opponents.

In an initial hearing the court had ruled in favour of the far right leader, awarding him £3,000. Prof Pelinka has already lost one similar case against the politician.

The cases have highlighted fears that the entry of Haider's Freedom party (FPO) in a coalition government with the conservatives has severely damaged freedom of speech in Austria and has also served to make the FPO's anti-foreigner rhetoric part of mainstream discourse.

In the remarks that landed him in front of the court, Prof Pelinka said: "In his career Haider has repeatedly made statements which amount to trivialising National Socialism.

"On the whole, Haider is responsible for making certain National Socialist positions and certain National Socialist remarks more politically acceptable."

"Salonfähig" is the precise German phrase - comments that become more and more acceptable to utter in Viennese salons without eyebrows being raised.

Haider gained international notoriety for enthusing about Hitler's unemployment policies and praising SS veterans as "men of character".

He has turned into a figure of fascination for linguists over the years, who have remarked that he has become increasingly proficient at using the methods of distortion, exaggeration, diversion, simplification, mitigation, and more than any other Austrian politician, humour, to play his populist game.

"Haider is someone who plays the populist game combined with a very clever rhetoric to which one cannot react with objective facts," according to Ruth Wodak, professor of applied linguistics at Vienna university.

A linguistic study she led some months ago concluded that Austria was the only country in which the far right was not only included in mainstream debate, but where it actually led the agenda.

Following last week's verdict, Haider, who resigned as the FPO's leader almost a year ago, but who remains its de facto leader, said losing the case to Prof Pelinka was part of the "professional suffering" he had learned to endure.

"Since my capacity to suffer is unlimited and has grown with the years I will cope with that," he said.

But he may take comfort in the fact that Austria's most popular newspaper and a strong FPO supporter, very effectively employs the Haider rhetoric.

The Kronen Zeitung which is the most successful newspaper in the world in relation to per capita sales, is loaded with the subliminal meanings that have become Haider's trademark.

Wolf Martin, who modified his birth name - Wolfgang Martinek - because it sounded too foreign, writes a daily poem for the tabloid in which he effectively uses innuendo to convey a heavily loaded and often far right message.

In November 1999 the man dubbed Haider's "poet laureate" attacked "anti-fascists" after some photographs at an historic exhibition on the Wehrmacht were discovered to be fakes. The last word of the poem, "ausgeschwitzt", from the verb "ausschwitzen", meaning to sweat out, is a word play on Auschwitz concentration camp.

The message in the final line was that the brains of Austrian school children will eventually "sweat out" the lies that have been planted there by their anti-fascist teachers about the Nazi era.

Last Friday he was said to have surpassed himself with a birthday poem in honour of Adolf Hitler who would have been 112 years old.

"Indeed, today is a great day!/ I've long been looking forward to/ everyone is celebrating today/ although most are having to celebrate in the privacy of their homes... we should honour him, and 'heil' him... "

At the end he employs a twist as the poem turns into a tribute to the second series of the TV show Taxi Orange, the Austrian version of Big Brother which started on the same day.

Seven years ago he wrote a similar tribute to Hitler - at the end suggesting it was in praise of another Adolf - Adolf Scharf, one of Austria's first postwar presidents - who has the same birthday.

"Who is interested in [the poem]?" asked popular commentator with Der Standard, Hans Rauscher. "Well, perhaps those who closely know Wolfgang Martinek's opinions and above all know that April 20 is the Führer's birthday... he also liked calling himself Wolf."

Austrian publisher Richard Brem says that the influence of Martin and Haider on the popular psyche of contemporary Austria cannot be underestimated. "More than any other people in Austria, Martin and Haider are shaping and influencing society in a very profound way, using coded language, similar terminology and in a teasing way."

"The whole shift to the right is down to them."

The recently deceased Austrian poet, HC Artmann, commented that Haider is the only national politician who takes an artistic or playful approach to language.

The Haider-Martin style has quickly caught on. Just as readers of the Kronen Zeitung have begun writing letters to the newspaper in "Wolf Martin rhyming style", so too has Haider picked up his quill.

He recently read one of his own Martin-style poems - an attack on Germany's Green foreign minister Joschka Fischer - at an FPO beer hall rally, to resounding laughter and applause.

fields.headline: Fantasic Four film plans emerge
fields.trailText: More details have emerged following yesterday's news that The Fantastic Four, based on the Marvel comic book series is, after years of development, to be turned into a film
fields.body:
More details have emerged following yesterday's news that The Fantastic Four, based on the Marvel comic book series is, after years of development, to be turned into a film.

Upcomingmovies.com, report that 20th Century Fox was always intending to make three films based on various Marvel comic characters. The first of these was X-Men and, following its box-office success, the studio is now confident to go ahead with the second, Fantastic Four. This will be followed by Silver Surfer.

Created by Stan Lee and Jack Kirby, Fantastic Four was first published in 1962. It centres around four astronauts who develop superhuman powers after flying their untested spaceship through cosmic rays. These rays transform them into the Fantastic Four - Mr Fantastic, Invisible Woman, the Human Torch and the Thing - and they band together to fight against the evil Doctor Doom.

What made the Fantastic Four different was that they not only decided against hiding their identities, but argued among themselves.

A feature-film version of the Fantastic Four has already been made, by B-movie King Roger Corman. It was never released.

 More on the Fantastic Four

fields.headline: Dyer: I'm staying at Newcastle
fields.trailText: Kieron Dyer has insisted that he wants to stay at Newcastle despite reports that Manchester United are prepared to smash the British transfer record to buy him.
fields.body:
Kieron Dyer has insisted that he wants to stay at Newcastle despite reports that Manchester United are prepared to smash the British transfer record to buy him.

"I am staying at Newcastle and that's all there is to it," Dyer told the Newcastle Journal. "As far as I'm concerned, any talk of a £15m bid is ridiculous and nobody at the club knows anything about it."

Dyer's denial comes on the back of reports which claimed Sir Alex Ferguson was planning to offer £20m for the former Ipswich player in the summer, after his £15m bid was rejected a fortnight ago.

And Dyer today made it clear he wants to see out the remaining three years of his existing contract.

"I'm flattered that my name keeps being linked other big clubs, but at the moment, all I'm concentrating on is getting fit.

"I won't go to the manager's door asking to leave St James' Park, and the club don't want me to leave," he added. "That's pretty conclusive - but I can't stop the speculation."

webTitle: GPs' threat to go private 'would cost NHS £5bn'

fields.headline: GPs' threat to go private 'would cost NHS £5bn'
fields.trailText: At least an extra £5bn of public and private money would have to be spent to maintain current primary care services if family doctors resigned en masse from the NHS in protest against excessive workloads, leading health analysts have claimed.
fields.body:
At least an extra £5bn of public and private money would have to be spent to maintain current primary care services if family doctors resigned en masse from the NHS in protest against excessive workloads, leading health analysts have claimed.

They have warned privatisation of general practice would make healthcare inaccessible to millions of people on low incomes, undermining public health and exacerbating health inequalities.

Professor Bonnie Sibbald, deputy director of the National Primary Care Research and Development Centre, said: "Based on my experience of the US healthcare system, privatisation would lead to at least a 10% increase in the cost of providing health care to the public."

This would add an extra £5.42bn to health spending, a premium that would be shared by private patients and the NHS. The current NHS budget is £54.2bn.

The stark warnings came after the British Medical Association decided to ballot the UK's 36,000 GPs last week on proposals for a mass resignation if the government did not agree a new GP contract and broader negotiating rights for the organisation by April next year.

One private GP service contacted by SocietyGuardian.co.uk said older patients with more health problems would pay considerably more for care.

PPP healthcare customer support coordinator Jane Elderfield said: "Our top rate is for a woman aged 85 or more on lots of medication - she'd have to pay £62 per month."

The standard premium is £16.50 per month for men and £21.50 for women up to the age of 44 who answer no to six health-related problems, although patients have to pay a further £5 per month per item for medication.

Dr Brian Goss, founder and chairman of private GPs' organisation the Family Doctors Network, said: "I believe 60-70% of the public could afford to pay for private general practice through an insurance arrangement or paying for each consultation.

"For the remaining 30% who don't have that disposable income, health authorities or primary care trusts could contract with private GPs and healthcare companies to provide those services without charging patients."

However, Dr Stephen Gillam, part-time GP and director of the primary care programme at King's Fund, said this would create a two-tier health service.

"This is the situation in the US, where the better off can afford first-rate care while those on low incomes receive a safety net service."

Dr Gillam said privatisation would severely reduce access to primary health care for the less well off who needed it most. "This would lead to poor vaccination rates - and severe outbreaks of conditions like measles - as well as placing more burden on already over-stretched A&E departments."

GPs would also be concentrated in affluent areas, as medical accountancy firms warned that private practice would not be viable elsewhere.

Valerie Martin, partner at PKF accountants, which has 1,200 GP practices on its books, said private practice would be "very risky" for most doctors.

"Most doctors would have to relocate to affluent areas in London or the south-east because their patients could not - or would not - pay," she said.

"A lot of the business costs that GPs with NHS contracts have are covered by reimbursements - they get back 70% of their staff costs. So you'd need a good list size of affluent patients to cover your overheads."

Going private would also leave doctors' vulnerable to economic downturns, said Ms Martin. "The last recession had a direct impact on our private GPs' profits, leaving them unable to offer new services or attract more patients."

London GP Dr Jules Eden, who runs e-med private medical services, said the set up costs for private practice were considerable.

"It's £20,000 a year to rent a room in lower Sloane Street, plus £15,000 for a secretary and at least £5,000 on marketing costs. If you've had to relocate, you can expect to take five to seven years to build up your patient list."

Despite its tough rhetoric, the BMA now says GPs would not necessarily go private if their threat to resign came to fruition.

Chairman of the BMA's GPs' committee, Dr John Chisholm, admitted most GPs worked in areas where private practice was not viable. But they could become non-principals, work under personal medical service contracts, accept an emergency contract from the government or leave medicine altogether.

"I don't think there would be a huge reduction of GP services available to the public," he said. "However, I would expect variations in provision to increase with fewer practices in deprived inner city areas."

However, Ms Martin said private practice would be the only option for GPs if they wanted to avoid working to government targets and reduce their NHS bureaucracy. "I don't think this threat has been thought through."

fields.headline: Omnicom earnings rise
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Omnicom has reported a rise in first quarter earnings despite a weakening of the US advertising market, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
Omnicom Group has reported a rise in first quarter earnings, despite a weakening of the US advertising market.

The advertising agency network's net income for the first quarter of 2001 grew by 20% year on year to £66m.

Omnicom's worldwide revenue rose 16% year on year to £1.1bn with international revenue for the first quarter of £489m, representing a 6% increase.

Revenue in the US, where the burst of the dot.com bubble has caused a worrying contraction in overall advertising spend, still rose by 25% to £623m.

This growth was largely attributed to a raft of new business wins, including Kentucky Friend Chicken.

John Wren, the chief executive of Omnicom Group, said new business was beginning to pick up in the second quarter.

"The business environment in the first quarter was challenging... but we feel that all of our business units performed well in the quarter," he said.

Omnicom's UK companies include TBWA, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and BMP DDB.

webTitle: Iraqi minister could face UK indictment

fields.headline: Iraqi minister could face UK indictment
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard detectives are investigating possible criminal charges against the foreign minister of Iraq, Tariq Aziz.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard detectives are investigating possible criminal charges against the foreign minister of Iraq, Tariq Aziz.

An indictment could severely restrict the movement of Mr Aziz because he would be open to extradition from a range of countries he visits, including France.

A long-time confidant of Iraq's leader, Saddam Hussein, he travels freely around world capitals, often to lobby against the UN sanctions imposed on Iraq after it tried to annex Kuwait in 1990.

A spokesman for the Metropolitan Police confirmed yesterday that the case had been referred to the force last month by the attorney-general, Lord Williams of Mostyn.

The anti-terrorist squad is carrying out the investigation. The Labour MP George Galloway, a campaigner against the UN sanctions, described the move as "disturbing".

But, he said, Tariq Aziz "is not worried. Were he to be held somewhere, he would turn that period of detention into a platform for the tragedy of Iraq."

Rupert Cazalet, a spokesman for Lord Williams, said yesterday: "We feel there is a possibility [of an indictment] and if there is, it should be properly investigated."

The police are studying documents compiled by Indict, a British-based organisation funded by the US Congress to investigate Iraqi war crimes.

Indict is seeking criminal charges against Saddam Hussein and Mr Aziz under the Taking of Hostages Act (1982), alleging that many of hostages taken at the start of the Gulf war in 1990 were subjected to mental abuse and torture.

In a statement, Lord Williams effectively ruled out charges against President Saddam: as head of state he could claim immunity, and the attorney general was not satisfied that the evidence was "sufficient to provide a realistic prospect of a conviction".

But the statement said: "Whether the court would uphold any claim of immunity that may be asserted by Tariq Aziz is less clear." Lord Williams was not satisfied that the evidence offered a realistic prospect of conviction in his case either, but said "there is scope for further inquiries to be carried out".

Mudhafar Amin, head of the Iraqi interests section in London, said: "It is just a political manoeuvre as part of the campaign to keep up the sanctions against Iraq."

fields.headline: Advertising watchdog rules against Virgin
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Train operator Virgin today blamed Railtrack for criticism it received from an advertising watchdog, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Train operator Virgin today blamed Railtrack for criticism it received from an advertising watchdog.

The Advertising Standards Authority said Virgin was wrong to promise customers in its New Year advertising campaign, that things were getting back to normal following last year's Hatfield disaster.

Virgin told passengers that from January 29 they could expect an average journey time of one hour 55 minutes between Birmingham New Street and London Euston stations.

It also promised the "improved service that you can rely on" would run every 30 minutes during peak times.

But the advertising watchdog upheld complaints from five customers who claimed Virgin had not delivered its promises.

It is the third complaint the authority has upheld against Virgin Trains's claims on running times and cheap tickets since last July.

Virgin said the blame for the latest ruling lay with Railtrack as the "custodian of the nation's railway" responsible for getting trains running on time.

webTitle: A sequel to American Psycho, the movie?

fields.headline: Murder most horrid
fields.standfirst: A sequel to American Psycho? Danny Leigh  fears the worst
fields.trailText: A sequel to American Psycho? Danny Leigh fears the worst.
fields.body:
"Above one of the doors covered by red velvet drapes in Harry's is a sign, and on the sign in letters that match the drapes' colour are the words THIS IS NOT AN EXIT."

And so, after nearly 400 pages of mayhem, viscera and exhaustive lists of male grooming products, it ended. American Psycho, the novelist Bret Easton Ellis's reviled saga of serial murder amid the glassy opulence of mid-1980s Manhattan, was over. Which, whether your response to its fusion of deadpan grand guignol and consumer durables had been adulation or disgust, frankly came as a relief.

Equally, when the closing credits rolled on last year's movie adaptation, directed with much panache by Mary Harron, your immediate reaction was not to storm the foyer demanding another ticket. If Ellis's 1991 opus opened a long conversation about both the dark legacy of Reaganism and its author's morality, Harron's film was a bloody full stop. You did not want more.

Yet more is what we're going to get. Lions Gate, producer of Harron's movie, recently announced plans to oversee a hugely unlikely sequel, set in the present and rejoicing in the literal-minded title of American Psycho 2 (thereby missing the chance to use Honey, I Shrunk the Tortured Hooker and the Dead Homeless Guy). The bad news is no mere Hollywood rumour: the project begins shooting next month

Not that Harron, Ellis or any of the original cast will be present - not even Christian Bale, so alarmingly plausible as the carnage-happy anti-hero Patrick Bateman. Lions Gate's concept revolves around a survivor of Bateman's rampage, a female college freshman, who reaches for the axe after developing a campus crush. In lieu of Bale's leering, disconnected cipher, we have snub-nosed starlet Mila Kunis from the sitcom That 70s Show.

In place of Harron, we have Morgan J Freeman (no relation to the better known Morgan "no middle initial" Freeman), arriving fresh from the teen soap opera Dawson's Creek. Instead of a glacially comic take on a seminal (if often unreadable) source, we have what sounds like an artistically bankrupt slash'n'stalk, destined only to collect dust in video shops.

As baffling decisions go, it's a doozy. For one thing, Kunis's character would have been in nappies during Bateman's reign of terror. Then there's the likelihood, explicitly favoured by Harron, that Bateman was simply a fantasist, a Wall Street Walter Mitty whose grisly exploits never took place beyond his own sick-puppy imaginings. And, most pertinently, American Psycho was, however obliquely, a joke at the very culture of vapid thrill-seeking that would later inspire some genius to suggest making a sequel to it. Or sequels. "If we make good movies," Lions Gate president Michael Paseornek remarked optimistically, "we could have a franchise here."

A franchise? Given that Ellis spent much of the 1990s in the stocks for the alleged misogyny, brutality and plain bad writing of his signature novel, you sense the irony won't be lost on him. But, like most apparently demented ideas, there is a logic at work. While American Psycho may not have been a hit, it was dirt cheap by Hollywood standards. And cheap movies, in the eyes of the industry, are good movies.

All of which makes Bateman and his progeny potential gold dust for an ambitious operation such as Lions Gate, which snaffled up the rights not just to Ellis's novel but to his title, lead character and any other spin-offs. Managed correctly, the brand should have no trouble attracting press attention and multiplex kids hungry for generic scares in the vein of Screams 1, 2, 3 and 4.

Lions Gate is arguably simply tapping into a tradition whereby all the best bogeymen - Jason Voorhees, Michael Myers, Freddie Krueger et al - routinely return like homicidal Jack-in-the-boxes (or, if they don't come back in person, have their traumatised victims do it for them). But while buying up a brand name and hiring unknowns to keep down the overheads may make economic sense, it doesn't make for great movies.

And American Psycho was, now and again, tantalisingly close to being just that - partly due to Harron's deft way with a slapstick set-piece, but largely because she wisely excised the violent grotesqueries that secured Ellis his professional bad boy reputation (and made his novel such heavy going). Stripping the project of its adolescent fixation with granny-baiting shock tactics, Harron produced a spiteful and genuinely inspired satire on 1980s manhood and rapacious consumption.

The odds are you won't get much of that sort of thing with American Psycho 2. And since the censors won't let Lions Gate show the worst of Bateman's excesses, what will we be left with? A fat, redundant nothing, hollow and context-free, that any right-thinking movie-lover will wish nothing but ill as it begins to slither their way.

You can only hope Ellis is doing something really fun with the money.

fields.headline: Key legal changes affecting charities
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lloyd of Bates Wells and Braithwaite solicitors briefed charities at Charityfair yesterday about key legal developments. Here are some of the highlights
fields.trailText: Trustee Act 2000
fields.body:
Trustee Act 2000

This came into force on February 1. The act makes considerable changes to the power of trustees.

The new act, which applies to charitable trusts but not to charitable companies, extends the powers of trustees of charitable trusts in the following areas:-

Investment: Trustees can now invest in most types of property, provided they have regard to their overriding duty of prudence. This requires them to review the investments from time to time against defined standard investment criteria (which deal with the suitability of the investments and the need for diversification) and to take appropriate investment advice in most circumstances

Delegation: Trustees of charitable trusts can now appoint investment managers and other agents, including nominees and custodians, without an express power in the trust deed. Investment managers must be appointed in writing, and must have a policy statement from the trustees about how they should act. Restrictions are imposed on the terms of their appointment.

Insurance: Trustees' powers to insure trust property are extended.

Freedom of Information Act

This received royal assent on November 30. The act provides a right to information held by public authorities. Any person making a request for information to a public authority is entitled:

A) To be informed in writing by the public authority whether it holds the information of the description specified in the request, and;

B) If that is the case, to have that information communicated to him.

The "public authorities" to which the act applies include central and local government, parliament, the armed forces, the national health service, certain schools, colleges, universities and other educational institutions and the police.

A small number of charities, such as the British Council and the Tate are public authorities under the act.

Protection of Children Act

This act places the Department of Health list of persons considered unsuitable to work with children on a statutory basis. This new list will be called the protection of children list. Eventually this list will be accessed via the criminal records bureau and this will act as a one-stop shop for organisations which need to check the backgrounds of individuals.

Regulation of care services in England and Wales

A new system of regulation for care homes will be introduced by the Care Standards Act 2000, which will come into force in spring 2002. There will be some important differences from the present regime.

The new act will apply to children's homes, independent hospitals, independent clinics, care homes, residential family centres, independent medical agencies, domiciliary care agencies, nurses agencies, fostering agencies and voluntary adoption agencies. In addition, local authorities will be required for the first time to meet the same standards as independent sector providers.

There will be one registration authority in England, the national care standards commission, with eight regional offices and one in Wales.

There will be national minimum standards for each of the services to be regulated and establishments and agencies will be inspected by reference to these standards.

A timetable has been published on the Department of Health website.

Charities which are not currently registered but which will need to when the new act comes into force should contact their local authority/health authority nearer the time for information on how to apply.

Data protection

Under a recent exemption published by the data protection registrar, a not-for-profit organisation is specifically exempted from the notification provisions under the Data Protection Act 1998 if it is processing is only:

 For the purpose of establishing or maintaining membership or support for a body which is not conducted for profit;

 If the processing is to provide and administer activities for individuals who are either members of the body or have regular contact with it;

 For those whose data is being processed (data subjects) and the types of personal data which are to be processed (data classes).

The organisation is subject to restrictions in relation to the disclosure of the data to third parties and the retention.

Taxation

For charities that engage in trading, the Inland Revenue has clarified its de minimus concession. This applies where trades, which amount in part but not wholly to a primary purpose trade, eg a museum shop which sells goods relating to a primary purpose (eg educational) and some of which do not (eg mugs, tea towels).

The revenue will accept that all of the profits of trade will be exempt from tax if:

 The turnover of the part of the trade which is not within a primary purpose is not large ie not more than £50,000; and
 The turnover of that part of the trade is less than 10% of the turnover of the whole trade.

Charities will also be exempt from tax on profits from small trading, which does not have to be ancillary if:

 The total turnover from all of the activities does not exceed the annual turnover limit or · If the total turnover exceeds the annual turnover limit the charity had a reasonable expectation that it would not do so;
 The profits are used solely for the purposes of the charity

The annual turnover limit is £5,000 or if the turnover is greater than £50,000, 25% of the charity's gross income but no more than £50,000.

For the purpose of this limit gross income means the total receipts of the charity for the year from all sources (grants, donations, investment, income etc).

Business sponsorship

New guidelines issued by the Inland Revenue clarify:

If a charity publicises a link with a sponsor this may be regarded as a trade. Test: If the publicity amounts to no more than an acknowledgement of the sponsorship in the charity's publications, posters etc then this will not be regarded as a trade.

However, if the reference to a sponsor in the publicity materials amounts to advertisements for the business then the payments will be treated as trading income. The Inland Revenue will regard a reference to a sponsor as an advertisement if it incorporates any of the following:

 Large and prominent displays of the sponsor's logo;
 Large and prominent displays of the sponsor's corporate colours;
7#149; A description of the sponsor's products or services.

Registered trade marks

Two recent developments of interest to charities are:

1. The UK trade mark registry has changed its policy and will now, in some cases, allow registrations for "retail services" and "mail order services". Therefore any charities with shops or catalogues should consider registering their mark in this category;

2. The registry has issued guidance about its policy on registering marks ending in ".com" or ".co.uk" or preceded by "e-" or "m-". As a general rule, the registry will disregard these prefixes and will consider whether the rest of the mark is distinctive.

Use of photographs

Charities should review whether their system of storing photographs means that the photographs qualify as "data" protected under the Data Protection Act 1998; ie can an individual be identified by that data? They should also review procedures for obtaining consent from individuals to use photographs of them.

The consumer protection (distance selling) regulations 2000

These seek to protect consumers who buy goods without being able to see them. This will apply to charities selling products via the internet, by mail order or by telephone.

 The consumer must be provided with certain information in good time before the conclusion of the contract - eg name and address of supplier, main characteristics of the goods and services, arrangements for payments, price and the consumer's rights to withdraw from the contract

 That the consumer is notified of his/her right to withdraw from the contract within 7 working days after receipt of goods or the conclusion of the contract (in the case of services) without penalty.

 That the supplier is required to execute the contract within 30 days. If the supplier fails to do so, then the consumer has a right to a refund with 30 days.

Sale of second hand goods

Any charities involved in the sale of second hand goods should be aware of a potential change in the law due to come into effect on January 1 2002. The government plans to implement an EU directive on the sale of consumer goods and associated guarantees.

Companies - electronic communications with shareholders - electronic communications order 2000

Charities that are companies limited by guarantee can now distribute annual reports, accounts and other information on the website or through other electronic communication and allow members to use e-communications to appoint proxies and give them voting instructions.
