fields.headline: Fat Friends set for reunion
fields.trailText:
10am: Fat Friends is set to return to our TV screens, writes Jason Deans.
05.02.01: End of the line for Fat Friends
fields.body:
Fat Friends is set to return to our TV screens, only months after writer Kay Mellor indicated she didn't want to do another series.

The ITV controller of drama, Nick Elliott, said he was hopeful a second series of the hit show would be on the screens this year or next.

After initially doubting whether she would have anywhere else to take Fat Friends, Ms Mellor has now written a first episode for a potential second run.

"Before, Kay was saying she didn't know where to go with it," said Mr Elliott. "But now she has become more and more keen"

He said it was now a question of whether Ms Mellor felt she had enough material to write the whole second series.

Fat Friends focused on a group of Yorkshire women struggling to shed the pounds at a weight-watchers club.

It featured a strong ensemble cast including Alison Steadman, Josie Lawrence, Meera Syal and Ms Mellor's daughter Gaynor Faye.

The drama averaged 9.3m viewers across its six week run in October and November last year.

webTitle: Liddiment steps up in ITV revamp

fields.headline: Liddiment steps up in ITV revamp
fields.trailText:
9.45am: ITV director of programmes David Liddiment is being promoted as part of the restructure of Carlton and Granada's ITV businesses. By Jason Deans.

23.04.2001: ITV revamps ONdigital to rival BSkyB
fields.body:
The ITV director of programmes, David Liddiment, is to take on a wider role as part of Carlton and Granada's restructuring of their ITV businesses.

Mr Liddiment is to be promoted to ITV director of channels, overseeing all ITV-branded services, including ITV2 and the new ITV Sport Channel, which is due to launch in August.

His promotion forms part of a reorganisation that will also see the ONdigital chief executive, Stuart Prebble, taking up the post of ITV chief executive, which has been vacant for more than a year since Richard Eyre's departure.

In his new role Mr Prebble will continue to oversee ONdigital, the Carlton and Granada pay-TV joint venture which is to be rebranded ITV Digital, and ITV.com, which is set to launch later this year.

The ONdigital chief operating officer, Rob Fyfe, is stepping up to become managing director of ITV Digital.

Carlton and Granada are expecting the reorganisation of their ITV assets into three new divisions - ITV Channels, ITV Digital and ITV.com - to generate cost savings of £20m annually within two years.

"This is the most fundamental change in British broadcasting since the launch of multichannel television," said the Granada chairman, Charles Allen.

"Granada and Carlton have forged a new partnership in ITV and are now bringing together the tremendous brand strength of ITV with the UK's digital terrestrial broadcasting platform."

Michael Green, the chairman of Carlton, added: "ITV will now leapfrog the BBC and Sky with this new partnership.

"A combined free-to-air and pay-television audience of 50m viewers a week offered entertainment, the internet and ecommerce is a world first."

webTitle: Housing association home is no longer a hot property

fields.headline: Housing association home is no longer a hot property
fields.standfirst: The cost of buying a home and the stigma of social housing is seeing housing association properties lie empty. Matt Weaver reports.
fields.trailText: The cost of buying a home and the stigma of social housing is seeing housing association properties lie empty. Matt Weaver reports.
fields.body:
When Nigel Cook first became director of Home housing association's north-west region, the homes he managed were in big demand. By the time he took early retirement last year tenants were leaving in droves.

"When I first took the job in 1984 a set of keys for one of our properties were really prized. Now, to many, it is just another property," he said.

A major problem is that in many parts of the region, particularly in Cumbrian coastal towns, it is as cheap to buy a home as to rent one from a housing association.

During Mr Cook's tenure the combination of an increase in new cheap housing in the area, a competitive mortgage market and low interest rates made house buying an attractive financial option.

During the same period, renting social housing had become increasingly stigmatised. Those who could afford to move out of social housing did so, leaving only those out of work and on benefit in social housing.

"If the opportunity presents itself people will leave a home that they feel is not giving best value. They want to live in other areas because the neighbours are seen as 'nicer people'," Mr Cook said.

He added: "The average rent on our new build properties was about £60 a week, we just couldn't compete with the cost of owner occupation. Waiting lists for housing association properties were absolutely zilch, there's no demand."

It is not only Home housing association that has suffered problems in the area. In 1999, Allerdale council transferred its homes to Derwent and Solway - a new housing association.

Since then the association has been struggling to meet its business plan because it underestimated the number of homes that would be empty and therefore not generating income. The association has now taken the unprecedented step of trying to encourage right to buy sales.

Usually, right to buy sales are considered a financial problem for stock transfer housing associations because landlords are not compensated for the huge discounts available.

But if the homes would otherwise be empty, housing associations will take any money they can get. However, Derwent and Solway acting director David Cumberland points out that the policy also helps stabilise communities.

"We want to see a steady flow of purchases," said Mr Cumberland. "It will mean that people will stay on the estates rather than move out of the area. We want to see a diversification of ownership. There is not the need for the same proportion of social housing as there has been in the past."

The turnover rate of housing is seen by housing management as a key indication of the popularity of homes. High turnover is also a key sign of an instability in communities.

In the mid 1980s, turnover was 3%. Now it is nearer to 15% in many of the Cumbrian coastal towns.

Graham Howarth, chief executive of Workington based Westfield housing association, said: "We set a target of 10% turnover, but it's bloody hard to keep to that."

His organisation is trying to reduce the stigma of renting from a housing association. The lettering on the association's repairs vans has been changed from "Westfield housing association" to "Westfield housing services". Mr Howarth said: "We are trying to disguise ourselves as private services."

"We try to do as much as we can, but it is probably not enough to keep people in. Some of the punters of our estates can purchase their property for £15,000 - there is no rent that we can charge to compete with that."

fields.headline: Germans gripe over green pact
fields.standfirst: A furore over an eco-tax on petrol reveals much about Germany's ambivalent attitude to the environmental cause, writes John Hooper
fields.trailText: A furore over an eco-tax on petrol reveals much about Germany's ambivalent attitude to the environmental cause, writes John Hooper.
fields.body:
It began with a headline that defied you not to read on. "Holidays only for the rich", screamed the tabloid Bild Zeitung. The point of the story underneath was a little more prosaic: the authorities on Mallorca were planning a new levy on visitors to help the island recover from some of the environmental damage wrought by tourism. The proposed tax would add about £35 to the average holiday for a family of four. That would scarcely put Mallorca into the Mustique class. But it has not stopped Bild from whipping up a campaign against the tax.

Last week, the paper published a letter to King Juan Carlos of Spain, which it urged its readers to cut out and send off to the palace in Madrid. The letter protested that Germans had done their best to keep the island tidy and insisted that they had a right to take part in the debate on Mallorca's "eco-tax". "Paella and Ballerman [a bar on the island which is popular with Germans] are almost as German as sauerbraten [marinaded beef] and Cologne Cathedral", declared the paper.

In fact, Mallorca's eco-tax is unlikely ever to come into effect. The whole affair has far more to do with Germany's politics than Spain's. Bild and the Christian Democrat movement which it broadly supports have for months now been railing against a different and altogether more onerous eco-tax: an additional, progressively increasing, levy on petrol which the Greens insisted on as a condition of joining Gerhard Schröder's coalition government.

Now, rising crude oil prices have combined with the eco-tax to push the cost of an average tank full of petrol to around DM100 [£32]. The result is a round of finger-pointing which said a lot, both about the present government and the voters who will choose next year whether to re-elect it. The immediate, if paradoxical, effect of the latest rise in pump prices has been to ease the pressure on the Greens. Mr Schröder's reaction was subtly to lay the responsibility at the door of the oil companies.

Last weekend, he voiced the fear that the increase could damage the economy and the hope that it would soon be reversed. But his central message was that there was nothing he could do about it. "If I could, I would", he said, implicitly signalling that the eco-tax was sacrosanct. As often happens with the Schröder administration, however, there was a member of the cabinet who had either not been told what the policy was - or had decided to ignore it.

Werner Müller, Mr Schröder's non-party economics minister, gave two interviews over the weekend which succeeded in upsetting both the motoring lobby and the Greens. He told hard-pressed car drivers that they did not have to fill up when prices were high, but also argued that the eco-tax should not continue to rise after 2003.

The oil companies have since brought the row full circle by reminding Mr Schröder that there is indeed something he can do - bring down taxes on petrol which, they said, were the highest in Europe. The affair has served as a warning to the chancellor of the downside attached to an alliance with the Greens, and to the Greens of the downside of being in government at all.

Germans give an impression to the rest of the world that they are keen environmentalists. And the appearance is not entirely deceptive. They will cheerfully submit to the chore of sorting their rubbish so that it can be recycled. They anguish over acid rain and climate change.

Yet, as a recent "mini-census" by the federal statistics office showed, large numbers of them baulk at anything that will interfere with their use of a private car. It showed that, the Green's eco-tax notwithstanding, the proportion of commuters going to work by car was still rising. It had jumped from 60 to 64% in the past five years alone. "Even for brief, inner-city trips of less than 10 kilometres [six miles], 45% of commuters opted for their car", the study found.

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

The Ministry of Defence last night blocked a Ulster TV documentary in which an ex-soldier claims military chiefs knew he helped murder members of the security forces while working as an IRA double agent. P4
The Cambridge Footlights tour has been condemned by anti-smoking campaigners after accepting £25,000 sponsorship from British American Tobacco. P5
The Duchess of York has been signed up by ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald to report on obesity. P9
NTT DoCoMo has been forced to delay what would have been the world's first 3G mobile service launch in Japan in May. P24
Reuters sought to calm fears about its business yesterday despite a issuing a second quarter revenue growth warning. P24
Vivendi and News Corp are to merge their loss-making Italian pay-TV businesses, Telepiu and Stream. P24
Amazon cheered US stock market investors yesterday by announcing it was on track for its first quarterly operating profit by the year's end. P24

FINANCIAL TIMES

The government has embarked on a £30m advertising blitz in the run-up to the election, making it by far the UK's biggest advertiser. P2
Granada and Carlton could be allowed to cross-promote their pay-TV services on ITV for the first time by the ITC. P4
A look at the BBC's flexible staff benefits scheme. P15
The anti-posh movement in broadcasting is beginning to have a noticeable effect on programme content, says Christopher Dunkley. P20
Reuters faced a shareholder revolt yesterday over incoming chief executive Tom Glocer's share option package. P25
NTT DoCoMo has been forced to delay the launch of its 3G mobile service in Japan because of technical problems. P25&33
Express Newspapers and Hollinger have settled their financial row over jointly-owned printing plant Westferry. P28
Dan Wagner is understood to be planning to break up internet technology group Bright Station and step down from its board. P28
Sony expects to invest $500m in its mobile phone venture with Ericsson. P30
The FIA yesterday granted a 100-year extension of Formula One broadcasting and commercial rights to SLEC, the company controlled by Kirch and EM.TV. P30
Vivendi confirmed yesterday it is looking at buying sports marketing agency ISL. P30

THE INDEPENDENT

The Duchess of York will make her debut as a TV reporter in tomorrow night's Tonight with Trevor McDonald. P7
Channel 4 is putting £2m into creating inner city cricket pitches. P7
London will be the HQ for Sony and Ericsson's new mobile phone venture. P16
BT is set to be the first company in the world to launch a 3G mobile service after NTT DoCoMo yesterday delayed its Japanese 3G launch. P16
Vivendi and News Corp are to merge their loss-making Italian pay-TV businesses, Telepiu and Stream. P17
Reuters shares slid 7% yesterday after a second quarter sales growth warning. P19

Former Indy Washington correspondent Andrew Marshall on his dot.com meltdown experience at eCountries. Business Review P1

The BBC governors have admitted Newsnight was guilty of pro-Labour political bias in its coverage of Peter Mandelson's resignation. P2
The Duchess of York will make her debut as a British TV reporter tomorrow on ITV's Tonight with Trevor McDonald. P9
The craze for downloading pop tunes onto mobiles could be depriving the music industry of £700,000 a day in royalties. P13
EMI is on the verge of halting merger talks with German rival Bertelsmann. P31
New Reuters chief executive Tom Glocer is within a whisker of joining the 90% club of bosses whose internet investments have collapsed, before even joining the group. P31 Kirch yesterday pledged that Formula One motor racing would continue to be shown on free-to-air TV. P33 Japanese mobile operator NTT DoCoMo yesterday delayed the launch of its 3G service for four months. P36 Ericsson and Sony are to merge their mobile handset businesses. P37
The future of Go Racing's £320m horseracing media rights deal faces a fresh crisis over concerns it could cost the sport hundreds of millions in lost revenues. P39

THE TIMES

The BBC's complaints unit has concluded Panorama wrongly accused Peter Mandelson of giving the programme misleading answers about the Hinduja affair. P2
Revenues from 3G mobile services across Europe in 2005 will barely cover the cost of a single UK licence, according to a new report from Jupiter MMXI. P25 Amazon said yesterday it is on track for its first operating profit by Christmas. P26 Reuters lost more than 6% of its stock market value yesterday despite reporting strong revenue growth. P27 Mobile phone operators try to make 3G numbers add up. P29

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

Disney has posted a second quarter loss reflecting the $1bn one-off cost of closing its go.com portal and some stores. P4
Amazon reported a 22% increase in sales and narrower than expected loss in the first quarter. P4
Viacom reported revenue and cash flow figures that beat analysts expectations, despite a first quarter loss due to the cost of acquiring CBS. P4
Vivendi and News Corp are to merge their Italian pay-TV businesses, Telepiu and Stream. P7
Profile of a dot.com survivor, Sticky Content founder Catherine Toole. P23
NTT DoCoMo has delayed the launch of its Japanese 3G mobile service. P23
Excite@home has named Patti Hart as its new chairman and chief executive. P25
Sony and Ericsson are merging their mobile handset divisions. P25

DAILY STAR

The Big Brother house is to have a nookie annex for its second series. P19

THE MIRROR

Film critic Barry Norman is quitting TV after 29 years because he's fed up watching films based on comic books. P15 The Duchess of York is to report on obesity for Sir Trevor McDonald's Tonight show. P18

THE SUN

The Duchess of York dubs herself frumpy Fergie in her new ITV current affairs reporter job. P12

DAILY MAIL

The Duchess of York has been signed up as a reporter on IT's Tonight with Trevor McDonald. P23

DAILY EXPRESS

Workers at Disney received shattering news yesterday with news of major cutbacks in the feature animation department. P15
A £1m prize may be offered to the winner of the second Big Brother. P22
BBC governors have rejected complaints that Anne Robinson's remarks about the Welsh on Room 101 were racist. P22

AND FINALLY...

The Independent reports on page three that it bought a porcelain figure of a peasant girl for £120 in yesterday's auction of disgraced former Tory minister Jonathan Aitken's property and is offering it to the highest bidder via auction@independent.co.uk. Now that's what we call a reader offer...

webTitle: Blair's CD ploy to reclaim streets

fields.headline: Blair's CD ploy to reclaim streets
fields.standfirst:
At-risk teenagers offered vouchers to stay out of trouble in move to cut squalor

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday launched an ambitious campaign to reclaim derelict "public space" from graffiti, litter and vandalism in order to restore the "liveability" factor to down-at-heel neighbourhoods in Britain's inner cities, towns and former industrial villages.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday launched an ambitious campaign to reclaim derelict "public space" from graffiti, litter and vandalism in order to restore the "liveability" factor to down-at-heel neighbourhoods in Britain's inner cities, towns and former industrial villages.

To dramatise his appeal Mr Blair promised CD or clothing vouchers to at-risk teenagers who stay out of trouble and "community pay-back" reparation orders which would require graffiti artists and bus shelter vandals to repair the damage they do to their own communities.

"Young offenders take something out of society through their offending. This scheme will allow them to put something back," said Mr Blair.

He later visited the Bell Green estate in Sydenham, south-east London, to watch youngsters using high-powered hoses to remove graffiti they had sprayed on walls. He shook hands and wished them "good luck". In unveiling a package of cash and measures to improve blighted communities the prime minister consciously invoked the quality of life agenda adopted by major European and North American cities - from Stockholm to Chicago - as well as the economic guru, JK Galbraith's famous warning that public squalor can undermine the benefits of private affluence. "Rundown and demoralised public services reduce people's quality of life, even though they may be getting richer. They are better off as consumers, but worse off as citizens," said Mr Blair.

Mr Blair's speech was made to a conference of community activists organised in Croydon by Groundwork, a network of trusts launched in Liverpool after the 1981 riots to bring local authorities together with business and local people to regenerate neighbourhoods.

In a package which mixed the carrot of extra funds and powers with the stick of "community payback" orders imposed on young offenders - as well as clothes, computer, travel or music vouchers for those who stay out of trouble - Mr Blair went beyond last year's attacks on "yob culture".

In the potentially most significant part of yesterday's initiative, the prime minister said that Labour, if re-elected, would legislate to create business improvement districts on the American model, which encourages local authorities to draw up contracts with local business to provide additional services and improvements in return for an extra business rate.

webTitle: Peers strengthen NHS watchdog in defeat for Labour

fields.headline: Peers strengthen NHS watchdog in defeat for Labour
fields.trailText: The government was defeated in the Lords last night when Conservative and Liberal Democrat peers joined forces to strengthen the power of patient watchdogs in the NHS.
fields.body:
The government was defeated in the Lords last night when Conservative and Liberal Democrat peers joined forces to strengthen the power of patient watchdogs in the NHS.

Alan Milburn had planned to scrap the independent community health councils that since 1974 have provided an avenue for aggrieved patients to seek redress. After protests from Labour backbenchers in the Commons he agreed to set up patient councils in every health trust.

But last night Lord Howe, the Tory health spokesman in the Lords, successfully moved that the proposed watchdogs did not have enough teeth.

The government was defeated by 162-121 during the report stage of the health and social care bill on an amendment that would allow patient councils to keep all the key whistleblowing powers exercised by the CHCs. This would include the authority to refer contested decisions directly to the secretary of state.

Lord Howe said the CHCs should be reformed, not "done away with". Where there were problems, these should be put right. "These proposals are not well thought through and are woolly and loose. In the end this is not a debate primarily about saving CHCs, it is about doing the best we can for patients."

The health minister, Lord Hunt, said the CHCs had not been successful in persuading the NHS to make improvements wanted by patients. "Because of that, we have decided not to reform them, as we might have done. We have decided to give them a wholesale overhaul," he said.

But the Liberal Democrat front bench spokesman, Lord Clement-Jones, said the proposals were "totally flawed ... CHCs are not all wonderful in their operations but they have, by and large, provided a pretty effective service over the years and to simply decide we are going to abolish them outright and put in place an unnecessary structure is extremely cavalier".

Donna Covey, director of the Association of Community Health Councils, said: "This is a victory for common sense ... The new clause allows for smooth transition from the old structures to the new."

But John Denham, health minister, said the government would be looking to overturn the defeat in the Commons. "The Lords amendment attempts to take patient influence away from the hospitals and primary care trusts that actually treat patients and to centre everything on remote committees.

"The bill has not yet completed its passage through parliament and we will be looking to restore the key elements of government policy," he said.

fields.headline: Army cannot cover for strike
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Fire chiefs have been refused emergency cover by the army during a strike next week because of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Fire chiefs have been refused emergency cover by the army during a strike next week because of the foot and mouth crisis.

The Ministry of Defence told the Berkshire service it would be unable to provide troops in Green Goddess tenders to replace civilian crews, who plan to walk out on Tuesday.

Mike Clement Green, Berkshire's chief fire officer, told 600 crew members, due to halt work for seven hours from 9am on May 1, that lives could be put at risk.

fields.headline: Knocked down by the girl on a motorbike
fields.trailText: The Commons devoted much of yesterday afternoon to name-calling. It began with President George Bush. Labour MP Nigel Griffiths called him "the toxic Texan".
fields.body:
The Commons devoted much of yesterday afternoon to name-calling. It began with President George Bush. Labour MP Nigel Griffiths was furious about his refusal to support the Kyoto pact on alleged man-made global warming. He called him "the toxic Texan".

Then Jane Griffiths, no relation, described the US president as "the fool on Capitol Hill", though it's Congress which lives there. Foolish woman.

John Prescott, answering environment questions, was hardly likely to reprove them. The deputy prime minister, who last week went to New York purely, so far as one can judge, to hold a photo op on a subway train, believes that he alone is responsible for saving the planet through his statecraft at Kyoto. So he must regard Dubya rather in the way a man who has spent years building the Taj Mahal out of matchsticks would regard the yob who has just stomped all over it.

But he took out his spleen on poor David Rendel, a tall sombre Lib Dem who asks quite reasonable questions. So Mr Prescott accused him and his party of "piddling on the side".

"Piddling on the side"? Mr Rendel is an old Etonian. He does not piddle. At the age of six, I expect Mr Rendel asked his parents in the car, "when are we going to stop? I need to micturate."

Then Gerald Howarth asked another sensible question, about flashing bicycle lamps, which are more visible than the other kind. His reward was from the ineffable Denis MacShane, who said to loud cheers, "All Tory cyclists are known flashers, as the minister knows!"

Surely the level of wit could not sink lower. But when the house gets into one of these moods, it's like a limbo dancing contest.

Hazel Blears announced proudly that she was "chair" (or perhaps "pillion") of the all-party motorcycle group. Motorcycles, she said, should be immune from congestion charges in city centres.

Keith Hill, the junior transport minister, bounced up merrily from the bench. He is a kindly man, full of common sense, good humour and merry banter. I would not have wished for the fate that awaited him. "I am extremely grateful for that intervention from my Hon Friend Blears the Bike!" he said with relish.

There was a pause, and then the place collapsed. Did he not know what the term means, when used about a woman? Did he have any idea how offensive he had been? Ms Blears went red, but managed to laugh. Some Tories were literally rolling about, barely capable of motor coordination. Michael Fabricant was still rocking and snorting 10 minutes later.

(Thanks to thoughtful reader Tony McSean, who snapped a window in France advertising a door and window service. The company not only makes the stuff but also fits it, hence the sign: "Fabricant. Poseur.")

Meanwhile, we had a chance to hear from Hilary Armstrong, the junior minister who, I suspect, has been given the job to make her boss sound good. Here was her answer to one question: "We will get on with doing things. We will do them along with people, and that is why we will consult and then we will have the legislation that is appropriate in order to bring in the changes that are necessary." So that's why New Labour is in office.

A moment later she announced that "local authorities have the discretion to operate discretion ... we are concerned that local authorities are able to act in the interests of those who they are responsible for, and that is why we have in England been moving on the local authority agenda..."

Mr Prescott sat nodding, as if it all made perfect sense. Which no doubt to him it did.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: the absurdity of politicians

fields.headline: It's no joke to see politicians act with foolish disregard
fields.standfirst: Labour pig-headedness is fodder for satirists and puts voters off
fields.trailText: Politicians, like vicars, are inherently funny. What politicians do to get elected, what they duck to avoid trouble is often absurd.
fields.body:
Politicians, like vicars, are inherently funny. What politicians do to get elected, what they duck to avoid trouble is often absurd. They have to say things they do not think and do things they hate. They must curry favour with obnoxious people and button their lip when any sane person would utter a rude riposte. In power they must pretend everything under their aegis is for the best in the best of all possible worlds. In opposition they make themselves equally ridiculous alleging that the nation is always on its knees.

What they say in public may bear slender relation to what they think in private - and yet breaking the omerta code is out of the question (on the record). Those who appear human - the Mo Mowlams, Ken Livingstones and Kenneth Clarkes - are mainly just more charming actors with a better knack for apparent sincerity. This does not make politicians villains, just professionals in a very tough trade.

But there is no riper material for satirists than the comedy of manners at Westminster. Only turn to Simon Hoggart for each day's delightful ongoing pantomime. Indeed only turn to Number 10's website for some sublime bons mots. Try "The prime minister's Passover message: Wishing you a happy and kosher Passover", signed with a personal flourish. Or maybe a soupçon of the PM's Diwali speech, (surprisingly not airbrushed): "Diwali aur naye saal mubarak - best wishes for a happy Diwali and New Year ... I was very struck, listening just now to Mr Hinduja talking to us, about how these values of common understanding and harmony and peace and working together stretch too across national boundaries..." And so on.

A political comedy, Feelgood by Alistair Beaton, which just opened in the West End, is set inside New Labour's inner sanctum in a hotel room at party conference time. It has the sort of irresistible and inventive funniness that would make even its chief victims, Alastair Campbell or Tony Blair, emit a belly laugh or two. Although peppered with political barbs - the leader "does not break promises, he just erodes them" - the fun resides in a brilliantly made old-fashioned farce where doors bang, people hide in lavatories and everything that can go wrong, does. It is Feydeau set not in the boudoir of a lady of ill repute, but in the conference suite of a party of ill repute, (as all parties always are).

Besides, it is a truth universally acknowledged that any party leading 14 % in the polls and destined for a second resounding victory must be in want of a good kicking. For lack of any effective opposition, who else is to check arrogance and hubris but the professional jesters and ego-deflators? The latest run of Bremner, Bird and Fortune has just come to an end on Channel 4: satire is always cleared off the airwaves well before an election. The two Johns' well-researched dialogues were often devastating in their demolition of fraudulent political reason ing. Bremner is a genius mimic, with some good conceits, such as the CCTV scenes between Blair and Campbell in their office. His Blair has become the Blair of national imagination.

To add to that sense that art and life are sometimes politically inextricable, yesterday the real PM made a big electioneering speech on yob culture that so closely mirrored the final, very funny prime ministerial speech in Feelgood, that the author can hardly have believed his ears. His leader (referred to by his team as DL for Divine Light or Dreadfully Lightweight), ends the play with a conference speech every word of which could come (or maybe did come?) from a real speech, including the rallying cry "The job culture, not the yob culture!" which surely Number 10 would have used yesterday if they'd thought of it. Well, Alistair Beaton is an former speech writer for Gordon Brown, so he knows how the dreadful rhythms of those toe-curling conference set-pieces do more to set the teeth on edge than rouse the rabble.

But cynicism, says the government gravely, is a dangerous modern disease. The press spews it out daily - after all, 70% of newspapers are not so much cynics as sworn enemies. We in the left of centre press are "critical friends", a tricky concept. (After all, friends are for support not criticism.) New Labour smiles wanly at the hailstorm of ever more savage jokes raining down upon them - and they wonder, as all politicians do, why no one loves them. This cynicism is corrosive, they fear. It suggests "They're all the same", and "Nothing works", plus ça change, why bother?

In truth, the perpetual harping on about the government as if it were uniquely venal and immoral began to pall a bit by the end of the Bremner run. The programme's grapeshot often went wide, Bremner's skilful impressions masking some pretty thought-free scripts. The perpetual this-government-stinks mode began to whine monotonously. After all, if everything New Labour does is self-serving balderdash designed to hold on to their red boxes and Rovers, then there is no particular pith or punch in attacks on the things they deserve a drubbing for. And why the narrow range?

Mark Thomas has delivered very funny body blows against far harder and more interesting targets - Export Credit Guarantees, inheritance tax avoiders, fat cats of all kinds stunned to be challenged in the flesh. There is an intellectual idleness about just popping away at politicians for being opportunistically two-faced, (or three-faced if you count the third way). It is in their job-description to try too hard to please while fail ing to live up to their own high rhetoric. There is not much sleaze in this government, but there is always comic potential in a dissonance between politicians' public and private personae. It is also the fate of progressive governments to disappoint. They never reach Jerusalem, not next year, not ever, but at least it is on the itinerary, while the right only yearns for yesterday.

The government may feel aggrieved about unwarranted popular cynicism, but the question is whether Labour really takes the problem seriously enough. They should peruse the Bremner tapes, go to see Feelgood, inhale the aroma of disappointment and worry harder about very large numbers who may not vote this time. (Why give a huge win to a party bound to win anyway?) It is these voters Tony Blair needs to convince, but attacks on yob culture look cynical. Pushing ahead with the universally condemned tube public-private partnership is incomprehensible: a paean of praise for developing a stronger, better public sector would clear the air. Come clean and start to boast about the redistribution done so far, with a promise of more to come. Voter cynicism is fuelled not only by the nihilism of the press and entertainers having fun - but also by Labour pig-headedness on some totemic issues. Too many people may vote for nothing unless they get something stirring to vote for. Meanwhile, good jokes cost votes.

We in the left of centre press are "critical friends", a tricky concept. (After all, friends are for support not criticism.) New Labour smiles wanly at the hailstorm of ever more savage jokes raining down upon them - and they wonder, as all politicians do, why no one loves them. This cynicism is corrosive, they fear. It suggests "They're all the same", and "Nothing works", plus ça change, why bother? In truth, the perpetual harping on about the government as if it were uniquely venal and immoral began to pall a bit by the end of the Bremner run. The programme's grapeshot often went wide, Bremner's skilful impressions masking some pretty thought-free scripts. The perpetual this-government-stinks mode began to whine monotonously. After all, if everything New Labour does is self-serving balderdash designed to hold on to their red boxes and Rovers, then there is no particular pith or punch in attacks on the things they deserve a drubbing for. And why the narrow range? Mark Thomas has delivered very funny body blows against far harder and more interesting targets - Export Credit Guarantees, inheritance tax avoiders, fat cats of all kinds stunned to be challenged in the flesh. There is an intellectual idleness about just popping away at politicians for being opportunistically two-faced, (or three-faced if you count the third way). It is in their job-description to try too hard to please while fail ing to live up to their own high rhetoric. There is not much sleaze in this government, but there is always comic potential in a dissonance between politicians' public and private personae. It is also the fate of progressive governments to disappoint. They never reach Jerusalem, not next year, not ever, but at least it is on the itinerary, while the right only yearns for yesterday. The government may feel aggrieved about unwarranted popular cynicism, but the question is whether Labour really takes the problem seriously enough. They should peruse the Bremner tapes, go to see Feelgood, inhale the aroma of disappointment and worry harder about very large numbers who may not vote this time. (Why give a huge win to a party bound to win anyway?) It is these voters Tony Blair needs to convince, but attacks on yob culture look cynical. Pushing ahead with the universally condemned tube public-private partnership is incomprehensible: a paean of praise for developing a stronger, better public sector would clear the air. Come clean and start to boast about the redistribution done so far, with a promise of more to come. Voter cynicism is fuelled not only by the nihilism of the press and entertainers having fun - but also by Labour pig-headedness on some totemic issues. Too many people may vote for nothing unless they get something stirring to vote for. Meanwhile, good jokes cost votes. polly.toynbee@theguardian.com

webTitle: Tories claim MMR vaccine policy risks lives

fields.headline: Vaccine policy risks lives, claim Tories
fields.standfirst: Fox attacks refusal to fund single measles jabs as inoculation falls
fields.trailText: The Conservatives launched a stinging attack on the government yesterday, accusing it of endangering the lives of young children by refusing to fund single doses of measles vaccination.
fields.body:
The Conservatives launched a stinging attack on the government yesterday, accusing it of endangering the lives of young children by refusing to fund single doses of measles vaccination.

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said that children would die and would be left disabled because of the government's insistence that children must have the combined MMR vaccination for measles, mumps and rubella.

Inoculation rates have fallen sharply in recent months because of parental fears that the MMR vaccine could be linked to bowel disease and autism in certain susceptible children. Some parents have resorted to taking their children to France for a single dose measles vaccine.

Dr Fox, a former GP, said yesterday that a Tory government would fund single dose vaccines to increase the inoculation rate. "We will be less doctrinaire and more pragmatic," he said. "Otherwise children are going to die and are going to be disabled. That is not an acceptable price for an absolutist political position. If inoculation rates continue to fall, as they have been, we would have to see whether we should make single dose vaccines available in certain areas to certain groups to get inncolulation rates up," the shadow health secretary said.

"A single dose vaccine is not as good as the MMR - it therefore only has a place where you have no alternative to raise inoculation rates. What we cannot do is say that irrespective of inoculation rates we will not re-evaluate the policy."

Dr Fox's intervention, which was condemned by the government last night as "irresponsible", comes in the wake of a dramatic fall in the MMR inoculation rates. Vaccination rates have dropped to 75% in some areas - notably parts of London - which is well below the 95% rate recommended by the World Health Organisation to stave off outbreaks.

The Department of Health launched a £3m campaign earlier this year to persuade parents that the MMR vaccination is the safest way of protecting their children. The MMR jab is given to babies at 18 months and is followed by a pre-school booster.

The controversy resurfaced in January when Andrew Wakefield, a consultant gastroenterologist who raised questions about the MMR jab in 1998, questioned the clinical trials which assessed the safety of the vaccine before it was introduced in Britain in 1988.

Dr Wakefield's concerns have been dismissed by the government as "bad science".

The government last night reacted furiously to Dr Fox's intervention. A Department of Health source said that doctors were free to provide single dose vaccines, although resources are directed towards funding the MMR jab.

"It is a great shame that Liam Fox has decided to turn what is a difficult decision for many parents into a party political football," the source said. "The key thing is that MMR is the safest vaccine."

Dr Fox also rounded on the government for failing to tackle the threat posed by HIV. He warned that the government's "failure" to give priority to HIV would place Britain "smack bang on course for a large epidemic. HIV should be given more priority than telling people to eat vegetables", he said.

webTitle: Shift to right as Tory attacks green tax

fields.headline: Shift to right as Tory attacks green tax
fields.standfirst: Special report: green living
fields.trailText: The Tories are to end their support for green taxes in a victory for the rightwing of the party.
fields.body:
The Tories are to end their support for green taxes in a victory for the rightwing of the party.

Oliver Letwin, shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, has repudiated the decision of John Gummer, former Tory environment secretary, to introduce Britain's first green tax in 1994. He also pledged the party to fight any new green taxes introduced by a future Labour government.

Mr Letwin chose a Commons debate on the budget announcing introduction of a new £1.60 a tonne aggregate tax on sand and gravel to signal the change.

During the debate the shadow cabinet minister attacked the new tax, which he said would cost up to 10,000 jobs in quarries, and repudiated his Tory predecessors for introducing the £1bn landfill tax on waste companies.

He told MPs: "I was not in parliament to vote for the landfill tax and I would not have voted for it if I had been."

Mr Letwin said he was against the government using green taxes to raise revenue for the exchequer.

His views counter efforts made by the Tory environment team under Damian Green and Archie Norman, who have attempted to move to "greener" policies to attract new voters.

The Tories are strongly committed to recycling and unlike Labour believe that there should be a moratorium on the building of new incinerators. However, their withdrawal of support for green taxation puts them closer to the new Bush administration in the US.

Stephen Timms, chief secretary to the Treasury, said yesterday: "We are witnessing a significant change in the Conservatives' position on environmental taxation. Most people believe that the landfill tax has been a success."

The Tory policy is also at odds with some big waste disposal companies who support the landfill tax and have even argued for a much higher levy to speed up recycling and reduce the need for using dumps..

webTitle: Nothing to lose but their G-strings

fields.headline: Nothing to lose but their G-strings
fields.trailText: Australia's topless dancers are forming a trade union   to prevent unscrupulous punters and employers   stripping them of their rights.
fields.body:
Australia's topless dancers are forming a trade union to prevent unscrupulous punters and employers stripping them of their rights.

Mystical Melody, a spokesperson for the new organisation, Striptease Artists Australia (SAA), said that it would work to improve the pay and conditions of thousands of women who work as strippers, lapdancers and topless waitresses down under.

The union will press for a more explicit pricing scale for performances, linking pay to how much flesh is put on display. A key concern, said Ms Melody, was to establish different rates for semi-nude and fully-nude performers, as well as to obtain proper remuneration for dancers' more explicit shows.

The length of the performance should also be taken into account when paying workers, she added. Ms Melody revealed that she and a group of fellow erotic dancers were forced to form their own body after existing groups failed to address the concerns of workers in an industry historically tarred by links to organised crime and drugs.

"So far no other organisation wishes to associate with the nature of the striptease industry," she said. Once the SAA is successfully registered and recognised by the Industrial Relations Commission, Ms Melody said she hoped the union could also help provide better professional development for the thousands of erotic performers who work in bars, clubs and pubs across Australia.

"Adult entertainment" and prostitution is a relatively recent phenomenon in Australia. Such practices were unknown to Aboriginal people, but arrived with the first convict ships carrying white settlers from England in 1788.

The shortage of women on the island - the putative colony had a ratio of six men to one woman until the 1820s - helped stimulate the sex industry, which has continued to flourish despite draconian laws in some states.

Prostitution remains illegal in Western Australia. The state authorities also outlaw the practice of throwing money at barmaids to incite them to strip, a tradition in pubs around the notorious goldfields of Kalgoorlie, a well-established centre of erotic activity which has titillated the large and isolated mining workforce for decades.

webTitle: TB outbreaks highlight the health gap among Britain's ethnic groups

fields.headline: A healthy colour
fields.standfirst: Recent TB outbreaks in schools have highlighted the health gap among Britain's ethnic groups.  Andrea Smith examines why the treatment of contagious diseases is such a sensitive issue
fields.trailText: Recent TB outbreaks in schools have highlighted the health gap among Britain's ethnic groups. Andrea Smith examines why the treatment of contagious diseases is such a sensitive issue.
fields.body:
When a tuberculosis notification lands on the desk of Surinder Bakhshi, the first thing the doctor wants to know is the patient's race.

"When I get a lab report through on a TB case, I first check which ethnic community it has occurred in. If it is in a community where I would not expect it, that worries me," says Bakhshi, a consultant in communicable disease control.

For while TB can infect any race, it is one of several illnesses, including coronary heart disease and sickle cell anaemia, that show dramatic variations in incidence depending on ethnic group.

In Birmingham in 1999 people of Afro-Caribbean origin were five times more likely to suffer from TB than the indigenous white population. The rate was 20 times greater among people of Indian descent and 26 times higher among people of Pakistani origin.

Leicester - one of the most ethnically diverse cities in the UK - had a TB rate that was four times the national average even before the current outbreak at Crown Hills Community College; last week numbers linked to this outbreak climbed to 50. The rate of coronary heart disease in Bradford among people of Bangladeshi origin is 30% above the national average for women, and 75% higher for men.

Discussion about the reasons for these variations can be difficult. It seems that just as party leaders Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy have agreed not to play the "race card" in the coming general election, so some healthcare professionals are cautious of spelling out how someone's ethnicity can affect personal health.

Yet healthcare planners do take these factors into account in devising services. Earlier this year Leicester Royal Infirmary announced that it would build a £1.8m infectious diseases wing. It will take cases of TB, drug-resistant diseases and tropical fevers such as malaria.

Malaria is not contagious but it can be confused with fevers that are, and it is being seen more frequently in Leicester's health centres. The reason is straightforward: many of the city's residents visit malarious areas and have visitors from these regions.

The factors behind TB are more complex and disputed. It is a disease that can lie latent in someone's body for their entire life and develops to an infectious stage only in a minority of cases. What causes this transition has been described as the "holy grail" of TB research by Mike Barer, professor of clinical epidemiology at Leicester University.

At the turn of the 19th century, TB was rife in London and New York, but vaccination and effective treatment appears to have led to its decline in the first 40 years of the 20th century. However, since 1987 its incidence has risen by 34%. The public health laboratory service attributes this increase in part to immigrants moving to Britain from countries that have a high prevalence of the disease. But making a link between immigration and disease can be contentious.

Elizabeth Anionwu, head of the Mary Seacole centre for nursing practice at Thames Valley University, says: "Like many people, I get very hot under the collar when people start talking about ethnic groups 'bringing disease' into this country.

"It is not because of their background that certain groups of the population are [sicker]. It's because of language issues, institutional racism within the health service or a lack of awareness of services."

East London and the City health authority has the highest incidence of TB in the country and almost half the people in its area are from ethnic minorities. Its view is that its high TB rates are not primarily explained by immigrants bringing the disease into the UK.

A study by the authority found that less than a third of TB cases in east London occurred among people who had lived locally for less than five years and it concluded that poverty, homelessness and deprivation were major factors in both established and new communities in its area. The authority believes that these factors could weaken someone's immune system, causing them to develop the disease if they were already infected, or encourage its transmission.

John Nicholson, chief executive of the UK Public Health Association, says: "Certainly in this country the proportion of people from ethnic minorities in a community is closely correlated with socio-economic factors such as poor housing which will affect illnesses ranging from TB to coronary heart disease."

Daisy Choudhury, a community development officer who works for the Bangladeshi welfare association in Burnley and has witnessed the link between unemployment, low income and health, says: "Bangladeshis used to work in the mills and factories in Burnley. When these closed down, most of the men became unemployed. Slowly people's health got worse with coronary heart disease, cancer, kidney failure, high blood pressure and diabetes."

She started an allotment club for Bangladeshis so that they could have access to affordable, fresh vegetables and get exercise. The club is women-only because of cultural objections to men and women working together if they are not related.

Choudhury adds: "I did this for Bangladeshi women. The men still go shopping and go into town, but the women don't go out for a walk. They don't go out for anything. It's good for them to have the exercise."

But Bakhshi disagrees that deprivation is a factor among ethnic minority communities in the case of TB. He says research that he and colleagues conducted disentangled the effects of poverty and ethnicity on TB rates and found that it did not have a significant bearing on the incidence of the disease in Asian groups.

He says: "Some people are very wary of talking about the particular health needs of different ethnic communities. If we are wary, how will we overcome the disease?

"I am Asian. I am Indian. I'm not afraid to talk about it. I want Asian people to understand that if they have a cough that has lasted a couple of weeks, it could be far more significant than if a white person has a cough. It could be TB and they might be giving it to their grandchildren.

"TB is always going to be higher among people who have come from countries where it is prevalent and we must take steps to contain it. There is no shame and no embarrassment about it. TB is easy to manage and easy to treat, but if we are so sensitive about it that we don't talk about it, then that is immoral."

fields.headline: Scots defend extra spending
fields.trailText: Senior politicians north of the border yesterday defended higher public spending in key areas as pressure grew for a review of the Whitehall formula which gives Scotland more money than the English regions.
fields.body:
Senior politicians north of the border yesterday defended higher public spending in key areas as pressure grew for a review of the Whitehall formula which gives Scotland more money than the English regions.

With the government facing a backlash against suggestions from John Prescott and other ministers that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland could lose their favoured status after the election, the Scottish National Party - the main opposition in the Edinburgh parliament - said spending was higher for a variety of reasons outside the area of the formula.

It called for the parliament to be given new powers to raise money and take its own spending decisions outside the Whitehall financial straitjacket. At present, the Edinburgh parliament can only "vary" tax by up to 3p in the pound on the basic rate of income tax, raising at most around £700m, or 3%of the total budget.

Andrew Wilson, Scotland's shadow finance minister, said services such as education were often better because council tax levels were higher in Scotland, thus providing more cash for schools. Scotland was also committed to higher spending in other areas, such as water distribution, because - unlike England and Wales - it had chosen not to privatise some essential services and consequently needed more money from the public purse. Public spending per head in Scotland remains 23% above the English average, while Northern Ireland and Wales are 39% and 18% above respectively.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Prescott signalled that a forthcoming review of local government finance will include a detailed examination of funding throughout the UK. He said that the formula, devised by Lord (Joel) Barnett when he was Treasury chief secretary in the 1970s was certainly not "written in stone".

Yesterday a spokesman for the prime minister sought to play down the suggestion that the Barnett formula was to be revised radically. "Our spending plans have been agreed for the years until 2004 and that includes plans for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland." Mr Prescott's Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions said there were no plans "at present" to review the formula.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: The first contender for Stupid MP 2001 finally emerges. Hats off to David Lock, a junior minister in the lord chancellor's office who seems to model his manners on Derry Irvine.
fields.body:
 The first contender for Stupid MP 2001 finally emerges. Hats off to David Lock, a junior minister in the lord chancellor's office who seems to model his manners on Derry Irvine. Mr Lock dons the dunce cap for trying to scare For You, a free sheet distributed to 25,000 Midlands supermarket shoppers, into apologising for repeating a claim in Private Eye that he stopped campaigning for Kidderminster Hospital on joining the government.

Even if this were a monstrous libel, my colleague Marina Hyde asks him, why go for a free sheet while ignoring the Eye? "Private Eye is a small circulation publication. If you're implying that I'm taking action because they're the little people, that's nonsense. I'm a minister. I'm extremely busy. I don't take action against everyone who criticises me." We presume you'll be having a go at us? "It's easy to sit on the Diary making snide comments [doh! like I'd be here if it was hard], but I'm the one having to talk to people who come to my surgery in tears ..." fields.headline: Best in NHS is doing well says hospital survey team
fields.trailText: A premier division of 40 top NHS hospitals in Britain was named yesterday by an international firm of health care consultants.
fields.body:
A premier division of 40 top NHS hospitals in Britain was named yesterday by an international firm of health care consultants.

The company, CHKS, drew up the list using recent confidential data from NHS trusts which employ it to measure their performance against one another.

The 40 range from local hospitals in rural areas to big urban teaching hospital trusts. Performance data was adjusted to take account of patients' different medical conditions and circumstances.

For 10 years CHKS has produced similar lists of 100 top hospitals in the US and for two years it has published a top 20 for Spain. This was the first attempt to draw up a table of excellence for Britain.

Graham Harries, the company's chief executive, said the results were not a league table. The top 40 could not be ranked in order of excellence and was not an exclusive list of all the high quality hospitals. The company measures performance in 115 NHS trusts - nearly half the total. About 75 of them volunteered for this exercise.

Mr Harries said: "This is not about success or failure but about celebrating the good in the NHS. Our staff work with these hospitals day in, day out, and we know they welcome the way we measure their performance so that they can improve where there are signs of weakness. What all the top 40 hospitals have achieved is a high level of performance across all the indicators, and that demonstrates to us and to their local residents that their hospitals are well managed and focused on the needs of their patients."

The hospitals were measured against 13 criteria including mortality rates, adjusted to take account of variations in the types of illness in each hospital's case load.

Other measures included readmission rates, the time taken to discharge stroke and hip patients, length of stay in hospital and the proportion of patients waiting less than six months. Figures were based on performance last year and were more up to date than government performance tables.

"For the first time we have a group of hospitals across the UK which has passed a series of rigorous tests that they themselves volunteered for... We applaud their openness and determination to provide the very best services to patients," Mr Harries said.

Asked what benefits the findings would have for patients, he said: "I think they will be able to have more confidence in the way they would approach their hospitals if they have to go into them.

"It's clearly important to make statements about things that are wrong but, on occasions, it's very positive to dwell on the things we do well."

He added: "All the participating hospitals have taken a step forward. They have been willing to be compared and bold enough to start improving. They will be better informed by having data and information to use."

An average week at all the top 40 hospitals included 50,000 patient admissions, of which 17,000 were emergencies. A total of 2,300 children were born, 190 hips replaced, 130 heart bypasses carried out and one heart transplant operation performed.

fields.headline: Labour's NHS power shift
fields.standfirst:
 Health authorities slashed from 99 to 30
 More cash for frontline staff
 More say for doctors
fields.trailText:
 Health authorities slashed from 99 to 30
 More cash for frontline staff
 More say for doctors
fields.body:
A massive cutback in NHS bureaucracy and a switch of resources to frontline staff, giving more power to disgruntled GPs and consultants, is to be unveiled today as the keynote of Labour's second-term plans for health.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will present the reforms as "shifting the centre of gravity in the NHS from Whitehall to frontline services". The changes will "liberate local services," he will claim.

Speaking in advance of a speech to launch the NHS Modernisation Agency, Mr Milburn said: "Public service reform, whether it is in health, education [or] local government, has got to be the driving force of any Labour second term. There is a huge amount of catching up to do in the reform of the public services, including the NHS."

He will announce plans to cut the number of health authorities in England from 99 to 30, as well as abolish the current 10 regional offices.

Financial muscle in the health service will pass to local primary care trusts which will decide how much money to divide between GP surgeries, local hospitals and other local services. By 2004, the trusts will be responsible for allocating 75% of an NHS budget that will have increased to £57bn.

The new approach may appeal to hospital managers and doctors who have become increasingly frustrated over the past four years by growing control from the centre. Mr Milburn will say the time has come for more authority to pass to the front line.

He said it was not surprising that the British Medical Association had criticised the government. It was doing its job as a trade union during the first big renegotiation of the doctors' contract for 50 years. But reform would go ahead and the doctors would feel the benefit of being freed from the frustrations they were feeling.

He said the new-style merged health authorities would no longer have hands-on responsibility for allocating money. "Local services will be controlled much more by local front staff in the primary care trusts and NHS trusts". The new health authorities will hold the system to account.

The merger of English health authorities will be implemented by 2004. Regional offices will be abolished by the end of the next parliament, although regional directors with small staffs will continue to oversee local performance.

Mr Milburn predicted that he would be able to cut the number of staff in the regional offices from 1,000 to 500. The merger and changed role of the health authorities would also see staff cutbacks, he said.

He wants to reduce the size of the Department of Health in Whitehall and focus its role on monitoring the delivery of policy, progress-chasing and ending bottlenecks.

He will also confirm the abolition of the NHS executive.

The aim he said will be to ensure that 75% of the£57bn NHS budget in 2003-4 will be handled by local primary care trusts. In 1997 the proportion of the budget controlled by GP fundholders was 15%. He compared the drive to devolve budgets to local health services to the shift in the control of resources to schools from local education authorities.

"The reduction in bureaucracy is designed to give more control to primary care groups to purchase services from local NHS trusts. The chief executives of the trusts have complained about day-to-day interference so they cannot get on with the job of delivering the NHS plan. The new flatter structure is going to liberate local services.

"In too many cases the local health authorities have been refusing to let go of the purse strings, and in some cases they have refused to let go of the contents of the purses. Not surprisingly, some doctors and nurses have felt disempowered by that process. That cannot go on.

"Inevitably the NHS plan was centrally driven, but if we are going to deliver radical public services reform and ask NHS staff to be ambassadors for better public service, frontline staff have to be the architects of change," the health secretary said.

He will also announce a shake-up of cancer services so that leading doctors and nurses are given control of cancer budgets spanning everything from prevention to treatment. He will invite bids from local clinicians. "Over time we can get to a position whereby cancer doctors and nurses are in control of the whole budget for NHS cancer care," he said.

He will announce that in the summer he will ask senior managers to work with local staff to identify obstacles to implementing the plan. The outcome will influence annual cash grants to hospital trusts and care groups next spring.

Mr Mllburn is taking a risk with his proposals since he is already facing a rebellion from doctors over their new contract, as well as from consultants on the amount of time they must devote to the NHS.

He admitted: "It is not surprising there is an element of change fatigue in the NHS. Nonetheless my message is that reform must happen."

He also claimed that a Labour general election victory will for the first time in decades give a centre-left party a mandate to tackle the legacy of public under-investment.

fields.headline: Poll shows 34% against royals
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The tide of republicanism has reached an all time high in Britain in the wake of the row over the Countess of Wessex's business links, with more than one in three voters saying that the country would be better off without the royal family.
fields.body:
The tide of republicanism has reached an all time high in Britain in the wake of the row over the Countess of Wessex's business links, with more than one in three voters saying that the country would be better off without the royal family.

The evidence for this steady rise in public hostility towards the monarchy is based on the results of a standard royal question repeated in regular Guardian/ICM polls during the past 14 years. They show that the republican-minded minority has grown from 13% in 1987 to a peak of 34% in this month's survey.

The detailed results of the poll show that Labour voters are now almost evenly split in their attitudes towards the royal family, with 39% saying Britain would be better off without them and 41% believing they should stay.

Support for the royal family has also staged a modest recovery in the past year, up from the all-time low of 44% recorded last time the question was asked - in June 2000 - to 51% now, suggesting that public opinion is again polarising on the issue. But Buckingham Palace is still a long way from reversing the spectacular slide in royal popularity since the mid-1990s, when consistently more than 70% of voters told the ICM pollsters that they believed Britain would be worse off without the royal family.

The results of this month's Guardian/ ICM poll also show that there is a clear two-thirds majority of voters who believe the royal family is in urgent need of modernisation and cannot just carry on as before.

At the same time most voters also want to see a tough line taken with members of the royal family who use their special status to further their private business interests. A clear 51% say they should be stripped of their royal status if they are shown to have acted in that way.

The findings will strengthen the hand of those urging Tony Blair to insist that the Countess of Wessex give up her public relations company after her admission that she had cashed in on her royal status. An official review of the guidelines on the royals' business interests, being conducted by the lord chamberlain, Lord Luce, is expected to be concluded before the end of the month.

The findings of the ICM poll will dismay palace advisers who had believed that their biggest enemy was a growing public indifference to the royal family, rather than a rise in outright republicanism.

They face a particular problem with the younger generation, as republican feelings are strongest amongst 18-24 year-olds, some 48% of whom say that the country would be better off without the royals, and only 40% of whom say that they want to keep the royals. Conservative and Liberal Democrat voters are more royalist than Labour supporters.

The last Guardian/ICM poll in which the "better off/worse off without the royal family" question was asked in June last year appeared to indicate a growing indifference to the monarchy. It showed 29% of voters saying they "didn't know" in response to the question whether they thought Britain would be better off or worse off without the royal family.

The row over the business interests of the Countess of Wessex appears to have once again polarised opinion about the royals. The "don't knows" have fallen from 29% to 16% and the anti-royalists have risen from 27% to 34%, suggesting that some of that growing indifference has translated into hostility, while the remainder has rallied to the royalist cause.

But the poll shows that an overwhelming majority of the public believe that there is a need for an urgent modernisation of the monarchy, and that, despite the efforts of the palace's "way ahead" group, its efforts to reinvent the royal family have still got a very long way to go in the public's mind.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,005 adults aged over 18 by telephone between April 20-22. The interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

It showed 29% of voters saying they "didn't know" in response to the question whether they thought Britain would be better off or worse off without the royal family. The row over the business interests of the Countess of Wessex appears to have once again polarised opinion about the royals. The "don't knows" have fallen from 29% to 16% and the anti-royalists have risen from 27% to 34%, suggesting that some of that growing indifference has translated into hostility, while the remainder has rallied to the royalist cause. But the poll shows that an overwhelming majority of the public believe that there is a need for an urgent modernisation of the monarchy, and that, despite the efforts of the palace's "way ahead" group, its efforts to reinvent the royal family have still got a very long way to go in the public's mind. ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,005 adults aged over 18 by telephone between April 20-22. The interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults. Useful link Latest ICM polls

webTitle: Poll says crime is key issue for older people

fields.headline: Crime is the key issue for older people, says poll
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Political parties need to do more to address older people's fear of crime if they are to secure their vote at the general election, according to an opinion poll published today by Help the Aged.
fields.body:
Political parties need to do more to address older people's fear of crime if they are to secure their vote at the general election, according to an opinion poll published today by Help the Aged.

The charity found crime was nearly twice as important as any other issue when older people on low incomes were asked to name the key priority for improvement in their area.

The survey by Mori found crime was the most pressing concern for 31% of the 504 over 65-year-olds living on less than £6,500 a year who were questioned. This compared with 17% citing money and pensions, 13% mentioning public transport and 9% saying health.

The survey found 55% believed that crime had increased over the past four years.

The same proportion said they were afraid of intruders entering their home and 61% were afraid of their home being burgled. Half were afraid to go out at night alone.

Women aged between 65 and 74 were the most afraid of crime, with 64% admitting to being scared of going out at night alone, while 34% of men of the same age said the same.

Mervyn Kohler, of Help the Aged, said: "Older people regularly raise crime as an important political issue, despite them being statistically less likely to be victims of crime.

"Their fear of crime is likely to stem from degradation of the community in which they live as much as from the threat of violence."

The charity appealed to the political parties to develop policies to help older people enjoy social activities instead of turning their homes into fortifications to keep out intruders.

Providing reliable and accessible public transport, better street lighting and visible policing would make a start in addressing these problems and boost the quality of life in local communities, Mr Kohler said.

The survey found older people in the north of England were more afraid of crime than those in the south, with 53% of northerners too afraid to go out alone at night compared to 49% of pensioners in the south and 48% in the midlands/eastern England region.

Mr Kohler said the results sent out a strong message to the parties that the concerns of older people could not be ignored.

Robert Worcester, chairman of Mori, said: "The over 55s have four times the political clout of the under 25s: there are twice as many of them and they are twice as likely to vote."

webTitle: Peers strengthen NHS watchdog in defeat for Labour

fields.headline: Peers strengthen NHS watchdog in defeat for Labour
fields.trailText: The government was defeated in the Lords last night when Conservative and Liberal Democrat peers joined forces to strengthen the power of patient watchdogs in the NHS.
fields.body:
The government was defeated in the Lords last night when Conservative and Liberal Democrat peers joined forces to strengthen the power of patient watchdogs in the NHS.

Alan Milburn had planned to scrap the independent community health councils that since 1974 have provided an avenue for aggrieved patients to seek redress. After protests from Labour backbenchers in the Commons he agreed to set up patient councils in every health trust.

But last night Lord Howe, the Tory health spokesman in the Lords, successfully moved that the proposed watchdogs did not have enough teeth.

The government was defeated by 162-121 during the report stage of the health and social care bill on an amendment that would allow patient councils to keep all the key whistleblowing powers exercised by the CHCs. This would include the authority to refer contested decisions directly to the secretary of state.

Lord Howe said the CHCs should be reformed, not "done away with". Where there were problems, these should be put right. "These proposals are not well thought through and are woolly and loose. In the end this is not a debate primarily about saving CHCs, it is about doing the best we can for patients."

The health minister, Lord Hunt, said the CHCs had not been successful in persuading the NHS to make improvements wanted by patients. "Because of that, we have decided not to reform them, as we might have done. We have decided to give them a wholesale overhaul," he said.

But the Liberal Democrat front bench spokesman, Lord Clement-Jones, said the proposals were "totally flawed ... CHCs are not all wonderful in their operations but they have, by and large, provided a pretty effective service over the years and to simply decide we are going to abolish them outright and put in place an unnecessary structure is extremely cavalier".

Donna Covey, director of the Association of Community Health Councils, said: "This is a victory for common sense ... The new clause allows for smooth transition from the old structures to the new."

But John Denham, health minister, said the government would be looking to overturn the defeat in the Commons. "The Lords amendment attempts to take patient influence away from the hospitals and primary care trusts that actually treat patients and to centre everything on remote committees.

"The bill has not yet completed its passage through parliament and we will be looking to restore the key elements of government policy," he said.
