fields.headline: Inequitable and unfair
fields.standfirst: UK's public spending must be reformed
fields.trailText: For years public service reformers in England have pointed to Scotland in support of their argument for higher public expenditure on health and education services. Why does Scotland have less private medicine than England?
fields.body:
The editor of the Berwick-upon-Tweed's local newspaper summed it up succinctly: "Berwick is out on a limb. We feel we won't get a fair deal from Westminster. Cross the border and you instantly see the difference." As our regional affairs editor reported yesterday, a small but growing number of people are doing more than noting the difference - they are crossing the border to gain access to better hospitals and schools.

For years public service reformers in England have pointed to Scotland in support of their argument for higher public expenditure on health and education services. Why does Scotland have less private medicine than England? Because access to good hospitals is so much easier. Why will Scotland be better able to ride the teacher shortage? Because it has recently concluded a three-year 23% pay rise for teachers that includes a 35-hour week, one third of which is reserved for class preparation and marking work.

How can Scotland afford these expenditures? Because under the current out-dated funding formula, it receives 23% more per head than the English average - with Wales getting 18% more and Northern Ireland, with its security problems, an extra 39%. England's deprived regions have been calling for a reform of the formula for years.

The formula was devised in the late 1970s by Joel (now Lord) Barnett, Labour's chief secretary at the Treasury when Scotland was considerably less well off than it is today. Even Lord Barnett believes it now needs reformulating. As he explained last year, it was "intended as a stopgap until a needs-based system came into operation. In fact no such change to take account of needs has been made". The Treasury select committee, which investigated the system in 1997, was even more scathing, criticising successive governments for not studying the appropriateness of the formula.

Ironically, if ever there was a government that should have reformed the system it is the current Labour government, with a prime minister and five cabinet ministers in the last four years drawn from the north-east. Devastated by de-industrialisation, no other region suffers quite so badly. The north-east may have the second highest unemployment rate and the highest proportion of people on welfare, but it still sees its richer neighbour, Scotland, receiving 16% more funds per head, even though it is 20% richer. But change is in the air.

Our regional affairs editor yesterday reported John Prescott, deputy prime minister, signalling that the review of local government finance in the new parliament would include a detailed examination of funding throughout the UK. There was some rowing back yesterday, but there should not be. There would be "blood on the carpet", but that is the only way reform could be pushed through. The reason why there has been no reform until now, lives on: the fear of provoking a tartan revolt and increasing support for the nationalist parties. But the mood among the ministers and Labour MPs representing England's depressed regions, has also changed.

The recently revised index of English regional deprivation shows how difficult it is to reach an agreed formula. Ideally, the needs-based analysis should be done by an independent board. Labour must produce a fairer and more equitable system. But it must also produce more public spending. A report from the Treasury earlier this month confirmed that in the first four years of the Blair government, public spending as a proportion of GDP was the lowest for 37 years. Don't rob Scotland and Wales: give England more.

fields.headline: Leave rights extended to 2.8m parents
fields.trailText: New rights to parental leave are to be extended to an extra 2.8m parents, ministers will announce today.
fields.body:
New rights to parental leave are to be extended to an extra 2.8m parents, ministers will announce today.

The move, which will be welcomed by trade unions and family campaigners, will almost treble those entitled to take up the right to 13 weeks' unpaid leave for parents of children under five.

It allows parents of children under five on December 15 1999, when the entitlement was introduced, to qualify for leave, as well as parents of children born or adopted after that date.

The extension will also give parents of disabled children the right to take a total of 18 weeks' leave at any point up to their child's 18th birthday. This is an extra five weeks and reflects the additional responsibilities of parents with disabled children. Some 360,000 families will benefit.

The changes will delight the TUC, which had taken legal action - represented by Cherie Booth - against the government over its implementation of a European directive on parental rights.

This month the employment commissioner, Anna Diamantopoulou, warned the government that the EU believed it had breached European law by confining the new right to parents of children born after the introduction date.

The DTI has in the past insisted that it would have a strong case in court. Sources denied that the concession was forced on the government by the court case, saying it was made as a point of principle after a long consultation and a green paper on parental leave. Unions had complained that the terms of the leave were too grudging. They are still keen to see paid leave, fearing that otherwise too few parents - particularly men - will take up the entitlement.

Paid leave, favoured by 1997-intake women MPs including Ruth Kelly, member for Bolton West, may be included in Labour's election manifesto.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is understood to favour new rights allowing women to return to work part time after having children. Ministers are still discussing the issue. Downing Street is anxious about the concession, amid concerns that businesses will mutiny against excess red tape.

But supporters of the change within governnment argue that it is precisely the kind of policy the government should offer if it is to put into practice its professed concern to redress the "work-life balance".

Research produced for the equal opportunities minister, Margaret Hodge, indicates that younger people are more enthusiastic than their older workers about moves to balance work and home life.

It found that 83% of under 35s felt everyone should be able to balance their work and home life in the way they wanted, while only 75% of the over-54s felt the same way.

 Tomorrow Tony Blair announces details of the baby bond that Labour has announced could go to each of the 700,000 children born annually in Britain.

It would be invested until the child turned 18, when it could be used to fund study, housing or a career.

fields.headline: Americans braced for Close Encounters
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The latest UK gameshow format to make the move across the Atlantic is Close Encounters, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The latest UK gameshow format to make the move across the Atlantic is Close Encounters, in which the contestants are secretly filmed and must then remember what they have been up to win a cash prize.

Close Encounters, which was created by UK format specialist The Chatterbox Partnership, has been bought by US cable channel USA Network.

In the show two contestants are secretly filmed for a week going about their everyday lives, which includes getting involved in situations set up by the Close Encounters production team.

The secret filming is then revealed to the participants, who can win cash prizes by correctly recalling what they have been doing in the previous week.

The Close Encounters format sale to USA Network is Chatterbox's first US format deal.

Chatterbox, which was set up by Ben Hall and Tom Ellemann, has created formats including It's a Small World, Pass the Buck and Whose House.

The Close Encounters deal was signed with Chris Sloan, the senior vice-president, reality programming and specials at USA Network.

USA Network is in discussion with potential production partners about making the show.

The format sale was brokered by the William Morris Agency.

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst: Stefano Hatfield reports on a new call to arms from the FCB Worldwide CEO, Brendan Ryan, at the American Association of Advertising Agencies annual gathering in Florida
fields.trailText: Stefano Hatfield reports on a new call to arms from an annual advertising gathering in Florida.
fields.body:
You know times are getting tough when US admen start talking about the need to demonstrate effectiveness and prove that advertising actually works.

"We too rarely talk about effectiveness in this business," said the chief executive of FCB Worldwide, Brendan Ryan, this past week. "We tend to speak about 'creativity'".

Ryan was speaking at the annual gathering of CEOs and other managers at the American Association of Advertising Agencies ("the 4As") in Naples, Florida, where the downturn was manifest in the lower turn-out - a little over 300 delegates instead of the 450 that attended last year in Bermuda.

This year's mood was pragmatic and chastened. How can we persuade clients of the value of advertising and stop them slashing advertising budgets?

The sub-text was that clients are beginning to view advertising as just another commodity, a raw material that can be bought entirely on price.

The passionate Ryan, incoming 4As president, is uniquely well-placed to address this subject. Last year FCB lost the $2.5bn Daimler-Chrysler account to BBDO in a winner-takes-all contest judged primarily on which agency could tender the cheaper price.

"Clients spend too much time worrying about what they pay us, rather than what we are [doing for them]," he argued. "It's concentrating on the last 10%. If what we do is grow sales profitably, why would you take your best weapon off the table at a time when you need it most?"

"Advertising is more and more being thought of as a luxury, he declared. "We have to restore the idea of the value that we provide".

It's hard to disagree with much of what he said. Ryan argued the need for "trusted methodologies to measure the effectiveness of an idea", encouraged agencies to tell their clients more when not to advertise, and called for advertising to become part of the marketing business courses at the country's top business schools.

All sensible stuff, but the extraordinary thing is that he still needs to be saying it.

The reality is that in boom times many, if not most, agencies do seem obsessed with creativity for creativity's sake. They appear to focus more on winning the plethora of advertising awards than demonstrating their work's effectiveness.

And, of course, there have been attempts to quantify the effectiveness of advertising ever since Lord Leverhulme's apocryphal comment, "I know that half my advertising budget is wasted, the trouble is I don't know which half".

Today there exist all kinds of econometric modelling systems that purport to demonstrate: spend "X" dollars here on "Y" media, and sales will increase by "Z".

If only life were that simple. One small problem with this theory is that in an era of media fragmentation, it is increasingly difficult to pummel consumers into submission with the weight of your media spend. Media plans have to be more creative and targeted.

A more fundamental problem is that creativity is not quantifiable. Who could place a value on "FCUK" or "Whassup?", "Just do it!" or "You've been Tango'd"? How could anyone possibly know in advance just what huge financial benefits would be the reward of following a creative hunch? No client will ever be able to know in advance, that yes, absolutely, a brand's advertising will work.

But the least the industry should have done years ago was to establish universally recognised tools and systems for measuring the effects of advertising on the consumer once a campaign is up and running. To this journalist it seems that every agency can prove that every one of its campaigns has worked on one level or another, so imagine how a cynical client, with real dollars at stake, must feel.

Advertising must guard its own image: in a downturn marketers will pounce on any signs of what they consider profligacy and extravagance. But, most of all, agencies have to persuade their own staff - particularly in the creative department - that they are not in the business to create art or win pencils, lions, arrows or any other awards, they are there to improve the image of their clients and grow their sales.

I feel strange even writing such words - it appears so obvious. But, sadly, they do really need to be said.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global

fields.body:
This is the first glimpse of the group of thirty-something women who have replaced the much-fancied Diet Coke man in the latest TV coke wars.

Coca-Cola has decided on a new Bridget Jones-style campaign for the diet drink because it thinks it will appeal to the British public.

The campaign is the first to be made specifically for the UK, using an all-British cast. Previous advertising has been imported from the US.

The adverts debut this Wednesday during Coronation Street and ER and will run throughout the summer.

One advert, "Call me", shows a woman who is asked for her phone number in a restaurant. Instead of playing it cool, she offers her suitor first her home number then her work number, pager, fax number, and finally her mother's telephone number.

"This is about showing contemporary British women being sexy and sassy," said a Coca-Cola spokeswoman.

"The ads are a humorous take on the things women do - like playing it cool when you fancy someone, or knowing how to turn on the charm when you need to."

The campaign was created by Wieden & Kennedy in London and directed by James Bobin, whose credits include Da Ali G Show and Fantasy Football.

The creatives were Tony Davidson and Kim Papworth and the production company was The Producers.

fields.headline: Channel 4 unleashes the Estate Agents
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 4 is to screen a six-part sitcom which pokes fun at the world of real estate, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is to screen a six-part sitcom which pokes fun at the world of real estate, called the Estate Agents.

The Estate Agents is the product of the comedy duo known as Electric Eel.

The programme is described by Channel 4's controller of entertainment, Kevin Lygo, as having "a touch of the Bottoms", a reference to the Rik Mayall/Adrian Edmundson comedy series which ended in the mid-90s.

Mr Lygo said the series would follow the "slightly South-Parky antics of three estate agents who are bastards and do what estate agents do."

The series, which will be shown in six half-hour episodes, came out of a successful sketch in Channel 4's Comedy Lab series.

Channel 4 will also screen six half-hour episodes of Los Dos Bros, another spin-off from the Comedy Lab, featuring comics Darren Boyd and Cavan Clerkin.

The Comedy Lab, which was launched three years ago by Channel 4, has already launched the career of several successful performers, including Trigger Happy TV's Dom Joly and Peter Kay.

fields.headline: D-day for Big Breakfast
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Channel 4 will axe the Big Breakfast on June 1 unless its producers can salvage the rapidly sinking show, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Channel 4 bosses will axe the Big Breakfast on June 1 unless producers at Planet 24 can salvage the rapidly sinking show.

Officially the programme has been given nine months by the Channel 4 programme director, Tim Gardam, but according to sources June 1 is decision day in the company's contract with the broadcaster.

Ratings for the show have sunk to just 300,000 following the departure of Johnny Vaughan and Denise van Outen and the show is now lurching from one crisis to the next.

Producer Richard Hopkins and presenter Paul Tonkinson were recently sacked and new chief Ben Rigden has been told he has until the autumn to turn the show around.

However, executives at Channel 4 are pessimistic about the show's future.

They say the reputation of the show has slipped so far it will be difficult to find any big name stars willing to join the team to give it the lift it needed.

Recent attempts were made to persuade the BBC presenter, Patrick Kielty, to join but he refused. Producers also tried to hire the Radio 1 DJ, Chris Moyles, but he too refused.

"We will make the decision on June 1. It might well be that the show comes back, but it is difficult to see it without a complete and total rethink," said a source.

What will happen is that the show goes out to tender and Planet 24 will be in with a chance just like any other production company."

"The problem is you can't hide on live television. Staying on your toes for two hours without corpsing is difficult. That's why Johnny Vaughan and Chris Evans were so talented," the source added.

The Big Breakfast is also attracting a huge amount of bad publicity with presenters Donna Air and others constantly under critical tabloid scrutiny.

webTitle: Vivendi and News Corp in pay-TV deal

fields.headline: Vivendi and News Corp in pay-TV deal
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Vivendi Universal and News Corporation have reached agreement to merge their loss making pay-TV businesses, Telepiu and Stream. By Mark Milner.
fields.body:
French multimedia group Vivendi Universal and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation have reached agreement to merge their loss making pay-television businesses, Telepiu and Stream.

Analysts believe the agreement will attract keen scrutiny from the Italian telecommunications regulator, but is unlikely to run into any problems from Telecom Italia, which holds 50% of Stream and has been looking for an exit for some time.

Vivendi will have two-thirds of the combined group, although News Corp has options to raise its stake to 50%.

One likely area of concern for the competition authority is that the merged company will have a near-monopoly on broadcasting soccer matches from Italy's top division.

Last year Stream, which has some 800,000 subscribers, lost 400m euros (£249m) while Telepiu, with 1.8m subscribers, lost 220m euros.

The losses will not exclude the deal from regulatory scrutiny. Vincenzo Vita, an under-secretary at the Italian communications ministry, said: "It is a merger in a market which is in trouble, where it is clear that there is not room for two operators... but the anti-trust authority will have to look at whether there can be one."

Vivendi Universal shares rose more than 2% yesterday in response to the deal and good first-quarter results released overnight. The group, formed by the merger of Vivendi and Seagram of Canada, said core earnings had doubled to 900m euros. Revenues rose 10% in the first quarter to 6.52bn euros.

Following the Seagram acquisition, Vivendi ranks just behind US rival AOL Time Warner as the world's top media and entertainment group, but still relies on its traditional utilities business for a good portion of profits.

Jean-Marie Messier, the chief executive, was confident the group would reach its annual growth targets for earnings and revenues over the next two years. "We have seen progress in all business units," he said. "We are ahead on cost savings and are very confident that we can meet our targets for 2001 and 2002."

Mr Messier also said Vivendi may be interested in buying ISL Worldwide, the sports marketing firm which owns a strong portfolio of TV rights and is threatened with bankruptcy. He said ISL would complement Vivendi's plans to form a sports marketing major with Bertelsmann.

fields.headline: Milburn unveils NHS overhaul
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, today signalled his intention to up the pace of the government's NHS reforms, unveiling a massive restructuring plan aimed at devolving more power and resources from Whitehall to frontline staff.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, today signalled his intention to up the pace of the government's NHS reforms, unveiling a massive restructuring plan aimed at devolving more power and resources from Whitehall to frontline staff.

Mr Milburn promised that Labour's approach to the NHS in a second term of government would be to give doctors, nurses and other care staff more influence to shape local services by giving them more control over budgets and care purchasing decisions.

"Too much of the NHS today still feels like a centrally run bureaucracy to those at the frontline. This has to change. The time has now come to free the NHS frontline," he told an audience of health service managers in London.

He promised to strip out layers of "top heavy" NHS administration by axing around 60 of the current 95 health authorities (HAs) in England, radically reforming the Department of Health (DoH), and strengthening NHS links with regional and local government.

Hundreds of NHS and civil service administrative jobs will disappear as a result of a "rationalisation" of the middle tier of health service management to be phased in by 2004, releasing £100m for patient care.

Mr Milburn said: "Organisational change of course carries the risk of bringing instability and so could impede reform, I recognise that. But I have been convinced by people in the NHS that change is now needed to take reform forward and embed a new decentralised approach.

"Not a big bang tomorrow but a phased programme to put power and resources in the hands of the NHS frontline."

The reform programme includes:
 The merger of existing health authorities into around 30 "strategic" authorities, covering populations of 1.5m. They will hold hospital trusts and primary care trusts (PCTs) to account, and resolve local disputes.
 Reform of managerial appointments - management of the strategic authorities may be offered to tender on a "franchise" basis, with "the best performing management teams" invited to apply.
 The appointment of possibly nine regional DoH directors of health and social care, each with a "small core group of staff," to "oversee" the health service and develop links with regional government.
 The abolition of the eight DoH regional offices, each of which employ around 150 civil servants, along with the abolition of the NHS executive, the operational management arm of the DoH.
 Reform of the DOH to become a "model for the modern service-delivery" Whitehall department. This will include the appointment of more NHS 'tsars' and other staff to civil service positions.

The programme will go some way to meeting mounting criticism from doctors and managers about the punishing pace of Labour's reforms, and the perceived centralisation of decision making and performance management in Whitehall.

But while Mr Milburn admitted "the NHS cannot be run from Whitehall" he insisted that Labour had been right to exercise strong central control in its first term to establish "a clear national framework within which local services can operate".

With that framework in place, Labour intends to "shift the centre of gravity to the NHS frontlineJust as schools have greater control over resources and how they are organised, so local health services must now be given greater control."

He recognised that many staff were weary from nearly two decades of NHS reforms. But he insisted there would be no let up on the pace of change: "My message is simple; reform must happen."

British Medical Association chiarman Dr Ian Bogle gave a catious welcome to the plans: "The intention of today's announcement, to cut bureaucracy and decentralise the NHS, is something we support.

"Anything that helps doctors treat their patients better is to be welcomed. But similar promises have been made in the past and have been constrained by central guidance and control."

Shadow health secretary Liam Fox said: "This has all the hallmarks of a panic reaction with the secretary of state desperately trying to head off a crisis in the medical profession that his own centralising tendencies has produced.

"With consultants and GPs threatening to leave the NHS, the secretary of state has clearly seen how popular Conservative plans are proving to be."

webTitle: How the new NHS will look

fields.headline: How the new NHS will look
fields.trailText:
Policy change: The Department of Health (DoH) will face a review aimed at shaking off its bureaucratic "Sir Humphrey" image. Health secretary Alan Milburn said: "The department faces a fundamental challenge: how to overhaul its apparatus to be better focused on seeing change through, not just devising new policies for change." He promised the appointment of more "tsars" (such as cancer tsar Dr Mike Richards and older people's tsar Dr Ian Philp) from outside the civil service. Mr Milburn said: "In this way the Department of Health can become a model for the modern service delivery Whitehall department."
Our comment: The DoH is a past master at resisting structural change - will this latest review prove any different?
fields.body:
Policy change: The Department of Health (DoH) will face a review aimed at shaking off its bureaucratic "Sir Humphrey" image. Health secretary Alan Milburn said: "The department faces a fundamental challenge: how to overhaul its apparatus to be better focused on seeing change through, not just devising new policies for change." He promised the appointment of more "tsars" (such as cancer tsar Dr Mike Richards and older people's tsar Dr Ian Philp) from outside the civil service. Mr Milburn said: "In this way the Department of Health can become a model for the modern service delivery Whitehall department."
Our comment: The DoH is a past master at resisting structural change - will this latest review prove any different?

Policy change: The DoH at regional level will be represented by regional directors of health and social care, each accompanied by a small team of civil servants. They will be based in the nine local government offices of the regions and tasked with overseeing health services and encouraging joint working with other agencies on health, transport, regeneration and the environment. "In this way if new regional government structures emerge there will be a ready-made relationship with the NHS," said Mr Milburn.
Our comment: The directors will be the DoH's emissaries for emerging regional assemblies and be on hand to negotiate any future transfer of NHS power to regional governments.

Policy change: Around 30 new strategic health authorities will come out of the planned merger of the 95 existing health authorities. They will provide a bridge between the DoH and local trusts. They will broker solutions to local problems and review the performance of health services in their area. Running them will be regarded as one of the top management jobs in the NHS. Mr Milburn is determined to get the best managers, even if it means offering the jobs out on a franchise basis to teams of top managers.
Our comment: Labour is determined to sweep away the "buggins turn" traditions of some NHS management appointments, could the franchise idea see health authority management teams run by private managers?

Policy change: Primary care trusts will, as now, provide and commission family doctor and community services, and purchase hospital care on behalf of their population. But they will hold the budgets and have more discretion over how the money is spent. They will be able to band together to share the cost of some common functions, possibly including administration and payroll services. They will develop closer links with local government.
Our comment: Will primary care trusts simply grow into giant purchasing organisations, lacking the flexibilty and knowledge of local health needs that many individual GP practices have?

Policy change: At hospital trust level, managers should give clinical teams more control over budgets. As well as previously announced initiatives to give ward sisters control of ward budgets, and matrons control over ward cleaning and catering services, Mr Milburn will announce proposals to give hospital clinicians greater control over extra resources for new equipment budgets. The best performing hospital trusts will have more freedoms, such as fewer inspections, with extra money and power to "take over and turn round" persistently failing neighbouring trusts.
Our comment: More cash for the best, but if the worst get less money how will they be able to recover? The prospect of being "taken over" by a more successful neighbouring trust introduces a radical new quasi-market incentive into NHS management.

fields.headline: Duchess of York signed up by ITV to report on obesity
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the monarchy
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Duchess of York's television career has not exactly been marked by greatness, so the former wife of Prince Andrew must be hoping that her latest small screen foray will be more successful than her disastrous attempt at hosting a chat show.
fields.body:
The Duchess of York's television career has not exactly been marked by greatness, so the former wife of Prince Andrew must be hoping that her latest small screen foray will be more successful than her disastrous attempt at hosting a chat show.

ITV have signed the duchess to present a report for their current affairs series Tonight with Trevor McDonald, and if tomorrow's edition is a success she will be asked to do more.

The duchess, who underwent a battle with her weight, will present a report on obesity. "I've had first-hand knowledge of what it's like to be overweight and have the media spotlight on me," she will say in her 20-minute report.

Her ITV debut comes two years after her Sky TV chat show, Sarah - Surviving Life, was axed for attracting just 12,000 viewers. One critic said it was "the most embarrassing 60 minutes in chat show history".

But the duchess' recent experience as a stand-in for the world's biggest chat show, CNN's Larry King Live, has been more successful.

A Tonight source said the report had been a success and that the duchess comes across as "warm and interested". Executives at Granada, which makes Tonight for ITV, hope she will present more "specials" for the programme.

"It will be a matter of establishing how much work she can fit into her schedule and what kind of issues we want her to report on," said a source. Tonight has used celebrity presenters in the past.

A career in mainstream British TV will be a boost for the duchess, at a time when the royals' business interests are coming under intense scrutiny. However, the duchess' activities do not come under the lord chamberlain's review of the royals' role, as she is no longer a member of the royal household.

In her report the duchess meets people who have struggled against their weight for years.

"I think I understand the depression and despair people face when they are trying to lose weight," she says.

"But what's frightening is that here in Britain we're following hard on the heels of America and fast becoming the fattest country in Europe."

 ITN also announced yesterday that it will extend News at Ten to 30 minutes during the election campaign, but the extended running time will include the regional news bulletin that currently goes out after 11pm.

webTitle: Bush defies China with Taiwan deal

fields.headline: Bush defies China with Taiwan deal
fields.standfirst:
Beijing academics warn of retaliatory action against the US over arms package, even though state-of-the-art Aegis system was excluded

Special report: China
Special report: Taiwan and China
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Beijing academics warn of retaliatory action against the US over arms package, even though state-of-the-art Aegis system was excluded.
fields.body:
China angrily accused the US yesterday of crossing a "red line" with its sale of advanced weapons to Taiwan and threatened swift retaliation.

Beijing's foreign ministry expressed "serious concern" over the announcement of the package of military technology and weapons systems. An editorial in the official China Daily warned the US would pay "a heavy political price".

Although the ministry's initial reaction was seen by some as relatively low-key and gave no indication of what steps Beijing will take in response, pro-government academics quoted in the state-run media were far less restrained.

"Protest is too mild an action, given this break of the red line," warned Professor Wu Xinbo, of Shanghai's Fudan University Centre for American Studies, referring to the inclusion in the US package of submarines and a missile defence system that will greatly enhance Taiwan's defence capabilities. "There will be some substantive actions and this will come very soon. These actions will make the US acutely aware of the cost of its behaviour on this issue."

The academics, widely seen as close to Chinese official thinking, dismissed Washington's decision not to accede to Taiwan's demand for destroyers equipped with the state-of-the-art Aegis radar system as a "bluff card", designed to distract attention from other parts of the advanced weapons package.

"A submarine, even in terms of military technology, is an offensive weapon. This is a fundamental change, a dramatic change," said Yan Xuetong, of the Institute of International Studies at Qinghua University in Beijing. "If they can use these submarines to attack Chinese warships and reduce Chinese capability on the seas, then their airplanes will have the capability to attack China's coastal cities." There were also warnings of retaliation, affecting everything from trade ties to anti-proliferation efforts. China has repeatedly used its growing economic clout in recent years to gain added diplomatic leverage, threatening to steer lucrative trade contracts away from countries that sell weapons to Taiwan. Commentaries in the state-run media were yesterday highlighting increasing US exports to China, America's fourth-largest trading partner, signalling one area where Beijing seems to feel it can apply pressure.

Mr Yan also indicated that international missile control agreements might be another target of Beijing's wrath. "China will feel helpless to maintain the international regime of non-proliferation if the United States tries to undermine that regime," he said.

But a western diplomat in Beijing predicted that, rather than risk the international outcry involved in repudiating non-proliferation accords, China would probably opt for a "revenge-by-stealth" approach.

"There are areas of military and technological co-operation that they can indulge in with states in the Middle East where they're technically not in breach of any agreements," he said. China has already been accused by the Central Intelligence Agency of giving substantial support to Pakistan's missile programme as well as selling missile-related items to Iran, Libya and North Korea.

Tensions between the US and China heightened this month after the mid-air collision between a Chinese fighter jet and a US spy plane led to the death of Chinese pilot Wang Wei and the detention of the American crew for 11 days until the Bush administration offered its regrets. Analysts say US requests for the return of the EP-3 surveillance aircraft are now unlikely to be granted.

And the granting of a US tourist visa to the former Taiwanese president Lee Teng-hui, reviled by Beijing for his allegedly pro-independence stance, for a trip to Cornell University, his alma mater, suggests relations may deteriorate further. The last time Mr Lee visited Cornell, while still president in 1995, China reacted by conducting live missile exercises off the coast of Taiwan. But there is no indication yet if it will retaliate the same way this time.

fields.headline: Japanese maverick grabs reins
fields.standfirst:
Wave of popular support sweeps flamboyant reformer into power, sending ruling elite a clear message: change is needed

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Junichiro Koizumi, a reformer promising tough love for Japan, is to be the next prime minister after a surprise victory yesterday in voting for the leadership of the conservative ruling party.
fields.body:
Junichiro Koizumi, a reformer promising tough love for Japan, is to be the next prime minister after a surprise victory yesterday in voting for the leadership of the conservative ruling party.

Defying all predictions, the former health minister rode a wave of popular support to overwhelm the traditionally powerful factional interests represented by his three rivals for the presidency of the Liberal Democratic party (LDP).

Guaranteed the post of prime minister by the ruling coalition's majority in parliament, he will inaugurate a cabinet tomorrow that is expected to be the youngest and most reform-minded that Japan has seen in decades.

He has also pledged to push aggressive reforms of the banking system, cap the issuance of government bonds and break up the LDP's factions.

Mr Koizumi, 59, is an immensely popular politician whose selection is likely to boost the ratings of the LDP in the upper house election in July. In opinion polls, 51% of floating voters said they wanted him as head of the ruling party.

"At last we have a real leader," one woman told a local television station.

In primaries leading up to yesterday's election, Mr Koizumi swept 123 of the 141 regional votes that were at stake, making it politically impossible for the party's grandees to deny him victory.

In the final count, which included a poll of MPs, he won 293 votes, putting him far ahead of his next closest rival, the former prime minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, with 155.

"It is unbelievable that I received such huge support," he said after the victory. "It is the individual citizens who moved politics."

"It is my responsibility to rebuild the party so that we can say with confidence that the LDP will change Japan and move ahead with major reforms."

Mr Koizumi cuts an unusually colourful figure in the grey world of Japanese politics.

Compared to the cheap suits and short-back-and-sides hairstyles that are alomst de rigueur among LDP members, Japan's new leader is a sharp dresser with long grey permed hair.

A divorcee, who has two sons from a marriage with a woman 14 years his junior, "Jun-chan" as he is nicknamed, lists his hobbies as skiing, movies, Kabuki and singing karaoke.

As a well known fan of an outlandishly dressed pop group, X-Japan, he helped to set up a memorial museum for the band's lead singer, who committed suicide.

His policies, particularly his advocacy of privatising Japan's huge postal savings network, have also earned him the reputation as a political punk inside the LDP: the party gets much of its money and support from the postal lobby.

"Jun-chan is a little different from your run-of-the mill politician. He doesn't make decisions based on personal interests. He is a politician who respects theories and logic," said one of the other three leadership candidates, Shizuka Kamei, before dropping out and throwing his support behind Mr Koizumi.

"He may prove to be a tough character on the international scene."

fields.headline: A man in a hurry
fields.standfirst:
Japan's new leader has no time for golf

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Japan's next prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, has a big job on his hands.
fields.body:
Japan's next prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, has a big job on his hands. The new Liberal Democratic party leader will be seen as an improvement on the inept Yoshiro Mori. Almost anyone would be. But Mr Mori's immediate legacy is daunting: continuing economic under-performance, relatively high unemployment, a neurotic stock market prone to sudden collapses, a dodgy banking system, and colossal government debt. Although it is hardly all his fault, Mr Mori also bequeaths to his successor a party which has forfeited much of its support after 46 years of almost unbroken rule and a political system in which the public has manifestly lost confidence.

Adding spice to this challenge, Mr Koizumi must try to direct a culturally and generationally fast-changing nation that many Japanese feel has lost its way and its self-belief in the past decade. The new man has until July, when upper house parliamentary elections are due, to turn the LDP's fortunes around. Assuming he can clear that hurdle, he has perhaps a year to do what eight other prime ministers in the past 10 years have failed to do: to articulate a vision for the new century while putting Japan Inc back in business.

The task facing Mr Koizumi is made all the harder by his lack of a popular mandate and doubts about his ability to deliver. Although he vows to enact "the will of the people", and although the internal LDP contest was more participatory and less faction-ridden this time around, the fact remains that 487 votes decided who leads 127m Japanese. Mr Koizumi, who sports a notably unconventional hairstyle, cultivates the image of a rebel and maverick. But his record is hardly that of a mould-breaker. The son of a defence minister, grandson of a parliamentary Speaker, and protégé of former premier Takeo Fukuda, Mr Koizumi, aged 59, has been an MP for nearly 30 years and has held several ministerial posts. His insistence that he will "change Japan" may thus entail changing himself, too.

In similar vein, Mr Koizumi's tough-sounding vows to push through "painful" structural reforms, curtail borrowing, clean up the banking sector and extend privatisation - the shock therapy policy of "creative destruction" - will, if pursued, bring inevitable confrontation with the vested interests upon which the LDP was built and could cause wider political problems for the ruling coalition. While most Japanese know something radical is required to get their country moving again, nobody actually knows how the public would react to a really harsh tightening of belts.

One tantalising possibility is that voters might at last demand a more democratic, pluralist and responsive system of governance than that now on offer. Whether the new leader is willing to take on the shoguns of sleaze will be tested tomorrow when he names a new cabinet. He says his choices will be dictated by merit, not LDP insider dealing. In which case, expect another party rebel, Makiko Tanaka, to get a job.

The US economic downturn means Mr Koizumi faces scrutiny from further afield as pressure grows on Tokyo to put its affairs in order and perhaps lead a recovery. Like Japan's voters, other G7 countries will watch him closely, too. He has a lot to do and little time to do it.

webTitle: 'We cannot wait any longer for economic reform'

fields.headline: 'We cannot wait any longer for economic reform'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Despite the great expectations for Junichiro Koizumi, it is far from certain that the man who is Japan's eighth prime minister in eight years will have any more success than his predecessors in ending the country's hard times.
fields.body:
Despite the great expectations for Junichiro Koizumi, it is far from certain that the man who is Japan's eighth prime minister in eight years will have any more success than his predecessors in ending the country's hard times.

Mr Koizumi's surprise victory is being heralded as a turning point in Japanese politics and the best hope yet that the world's second-biggest economy can recover from 10 years of stagnation that have left unemployment, bankruptcy and suicide rates at or near record levels.

Up to a point this optimism is justified: Mr Koizumi's win unquestionably broke the political mould.

Running as an independent, he overwhelmed a former prime minister from a powerful faction that has never lost an LDP leadership election. The result was a stunning setback for the party gerontocracy, who have held sway over Japanese political life for decades.

It was also about as close to a display of people power as Japan gets.

With support from 80% of the party's regions and the vast majority of its members, he can claim the clearest mandate for change in the country's modern history.

Change, however, will be painful.

Mr Koizumi has promised a period of creative destruction: large-scale structural reform that will shake out the ailing banking sector and test weak companies' mettle. He pledges by 2004 to clear up the bad loans held by financial institutions - estimated at between 30,000bn and 100,000bn yen (£172bn-£573bn) - even if it means two years of recession.

If he can pull it off, this would be a major policy shift. Since the financial crisis of 1997-98, successive administrations have said the economy is too weak for such major surgery.

"We cannot wait any longer for reform," Mr Koizumi said during his campaign. "Yes, there will be bankruptcy and unemployment, but if we fear this and postpone the necessary remedies, then we will never see a recovery of the Japanese economy."

Mr Koizumi insists reform and deregulation are the answer, but his party is a collection of lobbies - such as the building industry and postal workers - with a vested interest in obstructing change.

The first test of his sincerity will be his choice of a new cabinet, which will be unveiled later this week; he has promised to ignore the usual faction balancing act and to appoint solely on talent, including more women and young politicians.

He will find it difficult not to reward the factions that supported him, however.

And if he needed reminding of the price of failure, he need only to look at the rival he defeated yesterday, the former prime minster Ryutaro Hashimoto.

Mr Hashimoto came to power on a similar promise of reform in 1996. But in little more than two years the country was in crisis and voters had dubbed him public enemy number one.

webTitle: Two more tested for foot and mouth in humans

fields.headline: Two more tested for foot and mouth in humans
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Two more cases of suspected foot and mouth disease in humans are being investigated by the public health laboratory service, it emerged yesterday, a day after news that a slaughterman from Cumbria was being tested for the disease.
fields.body:
Two more cases of suspected foot and mouth disease in humans are being investigated by the public health laboratory service, it emerged yesterday, a day after news that a slaughterman from Cumbria was being tested for the disease.

The results on all three will probably not be known until early next week. Since the start of the epidemic, the laboratory service has investigated six cases but all proved negative.

A spokesman for the service would not say where the latest suspect cases were, but said they were not connected geographically either to the Cumbrian case or to each other.

There has been only one confirmed case in Britain of a human being infected with foot and mouth - during the last outbreak in 1967. The Department of Health has said that it is "fair to expect" one or two cases this time.

The disease is mild in humans. The main symptoms are tingling blisters on the hands. Other symptoms can include fever, a sore throat and blisters on the tongue or feet.

People can be infected though skin wounds, by handling diseased stock or by drinking infected milk, but not by eating meat from infected animals. The slaughterman in Cumbria is believed to have been sprayed with "material" from a slaughtered cow. The average incubation time for the disease is between three and eight days.

Health officials emphasised that the disease in humans should not be confused with "hand, foot and mouth disease", an unrelated and usually mild viral infection that mainly affects children.

There are no recorded cases of human-to-human transmission of the disease.

webTitle: A farmer's diary during foot and mouth

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
There's bad news and good: one ewe dead, one lamb saved

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: There's bad news and good: one ewe dead, one lamb saved.
fields.body:
Yesterday morning we estimated that only 10% of our flock is left to lamb, but this week has not started well. Before breakfast on Monday, a ewe died suddenly in the lambing shed. Archie, our lambing shepherd, thinks she choked on something, as she started to cough loudly and within two or three minutes was dead, leaving two lambs without a mother. I shouldn't have mentioned pet lambs last week - it was obviously tempting fate.

Feeding the orphans is a battle of wills - our patience versus their stubbornness. They have not yet worked out that the warm powdered milk is for them to swallow. Instead it dribbles out of their mouths, runs down our waterproof trousers and collects in a pool on the floor. We hope their hunger will finally win them round, or that we can find them a new mother. But as there are only five Mule sheep left to lamb, and because the Scottish Blackface ewes (a smaller and tougher breed than the Mule) can only manage to feed one Suffolk cross lamb, this becomes harder and harder to arrange.

Out in the fields the lambs are thriving. Their docked tails are finally dropping off and for them life is fun. They play, fight, leap and jump over and over again before having a feed and a sleep and starting once more. We love to watch them racing one another over a hillock or along the top of a bank, full of the joys of living. But this is a transient stage, as once they start to graze on the grass for themselves and endlessly chew the cud, they age almost overnight, becoming very middle-aged in outlook.

Yesterday morning we awoke to a dense fog which slowed us down: it was impossible to check the ewes and lambs properly. Visibility increased to around 50 yards after breakfast but many of our fields are large (up to 100 acres) and looking around properly was impossible. The evening check needed to be even more thorough than usual.

I think the tension is beginning to ease a little in the countryside as the days go by and the number of reported cases goes down. But the dire warnings and confusing advice from Maff and the NFU keep the stress levels pretty high. They have lambed reasonably well and we have had no sudden lamb deaths in the field, which I've discovered is a clear sign of an infected flock. We've had no more disasters than usual - as any farmer will tell you, when you keep livestock, you always have deadstock, too.

Peter has started to take down some of the lambing pens and muck out the soiled bedding with the JCB. This dirty straw is not saved for manure but burnt, as it is thoroughly soiled and could harbour a multitude of bacteria, including Ecoli, joint ill and other unpleasant germs. Every wooden hurdle and water bucket is thoroughly steam-cleaned and put away until the next lambing - whenever that might be.

Just as my deadline is reached, I can report that we have managed to set one of the pet lambs on to a ewe. One down, one to go!

webTitle: US offer of test refused at start of outbreak

fields.headline: US offer of test refused at start of outbreak
fields.standfirst:
Experts urge immediate vaccination policy

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Agriculture turned down a US government offer - made at the beginning of the foot and mouth outbreak - of a simple, reliable test which could have avoided the needless culling of a million or more healthy animals, according to one of the world's experts on the disease.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Agriculture turned down a US government offer - made at the beginning of the foot and mouth outbreak - of a simple, reliable test which could have avoided the needless culling of a million or more healthy animals, according to one of the world's experts on the disease.

Accusing Maff of spreading misery by dogmatically pursuing "10-year-old science", Fred Brown, former deputy head of the world foot and mouth research laboratory at Pirbright and now at the US animal disease centre, said that the test could have been done on up to 24 farms at a time and easily identified which animals had the disease.

"The US department of agriculture offered it to Maff on March 9 [week three of the crisis]. It's a hand-held test kit, you just press the button and it comes up with the answer in two to three hours. It is very accurate. They said they were 'too busy'. That saddened me a lot", he said. "Why destroy innocent animals? This is not like cutting down a forest."

Professor Brown said that an "unacceptable level" of healthy animals had already been slaughtered. The only way to move forward on a civilised basis, he said, was to instigate an immediate vaccination policy. The latest Maff figures suggest that more than 2m animals have been slaughtered but unofficially Maff admits that only 1% may have actually caught the disease.

"Vaccination is a success story", said Prof Brown, who worked on the 1981 small foot and mouth outbreak on the Isle of Wight. "When it was clear the disease was out of control, they should have vaccinated.

"The archaic view of the importance of disease-free status should be the subject of international debate." He was joined in London by Simon Barteling, a Dutch consultant who has spent 30 years investigating foot and mouth outbreaks around the world. He accused the European commission of trying to prevent the Dutch vaccination policy. This has brought Holland's outbreaks under control in less than 14 days.

"I always wondered why the British refused to vaccinate", said Dr Barteling. "Clearly if you cannot trace the contacts then it was out of hand. You then have to vaccinate or face a long history of human harm in all your rural areas."

Dr Barteling also dismissed the National Farmers' Union prime objection to vaccination which has always been that vaccinated animals can remain carriers and spread the disease. "This has been very much blown up," he said. "There is no well-documented case where a vaccinated animal has caused a disease. Billions of animals have been successfully vaccinated. There is a strong indication that though you may find carriers they do not pass it on."

Dr Barteling feared that the disease could remain in the national flock or herd and appear to die away over the summer but return in the autumn when the weather conditions suited it.

Meanwhile the Department of Health warned that anyone living within 3km of a large pyre could experience a worsening of asthma conditions and should avoid "sustained exposure" to the smoke, dioxins and particles emitted. They advised that people growing vegetables near a pyre to wash their produce but said that dioxins in the soil posed no immediate or long-term hazards.

The ministry said that private water supplies could be vulnerable to contamination by surface water run off from carcasses left lying on the ground and from animals buried in unlined sites.

Mike Childs, campaign director of Friends of the Earth, said: "The government is trying to pull the wool over people's eyes. In December European scientists called for renewed efforts to reduce people's exposure to dioxins.

"The UK government has even produced a report warning that people are exposed to too many dioxins. Alarmingly it also says that babies may be exposed to between 27 and 144 times above World Health Organisation safe levels. Simply telling people to scrub their vegetable won't wash."

webTitle: Sex abuse victim waives right to anonymity

fields.headline: Sex abuse victim waives right to anonymity
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A woman who was sexually abused as a child this week took the unusual step of waiving her right to anonymity as her abuser admitted a catalogue of offences against her and three other young girls over 30 years.
fields.body:
A woman who was sexually abused as a child this week took the unusual step of waiving her right to anonymity as her abuser admitted a catalogue of offences against her and three other young girls over 30 years.

Carolyn McKee, 31, originally from Ballynahinch, Co Down, suffered at the hands of Joseph Irvine, a former soldier, from age four to 10.

Now married and living in Oxford, she has spoken out about the abuse to try to end the shame and silence surrounding sex crimes which she believes help paedophiles to continue to threaten children.

Ms McKee, a lawyer, is still deeply affected by what Irvine did to her and suffered years of depression before she was able to face reporting him to police.

Irvine, 57, of Ballynahinch, pleaded guilty at Downpatrick crown court to 19 charges of indecent assault, six of taking indecent photographs of children and one of attempted rape. The incidents, in the period from 1974 to 2000, involved the three other girls as well.

One child was only three when the former Ulster Defence Regiment soldier indecently assaulted her. Another was 11 when he tried to rape her last year. He was remanded in custody yesterday to await sentencing.

In accordance with the law in Northern Ireland, Ms McKee's solicitor had to make a formal application in court to get the judge's permission to waive her anonymity, and she and her husband sat a few feet from Irvine.

Judge Peter Gibson said he was satisfied that granting her the permission had no bearing on Irvine's right to a fair hearing and would not compromise his other victims, who were unconnected with her and wanted to retain their privacy.

Irvine was the boyfriend of Ms McKee's babysitter and a friend of the family when he started to go to her home. "I can only have been about three or four when he first started to touch me and take indecent photographs," she said. "He came out with all the classic cliches: that it had to be our little secret, nobody would know.

"I know it's irrational, but I felt partly to blame. It makes me sick when I hear of ... abusers claiming children are sexual and want relationships. What rubbish! It's not just about sex, it's about power and manipulation.

"I have clear memories of certain incidents, but because I was so young when it started, it worries me that if I can't remember it all I can never completely exorcise it.

"Over the years, he stepped up the abuse in insidious ways, and I was more and more upset by it, until one day when I was about 10 he came round to take me out, and I kicked up a fuss and told my mother I didn't want to go with him. I didn't tell my mother what was wrong, but he knew I was on to him and he backed off ...

"Because he hadn't gone as far as raping me, although he was very close, I felt I hadn't suffered badly enough to deserve sympathy as an adult. But it had a lasting effect. For years, I was scared to show any emotions because of anything else that might come out.

"I felt isolated, even from my family. I thought I was tainted and ugly. My self-hatred expressed itself as aggression toward boys, and I developed anorexic tendencies in my late teens."

But it was in her 20s that more severe problems surfaced. She took several overdoses and went to her doctor suffering from depression. She later saw a psychiatrist, who told her she could still report Irvine to the police. "My parents told me to let the past go, but it has never been the past to me," she said. She made a statement to detectives and discovered that Irvine was being charged with further offences.

"I was appalled to find he was still abusing children. I didn't do this to be vindictive. The emotion I feel most toward him is pity, but I'm glad he's in prison where he can't do any more harm. Most abusers are not headline news. They just carry on quietly abusing for years, and the abused feel too ashamed to speak out. It's him who should be ashamed, not me.

"Silence and secrecy aren't the answers, so if I can raise the veil just a fraction by talking about what happened to me, I hope it can somehow help others."

fields.headline: Wireless gloom bursts chip balloon
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Chipmaker Infineon and designer Parthus yesterday shrugged off some of the gloom enveloping the semiconductor market by posting better than expected quarterly results.
fields.body:
Chipmaker Infineon and designer Parthus yesterday shrugged off some of the gloom enveloping the semiconductor market by posting better than expected quarterly results.

Shares in Infineon, Europe's second-largest semiconductor maker and majority owned by Siemens of Germany, jumped as much as 5% in early trade but concern about its core computer and mobile phone markets dampened an initially warm reception from investors.

Parthus shares slipped 2p to 88.5p despite the chief operating officer, Kevin Fielding's insistence that the Irish firm's business model was robust enough to withstand the downturn.

Parthus depends largely on licence sales for its revenues, and those remain strong. "Customers use their research and development budgets to buy licences, and those are unlikely to be cut because R&D is seen as the vehicle to drive them out of this downturn," he said. First quarter pretax losses widened to $3m (£2.1m) but sales climbed 14% to $9.8m, quarter on quarter.

fields.headline: At this price? Fibernet
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Fibernet shareholders have had little to smile about during the last year. Shares in the data networking group have slumped from a technology frenzy-fuelled high of more than £27 to recent lows of less than 400p.
fields.body:
Fibernet shareholders have had little to smile about during the last year.

Shares in the data networking group have slumped from a technology frenzy-fuelled high of more than £27 to recent lows of less than 400p.

Like almost every tech stock, it has been hammered by a downturn in sentiment. Yet Fibernet compounded the misery last November by launching a deeply discounted rights issue to raise £77m, infuriating many unhappy shareholders.

Yesterday, however, figures were released showing better times may be ahead. First half pretax profits doubled to £3.2m in the period to the end of February. Turnover climbed 35% to £24.6m, and the figures exceeded house broker Deutsche Bank's expectations. Much of the growth came from a rights issue funded build-out of its high speed internet network.

First customers have been won in the new markets of France and Germany. The company has £103m cash in the bank.

The shares ticked up 22.5p to 575p, but at this level do they present an opportunity? Deutsche Bank certainly thinks so, predicting the shares could rise as high as £12.73p by August next year.

The broker argues Fibernet is undervalued compared to its peers, and says its rating does not reflect the company's recent strong performance or its potential.

The roll-out of high speed web nets remains costly and frustrating. Management will have to keep a tight rein on capital expenditure in the present economic climate.

DSL infrastructure building has taken longer than expected due to a series of disputes between BT, regulator Oftel and rival operators hoping to muscle in on BT's space. Further delays cannot be discounted while telecoms stocks as a whole remain out of favour.

Shareholders at present should take heart from yesterday's figures, but new buyers should remain cautious. Hold.

fields.headline: Pathologist disciplinary case collapses
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A disciplinary hearing, set up at huge expense to investigate claims that a forensic pathologist botched postmortem examinations, has collapsed in embarrassing circumstances.
fields.body:
A disciplinary hearing, set up at huge expense to investigate claims that a forensic pathologist botched postmortem examinations, has collapsed in embarrassing circumstances.

Days before the Home Office tribunal was due to finish, a month after it started, all four of the panel hearing the case against Paula Lannas declared they should step down to avoid a conflict of interest.

Dr Lannas is left in limbo while a decision is made over whether there will be further proceedings. She has had little work for two years while the case has been pending.

Critics believe the collapse also raises questions about the policy advisory board for forensic pathology, which is responsible for the tribunal.

The board is chaired by Gordon Thomas, acting head of the Home Office's science and technology unit. One of its roles is to maintain a list of pathologists approved for working with police and coroners on suspicious deaths.

One pathologist, who asked not to be named, said last night: "This is going to call into question the credibility of the board. How can the public, let alone coroners and the police, have confidence in the crucial work it does if it can't run a disciplinary hearing?"

Since 1990 Dr Lannas, who qualified as a doctor in 1974, has performed more than 7,300 autopsies, including almost 400 on people who died in suspicious circumstances.

She was involved in the cases of Leah Betts, who died after taking an ecstasy tablet on her 18th birthday in 1995, and Joy Gardner, who died in 1993 after police tried to arrest her for deportation.

But in 1996 Dr Lannas's work came under scrutiny. After years of investigation by the board's quality assurance and scientific standards committee, the disciplinary tribunal convened - for the first time - at the Holiday Inn in Rotherhithe, south-east London, last month.

It heard that two Essex coroners had stopped her from performing autopsies in their areas. In three cases, it was claimed, she failed to carry out a "vital aspect of the autopsy".

Also investigated, the tribunal heard, was a postmortem examination on a baby who police believed had been murdered. So "suspect" were her conclusions that at a trial the prosecution told the jury it could not rely on her evidence.

Proceedings were being watched by at least one team of lawyers representing a person convicted after a trial at which Dr Lannas gave evidence.

However, her team were confident that she would win the tribunal case. In a statement at the start they said: "Dr Lannas maintains that throughout her career she has acted properly and professionally."

She was giving evidence when the case collapsed last Friday.

Her lawyer, Robert Sumerling, said yesterday the turn of events was "entirely unexpected". Dr Lannas was "very concerned and upset".

He said her team had drawn attention to what they believed was a "problem" with one of the panel. Next day the panel announced that they would all be standing down.

The Home Office would not discuss details of the case. It said only that the tribunal had been "discontinued" because members had "recused themselves because information came to their attention which could have been viewed as prejudicial". In a legal context, to recuse means to withdraw from a hearing because of a possible conflict of interest or lack of impartiality.

One legal source said: "This must be a great embarrassment to the Home Office. It is bound to have cost hundreds of thousands of pounds to bring this case ... This is the first time this tribunal has met, and it will probably now be the only time."

webTitle: Met lets Muslim policewomen don headscarves

fields.headline: Met lets Muslim policewomen don headscarves
fields.standfirst:
Special report: policing crime
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The old-style helmet is out, the hijab is in, at least for female Muslim recruits to the Metropolitan police.
fields.body:
The old-style helmet is out, the hijab is in, at least for female Muslim recruits to the Metropolitan police.

As part of an initiative called Protect and Respect: Everybody Benefits, the force has given Muslim women on duty the option of wearing a hijab, the traditional headscarf which is a symbol of their beliefs and modesty.

Sikh officers are already allowed to wear turbans and the Met is considering letting potential recruits from the capital's 10,000 Rastafarians have dreadlocks.

Prayer rooms are also on their way in the bigger stations as well as creches if they will help working parents.

The Met yesterday said it would consider whatever changes were necessary to make the force more accessible to different races and creeds. At the launch of a conference on policing and diversity, the Met's most senior officers promised it was the start of a new era.

They also conceded the strategy was essential if the force was to stand any chance of recruiting and retaining more officers from minority backgrounds.

The deputy commissioner, Ian Blair, is lobbying the Home Office to give proper recognition to different holy days, so that officers are not bound to the bank holidays in the Church of England calendar.

"We're negotiating at the moment, but I think we'll be pushing at an open door," said Mr Blair. "We have to change the current regulations so we can recognise the festival days of different religions."

Four different styles of the hijab in the Met's colours have been approved for women in uniform, and plain clothes officers can wear their own.

"We know of many Muslim women who had thought of joining the Met, only to be put off when they were told they could not wear the hijab," said Mahammad Mahroof, of the Association of Muslim Police.

"Hopefully, having this option will encourage more to become police officers."

Mr Blair said he was sympathetic to the idea of prayer rooms, but acknowledged it would be impractical to have one in every station.

Headquarters, though, will have a prayer room. Halal food will also be prepared in the New Scotland Yard canteen.

Although cautious of using the word, Mr Blair said "symbolism" was important to the Met as it tried to break away from a troubled, racism-tainted past.

"We are trying to show different people that they are welcome in the force."

The wearing of dreadlocks might be allowed if certain safety issues could be resolved, he said.

"We will look at this very carefully. The same problem affects women with long hair. We don't want officers being endangered. Perhaps there is a way of tying this type of hair."

webTitle: People trafficking second only to drugs, say police

fields.headline: People trafficking second only to drugs, say police
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A police officer yesterday warned that rackets running illegal immigrants into Britain were a national priority "second only to class A drugs" after more than 100 people were arrested in a series of dawn raids.
fields.body:
A police officer yesterday warned that rackets running illegal immigrants into Britain were a national priority "second only to class A drugs" after more than 100 people were arrested in a series of dawn raids.

The warning from Colin Smith, assistant chief constable of Hampshire, came after his force mounted its biggest operation against allegedly organised crime gangs behind human trafficking.

Police said that 250 officers and 42 immigration officials raided 28 houses in the rundown Newtown and Nicholstown areas of Southampton.

In one three-bedroom house officers found 25 people living without heating or hot water. Police said the illegal entrants, mostly from eastern Europe, had been "lured" to the south coast city with promises of lucrative work which turned out to be little more than slave labour. Some had come to Britain after an advert had been placed in a Polish newspaper.

Police detailed the alleged ruthlessness of those they arrested and misery the illegal immigrants were living in to portray the police operation as being as much "humanitarian" as anti-crime.

Ninety five people believed to have been smuggled into Britain by the gang were arrested for entering the country illegally. Officers said they were mainly Polish nationals with others coming from Latvia, Lithuania and Afghanistan. They were aged between 20 and 55, and 73 of the 95 detained were men.

Police said a further 18 people were arrested for "facilitating the illegal entry of people into the United Kingdom".

This group included nine Britons from the Southampton area, five Polish men and one woman, one Russian man and a woman, and one man from India.

During the raids police also stopped several vans and lorries as they pulled away to take more immigrants to local farms and factories to start their working days of up to 15 hours. Wages ranged from £3 an hour to nothing, police believe.

Assistant chief constable Colin Smith said organised crime was moving from drugs to human trafficking which brought high financial rewards but a lower risk of capture: "The key issue is that organised immigration crime is fast becoming a national priority second only to class A drugs in respect of serious organised crime.

"Human trafficking exploits the economic disparities between the relatively affluent UK and developing parts of Europe.

"The immigrants have come here having been offered high income employment. But they have arrived to find they have been working almost as slave labour on agricultural sites around Southampton."

Police said some of the illegal entrants had come to them to ask for help. Those arrested would be encouraged to return to their homelands and were yesterday being interviewed by Immigration Service officials.

The Newtown area is just a mile from the city's docks where container ships arrive every day. Steve Harvey, spokesman for the Immigration Service, said: "Some of the information we received was from people who have lost their jobs because people who are here illegally have taken them. We want to clamp down on these rackets to try and free jobs for the local labour force.

webTitle: Secret u-turn to send Kurds back

fields.headline: Secret u-turn to send Kurds back
fields.standfirst:
Asylum refusal rate soars after 'change of practice' by Home Office

Special report: refugees in Britain
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The government has secretly decided to order Iraqi Kurds seeking refuge from the war-torn country out of Britain, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The government has secretly decided to order Iraqi Kurds seeking refuge from the war-torn country out of Britain, the Guardian has learned.

The Home Office has admitted to an unannounced "change of practice" in the way it assesses asylum claims from Iraqi Kurds who say they are fleeing Saddam Hussein and conflict in the region.

This has led to a dramatic increase in the refusal rate. In February, the last month for which figures are available, 78% of Iraqi applicants were refused asylum or exceptional leave to remain, compared with 14% in July 2000. The refusals peaked in October when 91.4% of those seeking asylum were ordered out of Britain.

Amnesty International last night accused the government of putting its efforts to clamp down on asylum claims ahead of its duties under international guidelines to shield people fleeing persecution.

The Home Office says part of northern Iraq, which it calls the Kurdish autonomous area, is safe for the asylum seekers, as it is under control of Kurdish groups. But in some cases Iraqis from outside the safe area are being ordered out of Britain. In one case a man who says he was tortured after defying President Saddam was told that Jack Straw, the home secretary, regarded his case as one of "prosecution not persecution" and his arrest as having a "valid cause".

Some of the Iraqis ordered out of Britain say they will commit suicide rather than be sent back.

Critics say the change in policy is hypocritical, considering that Britain joined the US in bombing Iraq in January, citing as a justification the continuing danger its leader poses.

A Home Office spokesman said: "There has been a change of practice rather than a change of policy towards asylum seekers from the Kurdish autonomous area of northern Iraq. The Home Office country assessment on which case workers base their decisions has reflected the fact that the Kurdish northern autonomous area is regarded as safe for certain Iraqi Kurds by the Home Office and the office of the United Nations high commissioner for refugees.

"To that end the government is in the process of exploring the options to return Iraqi citizens of Kurdish origin to northern Iraq."

A spokeswoman for the UNHCR, Hope Hanlan, said: "A case-by-case approach is warranted. You can't guarantee the safety of anyone going back ... We do not pronounce ourselves on the safety of any country."

A spokesman for Amnesty said: "We weren't told of the change, it was noticed by us and other groups. The Home Office can call it what it wishes, a change of policy or practice - it's a bogus distinction."

The deportations cannot be enforced yet as there are no direct flights to the parts of Iraq not controlled by President Saddam. Control of northern Iraq falls between three groups, the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, the Kurdistan Democratic party and the Islamic Movement of Iraqi Kurdistan. Some of those refused asylum say they are fleeing these groups.

One man who says he fled President Saddam was arrested twice in Dora, an area controlled by the Iraqi dictator. The man, a power plant engineer, says he tried to resist an order to cut power to Kurdish parts of Iraq. He was suspended, arrested and tortured with electric shocks, beatings and mock execution.

The Home Office's refusal letter said: "The secretary of state considers your claim to be an example of prosecution not persecution. In order to qualify for asylum under the terms of the 1951 United Nations convention ... you would need to be able to show that you would not receive a fair trial or that any punishment you might receive as a result of a conviction would be disproportionate for reasons of race, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion. The secretary of state considers that you have failed to demonstrate that you would be treated unfairly for any of these reasons."

Ali Namik, 28, says he fled Halabja, a city controlled by the Islamic Movement of Iraqi Kurdistan, after the IMIK persecuted him for owning a video shop selling western films, and for being a communist: "I was tortured psychologically and physically. I was beaten up, sometimes with cables, sometimes for an hour they would beat me.

"They're going to kill me, I know what they're like. I won't let them kill me, I'll kill myself."

Ali Rahimi, a solicitor who says he has had 100 Iraqi clients refused asylum since October, said: "Returning to Iraq ... is absolutely terrifying for them. People can not believe what they see in the refusal letters. All they see is that this government is proposing to send them back to Iraq, the same government that has been in a state of war with Iraq for the last 10 years."
