webTitle: Comment: nuclear weapons back on agenda

fields.headline: Size doesn't matter
fields.standfirst:
America has put nuclear weapons back on the agenda. Big or small, they're still dangerous

Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: It is time we Europeans woke up to the fact, however uncomfortable it may be, that nuclear weapons are well and truly back on the agenda.
fields.body:
It is time we Europeans woke up to the fact, however uncomfortable it may be, that nuclear weapons are well and truly back on the agenda. A growing lobby of American political and military zealots, reawakened by President Bush's election success and egged on by leading scientists, want to attack "rogue" states with nuclear weapons.

Under proposals being considered by the US defence department, "mini-nukes" would attack dictators' underground headquarters and their supplies of chemical and biological weapons. Nukes would do what conventional bombs have conspicuously failed to achieve: knock out bunkers being built deeper and deeper into the rocks. User-friendly, "low-yield", nuclear weapons would limit collateral damage (ie killing civilians) and radioactive fall-out, argue their proponents.

"The US will undoubtedly require a new nuclear weapon... because it is realised that the yields of the weapons left over from the cold war are too high for addressing the deterrence requirements of a multipolar, widely proliferated world," Paul Robinson, director of America's Sandia Nuclear Laboratories pronounced recently. "Low-yield weapons with highly accurate delivery systems" would be a useful deterrent, he said, adding that such devices could help decision-makers "contemplate the destruction of some buried or hidden targets while being mindful of the need to minimise collateral damage".

In a paper entitled Nuclear Weapons in the 21st Century, Stephen Younger, head of nuclear weapons research at the Los Alamos laboratory, last year said low-yield nukes would be more effective against underground concrete bunkers and mobile missiles than conventional bombs. Weapons of less than five kilotons, the argument goes, would be a more credible deterrent than "normal" nuclear weapons. Indeed, they could have been used during the Kosovo war. And mini-nukes would enable the US to reduce its stockpile of 6,000 much larger nuclear warheads.

The taboo, whereby nuclear weapons would not be used against non-nuclear powers as a war-fighting tool, was breached last year in an amendment to the US defence budget authorisation bill tabled by two republican senators, John Warner and Wayne Allard. This required the Pentagon to study how best to bomb buried targets, including the use of low-yield nuclear devices.

A 1994 law, the Federation of American Scientists points out in a recent report, prohibits nuclear laboratories in the US from undertaking research and development that could lead to a precision nuclear weapon of less than five kilotons because "low-yield nuclear weapons blur the distinction between nuclear and conventional war". However, it warns that legislation for long-term research and actual development of low-yield nuclear weapons will almost certainly be proposed in the new session of Congress.

The notion that an accurate, low-yield, nuclear bomb would cause limited - acceptable - collateral damage is ludicrous. As Martin Butcher and Theresa Hitchens, two security analysts, point out, a five-kiloton warhead dropped on London might only destroy Islington. But it would kill thousands of people and make thousands more victims of burns, radiation sickness, and blindness.

"The use of any nuclear weapon capable of destroying a buried target that is otherwise immune to conventional attack will necessarily produce enormous numbers of civilian casualties," the federation points out in its report. "No earth-burrowing missile can penetrate deep enough into the earth to contain an explosion with a nuclear yield even as small as 1% of the 15 kiloton Hiroshima weapon," it says. "The explosion simply blows out a massive crater of radioactive dirt, which rains down on the local region with an especially intense and deadly fallout."

The Pentagon is due to send its report on mini-nukes to Congress in July, the same time a separate and comprehensive review of US strategic nuclear deterrence is likely to be published. One thing is certain. As Paul Rogers, professor of peace studies at Bradford University, puts it: "Building new nuclear weapons is firmly on the agenda of the Bush administration."

fields.headline: New warrant for Russian magnate
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The Russian press baron Vladimir Gusinsky left Spain last night as his recently regained freedom came under threat from Moscow prosecutors.
fields.byline: Giles Tremlett in Madrid and Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem
fields.body:
The Russian press baron Vladimir Gusinsky left Spain last night as his recently regained freedom came under threat from Moscow prosecutors who issued a new international arrest warrant accusing him of money laundering.

The move came the day after a Spanish court threw out a previous Russian extradition request on fraud charges, allowing Mr Gusinsky to travel for the first time in four months.

It also came after Mr Gusinsky claimed, in an interview in yesterday's Guardian, that the Russian president, Vladimir Putin would not cease in his attempts to destroy him as punishment for the critical journalism of his NTV station and other news outlets.

The Russian prosecutor's spokesman, Yuri Vasilchenko, confirmed yesterday that the new warrant had been lodged with Interpol. He said Mr Gusinsky was being accused of laundering 2.8bn roubles (£67m).

"The charges are backed by strong evidence and we expect that Gusinsky will be extradited," he said.

But the warrant will now arrive too late to catch Mr Gusinsky, who spent yesterday in Gibraltar where he has residency as an individual of high net worth and holds business interests.

His lawyers in Madrid said he planned to fly from there directly to Israel in his private jet last night.

Mr Gusinsky has joint Israeli-Russian nationality. He would probably be immune to extradition from Israel but would still face arrest and new extradition hearings if he returned to Europe or the United States.

Neither Mr Gusinsky's Madrid lawyers nor his representative in Israel, Mark Mejerson, were able to say exactly where he was last night.

Mr Gusinsky's Spanish lawyers reacted angrily to the news of a fresh Interpol warrant. "This is an abuse of both Interpol and the Spanish courts. What they are seeking is to have him detained for purely political reasons," said Gerardo Miguel.

Mr Gusinsky also has business interests in Israel, where he owns a 25% share in the newspaper Ma'ariv. He founded the Russian Jewish Congress and is a friend of many Israeli politicians, including the prime minister, Ariel Sharon.

Mr Sharon's spokesman, Raanan Gissin, said yesterday that Mr Gusinsky was welcome. "He is an Israeli citizen. He can come here any time he wants."

This month the Russian company Gazprom , closely linked to the state, took control of Mr Gusinsky's Media Most empire and its flagship NTV channel. Most of NTV's news staff resigned after the takeover, which they claimed was a Kremlin attempt to stifle the free press.

The group's Sevodnya newspaper was suspended and the staff of the weekly news magazine Itogi were dismissed.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A caption for a photograph of Winston Churchill (Notes & Queries, G2, page 18, April 19) in the North African desert, said he was accompanied by General Montgomery and the impression was given that the photograph was taken before the battle of El Alamein.
fields.body:
A caption for a photograph of Winston Churchill (Notes & Queries, G2, page 18, April 19) in the North African desert, said he was accompanied by General Montgomery and the impression was given that the photograph was taken before the battle of El Alamein. In fact the person on Churchill's left, while bearing a passing resemblance to Montgomery, was Lt Col EO Kellett of the Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry and the picture was taken at Khatatba in Egypt in July 1942, prior to the battle of Alam el Halfa, which took place before El Alamein.

It was Lindsay Duncan who played the Marquise de Merteuil in the Royal Shakespeare Company's 1984 production of Les Liaisons Dangereuses (Worlds of his own, Saturday Review, page 6, April 21), and not Lesley Duncan as stated.

A letter referring to the obituary of Wilf Page (page 20, April 23), said he was posted to RAF Uxbridge before the first world war. This should have said the second world war. Mr Page was only one when the Great War began and the RAF was not formed until 1918.

We said, impossibly, that the number of British submarines lost in the second world war was 74 from a total of 36 (100 years under the sea, Educa tion, page 68, April 24). The total number was 206.

... and Sullum Voe (Corrections and Clarifications yesterday) is, of course, spelt Sullom Voe.

webTitle: Tesco recalls chicken in pet food scare

fields.headline: Tesco recalls chicken in pet food scare
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Tesco has recalled thousands of frozen chicken steaks amid fears they may have been made with meat destined for the pet food industry, the company said last night.
fields.body:
Tesco has recalled thousands of frozen chicken steaks amid fears they may have been made with meat destined for the pet food industry, the company said last night.

The meat, considered unfit for human consumption, could have found its way into Tesco and Farmfoods supermarkets. Farmfoods has recalled its breaded chicken nuggets.

A Tesco spokesman said: "We were made aware there could be a problem with this product and have issued a recall notice with immediate effect."

Its "Premier" four-breaded chicken steaks had come from Perkins Frozen Foods UK, based in Stoke-on-Trent. The food standards agency (FSA) said Perkins could have used the meat "unwittingly". It has issued a hazard notice into two products made by the company.

The move came as the FSA and police continued to investigate allegations that tons of chicken, branded unfit for human consumption, had made its way from a Derby pet food company into the human food chain.

An FSA spokeswoman said it was unlikely there would be any significant health risks from the Perkins products but "as a precautionary measure, the FSA advises against their consumption".

webTitle: Makeover brings back the middle class

fields.headline: Makeover brings back the middle class
fields.standfirst: Revival to give M&S heart
fields.trailText: Two years ago Laura Ashley looked like a dead man walking. Under the misguided hand of its American chief executive, Ann Iverson, the company had overexpanded, overstocked and was overstretched.
fields.body:
Two years ago Laura Ashley looked like a dead man walking. Under the misguided hand of its American chief executive, Ann Iverson, the company had overexpanded, overstocked and was overstretched. Sales, together with the shares, were in freefall and the auditors warned it was perilously close to bankruptcy.

Then along came a Malyasian industrialist with deep pockets, Dr Kay Peng Khoo, and the company that is synonymous with pretty prints and chintz has undergone a transformation.

Yesterday it turned in profits of £10.2m, up from a £4.1m loss a year ago, and said sales were booming, especially in home furnishings.

It has played to its middle class strengths, shutting down its concessions in Homebase stores and instead offering a full design service together with all the products required for a Changing Rooms-style makeover.

Recent British Retail Consortium figures showed the home furnishings market up 7% in the last year, where Laura Ashley has witnessed a like for like sales increase of nearly 20%.

It has also made over its clothing ranges and brightened up its dull shops. It is closing its expensive European administrative operations - saving £1m in the process - and is now again in expansionary mode, targeting Europe and stand-alone home furnishings stores in posh provincial towns.

The product range has been expanded and branding licenses are being granted to other manufacturers on goods such as paint, carpets, fragrances and even spectacle frames.

There is the risk that the company will allow the name to be used on inappropriate products, ultimately devaluing it. But the finance director, Jim Bellingham, is adamant that Laura Ashley now has a prosperous future. "This is a very different company now," he said yesterday. "We are moving forward in a controlled fashion and we know what we are doing". And you get the impression that they truly do.

Marks & Spencer should take heart: Lazarus-like comebacks are possible.

Poverty league

For supporters of Coventry, Derby and Manchester City, these are agonising times as their respective clubs battle against the threat of relegation from the premier league. But for the economy, the nailbiting days are over - the worst has happened and UK plc is now languishing in the second tier of nations after a less than impressive performance over the past year. So says the Swiss-based business school, IMD, which in its annual index of world competitiveness shows that Britain - after rising as high as 9th in 1997 - slipped from 16th to 19th in 2000.

This is all wonderful ammunition for politicians, but no cause for Gordon Brown to wonder whether he is for the chop. For a start, the idea that countries compete with other is utterly meaningless, because one nation does not become poorer if another becomes richer. Companies compete; countries do not.

Moreover, the IMD survey is not an objective, scientific analysis but a hotchpotch of hard data and survey evidence collected by questionaire from ex ecutives, who - surprise, surprise - prefer countries where business regulation is minimal (the US) to those where it is tight (Europe). Britain scores well for direct investment flows abroad, where it is ranked 1st out of 49 countries, but 48th for central government debt, which fell by a record amount last year.

We all like to have a moan about Whitehall, but is government efficiency (UK: 24th) really worse here than in Estonia (16th)?

Fiery start

Reclusive Frenchman Jean-Pierre Garnier has had a fiery start as chief executive of Glaxo SmithKline. After just three months in the job, his name is a rude word for lefties worldwide.

Mr Garnier has been drawn into making "personal interventions" to sort out the industry's South African mess. As the leading producer of HIV-Aids drugs, Glaxo has more at stake than its peers.

The controversy has diverted attention from the job of merging two multinational companies, which has been upset by several big disappointments. Bowel drug Lotronex was withdrawn last year and it now appears that Relenza, Glaxo's much-hyped flu drug, has flopped worldwide.

Glaxo admits it has gaps in its late-stage pipeline, and will need to licence in drugs from elsewhere to fill them.

A report yesterday from Accenture questioned the urge to merge, criticising the "myth" that "bigger is better". It argues that it is more important to provide liberal, conducive working environments for pointy-headed scientists. In view of its labs' poor output, Mr Garnier faces a challenge in convincing the market that creating the Glaxo mega-corporation was worth the trouble.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Apprentices reprieved
fields.body:
Apprentices reprieved

The future of 240 apprentices at the Cammell Laird shipyard in Birkenhead appears to have been secured after the intervention of education secretary David Blunkett.

The workers received a letter yesterday from Mr Blunkett telling them that the new Learning and Skills Council had taken on the obligation written into their agreement to ensure that their apprenticeships were completed.

The apprentices feared for their futures following the company's collapse into receivership. Mr Blunkett told them yesterday: "This means that, should your placement at Lairds be terminated, the LSC will seek alternative work placement for you."

CGNU receives asbestos plea

Activists used the annual meeting of CGNU yesterday to question the board about a former asbestos mining company in which the insurer's Norwich Union arm holds a sizeable stake.

Members of the Action for Southern Africa group and representatives of the South African National Union of Mineworkers urged Norwich Union to "exercise its shareholder power" by calling on UK-based Cape to settle compensation claims from former employees allegedly suffering from asbestos-related illnesses.

Crosby Moni, deputy president of the South African NUM, requested a minute's silence in memory of those who had died but was told this would not be appropriate.

In a statement, Norwich Union said it was "well aware of the seriousness of the situation concerning the allegations about the past mining activities of the Cape group". Discussions had been held with the Cape management and other shareholders.

Boeing aims to catch Concorde

Boeing's chief executive yesterday stepped up the war of words with European rival Airbus, claiming that Concorde's position as the leading luxury aircraft would be overtaken by Boeing's new 750mph "sonic cruiser".

Phil Condit, who is seeking to transform the image of the world's biggest aircraft manufacturer said the sonic cruiser would replace Concorde as a market leader for first and business class passengers.

"Concorde is very expensive to operate. Although it will take us some years to overtake it, it will happen."

Shell cited in Karachi case

RoyalDutch/Shell, Premier Oil and the Pakistan government today face a legal challenge in a Karachi court from environmental campaigners over plans to explore for gas in the country's oldest national park.

Friends of the Earth and local activitists point out that Kirtharis is on the United Nations list of protected areas.

The campaigners dispute claims that the oil industry has operated in "perfect harmony" with the environment, by questioning Shell's record in Nigeria.

webTitle: Reuters insists the punishment will be slight

fields.headline: Reuters insists the punishment will be slight
fields.trailText: Reuters sought to calm fears that the business is being battered by the turmoil in the financial markets, despite warning yesterday of a slowdown in revenue growth during the second quarter.
fields.body:
Reuters sought to calm fears that the business is being battered by the turmoil in the financial markets, despite warning yesterday of a slowdown in revenue growth during the second quarter.

Shares in the news and information group fell almost 7% to 911p after publication of a trading update which said revenue growth would be slightly slower in the coming months.

Peter Job, the chief executive, called on investors to view the cautious statement in context. "We are not pointing anyone to a material difference," he said. "One could overdo this. We have used the word slight."

Mr Job said it was a misconception to believe a slowdown in corporate activity and bank job losses would damage the business. "I've seen various things saying Reuters has the bulk of its revenues from investment banks - that merger & acquisition and IPO activity slowing and banks letting people go is bad for Reuters. But you have to put some perspective on this. If you take the top seven investment banks, the total amount of revenue we get from them is less than 6% of our business."

The group reported a 17% increase in first-quarter revenues to £970m, driven by strong performances from its core financial division and Instinet, the electronic broking arm gearing up for flotation. The figures were at the top end of most analysts' expectations.

Reuters Financial increased revenues 11% to £658m with markets holding up in both the US and Europe. Instinet recorded a 27% rise in revenues to £250m.

Mr Job, who will be handing the chief executive post to Tom Glocer in July, said that the company's position had been strengthened by the collapse of Bridge Information Systems. "We have well established and strong products while competition in general is weaker," he said.

"Out of three global vendors of financial information one is in the bankruptcy courts. That business will not come out of the courts as it went in, so from a competitive standpoint that is good news for Reuters one way or another."

Two weeks ago Reuters bid for certain Bridge assets with the aim of substantially increasing its presence in the United States. It hopes to acquire the Bridge Trading brokerage unit, internet business eBridge and EJV Bond Data.

In addition, Reuters aims to buy Bridge Trading Technologies and Transaction services and has taken an option on Bridge's stake in internet service provider Savvis. It is competing with a US software firm, SunGard, for some assets.

The auction was expected to have been completed a week ago but Mr Glocer said the bankruptcy court was stretching the process to ensure the best deal for creditors.

Mr Job said the company is confident it can still achieve the target of £150m in annual savings by migrating its business on to the internet.

Peter Job, the chief executive, called on investors to view the cautious statement in context. "We are not pointing anyone to a material difference," he said. "One could overdo this. We have used the word slight." Mr Job said it was a misconception to believe a slowdown in corporate activity and bank job losses would damage the business. "I've seen various things saying Reuters has the bulk of its revenues from investment banks - that merger & acquisition and IPO activity slowing and banks letting people go is bad for Reuters. But you have to put some perspective on this. If you take the top seven investment banks, the total amount of revenue we get from them is less than 6% of our business." The group reported a 17% increase in first-quarter revenues to £970m, driven by strong performances from its core financial division and Instinet, the electronic broking arm gearing up for flotation. The figures were at the top end of most analysts' expectations. Reuters Financial increased revenues 11% to £658m with markets holding up in both the US and Europe. Instinet recorded a 27% rise in revenues to £250m. Mr Job, who will be handing the chief executive post to Tom Glocer in July, said that the company's position had been strengthened by the collapse of Bridge Information Systems. "We have well established and strong products while competition in general is weaker," he said. "Out of three global vendors of financial information one is in the bankruptcy courts. That business will not come out of the courts as it went in, so from a competitive standpoint that is good news for Reuters one way or another." Two weeks ago Reuters bid for certain Bridge assets with the aim of substantially increasing its presence in the United States. It hopes to acquire the Bridge Trading brokerage unit, internet business eBridge and EJV Bond Data. In addition, Reuters aims to buy Bridge Trading Technologies and Transaction services and has taken an option on Bridge's stake in internet service provider Savvis. It is competing with a US software firm, SunGard, for some assets. The auction was expected to have been completed a week ago but Mr Glocer said the bankruptcy court was stretching the process to ensure the best deal for creditors. Mr Job said the company is confident it can still achieve the target of £150m in annual savings by migrating its business on to the internet.

webTitle: The downward spiral of British industry

fields.headline: History repeats itself in Bathgate
fields.trailText: Claude Miller's career path tracks the downward spiral of British industry.
fields.body:
Claude Miller's career path tracks the downward spiral of British industry. The 49-year-old purchasing manager was first made redundant from the British Steel plant at Ravenscraig, then from a small hi-tech firm, and yesterday joined the 3,000 workers at Motorola's Bathgate factory who learned that the facility was to close.

Outside the factory, Mr Miller said workers were devastated by the news, which came despite high-level political intervention.

"I just didn't think it would close," he said. "I thought there might be redundancies but we thought they might keep the factory open. There was still hope. There are a lot of committed people in there; people who have been here for years and have put time and effort in."

As with many others who work for the company, the job losses are now a family problem. Mr Miller's sister, Susan Innes, his nephew and nephew's fiancé all found employment in the factory, which sits on the edge of the small West Lothian town.

Mrs Innes, who has worked at Motorola for eight years as a manager, said the reality of the news had not yet sunk in.

"I have not yet absorbed what it means. I am just thinking of my family. My son came out of college and started there and I wanted him to have a future. He and his fiancé have just bought a house and I don't know what they will do now. I don't know what any of us will do."

In Bathgate the news was greeted with dismay and anger. The town knows the pain of lay-offs only too well. In the 1980s it had to cope with the rundown of the mining industry and the closure of the British Leyland truck plant, which once employed 6,000 people.

Yesterday, local councillor Willie Dunn, the economic development spokesman for West Lothian council, said that once again the community would have to pull together to support those who had lost their jobs and try to find alternative employment.

"This is obviously a big blow to the area but we have learned from the mistakes of the past so we can move forward from this. It's going to be hard and it's a long road but we can move forward and help people get other jobs in the area."

Mary Mulligan, the Labour MSP for Linlithgow, said news of the closure had been all the more galling because the plant had such a strong track record.

webTitle: DNA shot fails to hit market spot

fields.headline: DNA shot fails to hit market spot
fields.trailText: Powderject Pharmaceuticals has claimed a breakthrough in vaccine technology by coming up with a DNA-based injection which appears to work on patients who are resistant to existing anti-hepatitis shots.
fields.body:
Powderject Pharmaceuticals has claimed a breakthrough in vaccine technology by coming up with a DNA-based injection which appears to work on patients who are resistant to existing anti-hepatitis shots.

The Oxford-based company has taken elements of DNA from the hepatitis B virus which do not cause disease but do stimulate an immune response in patients. These are added to gold particles and blasted through the skin in powder form.

Results from the first phase of clinical trials showed Powderject's DNA vaccine produced an immune response in 80% of patients who did not react to a conventional hepatitis B shot.

Powderject says this is the first time a DNA vaccine has been found to work in usually "non-responsive" patients.

The company's chief executive, Paul Drayson, said the data underlined what he called Powderject's world lead in the field.

However, the stock market was unimpressed: the company's shares slipped 1p to close at 414p last night.

fields.headline: SWT spends £1bn on new carriages
fields.standfirst: Stagecoach buys German upgrade
fields.trailText: Weary commuters on South West Trains can look forward to greater comfort and less overcrowding from late next year as a result of a record £1bn order for almost 800 new carriages placed yesterday.
fields.body:
Weary commuters on South West Trains can look forward to greater comfort and less overcrowding from late next year as a result of a record £1bn order for almost 800 new carriages placed yesterday.

Stagecoach, SWT's owner, said it had ordered 785 carriages from Siemens, the German engineering group, which is already producing the units in Düsseldorf and Vienna.

Most of the order will replace SWT's 580 ageing "slam-door" carriages, which are being phased out under a general government order by the end of 2004.

But some 200 will help SWT increase peak capacity by 25% and put on extra services between Waterloo and Windsor, Woking and Basingstoke.

Against the odds, SWT was selected by the strategic rail authority as the preferred bidder for a new 20-year franchise, due to run from 2003. It beat off bids from FirstGroup and GNER.

The £1bn order for new carriages is part of an initial £1.7bn investment programme - including station improvements - agreed with the SRA, which is also considering SWT's offer to put in a further £2.3bn during the life of the franchise.

The new carriages are being financed through a deal between Stagecoach and train leasing company Angel Trains, a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Industry insiders estimate that the bedraggled rail undustry will need to invest £8bn until 2010 in around 10,000 new vehicles.

The SRA, which has withdrawn its own order for new SWT trains, said the Siemens contract would help it meet its target of increasing rail use by 50% over the next decade.

The German company plans to begin trials for the new carriages on a purpose-built track recreating the old Southern Railway at its testing centre in Wildenrath, near Düsseldorf, later this year.

fields.headline: Wolves at last chance saloon
fields.trailText: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has taken an axe to its pubs and brewing operations in a last-ditch attempt to cling on to its independence.
fields.body:
Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has taken an axe to its pubs and brewing operations in a last-ditch attempt to cling on to its independence.

The company yesterday confirmed plans to shut its Mansfield Brewery, sell its Camerons plant in Hartlepool and slim down its managed pub chain to a modest cluster of outlets in the Midlands.

Chief executive Ralph Findlay vowed to press ahead with the cuts after questioning the "credibility" of possible bidders - pub chain Pubmaster and leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare could only come up with "conditional" proposals in time for a bid deadline on Friday.

Mr Findlay said: "What we've had are expressions of interest - they're not bids.

"It's not certain that those are capable of being converted into bids. At some stage, you've got to take some view about their credibility and their ability to prosecute what they're proposing."

However, despite his defiant language, Mr Findlay left the door open for company's two suitors, saying that Wolves would continue to cooperate with their due diligence.

Mr Breare and Pubmaster are both thought willing to offer up to 510p a share - worth £480m.

Mr Breare is believed to be three or four weeks away from a formal bid. He said: "Given a reasonable level of cooperation, as promised, we're in reach of being able to make a final proposal to their board."

Pubmaster was more circumspect - its chief executive, John Sands, said he may need to do more due diligence in light of Wolves' new strategy to ensure a takeover remained a "viable option". Some market sources suggested he was trying to "talk down the price". Wolves' shares fell 34p to 479p.

Wolves' closures will mean 200 job losses, mainly in logistics operations at Burton-upon-Trent. The closure of its Mansfield Brewery is likely to cause local anger - the town's Labour MP, Alan Meale, has been a fierce critic of Wolves. But the company said many Mansfield staff could be offered alternative jobs nearby.

fields.headline: Ministry in battle for control
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence has struggled for years to contain the costs of its big contracts and reduce delays in equipment entering service . Despite an array of initiatives - the latest being "smart procurement" - the ministry has become a byword for profligacy.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence has struggled for years to contain the costs of its big contracts and reduce delays in equipment entering service . Despite an array of initiatives - the latest being "smart procurement" - the ministry has become a byword for profligacy.

The Type 45 destroyer was conceived as a tri-nation project with France and Italy. The government dumped this in April 1999 because of irreconcilable disputes.

It was due to enter service in early 2003, but the first three ships should be delivered to the navy in November 2007. According to the national audit office, it will cost the MoD an extra £565m to run the existing Type 42 destroyers because of the delay - offset by an unspecified saving on late investment in the new destroyers.

Surveying the MoD's 20 biggest projects, the NAO found forecast costs were 0.2% lower in 2000 - when the "smart" process began - than in 1999, but they remained 5.7% higher than when the main investment was approved - £2.4bn on top of the £42.3bn estimate.

The bulk of this is accounted for by Eurofighter, £1.47bn over-budget, with the remaining 19 projects running £937m or 3.8% higher.

At the same time SirJohn Bourn, head of the NAO, found in-service dates had slipped by a further three months in 2000 to 28 months, prompting David Davis, chairman of the defence select committee, to warn of delays seriously compromising defence capability.

webTitle: Dirty deeds on the high seas

fields.headline: Dirty deeds on the high seas
fields.standfirst: How Britain's defence needs are decided by backstabbing and coercion in the corridors of power
fields.trailText: How Britain's defence needs are decided by backstabbing and coercion in the corridors of power.
fields.body:
Claire Burt stands on the bridge of the RV Triton, an experimental trimaran warship, and looks out at the imposing bulk of HMS Illustrious, the aircraft carrier, berthed just up the quay in Portsmouth naval dockyard. As project manager for the vessel, commissioned by the defence evaluation and research agency, rebranded as QinetiQ, she's excited by the prospects for the vessel and her enthusiasm is infectious.

On May 9 Triton, in the middle of trials, sails for America where it is being offered to the navy and the coastguard. The 97m vessel is equipped with 500 sensors monitoring her stresses and performance, notably in high seas and force 9 gales.

Back in Southampton, Martin Jay, the chief executive of Vosper Thornycroft, which built Triton and delivered it last August, two months ahead of schedule, says casually: "There's an innovative verve about this company. You can't imagine a BAE yard building it." Behind his irony lies a bitterness about the ruthless manner in which Britain's premier defence contractor is trying to muscle Vosper out of the warship business - as Jay sees it.

There is more to this than David versus Goliath. The struggle between Vosper and BAE Systems touches the quick of how the government should ensure national security and value for taxpayers' money in an era of unprecedented peace - and vicious regional conflicts. Is competition the way to avoid the costly delays that have characterised procurement in the past? Or, like the French, should Britain allow its national champion to monopolise the market and force smaller rivals into niche segments - at a time when globalisation is producing fewer, bigger suppliers and forcing greater dependence between these and their customers? Does competition create two weak rivals incapable of efficiency and innovation?

These strategic issues are being addressed by companies with the traditional use of ferocious lobbying power, political threats, industrial muscle and the whole sorry panoply of bloody bolshieness that passes for defence acquisition - what Jay calls "dirty deals done in dark corners". Shareholders sweat; employees fear for their jobs; industry executives spend more time in Whitehall cajoling and backstabbing than running their companies.

The immediate issue is who shall build 12 Type 45 destroyers for the Royal Navy in a contract worth up to £6bn, with an in-service date of 2007. In July 2000 the MoD decided the first three should be divided, with Vosper building one and BAE Marine, part of the aerospace group, two. BAES remained prime contractor, main driver of an alliance of the warship builders and the defence procurement agency.

That alliance collapsed last December when BAE Marine made an unsolicited bid to build all 12 Type 45s - an offer being evaluated by Sir Robert Walmesley, chief of defence procurement, and to be considered by ministers who are unlikely to act before June 7. BAE insiders insist their hand was forced because Jay and the Vosper board rejected an agreed structure, process and price for the contract and put in a higher, take-it-or-leave-it price.

BAE says its offer represents greater value and, if the project comes in below the price, the savings will be shared with the exchequer. It has effectively told Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, and Sir Robert it wants to be sole builder of bigger, more complex warships while Vosper and its peers can design and build smaller craft. It has offered Vosper free rein to build naval ships below 85m - which it would then market abroad for the Southampton company. Vosper cried foul. Monopolists, they shouted. Its far bigger rival (and occasional joint venture partner), forced to issue a profits warning in January because of cost overruns and losses on other MoD contracts, was trying to solve its problems by coercing Whitehall into allowing it control of the warship market.

The monopolist charge sticks, certainly with BAE's main competitors. "Competition is something which is necessary, helpful and good for the customer; any restriction of markets is a disease," says one senior European defence executive. "BAE Systems is telling the world it wants to be the monopoly supplier in the UK and demanding open access to the US, European and other markets."

BAES's military-industrial-political power is such that even its bitterest rivals do deals with it, often afraid to take it on. Jay, fighting to retain warship building as a part of Vosper's business (albeit one that accounts for 30% of sales and profits) brushes aside the "fear factor" and ac cuses BAES of trying to hold the government to ransom.

His reasoning is simple. BAES, via its merger with the then GEC's defence electronics division, inherited three shipyards - Barrow in Furness, and Govan and Scotstoun on the Clyde - and needs to invest £147m to bring them up to date. It has admitted that at least one of these is surplus to needs (probably Scotstoun) while Govan, empty of work, is losing £3m a month or more. Jay claims BAE Marine can submit a lower price only because the mother group, as prime contractor, can recoup the losses further up the supply chain.

It is not an argument that cuts much ice with BAES which denies it seeks a monopoly. Rather, it says, it wants a "strategic restructuring" of the warship industry that will bring an end to the cyclical nature of MoD work which in turn forces it to spread programmes around Britain's yards - often with disastrous results, as at Cammell Laird. "It's a great opportunity to get some security into the industry, stop playing Russian roulette with people's jobs and improve our performance in export markets," say insiders.

Its counter-argument is that its approach, by ensuring economies of scale, will bring greater value for money and make capital investment that much less risky. Jay, in turn, says forcibly that open competition - "It's written into the very fabric of this company" - will encourage innovation, cost control and greater productivity and his company has a track record in this regard. "We've consistently been profitable; they're losing money," he says, prompting the reply from BAES: "He doesn't want competition; he wants allocation - and taxpayers' funds to build the new yard for the destroyers in Portsmouth."

So far, in this increasingly nasty dogfight, Vosper has gained the upper hand in terms of public support. Its case won't necessarily cut the mustard in Whitehall where senior insiders say: "This is not just about Type 45s but the future direction of the warship construction industry in the UK, especially the production of highly complex ships such as carriers, frigates, destroyers and assault vessels." BAES, on the other hand, has too often overplayed its powerful hand and created enemies, not least among important ministers.

The only certain outcome is that the ships will be British-built.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: We are delighted to note Gordon Brown marking the eve of yesterday's keynote speech to the annual conference of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development with a slap-up dinner of traditional British fare.
fields.body:
 We are delighted to note Gordon Brown marking the eve of yesterday's keynote speech to the annual conference of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development with a slap-up dinner of traditional British fare. In what many will interpret as a hardening of his resistance to European integration, Gordon was seen to pass by a string of continental eateries on Kennington Road, south London - turning instead to the fine Gandhi's Restaurant, whereupon he ordered a lamb bhuna, boiled rice, two poppadums and a pint of lager.

It is perhaps a sign of New Labour's renowned discipline - you will recall Robin Cook's seemingly casual aside on the importance of chicken tikka masala last week - that the trattorias of Islington have been so abruptly usurped in the affections of Westminster folk. Jack Straw, we understand, is another New Labour loyalist who has been spotted dashing south of the river to pick up a Gandhi's takeout - sometimes, say sources, up to three times a week.

 As the crisis among the telecoms companies drowning in debt deepens we draw encouragement from the host of mobile phone retailers who yesterday took five full-page ads in the Sun. Or, to be precise, five full pages, minus two column inches on page 42. "Serious debts?" an advertisement inquires in the tiniest of fonts. "Avoid bankruptcy - up to 95% of unsecured debt can be written off with our help..."

 At last, negotiations with Noel Edmonds begin. He wrote to us, you recall, asking to use the Guardian as a vehicle to "unashamedly promote" his video-conferencing firm VMC. Now his office has instructed us to fax through a proposal. "Dear Noel," we begin. "Thank you for your kind offer. After some thought, we have come up with a suggestion which we think will provide your company with an ideal showcase. A live VMC video-conferencing link will be set up between the Guardian's website and the Edmonds country retreat in Jacobstowe, Devon. Members of the web-surfing public will be able to email pop trivia questions for you to GuardianUnlimited, then watch our journalists ask those questions live over the VMC link. There's a twist. Sitting in your favourite armchair by the fireside, you will attempt to answer questions as best you can, but for every incorrect response a gunge tank above your head will shower you in a brightly coloured goo." All that remains is to fix a date in Noel's diary.

 Our attention is drawn to a press release from Bank of Scotland. It concerns an innovative scheme the bank is pioneering to reverse the decline in the number of children following their forebears into Britain's many excellent family-run businesses. It is an intriguing scheme - worthy of wider publicity than this column can provide. Pressure of space means we must confine our coverage to the heading: "Bank launches family planning service".

Simon.bowers@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Deal eludes Elementis
fields.trailText: It is more than four months since speciality chemicals company Elementis revealed it had received a speculative takeover approach, and traders are starting to wonder if a deal will ever appear.
fields.body:
It is more than four months since speciality chemicals company Elementis revealed it had received a speculative takeover approach, and traders are starting to wonder if a deal will ever appear.

According to the gossips the venture capital group which approached Elementis in December has walked away after taking a closer look at the company.

The only hope now, say traders, lies with the potential buyers Elementis is targeting with its "marketing" campaign. With full-year figures in February, Elementis announced it had started a marketing exercise to determine whether it could obtain an offer at the right price from a potential predator. Given the recent flurry of takeovers in the sector and Elementis's diverse portfolio, traders are not confident it will sell at a price acceptable to financial buyers.

Elementis closed 0.5p higher at 97p last night.

webTitle: Lyn Gardner on The Right Size show

fields.headline: Adventures in Wonderland
fields.standfirst: Their last show was about being stuck in a bathroom for 25 years. Now The Right Size are back, with another surreal set-up. They talk to  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Their last show was about being stuck in a bathroom for 25 years. Now The Right Size are back, with another surreal set-up. They talk to Lyn Gardner.
fields.body:
Hamish McColl and Sean Foley have spent much of the past four years trying to escape from a bathroom. For the foreseeable future they will be attempting to get out of the upholstered netherworld into which they have slipped down the back of a sofa. It's funny how some people earn a living.

McColl and Foley are better known as The Right Size. Almost as soon as they began touring in the late 1980s, they earned a loyal following on the small-scale circuit. They were admired by the same people who enjoyed Theatre de Complicite and other physical-theatre shows. Even so, this pair of clowns seemed destined to spend the rest of their careers playing out their fantastical scenarios in provincial arts centres.

Then, in 1997, they got stage designer Alice Power to build them a bathroom. Inspired by the experiences of Beirut hostages Brian Keenan and John McCarthy, Do You Come Here Often? was 75 minutes of absurdist comedy in which McColl and Foley, as the prattish David and spacey Kevin, were trapped for 25 years with only each other and a pastel-coloured bathroom suite for company. Suddenly McColl and Foley were being compared to Morecambe and Wise on the one hand, and Beckett's Vladimir and Estragon on the other. Over the next few years they conquered Edinburgh, the West End and Broadway.

Now, after a long gap, they are back with a new show. Bewilderness is about two middle-aged men on a golfing holiday in Devon, who hear someone crying for help from down the back of a sofa. Unwisely, they decide to investigate. Before long, they find themselves trapped in a surreal betwixt-and-between world, where a man wearing a ruby slipper rides a bicycle, and somebody else is dressed up as a broom. McColl and Foley are sharing the stage with Freddie Jones, a longtime fan of The Right Size, who has worked for both Fellini and David Lynch. I bet he's never done anything quite as weird as Bewilderness.

So why has it taken McColl and Foley so long to produce a follow-up to Do You Come Here Often? In fact, they have not been idle. They have made Brecht seem improbably jolly and entertaining while playing the lead roles in Lee Hall's version of Mr Puntilla and His Man Matti at the Traverse in Edinburgh and the Almeida in London. They have also spent time writing radio comedy.

Foley likens what they have been doing to "the old fallow field system. You crop a couple of fields and leave another untouched. Then, after a couple of years, you go to work on it again and see what grows there."

This is quite a long speech for the laconic Foley. Meeting them you are struck by how much their stage personas reflect their real-life personalities. McColl, 39, is all pop-eyed enthusiasms; Foley, 36, is quiet and makes his points with well-timed gestures. In Bewilderness McColl's interpretation of the world down the back of the sofa as a benign wonderland is countered by Foley's dour rationalism. In a way the show is a metaphor for the experience of theatre itself: one person looks at the stage and sees a magical place, while another sees only a bare space with an actor walking across it.

Like all The Right Size's shows, Bewilderness is a devised piece, which develops as it is performed - though McColl notes that "although we always say that we do shows, not plays, this does have more of the feel of a play about it. The hardest thing with devised work is to find a structure that works. Over the years I've seen so many devised shows that have included brilliant bits but haven't worked as a whole. Working on Mr Puntilla and doing more writing has definitely influenced us."

It has also influenced perceptions about the company. Just as Complicite began to be taken seriously by the mainstream only when it put on Shakespeare, so McColl and Foley feel that doing Brecht has given them a new credibility. "It's the culture," says Foley. "You don't get recognition for making people laugh and low comedy is what we do best."

But they are selling themselves short. One of the best things about Do You Come Here Often? was that, though it was full of gags, Foley and McColl never looked as if they were trying to make you laugh. Rather, laughter was the best possible outcome in a scenario that could just as easily have led to tears.

Similarly, in Bewilderness, the fine line between comedy and tragedy is expertly etched. Having seen the show, I now feel about the B1102 at Uttoxeter how I felt when I was 11 and read CS Lewis's final book in the Narnia chronicles and discovered what really happened to Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy. Classic children's literature, including the Narnia books, The Wizard of Oz and Alice in Wonderland, appears to be a strong, although perhaps unconscious, influence on Bewilderness. So does Dante's Inferno.

So what, in the end, is the show about? "I suppose it's about us. All our shows are about us," says McColl. "It's about two men approaching middle age questioning what we have done, what is behind us and what is in front. It is about being at the midpoint of your life and stumbling off the road into the wood."

"We're always saying, 'That's it, that's our last show. We can't top that.' Maybe this time we won't," adds Foley.

"Maybe after this we'll have nothing left to say," ponders McColl gloomily.

"Cheer up," says Foley. "Clowns get better with age."

 Bewilderness is at the Traverse, Edinburgh (0131-228 1404), until Saturday, and at the Lyric Hammersmith, London W6 (020-8741 2311), from May 2-June 2.

webTitle: Profile of rock band The Black Crowes

fields.headline: Britney's worst nightmare
fields.standfirst: Sick to death of all that bland pop? The Black Crowes are here to help.  Caroline Sullivan  meets 'the most rock'n'roll rock'n'roll band in the world'
fields.trailText: Sick to death of all that bland pop? The Black Crowes are here to help. Caroline Sullivan meets 'the most rock'n'roll rock'n'roll band in the world'.
fields.body:
It is a tall order being the Jesus of Rock, and Chris Robinson, the scraggly-haired former heroin-dabbler who fronts the Black Crowes, would not be everyone's choice for the job. But at least one person thinks he is Liam Gallagher, Iggy Pop and Bart Simpson rolled into one. Kate Hudson, the Oscar-nominated actress, married Robinson on New Year's Eve after knowing him for eight months. At 34, he is 13 years older than Hudson and almost closer in age to her mother, Goldie Hawn (who is apparently also a fan).

In the flesh, Robinson looks less a lady-killer than a parody of an early-1970s rock star. The shoulder-grazing hair is complemented by turquoise jewellery and extra-long blue flares, in contrast to the subdued sportswear of his guitarist brother, Rich. But the look, which conjures up iconic hellraisers such as Rod Stewart and Keith Richards, is part of the image. Known as "the most rock'n'roll rock'n'roll band in the world", the Crowes have a reputation for world class hedonism that has helped sell 15m albums to a following who like it loud and basic.

One of those admirers is Noel Gallagher, whose perpetual feud with Liam mirrors the notoriously strained relations between the Robinson siblings. Inevitably, the Gallaghers and the Robinsons became friends. Now they have taken it a step further.

Recognising the ticket-selling potential of teaming up the two most unreconstructed bands on the planet, Oasis and the Black Crowes are about to kick off the jocularly titled Tour of Brotherly Love. If all goes well - and by past example it probably won't - they will spend the next month criss-crossing America, where Oasis will get used to the unfamiliar feeling of being a support band (officially they're co-headlining, but the Crowes will be closing the show).

The Crowes' continued existence defies reason. Even when they emerged from Atlanta in 1990, cigarettes drooping from smirking beaks, they were old hat, exhuming an era - the early-1970s blues of the Rolling Stones and the Faces - better left entombed. Undeterred, millions of punters snapped up their debut album Shake Your Money Maker, seduced by their devotion to sex, drugs and Ron Wood haircuts.

And thus have they continued, swaggering through five platinum LPs and Chris's heroin experience. "It was never really my thing - it never worked its way into my system," he now insists, languishing with Rich on an outsized hotel sofa in Notting Hill. "I know too many dead people. When Jerry Garcia died I was using a lot of drugs and I called David Crosby because he's a 12-stepper [former user] and I wanted to know what he felt. He said, 'I knew Jerry, and you don't tell the smartest person you know what to do.' And I just stopped doing drugs. It's over a year since I last used cocaine."

He may have turned over a new leaf, but the band's new album, Lions, is vintage Crowes. Refusing to fix what ain't broke, they have stuck with their customary fricassee of southern boogie and blues, heroically bawled by Chris, whose larynx seems to be thriving on his cannabis-and-booze regime.

It is far from innovative, but does mark a new chapter in the saga. Simply by refusing to follow fashion for 10 solid years, the Crowes have suddenly ascended to the perch marked "survivors" and improbably become hip. The guest list for a recent show at the Scala in London included the Gallaghers, the Prodigy, actor Kyle MacLachlan and assorted models, indicating that the Robinsons are in for a fashion moment. Chris believes he knows why: "It's because of all these disposable Britneys - all those blond girls are Barbie and Limp Bizkit's Fred Durst is GI Joe, and nothing's authentic any more."

Perversely, Chris and Hudson, who won acclaim for her role as a teenage groupie in the film Almost Famous, have become Hollywood's newest glamour couple - much to his disgust. "We're trying to live our lives with integrity, and we don't want to hang around with sycophantic motherfuckers. Kate's not a scenester; she's a talented actress from a beautiful, strong family."

He goes misty. "I'd never been in love before. We went to Central Park and we walked and talked all afternoon, and when she went to the rest room, I thought, 'Fuck me, life is never going to be the same again.' I'd been wondering what it'd be like to be a bachelor all my life, and then we met and fell in love. She moved in that weekend."

It may be all sweetness and light at home, but between the two brothers the tensions are plain to see. "Yeah, you can ask us what happened on Christmas Day 1975 and we'll have two different scenarios," acknowledges Rich. "We've been together since our teens, which is the most turbulent time of your life. But we've played thousands of shows and made six albums and our commitment speaks for itself." Presumably it's easy to relate to the Gallaghers, then? "Oh, their feuds are just fuel to keep the British tabloids going," Rich shrugs.

"They're just lads, aren't they?" his brother adds.

The Crowes are no strangers to laddishness, beginning with extensive tours of the southern US where they honed their appetite for partying. Their 1994 album Amorica crossed the boundary into offensive sexism with a cover shot of a woman's barely covered crotch, complete with tendrils of hair. It provoked boycotts of the shops that stocked it, yet the Crowes retained their core following, with whom they enjoy an unusually close relationship (they are anti-corporate to the extent of encouraging audiences to tape their gigs, and even provide technical advice on their website).

Challenged to explain Amorica, Chris mounts a creative defence, and the interview takes an unexpected detour. For the past 40 minutes he and Rich have been archetypal rockers, but now they turn into Melvyn Bragg. "The cover was a statement about America - the duality, the freedom and hangups," says Chris. "We saw it almost as a McDonald's logo. If you see it as sexual you're missing the political point. I think they should put parental-guidance stickers on our LPs. I don't curse on them, but they're subversive in other ways."

There is more to the band's hedonism than meets the eye, he insists. "What looks like abuse is a subtext. There are many different avenues of expression. The painters and film-makers and authors we like all have that human realism. If art's not provocative, what's the point?"

Not what you would expect of a couple of Black Crowes, especially delivered in urbane east coast accents that betray no trace of their Georgia upbringing (the brothers have relocated to Manhattan and Connecticut). So what do they have in common with Oasis, who boast of never having read a book between them?

"We're both passionate about music and we can talk to Noel for hours about old records," Chris says. He prefers Gallagher's company to that of fellow Georgian Michael Stipe, who "makes a living out of an artsy hodgepodge of a bohemian lifestyle". As opposed to the Crowes, who make a living out of reducing rock to its base metals. But just occasionally, that feels right.

 Lions is out through V2 Music on May 8.

He prefers Gallagher's company to that of fellow Georgian Michael Stipe, who "makes a living out of an artsy hodgepodge of a bohemian lifestyle". As opposed to the Crowes, who make a living out of reducing rock to its base metals. But just occasionally, that feels right.  Lions is out through V2 Music on May 8.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Serb bodies exhumed
fields.body:
Serb bodies exhumed

Forensic experts from the UN war crimes tribunal yesterday unearthed at least six bodies from graves believed to contain the remains of more than 250 ethnic Serbs killed in a 1995 Croatian offensive.

It was unclear how many bodies were being retrieved during the first day of excavations in Knin, 190 miles south of the capital, Zagreb, because the site was sealed off by police. Knin was the hotbed of rebel Serbs' attempts to prevent Croatia's independence from Yugoslavia in 1991. AP, Zagreb

Politician killed in Kosovo

Assailants shot dead a local leader in Kosovo's largest political party yesterday, a UN spokesman said.

Ismet Rraci, 50, was attacked outside his home at about 8am in Klina, 30 miles from the capital Pristina, the UN said. Rraci was a municipal council official and a member of the Democratic League of Kosovo led by Ibrahim Rugova. AP, Pristina

Boy dies in Kashmir strife

A boy was among 11 people killed in shootings and explosions in Kashmir, police said yesterday. Four members of the Indian security force were also among the dead, while 25 people were injured in the violence in the disputed Himalayan territory.

Residents accused police of firing indiscriminately but police denied the allegation. No militant group has claimed responsibility for the blast, police said. Reuters, Srinagar

Space tourist gets his wish

The consortium of countries building the International Space Station has approved the flight of space tourist Dennis Tito to the station, Nasa said yesterday.

Mr Tito, 60, has paid $20m (£13m) to the Russian space agency to realise his boyhood dream of space flight. AFP, Washington

Time runs out for blind cod

A scrawny blind cod, which cheated death despite being caught and thrown back 40 times by one fisherman alone, has apparently been killed by kindness after being sent to live at a Norwegian aquarium.

The fish died from unknown causes at the Atlantic Sea Park, in Alesund, last week. AP, Oslo

fields.headline: Britain is untrustworthy, say MEPs in spy inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European parliament
fields.trailText: Britain was singled out for criticism yesterday as members of the European parliament put the finishing touches to their controversial investigation into a global surveillance network run by the US.
fields.body:
Britain was singled out for criticism yesterday as members of the European parliament put the finishing touches to their controversial investigation into a global surveillance network run by the US.

While the biggest target of next month's report is likely to be France - whose extensive network for electronic interception at home and abroad is not subject to any parliamentary supervision - Britain was accused by several MEPs of being untrustworthy in EU terms because of its relationship with the US.

But sources in the temporary parliamentary committee set up to look into Echelon - a group whose creation was initially opposed by the British government - admitted last night that it will not be possible to prove definitively that the US uses economic espionage to help its firms win contracts as a matter of policy, though there are some isolated examples.

Last year it was alleged that the US used Echelon to beat the European consortium Airbus on an aircraft deal with Saudi Arabia.

Echelon, established during the cold war, is a network of listening posts reported to be capable of intercepting millions of telephone, fax and email messages.

MEPs want to draw attention to hi-tech surveillance and its implications for privacy, and are expected to point out the need for proper regimes in EU states to oversee the use of such surveillance, committee sources said. France is considered a culprit.

Britain has been wary because the surveillance and intelligence issue has been presented as one where a choice has to be made between loyalty to the US and to European partners - and also because intelligence and security matters are normally off-limits for consideration by the EU.

An espionage expert, Nicky Hager - whose native New Zealand is part of the Echelon network - told the committeee yesterday that interception facilities at Morwenstow in Cornwall and Menwith Hill in Yorkshire were almost certainly used to spy on European targets.

Mr Hager urged the committee to encourage greater public use of encryption techniques to guard their privacy.

He also argued that Britain was in a uniquely sensitive position because of its EU membership and close US relations."It is only secrecy that allows the British government to maintain two incompatible positions at once," he said.

Several MEPs insisted that Britain's relationship with the US meant that it could not be trusted by its EU partners.

"Britain has one leg in Europe and one in mid-Atlantic," said the committee's chairman, Gerhard Schmid, a German Social Democrat. "If there are conflicts of interest between the EU and the US there could be potential conflict for the UK."

Giuseppe Di Lello Finuoli, an Italian leftwinger, protested that Britain's GCHQ eavesdropping station in Cheltenham, which works with the US national security agency, had tested encryption equipment being used by the EU council of ministers, responsible for developing the union's fledgling rapid reaction force.

Committee members visit Washington early next month for talks with senior intelligence figures before finalising their keenly awaited report.

Earlier this year they saw Jack Straw, Britain's home secretary, but did not get the meeting they wanted with the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who has ministerial responsibility for GCHQ and the Secret Intelligence Service, MI6.

Britain has never denied helping the US operate Echelon listening posts and satellites, as do Canada, Australia and New Zealand under a long-term agreement.

London's position is that any interception of communications carried out by GCHQ is covered by strict legal guidelines, ministerial control and parliamentary supervision. Only threats to the supply of energy, commodities and raw materials or attempts to manipulate or undermine financial markets would justify interception, the government says.

webTitle: Effects of ban on child labour

fields.headline: Football ban sends child workers into worse jobs
fields.trailText: Under pressure from public opinion, the world's big football makers - the likes of Nike and Reebok - agreed four years ago with their contractors in Sialkot's vast football-stitching industry to ban work by children under 14.
fields.body:
Zarina Bhati looks round her damp, half-built home as she nurses the baby on her lap. The unfinished walls and the ageing Sony stereo were paid for by child labour.

For eight years Mrs Bhati and her sons stitched footballs at home, earning enough to move out of their small rented house in Sialkot, close to Pakistan's border with India.

"It was always a big dream to buy a house. I wanted to put cement on the walls and whitewash them," she said. "Now I doubt it will ever happen. There is no work."

Under pressure from public opinion, the world's big football makers - the likes of Nike and Reebok - agreed four years ago with their contractors in Sialkot's vast football-stitching industry to ban work by children under 14.

Production in this grey, featureless town which makes 80% of the world's footballs, was moved from homes like the Bhatis' to larger, well monitored stitching centres; child labour all but disappeared in Sialkot football-making.

"I consider it a blessing," said Nasir Dogar at the UN's International Labour Organisation office in Sialkot. "It was successful and now it is a model for other countries."

But some perplexing implications are emerging. "It was very easy for women to stitch footballs in the household, now many of them have lost their work because they cannot leave their homes," said Sajid Kazmi of the Sustainable Development Policy Institute in Islamabad. "And if children cannot work in the football industry they will shift to more hazardous industries."

Mrs Bhati and her sons used to sit on small metal stools in the front room and stitch eight footballs a day at 25 rupees (29 pence) a ball. "Now there is no women's stitching centre in this village and so there is no work for me," she said.

Of her five sons under 18, oine works in the leather industry, one in a barber shop and two are just old enough to stitch footballs in the centres. Only the youngest, a 10-year-old, goes to school.

"I think work is a part of a child's education," said Mrs Bhati. "It is more beneficial than going to school. At least they learn a skill."

Many aid organisations now believe that child labour in Pakistan, where nearly half the population is under 15, will not be eliminated by imposing bans on one industry at a time.

The local companies involved complain of rising costs and say foreign buyers are not rewarding their efforts to cut out child workers. Meanwhile, little has been done to improve the actual working conditions.

"This approach cannot succeed. We should consider what life a child will have if they are withdrawn from child labour," said Khalid Khalil, project co-ordinator at Sahe, a private organisation promoting education in Sialkot. "Quality education is the best way to prevent child labour."

Since the child labour ban 6,000 children have enrolled at new schools set up by the International Labour Organisation around Sialkot to prepare them for mainstream education. So far 1,660 children have been integrated into mainstream schools.

But another 1,760 have dropped out - mostly because of bad teaching, which makes schooling seem pointless. Excluded from football-making, many have simply turned to other jobs.

The ILO and Sialkot's unusually active chamber of commerce are trying now to get child labour banned in the more hazardous industry of producing surgical instruments, another big export. But enterprises such as brick kilns and car workshops go on using hundreds of thousands of children in appalling conditions, unseen by foreign consumers.

Pakistan has yet to sign the latest ILO convention against the worst forms of child labour.

Nabeed Arain used to stitch footballs at home with his mother. When the ban was introduced the 13-year-old went to a small school funded by Reebok. In 18 months he dropped out after his teacher dismissed him as a slow learner.

For the past six months he has been grinding scissors in a dirty workshop in Sialkot for 12 hours a day as he learns the complex processes involved in making surgical instruments.

He has not been paid yet but from May he will receive 1,000 rupees (£11) a month, far more than he could earn on footballs.

"My friends all work," said Nabeed. "They are all earning money so I want to earn too. I know I can earn more money in surgical instruments than footballs and besides there is no other choice."

fields.headline: Old MacDonald had a modem ...
fields.trailText: Is the great foot and mouth disaster rapidly becoming the first email democratising story of our time?
fields.body:
Is the great foot and mouth disaster rapidly becoming the first email democratising story of our time? Against the background of Maff's self-interested manipulation of figures - the collapse and truncation of its once coherent data posting on its website - the gulf in information from the "field" has been filled by direct communications from people affected by the consequences of the disease.

These are not the propagandist circulars from the Soil Association or other pressure groups, but person to person emails coming apparently at random from as far afield as Dumfriesshire and Cornwall. In my case, some have come via the Channel 4 News website, some have managed to work out a presenter or journalist's personal email, but all have developed in the course of the epidemic. They have inevitably played an increasing role in shaping our approach to covering this catastrophe.

Some of the emails are simple accounts of the spread of the disease to within first 20, then five, and then one mile of the writer's home. Then an account of the cull and the detail of the screw-ups that accompanied it. In numerous cases they have led to direct coverage on the screen. The sheer weight of these messages has outstripped any spinning Maff or anyone else could manage.

So that "towny" hacks, alienated by the fox hunting debate and the Countryside Alliance have, through personal relationships developed across the net, found themselves sucked into an understanding of a rural disaster not seen in our lifetime. Ministers and officials regularly express exasperation with the way in which the media is tackling foot and mouth. Where once the Press Association wire, the ministerial press release, the NFU statement steam-rollered all before them, today the semi-private inbox is countering hard. Anecdotal evidence arrives by the basketful to dissuade the town-bound hack from accepting much of what "officialdom" is putting out.

There's the hotel owner in Borrowdale; the pig breeder in Wiltshire; the aristocratic rare-breeds sheep owner in the Borders - each has brought something to the environment in which we decide how and what to cover in all this. Hence the government and the farming establishment have constantly found themselves on the back foot, driven both by events and the freewheeling flow of information in a way few of us have seen before. Certainly the BSE crisis never looked like this.

Many of these emailers lead to others. One introduced me to Edinburgh University's key animal health researcher, Dr Keith Sumption, whose work has now become our bible. It is he who has shown that of the last 22 outbreaks, those in which vaccination and culling were deployed together produced the final case just 42 days after the first outbreak. I've also been led to the Reverend Rosie Radcliffe's vivid accounts of how the disaster has afflicted her Cumbrian parish - I didn't envy her wrestling with the issues in her Easter message.

It was via email that I was asked the very simple question about the complete absence of any residual government provision for tackling such an outbreak. "How is it," I was asked, "that we have been bombing the shit out of Saddam for more than a decade, and for why? Aren't we told that it's because he's got weapons of mass destruction including biological? And in the list that Geoff Hoon and the Tories before him wheeled out, aren't we told of anthrax and foot and mouth? Well how come, then, we've spent millions bombing him, but nothing on guarding against the consequences of the old bugger dropping a phial of F&M in, say, Devizes?"

Welcome to the new world of intelligent people power. Ministers, officials, you have trouble on your hands. You too know our email addresses!

TV with a public face

Talking of new technology, digital television rampages on with the big corporates such as Boots and Sainsbury's readily gobbling up channels on which to spew out their wares. What is to become of public service broadcasting? The fledgling Community Channel is out there with more than 120 charities doing their business over the ether for some 10 hours a day. It's in the digital mix but without substantial public funding it will die.

There has to be a recognition that as the BBC and ITV established in the analogue age, there must be public service in the digital mix or we shall all be seriously the poorer. The Community Channel, like the Open University, has to be seen as another building block in a civil society. For example, a whole host of voluntary agencies got together during the Indian earthquake to raise awareness via the channel. Sky, ITN and the BBC all made surplus images freely available for the Red Cross, Oxfam and others to do with as they pleased. It was a powerful example of how interactive community television can make an impact in the digital age. But these are early days; the viewing figures, even the access is still low. The Community Channel, on very slender resources, is already showing that it can be done. However, much of the rest of digital television is in danger of consolidating us into a nation of couch potatoes.

A plethora of cheap shopping channels is inevitable, but we can affect what joins them if we think imaginatively. This is a once in a lifetime chance to add community substance to another new age of communication.

Where are all the Brits?

Unexpected Easter breaks courtesy of the postponed general election have exposed some to the joys of time off on working days. In central London, making perhaps 20 transactions, ranging from buying theatre tickets to buying a futon for my daughter, I did an informal trawl through shops, coffee houses and the rest.

In almost every outlet I was served by motivated, zestful people, almost none of whom were British nationals. They ranged from the Kosovan of uncertain status toiling in the carwash, to the Algerian serving BLTs in Pret a Manger, the Ethiopian serving at the next counter, to the Ukrainian student usheretting at the cinema and more. The service was good and the current boom in high-street comfort stations is entirely sustained by these people.

But these are not the jobs the British will not do. Those were always thought to be further down the service food chain. Our dustbins are still emptied by very white, quite often very mature refuse collection teams. So where are the young, mainly white Brits who might once have served on the high street? Sporting a red cross daubed across their faces watching Sky digital? I hope not, but where would the "new service economy" be without those who seem to have taken their place

 Francis Wheen is away.
