webTitle: Guardian investigation into Russian uranium smuggling

fields.headline: Hot house
fields.standfirst: When police raided Alfonso Sandoval's house, their Geiger counters went mad. But what was a Colombian doing with £1m worth of uranium? Had it come from the former Soviet Union? And where was it heading next? By  Ian Traynor in Moscow and  Steven Dudley in Bogota
fields.trailText: When police raided Alfonso Sandoval's house, their Geiger counters went mad. But what was a Colombian doing with £1m worth of uranium? Had it come from the former Soviet Union? And where was it heading next? By Ian Traynor in Moscow and Steven Dudley in Bogota.
fields.body:
On a warm Friday afternoon last month, six Colombian secret policemen, along with members of the prosecutor general's office and various geologists, knocked on the door of Alfonso Sandoval. Although located in a posh western suburb of Bogota and close to the US embassy, Sandoval's house showed signs of ageing. The walls were coming apart and the paint was chipping.

The agents had been closely following Sandoval for two months and believed they had gathered enough evidence to search for illegal substances in his home. The unassuming-looking Sandoval let in the agents who scoured the first and second floors. Just beyond the kitchen in a back room they found a computer, a spectrometer for measuring the purity of radioactive elements, and two lead canisters with 600 grams of highly concentrated uranium. The geologists' Geiger counters immediately showed heavy signs of radiation.

The house was severely contaminated. The FBI was alerted. And Sandoval instantly fell under suspicion of being at the centre of a new and lethal international smuggling ring ultimately aimed at flogging a nuclear warhead, or the wherewithal to make one, to any unsavoury regime or dictator.

Sandoval's uranium was not weapons-grade, at least not yet. But it was much more highly enriched than the material used in civilian nuclear energy generation and was roughly of the degree of enrichment used to fuel Russia's ageing fleet of nuclear submarines - around 66% pure. The Colombian authorities estimated the local market value of the 600 grams at just over £1m.

The files on Sandoval's computer revealed detailed information on uranium enrichment processes. The Colombian investigators believe that Sandoval was engaged, however implausibly, in a high-risk, home-grown uranium enrichment exercise.

That scenario is scorned by the experts who point out that enriching uranium is an extraordinarily intensive and complex process. They add that Saddam Hussein, with limitless funds, has spent 10 years trying and failing to produce weapons-grade uranium using the rudimentary techniques employed by the US in the Manhattan Project in the 1940s.

So what was Sandoval up to? And where did the uranium come from?

Given the assumed links between Russian and Ukrainian mafias and Colombian drugs cartels, speculation about the origins of the nuclear pellets is focusing on the huge and chaotic nuclear industries of the former Soviet Union, although in the decade since the communist behemoth collapsed there has been only one significant confirmed case of weapons-grade fissile material being smuggled west and sold. Interestingly, that case also bore Colombian and Russian fingerprints. "The uranium could be of Russian origin," says David Kyd, spokesman for the International Atomic Energy Authority (IAEA) in Vienna. "But you would need detailed laboratory analysis and a number of days before you would be able to find a signature."

Weapons-grade uranium is 95% enriched, while the stuff used in nuclear power stations is 2%-3% enriched. The 66% enrichment, says Kyd, is "bizarre".

Given the corrupt and impoverished condition of the Russian nuclear and military industries, there is no doubt that through the past decade, Russian boffins have been selling the secrets of their arcane trade to the highest bidders, whether in Iraq, North Korea, or Libya, despite US aid programmes aimed at securing Russian scientists' salaries, safely disposing of weapons-grade uranium and plutonium, and de-nuclearising other parts of the former Soviet Union. Filching and smuggling of low-level radioactive materials, however, is rife in Russia.

"There have been repeated attempts to take radioactive metals to Finland this year," admits Dmitriy Kokko, an officer with the customs service in north-west Russia. "Cases of smuggling or accidental export are taking place all the time."

A St Petersburg conference two weeks ago was told that there had been 500 attempted cases of radioactive materials being smuggled out last year alone. But most of these cases entail relatively low-risk isotopes, metal being sold for scrap in the west, or materials stolen from medical laboratories. Innocent people may get sick from this, but it does not have the makings of a nuclear bomb.

In a typical week earlier this month, a container of radioactive isotopes was stolen from an aluminium plant in Ukraine and offered for sale, while two sailors in Russia's Pacific fleet were arrested in Vladivostok after trying to sell parts taken from a naval nuclear installation.

"You can only get the highly enriched uranium and the plutonium at a few closed centres in Russia and we don't get reports of this being stolen," says Igor Kudrik, a Russian expert at the Bellona nuclear watchdog in Norway.

"But the situation is very serious. The Russians don't report thefts of fissile materials, but three or four times a year it emerges that someone has been arrested for stealing fissile materials. We're never told what happened to the material."

Apart from not being of the required degree of enrichment to make a bomb, the Sandoval uranium stash was also very small - just over half a kilo - experts say you need 25 kilos to make a bomb.

Nuclear weapons can be made from two types of radioactive material - enriched uranium and plutonium. Natural uranium contains two kinds of atoms, U-233 and a tiny amount of U-235, which is radioactive - that is, it decays, giving off energy and particles. Sometimes, the decaying U-235 atom will turn a U-233 atom into another U-235 atom. If the concentration of U-235 reaches a high enough level, it can produce new U-235 faster than it decays. If uranium is enriched so that U-235 reaches 2-3%, it can generate enough energy for nuclear power. If it reaches 95%, and there is enough uranium in the first place, there will be a nuclear explosion. Plutonium, which does not exist naturally, works in the same way, but with a different set of atoms.

The most notorious case of nuclear smuggling from the former Soviet Union entailed plutonium. In 1994, a Colombian, Justitiano Torres Benitez, was arrested at Munich airport after arriving on a flight from Moscow carrying 340g of plutonium. Together with two Spanish middlemen, he was jailed in 1995. He got just under five years. He should be out by now.

Yet that case illustrated all the ambiguities of the shadowy world of nuclear smuggling, with spies, counter-spies, journalists and double agents pursuing crooks, fraudsters, scientists, businessmen and buyers, with nobody sure what game is really being played.

The nuclear material in Torres' case really did come from Russia. Alarming. But the buyer, and to many the instigator of the entire crooked sting, was the German state, in the form of the German Federal Intelligence Service. Had a German undercover agent not offered the men £170m for enough plutonium to make a bomb, the defence argued convincingly, the shipment would never have taken place. The Germans were embarrassed. The Russian were incandescent.

There has never been evidence to suggest that any of the nuclear warheads in the former Soviet bloc have gone missing or been sold off. Former Warsaw Pact countries such as Hungary or Poland never had control over the warheads on their territory, which have long since been withdrawn; Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus have all renounced the warheads on their territory, and these have, it seems, been accounted for and returned to Russia.

That still leaves a grey area in Russia itself, where, behind their security screens, the 10 closed cities involved in nuclear weapons production have become hotbeds of entrepreneurship. No unauthorised visitors are supposed to go there. But they do.

A few years ago Victor Osipov, director of a technology park in the closed plutonium-making city of Seversk, told the Guardian: "There are 5,500 small businesses registered in the town - but only about 1,000 pay taxes. There's a strong core of entrepreneurs who would be capable of starting a whole nuclear industry from scratch."

And a further part of the problem is that no one really knows how much bomb-grade material exists in Russia. For several years now the US department of energy has been funding a programme to track and trace all the uranium and plutonium across Russia. The result so far is inconclusive. The inventory is not complete, meaning it is harder to establish the facts if and when some of the stuff goes missing.

And among the experts, the fear is now that the new and hard-nosed Bush administration in Washington will cut back on such aid programmes which, in any case, are humiliating to the Russian atomic lobby, once the Soviet elite.

President Bill Clinton and his energy secretary, Bill Richardson, viewed the nuclear containment aid to Russia as a US national security priority. "Under Spencer Abraham [Bush's new energy secretary] those programmes will be whittled back," says Kyd of the IAEA.

Sandoval in his backyard bomb factory, meanwhile, seems an unlikely lynchpin of a new international syndicate trafficking in the nuclear nightmare.

For a wannabe boffin with an atomic absorption spectrometer, he has no formal education and, at the time of the raid, he was recovering from open-heart surgery, though he has admitted to having spent time in Russia. He was also arrested in Spain in the early 1980s on charges of drug trafficking but released shortly after.

Government investigators are still monitoring Sandoval's possible associates, but have yet to link any of the other illicit networks with the one that may have brought the uranium to Colombia. While there are natural deposits in uranium in Colombia, there are no uranium mines.

If convicted, Sandoval could face between three and eight years of prison. But Colombian law is very vague about the crime in question, and Sandoval has been released while the investigation proceeds in the prosecutor general's office. Authorities say they released him because he could aggravate a heart condition he has if left in jail.

fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

(b) Van Halen

(c) Van der Graf Generator

(d) Van Morrison

fields.headline: No 1,866
fields.standfirst: Norfolk
fields.trailText: Norfolk.
fields.body:
Eeh, Norfolk's looking a bit peaky. Actually, that's County Wicklow.

You've lost me. No, we've lost Norfolk.

Oh, I see, Norfolk's away on holiday is it? Is County Wicklow just standing in in the meantime? Like, er, Fern Britton and John Leslie, when Richard and Judy are away? No, County Wicklow is standing in for Norfolk in a multi-million pound movie called Reign of Fire.

Right, right, so County Wicklow is sort of a body double for Norfolk? Kind of, if you want to put it like that.

Norfolk wasn't prepared to do its own stunts, eh? I don't think it was even asked. The good people of Norfolk are pretty narked about it, though.

Really? You mean they actively want to jump out of helicopters and run around in their scanties? No, they're annoyed that the bigwig Hollywood producers have substituted hilly County Wicklow for Norfolk, which is famously flat.

Norfolk's not that flat is it? Well it's hardly well-endowed.

So, sort of the Calista Flockart of British landscape, being played by Pamela Anderson, pre-op? Precisely.

Wow. So just how flat are we talking? We're talking a whole luxury loft conversion: the highest part of Norfolk is a 300ft bit near Cromer.

300ft? That's pretty rubbish. Uh-huh. And the film features a castle on top of a mountain.

I see your problem. Maybe Norfolk could consider being surgically enhanced for the role? Yes, but that might pose problems should Norfolk ever wish to breast-feed or fly.

Fair enough. So what's the film all about? Jennifer Lopez as a Norfolk broad, hopelessly in love with in-bred whelk-seller, Adam Sandler? Close. No cigar. It stars Christian Bale, Izabella Scorupco and Matthew McConaughey as a sweaty-browed US militiaman, fighting evil fire-breathing dragons which invade England.

Do they have dragons in Norfolk? No, no, but I hear County Wicklow's wriggling with 'em.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: In A Green Shade | The Reith Lectures 2001| Frontiers
fields.body:
Patrick Wright presents an evening devoted to the history, development, and future of the British countryside. In A Green Shade (7.30pm, Radio 3) picks Stanley Baldwin as the 20th century politician who did most to depict the countryside as the embodiment of British ideals. But, within two generations, the combined pressures of population, war, and technology had transformed that mystical idyll. A wide range of gurus debate the various issues: June Tabor and her band provide the musical links.

Professor Tom Kirkwood addresses the inhabitants of a Midlands retirement village for the fourth of The Reith Lectures 2001 (8.0pm, Radio 4). So far he has considered the natural constraints on human longevity. Now he deals with the ways we determine our own fate through our lifestyles. A taste for tobacco, sugar, fry-ups and indolence will see people off sooner than any inherited weaknesses. But those who attain old age deserve respect: it's where most of us are heading.

Peter Evans opens the new season of Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4) with an investigation of a new branch of learning - econophysics. As the name implies, it is an attempt to bring the disciplines of physics to the rather wilder world of finance. A lot of those involved are statisticians exploring whether there is any reliable way of forecasting calamities such as the stock market crashes of 1929 and 1987 (and 2001?).

fields.headline: Where are the bodies bared?
fields.trailText: Manhattan On The Beach | O'Shea's Dangerous Reptiles
fields.body:
If you get caught between mooning and New York City, you are most likely somewhere in the Hamptons, though not the posh end obviously. In Bridgehampton, where "new riche is better than no riche at all," the men simply don't get their bottoms out. And even if they did, no one would notice since they are too busy working the room (or more precisely, the marquee) and not paying attention to the polo matches. In Westhampton, it is a different story. There, the men flash their asses, wear big pink wigs and spray each other with squirty cream. And that's just the straight ones.

This is Manhattan On The Beach (Channel 4), a place where all human life - well all human life that has decamped from New York - is on display.

The Hamptons, which I always imagined to be a place of wooden verandahs, linen shirts, sea breezes and louche, Gatsby coolness, turns out to be a cross between a Club 18-30 holiday and All Bar One on a Saturday night. At one end of the spectrum, the poor people frequent all-day bars while baring their steroid-and silicon-enhanced bodies in the hope that someone as brainless as them will want to jump their bones (which, invariably, they do).

In the middle, upwardly mobile professionals pay £2,500 to spend every other weekend of the summer sharing a house with 40 other people. And at the top end of the spectrum, women who look like Cher's granny say things like "Some of the outfits are a little too too, but it's fashion. You can never overdo fashion, Marjorie Gubelmann, you know that!" All in all, it's not a pretty spectrum.

But the prize for Weirdest of All Interviewees (with special commendation for Blissful Lack of Self-Awareness) goes to Daniel the Actor. He visits the Hamptons for "the chicks". "If you haven't dated a psychiatrist, you haven't lived", he oozed, explaining his rules of seduction. "You want to get yourself great sex, baby, you give me a house with a bunch of 35 year olds."

Daniel even has special pants he wears if he pulls a psychiatrist. They are red and skimpy and look like they would only hold one of Daniel's buttocks. "Shrinks love them but other women find them disgusting and homosexual on men." This seems unfair since the homosexuals I know wouldn't be caught dead in a pair of such atrocious tanga briefs. Americans are weird.

"Diving here," says Mark O'Shea, "would be crazy. These waters are teeming with crocodiles, sharks and lethal jellyfish." Given that O'Shea regards pursuits that most of us would place in the Completely Bonkers column of Potential Pastimes And Careers as quite normal, it's surprising that he doesn't smear himself in fish blood and take the plunge. This is O'Shea's Dangerous Reptiles (Channel 4), after all, not Mark's Cutesy-Wutesy Bunnies Half Hour, although one does wonder how a tarantula sneaked into the programme's titles.

O'Shea had ventured to the sea snake capital of the world (bet that works wonders on tourism brochures) for a spot of scuba diving and stating of the obvious. "Unlike me," he said, "sea snakes are perfectly adapted to life under water." You don't say.

Never one to shirk from a challenge, O'Shea, who looks like someone who'd try and sell you herbal ecstasy at a music festival, set out in the inky dark to fish snakes out of the sea off Western Australia. He was doing so, along with his colleague, Brian, to milk the snakes for venom. They were planning to develop an antidote but because snake venom is in even shorter supply than the milk of human kindness, it look a long time to get a little. And the snakes, like irate draught excluders, didn't look best pleased at having to chew on a test tube covered in latex.

I kept expecting a giant squid to appear and pull their boat down, down, down to see Captain Nemo, but it wasn't to be. Instead, they caught over 100 snakes which skimmed under the water like pieces of ribbon on a fan. Later, whilst conquering his fear of diving, O'Shea warned of his slithery companions - "These are very bitey" - as he flourished a grabbing arm device, most likely bought from the Innovations Catalogue. Indeed, it was slightly disappointing that he didn't pop a Slippasock ("The cosy slipper with the flexibility of a sock - with a non-slip sole!") over the snakes' heads to calm them down. Maybe next week.

But the prize for Weirdest of All Interviewees (with special commendation for Blissful Lack of Self-Awareness) goes to Daniel the Actor. He visits the Hamptons for "the chicks". "If you haven't dated a psychiatrist, you haven't lived", he oozed, explaining his rules of seduction. "You want to get yourself great sex, baby, you give me a house with a bunch of 35 year olds." Daniel even has special pants he wears if he pulls a psychiatrist. They are red and skimpy and look like they would only hold one of Daniel's buttocks. "Shrinks love them but other women find them disgusting and homosexual on men." This seems unfair since the homosexuals I know wouldn't be caught dead in a pair of such atrocious tanga briefs. Americans are weird. "Diving here," says Mark O'Shea, "would be crazy. These waters are teeming with crocodiles, sharks and lethal jellyfish." Given that O'Shea regards pursuits that most of us would place in the Completely Bonkers column of Potential Pastimes And Careers as quite normal, it's surprising that he doesn't smear himself in fish blood and take the plunge. This is O'Shea's Dangerous Reptiles (Channel 4), after all, not Mark's Cutesy-Wutesy Bunnies Half Hour, although one does wonder how a tarantula sneaked into the programme's titles. O'Shea had ventured to the sea snake capital of the world (bet that works wonders on tourism brochures) for a spot of scuba diving and stating of the obvious. "Unlike me," he said, "sea snakes are perfectly adapted to life under water." You don't say. Never one to shirk from a challenge, O'Shea, who looks like someone who'd try and sell you herbal ecstasy at a music festival, set out in the inky dark to fish snakes out of the sea off Western Australia. He was doing so, along with his colleague, Brian, to milk the snakes for venom. They were planning to develop an antidote but because snake venom is in even shorter supply than the milk of human kindness, it look a long time to get a little. And the snakes, like irate draught excluders, didn't look best pleased at having to chew on a test tube covered in latex. I kept expecting a giant squid to appear and pull their boat down, down, down to see Captain Nemo, but it wasn't to be. Instead, they caught over 100 snakes which skimmed under the water like pieces of ribbon on a fan. Later, whilst conquering his fear of diving, O'Shea warned of his slithery companions - "These are very bitey" - as he flourished a grabbing arm device, most likely bought from the Innovations Catalogue. Indeed, it was slightly disappointing that he didn't pop a Slippasock ("The cosy slipper with the flexibility of a sock - with a non-slip sole!") over the snakes' heads to calm them down. Maybe next week.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Buena Vista Social Club | Jaws | Angel Heart
fields.body:
Films

Buena Vista Social Club
(Wim Wenders, 1998)
8pm, FilmFour

Another fecund partnership of Wenders and Ry Cooder, the musician who made the score for Paris, Texas. This is the story of Cooder pulling together a group of aged Cuban performers to make a CD and go on tour. All in their 80s or 90s, the musicians - including Compay Segundo, Ibrahim Ferrer, Omara Portuondo and Ruben Gonzalez - play their stuff and talk about their lives, Wenders works into a rich, heartwarming whole. The music speaks for itself, but the photography also - from the fading elegance of old Havana to the New York skyline, and the radiant, aged faces of the musicians themselves, is superb.

Jaws
(Steven Spielberg, 1975)
9pm, The Studio

It's the heavy-bass John Williams score that instils the menace of the great white shark, feasting on unwary Amity Island holidaymakers. Spielberg keeps the fish mainly out of sight, a horror lurking on the edge of consciousness, until the explosive denouement. Roy Scheider's police chief Brody, fighting tourism-minded bureaucracy as much as the beast, Richard Dreyfuss the irksome marine expert, Robert Shaw's loopy old Captain Fishbait, and Spielberg's consummate direction keeping it going at a rate of knots.

Angel Heart
(Alan Parker, 1987)
10pm, FilmFour

Parker's weird Faustian thriller opens noirishly then turns up the Technicolor to become a lurid Hammer-like horror. Mickey Rourke plays 50s New York private eye Harry Angel, who has, literally, a hell of a job searching for a missing man; Robert De Niro is evil incarnate as Louis Cyphre. Some shocking, gruesome images, such as the ceiling that bleeds, but at heart very silly.

The Godfather Part 2
(Francis Coppola, 1974)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Best of the Godfathers, and the first sequel to win a best film Oscar. It follows the career of Al Pacino's Michael Corleone, now establishing himself as most ruthless of the mafia dons, and interweaves the story of his father Vito's arrival in New York, and how he became a man of respect. Robert De Niro is spellbinding as Vito.

All About My Mother
(Pedro Almodovar, 1999)
11.25pm, Sky Premier

Almodovar, once the purveyor of high-camp comedies, is turning to more sophisticated and moving material these days and this is his best yet. It tells the story of Cecilia Roth's Manuela who, grief-stricken at the sudden death of her teenage son, moves from Madrid to Barcelona and discovers a new life caring for pregnant nun Rosa (Penelope Cruz) and veteran actress Huma (Marisa Paredes). It was well worth its best foreign picture Oscar.

Sports

Live Football
Midnight, Sky Sports 1

It's international time again, and the truly keen can find Scotland, Ireland, France, Portugal and, er, the Ivory Coast in action. Wait until midnight to catch the USA's "grudge" match against Costa Rica, who they somehow rarely manage to beat.

fields.headline: David Nathan
fields.standfirst: Theatre critic and writer whose work elevated the Jewish Chronicle
fields.trailText: Theatre critic and writer whose work elevated the Jewish Chronicle.
fields.body:
David Nathan, who has died of cancer aged 74, was a respected drama critic, a theatrical biographer and a sometime sketch-writer for the BBC-TV satire show That Was The Week That Was. From 1985 to 1991, he was deputy editor of the Jewish Chronicle, where his professionalism helped establish the paper as not just the leader in the Jewish world, but as a consistent trendsetter in British weekly journalism.

As a writer, his work included radio and television plays, a novel, The Story So Far (1986), short biographies of Glenda Jackson and John Hurt, and a study of comedians, The Laughtermakers: A Quest for Comedy (1971). He also wrote a chapter for [George Bernard] Shaw And Politics, published by the Pennsylvania State University Press. After TW3 - where his principal collaborator was Dennis Potter - he contributed to its successors Not So Much A Programme, More A Way Of Life, and BBC 3.

David will, however, best be remembered as a drama critic. His short, white hair - with which he seemed to have been born - was always visible in the stalls at a play's press night, and quotes from his favourable reviews frequently appeared on theatre bills. It did not matter that he was writing for a weekly with a limited circulation; his name was enough, and, though his more trenchant criticisms may not have been quoted, they were respected by producers and performers alike. He was president of the Critics' Circle from 1986 to 1988.

David was born in Manchester. He always wanted to be a journalist, and to practise that craft in London. At 16, he became a copyboy, and later a copytaker, on the News Chronicle. It turned him into a fast, accurate typist; his shorthand, too, was exemplary. From 1944 until 1947, he served in the Royal Navy.

The postwar years were hard times in Fleet Street - newspapers were down to four, and then six, pages a day, and job opportunities were rare. So David got his first two years' reporting experience on the St Helens Reporter, followed by the Nottingham Guardian and Evening Post, where he began his career as a theatre critic and, ultimately, became London editor. In 1952, he joined the Daily Mail as syndication news editor, and, from 1954-55, was the rewrite editor at the London bureau of Associated Press.

His big break came in 1955, when he joined the Daily Herald. Although employed as a general reporter, he established his reputation as a theatre critic and entertain- ment writer. He remained with the paper after 1964, when it was relaunched as the Sun - a failed broadsheet devised by the Mirror group's Hugh Cudlipp - but left at the end of the decade as it was transformed into a mass-circulation tabloid by Rupert Murdoch.

From 1971 to 1978, David worked as a sub-editor at the Observer, but kept his hand in as theatre critic at the Jewish Chronicle. After 1985, when he was invited by the new editor, Geoffrey Paul, to become his deputy, he helped make the paper sparkle.

He wrote profiles and drama reviews, and became known in the Jewish community as a journalist who would not be fobbed off with the evasions that members of that group had, for long, thought they could get away with. His writing set the tone for a newspaper that became essential reading from Downing Street to Jerusalem.

David is survived by his wife Norma, and two sons - one of whom, John, has succeeded his father as the JC drama critic.

 David Nathan, writer and critic, born December 9 1926; died April 21 2001

fields.headline: Tom Dobney
fields.standfirst: RAF recruit who - at 15 - was the world's youngest military pilot
fields.trailText: RAF recruit who - at 15 - was the world's youngest military pilot.
fields.body:
Six decades ago, Tom Dobney, who has died aged 74, became the youngest military pilot in the world. In October 1940, stimulated by a dare from a fellow schoolboy at Nuneaton grammar school, the then 14-year-old falsified his birth certificate and enlisted in the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve. His form 543, or service record, advanced his date of birth from 1926 to 1922; his height, on enlistment, was registered as 5ft 5in. The speed at which he was growing might have, but didn't, raise eyebrows.

The Battle of Britain had just ended, and Dobney, frantic to emulate the RAF pilots, had coerced his divorcee mother into assisting in the subterfuge. He was in uniform within a month and, in May 1941, six days past his 15th birthday, flew solo in a Tiger Moth trainer, after 12 flying hours, at Staverton, Gloucestershire. He earned his wings at training school in Medicine Hat, Alberta, and, back in Britain - after reportedly having met George VI in Bournemouth - he joined an operational training unit at Abingdon, the final step to a Whitley med- ium bomber squadron.

Thus was the 15-year-old a pilot, with a crew of fully-grown young men. With the phasing-out of the Whitleys, however, he was switched to a unit in East Anglia, training Blenheim light bombers destined for the Middle East.

Then came a call from his commanding officer. Dobney thought his application to fly fighters had materialised. Instead, he was reunited with his father, who, having met his mother by chance, had learned of their son's unorthodox entry into the RAF. Aghast, he had alerted the authorities, and the teenager was discharged immediately.

But Dobney didn't give up easily. Later that year, he re-enlisted at a different recruiting centre - again saying he was 18 - and was given a new service number. This time, he had to wait nearly a year for the call-up, and within a month was rumbled. When, at last, he signed on correctly, there were no hard feelings. He was still a quali fied military pilot, but played no further part in the air war. By 1948, he was flying four-engined York transports on the Berlin airlift, and, after a spell with the Metropolitan police, returned to the RAF as a runway controller.

Later, he became deputy art editor in the Manchester office of the Daily Express, retiring in 1986. His youthful adventures brought publicity - some of it unwelcome - although there were benefits, including an invitation to fly in the Battle of Britain Flight's only remaining Lancaster heavy bomber. He also earned an entry in the Guinness Book of Records as the world's youngest qualified military pilot.

Dobney leaves a widow, and six children from two previous marriages.

 Tom Dobney, pilot, born May 6 1926; died April 3 2001

fields.headline: Woman 'tried to rig' scene of killing
fields.trailText: A former aide to the Duchess of York desperately tried to cover her tracks after murdering her boyfriend when he would not marry her, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A former aide to the Duchess of York desperately tried to cover her tracks after murdering her boyfriend when he would not marry her, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Jane Andrews, who claims she acted in self-defence, tried to "rig" the crime scene to make it look as if she had been frightened of Thomas Cressman, a businessman, the prosecution claimed.

And while she was on the run, the jury was told, she sent emotional text messages to friends claiming that she had left home hours before the murder, and that Mr Cressman was being blackmailed.

The prosecution alleges that Andrews, 34, hit Mr Cressman, 39, with a cricket bat and then stabbed him through the chest with a 19cm kitchen knife.

When his body was found in the blood spattered bedroom of their west London flat he was still holding the knife between the thumb and forefinger of his right hand, as if he had tried to pull it out. A pathologist said he believed the blade had been driven in to its full length.

Bruce Houlder QC, prosecuting, said a bathrobe cord had been loosely tied from the outside of the bedroom door to a banister, as if to make the door secure - allegedly by Andrews trying to make it appear that she had been frightened.

But a blood stained towel was found on the floor above, showing she had not been so frightened that she had fled the house immediately, he said.

The court was also told of emotional notes left in the flat and highly charged messages she sent to family and friends after Mr Cressman's death.

One of two notes in the flat read: "My dearest parents, I am so sorry. No more hurt inside me any more." The second read: "Tom hurt me so much. He was so cruel to me."

Two days later, as police searched for her, she left two messages for her former husband. The first said: "Four days now, and Tom has not called me - why?" The second said: "What is wrong? All the press want me."

The jury was also told of dramatic text messages exchanged between Andrews and a friend.

In one she claimed that the last time she had seen Mr Cressman was Saturday lunchtime. He is believed to have died early on the Sunday morning.

A later message to the friend said: "I can't come back. No one would believe me. I will not be locked up. I must die and be at peace."

Mr Houlder said Andrews claimed in one message that Mr Cressman was being blackmailed. "It turned out bad and he had to pay lots," she said.

Later she sent the message: "I've just heard on the radio that Tommy's been murdered. I can't believe it - I'm dying inside."

She was found by police lying under a blanket in her VW Polo, having taken between 30 and 40 painkillers.

When interviewed by police Andrews claimed that at the end of a holiday they spent in France Mr Cressman had called her names and struck her, the court was told.

Back at home she had challenged him again about suggestive emails he had exchanged with a woman in America. She told police he "snapped" and grabbed her round the neck.

That night they went to bed together. She told police she armed herself with the cricket bat and knife because she was worried he would hit her.

He woke up and began hitting her, she claimed. She struck him with the bat. He was trying to kick her, so she grabbed the knife. He punched her, and she remembered him falling. She saw she had blood on her and left.

Andrews, who worked for the Duchess of York until 1997, denies murder.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Homeward Bound: Widnes station tribute marks Paul Simon's unlikely inspiration

fields.headline: Homeward Bound: Widnes station tribute marks Paul Simon's unlikely inspiration
fields.trailText: It was while he was sitting on a platform at Widnes railway station on Merseyside, waiting for a train to take him back to London to his girlfriend, that Paul Simon began scribbling the lyrics of his haunting song Homeward Bound.
fields.body:
It was while he was sitting on a platform at Widnes railway station on Merseyside, waiting for a train to take him back to London to his girlfriend, that Paul Simon began scribbling the lyrics of his haunting song Homeward Bound.

Almost 36 years on, the station has hardly changed. It has the same 19th century architecture and bottle green and cream wrought iron footbridge which were there when Simon was waiting for his train.

Yesterday a few passengers huddled together in a glass shelter shielding themselves from the biting wind which swept across the platform, scattering empty drink cans and chocolate wrappers.

Like many other railway stations, it has a board in the main ticket area with local information about the nearest bus stops and taxi ranks. But underneath it says simply: “It was while waiting at this station that Paul Simon was inspired to write the song Homeward Bound.”

In previous years, two plaques have been erected above the ticket kiosk commemorating the moment when a classic of popular song was conceived. Unfortunately, both have been stolen.

Kenneth Geraghty, a train adviser at the station, pointed to the empty space where the plaques used to be. “I don’t know how long the new plaque will last,” he said pessimistically. “We still get the occasional fan coming to see where he wrote the song, but not that many any more.”

The new brass plaque, made by students at Warrington Collegiate Institute, is said to be thief-proof. It is tucked away on the main platform next to the door leading to the exit.

Simon appealed for the return of the stolen plaque at one of his concerts at the Albert Hall.

There is some debate about whether Homeward Bound was actually written at Widnes station. In September 1965, when Simon wrote the song, there was another railway station in the town which had a direct link to London.

Simon’s friend Geoff Speed, who provided lodgings in Liverpool for the musician in September 1965, said: “It is probable he wrote one verse in Liverpool and the chorus in Wigan, with the song being finished in Widnes. We heard him writing the tune when he was staying at our house and then we dropped him at the station. He probably finished the song on the platform.”

Stephen Wainwright, a lecturer in television production at Warrington Collegiate Institute, said the plaque was the culmination of extensive research by four students investigating the Paul Simon story. “Although it is debatable whether Simon actually wrote Homeward Bound at Widnes station, the plaque, I am sure, has returned to its spiritual home.”

I’m sitting in a railway station

Got a ticket for my destination

On a tour of one night stands

My suitcase and guitar in hand

And every stop is neatly planned

For a poet and a one-man band

Homeward bound, I wish

I was Homeward bound

fields.headline: Chinese malaria remedy tested
fields.trailText: A species of wormwood known to the Chinese for 2,000 years could provide a defence against malaria, according to British researchers.
fields.body:
A species of wormwood known to the Chinese for 2,000 years could provide a defence against malaria, according to British researchers.

Artemisia annua was unknown in the west until 20 years ago. Now it represents hope against drug-resistant malaria, according to Nicholas White, director of the Wellcome Trust's south-east Asia research unit in Bangkok.

He and colleagues are using a drug derived from the herb - artemisinin - to cure 98% of cases of malaria and cut infection among children by 90% in camps for displaced people on the Thai border with Burma.

Malaria infects 400m people a year worldwide and kills more than 1m each year. Nine out of 10 cases are in Africa. In east Africa it kills a child every 30 seconds. Today is Roll Back Malaria day, part of the World Health Organisation's push to save lives in Africa and other malarial regions.

Malaria is caused by a parasite spread by mosquitoes. There is no vaccine, and even the newest drugs are becoming less effective. Artemisinin was first reported as a treatment in a Chinese medical journal in 1981.

"The malarial world was gobsmacked," said Professor White. But the acceptance by western governments and pharmaceutical companies has been slow: drugs based on the herb have still to be approved for clinical use in Europe and the US. Thailand began to look at artemisinin a decade ago as the parasite began to show resistance to standard drugs such as mefloquine.

"There was nothing else. They were facing untreatable malaria by the end the decade," he said. "To cut a long story short, we were able to confirm the amazing efficacy of the drug, the lack of any side effects, the very, very rapid action, very well tolerated and also in combination it made mefloquine a very good drug again. It stopped further resistance developing."

Microbes reproduce at dizzying rates, and drug resistance arises spontaneously in tiny numbers. But drug treatment immediately favours the parasites with the resistance genes, and they have a clear field to multiply. No antimicrobial medicine works for ever. But the artemisinin treatment, in combination with other drugs, seems to reduce the levels of the parasite in the bloodstream, Prof White said.

Chinese herbalists traditionally use the drug as a fever treatment. Later, researchers produced a water-based formulation delivered by tablet or needle for large numbers within China.

The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation announced earlier this year $4.7m to underwrite wider trials of the combination therapy.

The World Health Organisation has yet to endorse artemisinin.

fields.headline: 'Suspicious' hotel fire kills couple
fields.trailText: A police investigation was under way last night into the deaths of a married couple in a fire at a hotel in Greater Manchester.
fields.body:
A police investigation was under way last night into the deaths of a married couple in a fire at a hotel in Greater Manchester.

Firefighters arrived at the seven-storey Moat House Hotel in Bolton at 12.30am after a fire broke out on the third floor. It is not yet known what caused the blaze but Greater Manchester police described it as suspicious.

Most guests were evacuated safely by hotel staff but a couple were found dead on the third floor and two people were injured and taken to hospital.

Jeff Gill, of Greater Manchester fire brigade, said: "The fire was contained to a section of the third floor corridor. Firefighters had to search 115 rooms to make sure that no one on their way out in the smoke and confusion had got lost."

Guests were taken to two nearby hotels. They expressed surprise at the severity of the fire. A man who was staying on the fourth floor said: "We were all outside believing it was nothing too serious. I saw a bit of smoke on my way out but didn't think it was a major fire."

An investigation has been launched and hotel staff have been questioned by police and fire investigators to establish the cause of the blaze.

"It is a terrible tragedy and our deepest sympathies go out to the families involved," a spokesman for the hotel said. "We plan to offer all the guests and our staff counselling to help them overcome the trauma of this event."

Some of the evacuated guests were taken to the Pack Horse hotel a mile away.

Rosa Lorens, 44, was staying at the Pack Horse when the evacuees arrived. "They were in a state of shock," she said. "No one knew what had caused the blaze and no one could believe that people had died."

webTitle: Drive to put suntans in the shade

fields.headline: Drive to put suntans in the shade
fields.standfirst: Beauty industry asked to endorse message that pale is beautiful
fields.trailText: Having a sun tan may soon be as socially undesirable as smoking if anti-cancer campaigners get their way.
fields.body:
Having a sun tan may soon be as socially undesirable as smoking if anti-cancer campaigners get their way.

They claim thousands of people each year develop skin cancer because of the public's enduring love affair with sun-bathing.

The Imperial Cancer Research Fund yesterday raised the stakes in its campaign highlighting the risks by calling on the beauty industry to help people decide that "pale is beautiful" and enlisting the support of a holiday company, JMC, to spread its "sun sense" message.

The best way to make friends jealous about holidays, the charity said, was to send a postcard, not bring back a tan.

Charity officials denied they were spoilsports, saying the incidence of skin cancer - the most common form of cancer in the United Kingdom - was increasing. Non-melanoma skin cancers are usually treatable but they claimed 467 lives in 1998.

The more serious melanoma type killed 1,640 people the same year, and the number of cases each year is about three times that figure. The charity said there were up to 100,000 new cases of the non-melanoma form each year - double the cases reported in official figures.

But in a survey published today one in seven people said they would still want a tan despite the possibility of developing skin cancer. One in five people said they would "binge sunbathe" over a weekend, with this figure rising to one in four among 15-24-year-olds. One in seven would sunbathe without any sunscreen, the report said.

Charlotte Proby, consultant dermatologist for the charity, said: "I'm concerned at how desperate some people are for a tan. A suntan shows that the skin is being damaged by too much sunlight and is trying to protect itself. Sun-seeking behaviour and inadequate sun protection increases the risk of being sunburned and this damage will increase the risk of developing skin cancer."

A telephone poll of 1,000 people aged 15 and over, commissioned by NOP Solutions, revealed that the need for a suntan was so great for some Britons that even a skin cancer scare would not put them off. Three-quarters wanted a tan at some stage during the year, with a quarter preferring a year-long tan.

The survey suggested, however, that some health messages were getting through. Seven in 10 people said those with suntans took risks with their health, and a similar number said that tanned people had damaged their skin. But 71% also thought people with suntans looked healthy.

Nearly as many men as women wanted a suntanned look (74% compared with 77%), although six in 10 people said the thought of wrinkly skin would put them off.

One in six would not want a suntan if pale skin became fashionable.

Cheryl Jagger, 25, of Bradford, whose "cute" mole was diagnosed cancerous and removed after a holiday in Turkey six years ago, said: "People think it's brilliant to have a tan and it looks wonderful. But there is no such thing as a safe tan. The only thing that is safe is out of a bottle."

The holiday company JMC said: "We are not foolish enough to believe we can stop people enjoying the sun but we can help them do it without damaging their health."

The cancer research fund recommended that people avoided the sun between 11am and 3pm, covered up with loose clothes, a sunhat and sunglasses. They advised people to wear sunscreen of at least factor 15. People should also protect themselves when swimming.

fields.headline: Madonna charges £85 for London concert
fields.trailText: Madonna, the sixth richest pop star in Britain, is to charge fans up to £85 to see her concert on July 4 - US Independence Day.
fields.body:
Never has the Material Girl more richly deserved her title. Madonna, the sixth richest pop star in Britain, is to charge fans up to £85 to see her concert on July 4 - US Independence Day.

To the obsessives who reportedly paid touts up to £1,000 to get into her exclusive show at Brixton Academy last November, it must seem like a bargain. To regular music lovers, the price tag on seats at Earl's Court, in west London, is rather steep.

But the 18,000 tickets are likely to sell out within minutes when they go on sale at 8am tomorrow. The concert will be the singer's only UK appearance on the 19 date Drowned World tour of Europe and the US, her first since 1993's The Girlie Show.

Only 2,500 people were allowed to attend the invitation-only fanclub event in Brixton, sparking increasingly outrageous bids for the precious tickets.

Publicists promise the new dates will be "the most extravagant stage spectacle of her career" and a spokeswoman for the singer insisted fans would be happy to pay upwards of £45 to see their idol, adding: "They will be getting their money's worth."

She said prices compared favourably with those for other acts, such as U2, although tickets for the Irish band's forthcoming UK shows were a maximum of £45.

A three-day pass for this summer's Reading Festival - which is headlined by Eminem, the Manic Street Preachers and Travis - costs only £80.

Madonna's tour kicks off on June 5 in Cologne, Germany, and she is expected to perform highlights from her two-decade career as well as material from her latest album Music. According to the 13th annual Rich List published by the Sunday Times last weekend, Madonna and her husband, film director Guy Ritchie, are together worth £180 million.

 Madonna will loan a piece from her private art collection to Tate Modern for the biggest exhibition of surrealist art shown in the UK in 20 years, it was announced yesterday.

Frida Kahlo's Self-Portrait With Monkey - which features the Mexican artist with a monkey round her neck - has not been loaned for 10 years. The exhibition includes works by leading figures of the surrealist movement such as Dali, Man Ray, and Ernst.

webTitle: Lonely Planet guide to Britain amusingly critical

fields.headline: Welcome to Britain: it's expensive and wet - and the breakfasts will kill you
fields.standfirst: Guidebook takes swipes at big attractions - but urges visitors to go off the beaten track
fields.trailText: Guidebook takes swipes at big attractions - but urges visitors to go off the beaten track.
fields.body:
So far this year they have battled the effects of the strong pound, wet weather and endless images of slaughtered animals smouldering on pyres. Today Britain's tourism chiefs face a further setback - an outspoken guidebook to the country which condemns London as "horrifically" expensive, likens our hotels to Fawlty Towers and warns visitors to expect drunken brawls between "liquored-up lager louts".

The new Lonely Planet guide to Britain also takes swipes at some of the country's most popular attractions, condemning Land's End as "a Thatcherite monument to the triumph of crass commerce over culture" and claiming that the Shambles in York is "overrun with people [seemingly] told to buy something silly and be back on the tour bus in 15 minutes".

The authors say that on Liverpool's Mathew Street, home to the Cavern Club, visitors can hardly move due to "businesses cashing in on the Beatles phenomenon" and advise those attending the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace that they may "go away wondering what all the fuss was about". Though they describe the Millennium Bridge across the Thames as "beautiful", they say its opening and subsequent closing was the "cock-up of all cock-ups".

The book even includes traditional jibes about the weather, warning visitors to "expect rain at any time". On the plus side, say the authors: "Tourists tend to enjoy the traditional English breakfasts (the Scottish and Welsh variations can include such horrors as black pudding) because they don't eat such things often at home. If they did they would die."

In short, it does not appear to be the good publicity the industry is seeking as it tries to rally from the impact of the foot and mouth epidemic. Tourism, worth an estimated £64bn to Britain each year and employing 7% of the workforce, is believed to be losing at least £100m a week.

"I'm not sure visitors to Britain would recognise the country that Lonely Planet describe," said Richard Tobias, chief executive of the British Incoming Tourists Association. "It's obviously not helpful. It's certainly not representative of the feedback we get from visitors. In terms of hotel accommodation our prices fare very well indeed and I've certainly never been to a hotel like Fawlty Towers. Service compares favourably with Paris or Madrid. Brawls certainly are no more common than in any other European city."

But he added: "Lonely Planet has a strong following and is well-read, but I'm not sure it is taken terribly seriously by most travellers. It's amusing rather than objective."

A spokeswoman for the Department of Culture, Media and Sport - which is responsible for tourism - was equally unworried, hinting that the authors had made some good points. "The tourist industry is well aware of the challenges it faces and is working hard to meet them," she said. "Lonely Planet look at the things that are unusual and off the beaten track and that's always welcome for the small attractions that deserve attention."

Tourism officials in the guide's direct targets were less sanguine. "The Lonely Planet people are on another planet," said Kevin Boorman, marketing manager of Hastings, which the authors dubbed "depressing". "We're really bohemian and they're really out of date - we've blitzed the seafront and there's a great air of vitality.

"The weekend after this one we have a huge festival, with morris dancers coming from all over the country. The Evening Standard even ran an article calling Hastings the hippest place on the south coast."

But the publishers of the guidebook are unrepentant and insist it will actually boost British tourism. "It's not a great time for the tourist industry," admitted a spokeswoman, Jennifer Cox. "But this book is extremely positive about the majority of places. We rave about Fishguard."

The book makes numerous unusual recommendations, enthusing about Skegness in Lincolnshire, suggesting that people would be "hard-pressed not to have a good time in Manchester", and describing Leeds as "one of the most inviting of Britain's big cities". "It's an extremely upbeat guide - especially about the Midlands - and it looks at what a problem we have with all the tourists going to the same places," Ms Cox said.

"We tried to think about where people really should be going. If you're going somewhere you don't want the only thing you see to be the backs of hundreds of other tourists in orange cagoules, all walking the same routes."

She added: "What's putting tourists off are the images of cattle burning on pyres. Independent tourists are the key to getting us out of this hole ... We need guidebooks that make Britain sound like it's lively and fun and happening and not just somewhere you'd see on a biscuit tin...

"The kind of things we say are the kind of things anyone who lives here knows about. We're not creating the problems - we're saying they exist and it would be foolish to ignore them."

The best of British...

Dundee "The dour, desolate Dundee of legend is fading. The city [has] cultural vigour and ambition ... But its real asset is its people - among the friendliest, most welcoming and most entertaining people you'll meet"

Fishguard "Ferry ports tend to be ugly, depressing places, but Fishguard stands out as an exception to the rule. It's on a beautiful bay [and the coastline] is far less touristy than the southern part of Pembrokeshire"

Sheffield "A city working hard to reinvent itself. Galleries and parks are being spiffed up in the centre and attractions pegged to the industrial past are well worth a visit ... England's fourth largest city is a lively place with an exuberant student population"

Leicester "[It] has suffered the triple disasters of wartime damage, uninspired post-war development and catastrophic industrial decline, but it has reacted to it better than most, reinventing itself as an environmentally progressive, ethnic entrept of a city that could teach other, bigger cities a thing or two about multiculturalism"

...and the worst

Around Glasgow "Glasgow is surrounded by a grim hinterland of post-industrial communities ... [with] endless suburbs of grey council-house architecture. It's here, possibly, that the area's gritty, black humour is engendered"

Dover "The foreshore is basically an enormous, complicated and unattractive vehicle ramp for the ferries. The town itself, under siege from heavy traffic, has no charm. The feeling that everyone is en route to somewhere much more interesting - as quickly as possible - doesn't help"

Cornwall "Land's End has been reduced to a commercially minded tourist trap, and inland much of the peninsula has been devastated by generations of tin and china-clay mining"

Hotels "Many ... are just fine, although stay in enough old British hotels and you'll soon realise that the TV series Fawlty Towers [starring John Cleese] was really a documentary"

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Lamplugh woodland hunt
fields.body:
Lamplugh woodland hunt

Police yesterday began searching an area of woodland near the Somerset village of Nether Stowey for the body of the estate agent Suzy Lamplugh, who disappeared in London in 1986. Detective Chief Inspector Jim Dickie said he was optimistic that the body would be found.

Morning-after pill challenge

The Society for the Protection of Unborn Children is seeking permission from the high court to challenge the government's decision to allow pharmacists to sell the morning-after pill without prescription to women over the age of 16.

Chicken steaks recalled

Tesco has recalled thousands of frozen chicken steaks amid fears they may have been made with meat destined for the petfood industry, the company said last night.

Royal butler charged

A royal butler, Harold Brown, 48, now working for Princess Margaret, has been charged on four counts of theft involving items which vanished from the estate of Diana, Princess of Wales, in 1997, Scotland Yard said.

Cancer all-clear for Steel

The Scottish parliament's presiding officer, Sir David Steel, 63, has been given the all clear after tests for prostate cancer, he said yesterday.

fields.headline: When time stood still
fields.trailText: I was puzzled to read that Belfast poet, Michael Longley, had a "12 year silence in the 1980s" (Medal crowns Belfast poet's renaissance, April 24), until I was reminded of Derek Jarman's quip that the 80s were so awful, they felt like they went on "for about 30 years".
fields.body:
I was puzzled to read that Belfast poet, Michael Longley, had a "12 year silence in the 1980s" (Medal crowns Belfast poet's renaissance, April 24), until I was reminded of Derek Jarman's quip that the 80s were so awful, they felt like they went on "for about 30 years". Mr Longley's desire to squeeze an extra two years into a decade seems modest by comparison.
Chris Coates
London

 I fear for the Brazilian rain forests if you continue to take Tony Blair's message so literally. I have just received three copies of the Education supplement with my paper.
Trevor Grant
Abingdon, Oxon
trevor.grant@oriel.oxford.ac.uk

 I'll try to be less cynical than Tim Watson (Letters, April 24) about choices for Labour's campaign song: We've Only Just Begun, The Carpenters; The Only Way is Up, Yazz; anything by The Spinners...
Richard Cohen
London

 After four years, surely only one song is appropriate: Things Can Only Get Better.
Geoff Booth
Knebworth, Herts
geoff@aaardvark.freeserve.co.uk

 Madeleine on the underground (Underground scent promises transports of delight, April 24)? A la recherche du trams perdu, perhaps?
Tim Bennett-Goodman
London

 Is this a rehearsal by the underground to take away the stench of Pee Pee Pee?
John Stone
Thames Ditton, Surrey

 The government's failure to convince farmers of the merits of vaccination has helped me to understand power relations in Blair's "Third Way". A true steakholder economy if ever I saw one!
Alex Spalding
Norwich

fields.headline: And other identities
fields.trailText: As a British Muslim, elected by local people of all races as a councillor, I welcome Robin Cook's speech on how my country, Britain, is a mixture of races.
fields.body:
Robin Cook would reduce the British identity to those factors that all British passport holders have in common. But the question of whether someone is or is not British would cease to be controversial if it were separated from the issue of right of entry and residence. It would facilitate this if we replaced the term "British passport holder" with the more appropriate "ECUK passport holder".

This would show that the government is not the custodian of British identity. It would end the pretence that the label "non-British" is an insult - and end the British conceit of believing this to be so.
John Riseley
Farnborough, Hants
johnriseley@hotmail.com

 As a British Muslim, elected by local people of all races as a councillor, I welcome Robin Cook's speech on how my country, Britain, is a mixture of races. I hope other politicians follow Mr Cook's example and, one day, we will have a top Tory who acknowledges that you can be British, Muslim and European, and all three identities add value to our great country.
Cllr Jahangir Akhtar
Rotherham

 Colour prejudice, racism and religious intolerance: I blame all the governments from the late 1940s on. If they had managed the periodic waves of immigrants sensibly, we would all be sporting an attractive "one of coffee two of cream" skin colour. This would have negated the need for millions of blue/white Brits to jet off to Spain to go through the painful acquisition of a tan that would last only a few weeks.
Bob Darlington
Leeds
bob@trill86.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Facing up to racism...
fields.trailText: What do we do in the face of racism? Geoffrey Wheatcroft (Comment, April 24) argues against the "illiberal bullying" inherent in measures like the Race Relations Acts, and the boycott against apartheid South Africa.
fields.body:
What do we do in the face of racism? Geoffrey Wheatcroft (Comment, April 24) argues against the "illiberal bullying" inherent in measures like the Race Relations Acts, and the boycott against apartheid South Africa.

In pursuit of his argument, he leaves aside the context of a racist culture and its pervasive values which underpin so much of modern history and current experience. He also attacks the definition of a racist incident and the concept of institutional racism.

Currently a racist incident is one that is perceived to be so by any of the parties involved. This is a useful initial working definition which allows investigators to explore whether or not the perception is right or wrong. That is all. The social context is one where racist incidents continue to occur, and, in many cases are officially denied.

Wheatcroft makes a very careless observation on institutional racism. The term itself clearly excludes individual blame. No individual can commit institutional racism. The concept deals with the racist functioning of institutions whatever the values of individuals operating the institution.

All freedoms need to be robustly defended. But racism is the systematic denial of rights, resources and services to people who are usually relatively powerless in the face of those who deny them.
Garry Burton
London

 Geoffrey Wheatcroft accuses campaigners against the apartheid state of South Africa of adopting methods identical to those of McCarthyism. This is a re-writing of history. McCarthyism sought to repress people for their alleged political beliefs; for the people of South Africa, the campaigns sought to win their freedom from such repression; entirely the opposite scenario.

The boycotts and isolation of South Africa, condemned by Wheatcroft, were called for by the South Africans themselves. The Anti-Apartheid Movement was always very clear that it responded to requests from the liberation movements and did not seek to impose its own agenda.

Just what does Wheatcroft think should have been done instead, against a system described by the UN as a crime against humanity? The liberation of South Africa was won by the people themselves, but the boycotts and policy of isolation from the rest of the world played a significant part. Without them, Nelson Mandela might still be in prison, and many more people would have been tortured and killed.
Mike Sparham
London

 Geoffrey Wheatcroft has the cheek to lecture Nelson Mandela, the ANC and their international supporters. What struggle against oppression has Mr Wheatcroft won? What "liberal" tactics did he find worked for him?
William Baltimore
London

 If Geoffrey Wheatcroft can drag himself away from his obsession with his abstract libertarian "rights", perhaps he would like to visit the Glasgow Royal Infirmary, where I could show him the all-too-real consequences of his mock-liberal "freedom" to reject the Commission for Racial Equality's minimum standards on anti-racism.

In that hospital lie two Palestinian refugees, brothers Haitham and Iyad Saada, the victims of a horrendous attack by a baseball bat wielding mob of up to 40 people. Few people doubt that the attack is directly linked to the fact that many politicians and newspapers have exercised their "freedom of expression" by whipping up anti-refugee bigotry.
Mark Brown
Glasgow Campaign to Welcome Refugees markbrown150@cswebmail.com

fields.headline: Booked in
fields.trailText: Contrary to Justin Cartwright's claim (Stranger than fiction, April 19), the Gauteng education department has not dropped Nadine Gordimer's book, July's People, or any other works by other authors from the school syllabus.
fields.body:
Contrary to Justin Cartwright's claim (Stranger than fiction, April 19), the Gauteng education department has not dropped Nadine Gordimer's book, July's People, or any other works by other authors from the school syllabus.

Kader Asmal, the education minister, commented that the views expressed by a group of teachers were "ill-informed, pedagogically unsound and smacked of anti-intellectualism". The minister further found the comments about Ms Gordimer's work most insulting, given her stature as a world-renowned writer and opponent of apartheid. The minister personally conveyed these sentiments to Ms Gordimer.
Monica Williamson
South African High Commission, London

webTitle: Letters: try being a vicar's widow

fields.headline: Try being a vicar's widow
fields.trailText: Susan Devonshire Jones admits that "being married to a vicar does your head in" (G2, April 20). She may have worse to come. My husband died just two years after he retired. As a clergy widow I have very little to show for 36 years in a working partnership.
fields.body:
Susan Devonshire Jones admits that "being married to a vicar does your head in" (G2, April 20). She may have worse to come. My husband died just two years after he retired. As a clergy widow I have very little to show for 36 years in a working partnership.

We moved six times in those years. There wasn't much opportunity to make close friends. After the vicarage, it is hard to adjust to a world where not even the neighbours are in the habit of "dropping in" - however much they are encouraged to do so.

The final move diminished what little savings we had. From the clergy widow's pension of £553.34 a month, £219 is deducted for the mortgage on the Pensions Board's small bungalow in which I now live. I gave up full time teaching so that I could be part of a working team, so I don't get an occupational pension: just £365.88 state pension, based on the years I worked before marriage. There is enough to live comfortably on, but not much to spare.

This is the downside but there are compensations. I'd have had a very different life, which I can only guess at, if I hadn't married a clergyman. I would also have missed out on many unique experiences: meeting such a wide variety of people - from the tramps to the very famous; living as part of a real community of ordinary working people; and sharing with good, caring Christians (and whatever Guardian writers say, there are many of these) their times of grief or happiness. Oh dear, this sounds trite. But it is true.
Rosemary Freeman

fields.headline: Wackford no more
fields.standfirst: After Squeers' rehabilitation, who is next?
fields.trailText: In Nicholas Nickleby, Dickens says: "Mr Squeers's appearance was not prepossessing. He had but one eye, and the popular prejudice runs in favour of two." After this cheap crack at monoculists - so much for Nelson - Dickens picks on Wackford's clothes.
fields.body:
In Nicholas Nickleby, Dickens says: "Mr Squeers's appearance was not prepossessing. He had but one eye, and the popular prejudice runs in favour of two." After this cheap crack at monoculists - so much for Nelson - Dickens picks on Wackford's clothes. His trousers were "a great deal too short." So how long were Dickens' own? And does he tell us how many eyes David Copperfield had? No.

Dickens portrays Wackford Squeers in an unfavourable light, mocking his physical and sartorial defects. But at long last, someone is speaking up for Mr Squeers. Dickens modelled Squeers on a William Shaw. Shaw's great-great-grandson, Ted Shaw, claims this week that Squeers-Shaw was kindly and caring. When Dickens met Shaw while researching he noted in his diary: "Shaw, the schoolmaster we saw today, is the man in whose school several boys went blind from gross neglect." Shaw was convicted on two charges and fined the huge sum of £300 each time. Ted Shaw ought be able to defend his ancestor. But can we look forward to the descendants of Fagin, Bill Sikes, Iago, Torquemada and Caligula following his example? As for Smike, he got what was coming to him.

webTitle: Care home vacancy website to tackle bed search problem

fields.headline: Service with a surf
fields.standfirst: Care home vacancy website to tackle bed search problem
fields.trailText: Care home vacancy website to tackle bed search problem
fields.body:
Finding care home places for elderly patients ready to leave hospital, thus avoiding so-called "bed-blocking", is one of the biggest challenges facing the health and social care systems. But a new scheme may have an answer.

The idea is an internet website which will offer constantly updated lists of vacancies in residential and nursing homes. Instead of ringing round in search of a suitable vacancy, social workers and other care professionals will be able to tap into the website and run a one-off check.

The scheme is being developed by a partnership of TSO Enterprises, the enterprise arm of the Stationery Office, and venture builder Nao. From today, the website - also available to relatives of people looking for a suitable home - carries comprehensive listings of all registered homes. But in a second phase, it will carry details of vacancies at the homes in what the partners are calling "real time bed availability".

That facility is currently being tested with the cooperation of health and care staff in 12 local authority areas. It could be introduced nationwide in a few months and offered as a charged-for service. Local councils and health trusts will pay an annual fee - the amount still to be determined - to use the service.

"Despite an ageing population, the home care industry is fragmented," says Julian Fagandini, managing director of TSO. "With nearly 500,000 beds owned by over 12,000 operators, no wonder it's difficult to find pertinent information and suitable home care."

There are more than 50,000 unused beds at any one time in the private sector, says Luke Jensen, joint chief executive of Nao. "The homecare market is increasingly under pressure to relieve the economic strain caused by bed-blocking in hospitals. The problem is increased by the time-consuming procedure of sourcing available beds in suitable homes. Despite recent capacity reductions, we estimate that currently over 10% of the capacity is unused."

The website address is: www.bettercaring.co.uk

webTitle: The advantages and problems of adapting business practice for non-profit organisations

fields.headline: Cash of cultures
fields.standfirst: The voluntary sector involves big money. As its key annual event takes place this week,  Roger Cowe  looks at the advantages and problems of adapting business practice for non-profit organisations
fields.trailText: The voluntary sector involves big money. As its key annual event takes place this week, Roger Cowe looks at the advantages and problems of adapting business practice for non-profit organisations
fields.body:
Charityfair, the key annual event for the voluntary sector, this week celebrates its 10th anniversary with more than 180 events for people working and volunteering in the voluntary sector - or thinking of doing so. The sector is big business these days, so much so that the world's leading management consultants want a piece of the action.

Both McKinsey and Bain - US-based global consultancies which are leaders in giving strategy advice to multinationals - have recently moved to address what they like to call the non-profit sector.

McKinsey has set up a team to serve non-profit customers - though they'll still be charged fees. Bain has established a separate but associated firm in the US, called Bridgespan, and wants this to be a model for other "professional service" firms to follow around the world.

These organisations believe they can help charities be more effective by applying the traditional analytical and strategic techniques which help the world's leading businesses decide how best to make money.

But they have discovered it is not as simple as that. The companies they work for are relatively simple. Multinationals such as Unilever, Shell or IBM may be huge, with a global network of offices and relationships. And their activities embrace many products, processes and markets. But their overriding objective is simple - making money.

Power structures in business are also relatively straightforward, even if it doesn't seem like that to somebody stuck in the middle of a corporate hierarchy. Essentially, however, the chief executive reports to a board which is normally quite remote and uninvolved. And however many staff there are, they all owe at least theoretical allegiance only to the company; that is, the boss.

Tom Tierney, the former global chairman of Bain who left to set up Bridgespan, characterises consultancy work for such firms like this: "The corporate chief executive has an enormous amount of power. As consultants, we come up with a dazzling and insightful programme. All the chief executive has to do is implement it and everybody applauds - he or she is a hero."

He contrasts that set-up with the non-profit sector: a much more influential board, as well as donors who a chief executive cannot afford to neglect; plus volunteers who will not automatically jump to attention just because their chief executive says so.

Tierney also points out the difficulty of measuring progress where there is not the single simple goal of showing a profit.

"In business the bottom line is clear, but in some mission-driven organisations it is not always clear what the final outcome is. The complexity of running even a small charity is quite a bit more challenging than running most businesses," he says.

Bridgespan managing partner, Jeff Bradach, has studied the voluntary sector at Harvard university. He acknowledges the challenge for his firm, used to working with complex business problems but where the parameters are clear and there is usually ample data.

He cites a housing charity, Habitat for Humanity, a past winner of a Guardian charity award for its work in Belfast, which has an approach to construction that he says would appal business managers if they did not appreciate that means are as important as ends for the organisation.

"The problems are really quite distinctive. It is easy to see how you could get into trouble by simply applying business methods to non-profit organisations," Bradach says.

Reflecting on the firm's first year in the field, he says he's impressed by the level of skills evident in the first batch of non-profit clients: "All of us have come away impressed by how much people in these organisations get done with so little resources. The entrepreneurialism and resourcefulness is truly remarkable. We stand in awe, frankly." These are not only the conclusions of US consultants, although the American appetite for management consultants and gurus does mean their ideas are being widely disseminated there.

For example, business management expert Peter Drucker has set up a "Foundation for non-profit management". Its vision is to "bring the best leadership and management voices, with a focus on providing social sector organisations with the ideas and tools that enable them to better serve their customers and communities."

That sounds a bit like teaching charities what management is all about, but Drucker knows more about management than most and is not as naïve as that. He says: "The 21st century will be the century of the social sector organisation. The leadership, competence and management of the social sector non-profit organisation will largely determine the values, the vision, the cohesion and the performance of society."

The message is that businesses have as much to learn from voluntary sector managers as vice versa; a message which is just as applicable in the UK, according to Stephen Bubb, chief executive of the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations (Acevo).

He cautions against the caricature contrast of big bad business and terribly nice charities. "There's a mindset that thinks of charity as sweet and nice. It's a shock for some when they find there are lots of first-rate professional staff who could have been very successful in the private sector."

While acknowledging that there are differences, Bubb argues that each can learn from the other. For example, he suggests charity managers are not always good at getting to grips with restructuring and other tough challenges which might involve redundancies and other difficult personnel issues.

On the other hand, businesses are often struggling to come to terms with the fact that old-fashioned command and control does not normally yield brilliant results even in the commercial world.

"People often think in terms of what the private sector can bring to charities. But there is a hell of a lot of good leadership practice in the voluntary sector which businesses want to learn about. They want to learn about motivation and inspiration - the softer skills that commercial people are often bloody poor at."

Voluntary sector managers often have to lead volunteers. "They don't have contracts of employment. You have to use a lot of skills which commercial leaders would be better for having."

McKinsey has set up a team to serve non-profit customers - though they'll still be charged fees.
