webTitle: Community fund's new leader signals a change of heart

fields.headline: Community fund's new leader signals a change of heart
fields.trailText: National lottery money should be used to pay for voluntary groups' core costs as well as for new projects, according to the incoming England director of the community fund - formerly the lottery charities board.
fields.body:
National lottery money should be used to pay for voluntary groups' core costs as well as for new projects, according to the incoming England director of the community fund - formerly the lottery charities board.

The assertion by Richard Gutch will be seen as a clear signal that the community fund is to change its policy on an issue identified repeatedly as one of the most pressing for voluntary organisations. The Family Policy Studies Centre this week is citing lack of help with core costs as a reason for its decision to go into voluntary liquidation.

Gutch, who takes a up his new post next week, says: "I hope we will move towards a more flexible approach towards core costs where we think: 'What is the best way to achieve the outcomes that we all want?' If this is going to mean funding core costs for some applicants, then we should."

If the community fund does move away from meeting the costs only of new projects, the change will come in its new strategic plan due to be submitted to parliament next March. Gutch, who is leaving the charity Arthritis Care, where he has been chief executive for nine years, is already sounding out key figures in the voluntary sector on what they would like the fund to do.

Of 40 charity leaders he has written to, 15 have so far responded. Eleven have specified core costs as a priority issue and nine have said the fund should be more flexible on length of grant funding, breaking the ubiquitous three-year mould.

Gutch would also like to see the fund doing more to help with voluntary organisations' infrastructure, assisting perhaps with trustee training and development. He says: "There is general agreement from everybody I have spoken to that the community fund needs to have a more focused approach with clear strategic priorities, much more emphasis on outcomes, so that you can actually see that this is the kind of effect we are going to try to make in these priority areas. Then, five years on, you can look back and try to demonstrate exactly what difference has been made."

At 54, Gutch sees his move to the community fund as "one last challenge". It also represents a return to a more general role: before joining Arthritis Care, he was assistant director of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations.

He leaves a charity that has been transformed from an archetypal centralised and paternalistic organisation into something of a model of new practice. User involvement has been introduced at all levels, with key posts now reserved for people with arthritis; the governance structure has been modernised, with a board of 50 trustees pruned to 18 and new regional tiers put in place; and the charity has pioneered self-management techniques for those living with arthritis - techniques now being used by the Department of Health as a basis for its "expert patient" programme.

Last year, in an initiative to raise awareness of arthritis, the charity took a roadshow on a national tour of 43 locations. Gutch reflects: "I think it has been possible for what was a traditional charity - over 50 years old - to move from being an organisation for people with arthritis to being one of people with arthritis."

With an earlier background in local government, focusing on community development, Gutch is enthusiastic about the potential of the community fund's £180m grants budget for England. But he recognises it will take time to achieve his goals, particularly on funding core costs. As a first step, he believes all grant applicants should be required to spell out the management, administrative, support and training overheads of any project.

"There is a lot of work that has to go into developing this approach, I would the first to admit that," Gutch says. "One challenge is to develop clear criteria as to under what circumstances do you fund core costs. But the starting point has got to be that any project has got to recognise its core costs."

webTitle: National lottery funding makes healthy living a priority

fields.headline: National lottery funding makes healthy living a priority
fields.trailText: The Peak District, famous for its spectacular Derbyshire scenery but less well-known for its rural deprivation, will tomorrow receive £1m national lottery funding to develop one of the planned network of "healthy living centres".
fields.body:
The Peak District, famous for its spectacular Derbyshire scenery but less well-known for its rural deprivation, will tomorrow receive £1m national lottery funding to develop one of the planned network of "healthy living centres".

The award will be one of six, totalling £5.2m, made by the new opportunities fund (NOF) - the lottery grant distributor that works to a framework set by government. In all, £300m is earmarked for healthy living centres, of which 45 have been approved so far at a total cost of £35m.

The first project to win approval, St Augustine's in King's Lynn, Norfolk, is due to be opened on Friday. It will mean that a locality with one of the worst health records in the county will, for the first time, have its own GP and primary healthcare services.

Based in the Hope Valley, the Peak District project aims to bring to local towns and villages a range of activities, including advice and exercise sessions, youth services and a peak walks programme. Exercise will be provided "on prescription" by GPs, who will refer patients to physiotherapists for swimming and gym workouts.

Julie Hirst, of the Peak District Rural Deprivation Forum, says the announcement is timely. "Fears about the mental health of farmers have been heightened by the problems caused by the foot and mouth outbreak. There are also high levels of stress and depression in this community, which often go untreated due to cultural taboos. This funding will enable us to offer fully integrated support and advice where it's most needed."

Stephen Dunmore, NOF's chief executive, says: "Building on the track record of the partners [behind the scheme], I am sure this project will soon demonstrate a tangible impact on the health and well-being of the whole community."

Other awards to be made tomorrow are £1m for a healthy living centre in Croydon, south London; another £1m for a project in Wigan and Leigh, Greater Manchester; £1.2m for a scheme in Derry, Northern Ireland, aimed at improving the health of children and their families; £700,000 for a project in Bangor, Gwynedd; and £300,000 for a scheme to meet the health needs of homeless people in Hammersmith and Fulham, west London.

The King's Lynn centre is to be opened by the Bishop of Norwich, the Rt Rev Graham James. The project manager, Lin Twell, says: "The provision of a locally-based GP and primary healthcare service has taken us many years of hard work to achieve - so it is with a sigh of relief that we can finally say that we have finished the job we set out to do."

St Augustine's will be more than a GP surgery, however. It will also accommodate a fully equipped childcare centre, a community cafe, a learning centre, a large arts studio, a range of advice agencies, and allotments where people can learn to grow fruit and vegetables.

webTitle: Social rents are outstripping mortgage costs

fields.headline: Social rents are outstripping mortgage costs
fields.standfirst: Falling interest rates have left housing associations facing a chronic shortfall in demand, writes Matt Weaver
fields.trailText: Owner occupation is cheaper than renting 'affordable' homes from housing associations across much of the country, according to unpublished research. Matt Weaver reports.
fields.body:
Owner occupation is cheaper than renting "affordable" homes from housing associations across much of the country, according to unpublished research.

SocietyGuardian.co.uk has obtained a preview of Cambridge University research that identifies 55 areas where mortgage repayments cost less than renting from housing associations (see list).

The research by the university's Dataspring unit for the Housing Corporation underlines why social landlords are suffering from chronic demand shortfall problems, which are threatening their financial viability.

The research explains that while house prices may be rising, the actual cost of paying a mortgage has fallen, or increased by very little, because of low interest rates.

At the same time the rise in housing association rents has been outstripping the rate of inflation, to allow associations to pay back private loans. This, together with low starting prices for houses in the north, means that in two entire regions owner occupation is as cheap or cheaper than social renting.

The research compared housing association rent levels with the local cost of owning a house at the lower end of the market - based on lower quartile house prices.

In the north-east, on average there is now no difference between the price of renting a two-bedroom housing association home and buying a two-bedroom home, in contrast to 1989-90 when social renting was 41% cheaper than buying.

In Yorkshire and Humberside the difference is even more stark - in 1989-90 social renting was 61% cheaper, but a decade later it is actually 3% more expensive to rent a housing association home than pay off a mortgage.

In 49 of the 55 districts, buying a home is more than 15% cheaper than renting from a housing association.

An executive summary of the report has been published, but does not identify the 55 areas. It warns housing associations to take note of the figures to "prevent high turnover and vacancy rates".

The research is highly sensitive for the housing association sector. Last year Dataspring found that buying was cheaper than renting in 25 areas. This finding was described as "dynamite" at the time, but the housing corporation refused to publish the figures because of a row about the methodology used.

The new research, which shows the picture is now even bleaker, will be published in full as a discussion paper on the methodology for comparing social rents with the cost of home ownership.

Professor Christine Whitehead, who supervised the project, said: "Housing associations in these areas should be careful about what they are doing. And it's not just these area, people may be prepared to pay more to be an owner occupiers."

But she warned that the figures should be treated with caution because the quality of cheaper homes to buy are not as good as housing association homes which are often newer and better maintained.

The research comes at the start of a 10-year programme to reform social rents to a government formula based more closely on market values.

Ms Whitehead argued that housing associations should examine the new research closely in the context of rent reform. She said: "In many ways this type of market mechanism is more important than administrative rent restructuring."

Dr Paul Hickman, senior research fellow in housing at Sheffield Hallam University, said: "In many parts of the north, demand for social housing has been undermined by the relative affordability of home-ownership as many tenants, both actual and potential, have chosen to buy their own homes."

He warned that the government's rent restructuring policy was too blunt an instrument to tackle low demand.

He said: "The clumsiness of the formula and its failure to recognise local factors may result in landlords adopting rent structures that are out of kilter with prevailing local house market conditions."

fields.headline: Adding value
fields.standfirst: Fernley Calver, a youth worker making school fun for boys at risk of exclusion. By  Deborah Mulhearn
fields.trailText: Profile: Fernley Calver, a youth worker making school fun for boys at risk of exclusion. By Deborah Mulhearn
fields.body:
Sitting in on a Year 10 maths lesson wouldn't be many people's idea of fun, and normally it isn't Fernley Calver's. He is already kept busy running the Carroll Youth Centre in Winchester, where he does everything from scouring graffiti from the walls to chasing increasingly elusive funding. But he approached the local comprehensive, Kings', when he noticed a hard core of boys spending all their time in the centre because they had been excluded from school.

The well-heeled Hampshire city is not the sort of place normally associated with alienated youth. Its schools are high up the league tables and unemployment and crime rates are low. But there are pockets of deprivation behind the comforting statistics and, for the relatively small number of young people who do not fit the mould, there are few safety nets. Life can quickly spiral from truancy to petty crime, or from being merely aimless to long-term jobless.

"Disillusionment and sense of failure is compounded by being surrounded by affluence," says Calver.

The youth centre is on the Stanmore housing estate, the biggest council estate in Winchester, only a mile and a half from the city centre but a world away from the genteel cloisters of the famous cathedral and college. Calver knew that with a permanent exclusion on their records, the boys' job prospects would be poor; their disruptive behaviour and consequent low performance in national curriculum tests meant the school would be glad to see the back of them.

Calver felt he could break the cycle of disruptive behaviour and poor achievement by using his youth centre experience to keep the boys better focused at school. "I'm better placed than mentors or classroom assistants because I'm autonomous and they know this. I'm not employed by the education authority or the youth service, so I already have credibility with them - although it also means they can tell me to eff-off, which they do sometimes."

The year head identifies participants for the inclusion scheme, who have to agree to take part, and targets are set. It is almost always maths lessons where Calver is needed. He meets the boys five minutes beforehand, then sits with them through the lesson, defusing potential confrontations, with a follow-up session later. "It's not my agenda to improve exam results," he says. "These are 14- and 15-year-old boys struggling with academia. A lot of the behaviour is driven by poor attention span and if I can keep them on an even keel, they can do some of the maths. One boy said I acted like a wall between him and the teacher and the other pupils."

Calver, 40, left school at 16 with no qualifications and, until seven years ago, was a bricklayer. He became a trainee at the then new youth centre, while he studied for a degree in community and youth studies. A trip to Kenya in 1986, international youth year, to work in a charity school changed his outlook: "Everyone has so much here. In Kenya, there were 5,000 applicants for 20 school places."

Back in Winchester, Calver's inclusion project seems a crazy inversion of his work in Kenya. But he is succeeding - and the school is happy. Five of the six boys he has worked with have stayed in school for three terms; the sixth went to a special unit. He recognises the project has limitations. It is labour intensive and built on one-to-one relationships which, he admits, cannot easily be replicated.

The youth centre was set up in 1993 with a bequest from two social worker sisters. Its £25,000 annual funding from Hampshire youth service has now been cut to a share of a pot of £6,000, spread among four full-time voluntary projects in the area. Revenue is generated from after-school clubs and community groups, but Calver is the only full-time paid worker.

"I can't spend too much time away from the youth centre, and I don't need the extra paperwork," he says. "We're putting in a bid for European funding for another full-time worker who will spend half the time at the school and half at the youth centre."

Calver believes his presence in a class benefits all the pupils, as well as improving the behaviour of the targeted children. "Realistically, it's about them getting through their school life and teaching them that they have to be in a given place at a given time. If they can achieve this, they will stand a better chance in job interviews and then holding down the job, if they get it, and not getting into conflict with authority."

After initial scepticism, he feels he has won the teachers round. "Maybe they were uneasy about having me scribbling away at the back of the class. It has taken a while, but the teachers are now starting to ask for my opinion and advice."

Calver knew that with a permanent exclusion on their records, the boys' job prospects would be poor; their disruptive behaviour and consequent low performance in national curriculum tests meant the school would be glad to see the back of them. Calver felt he could break the cycle of disruptive behaviour and poor achievement by using his youth centre experience to keep the boys better focused at school. "I'm better placed than mentors or classroom assistants because I'm autonomous and they know this. I'm not employed by the education authority or the youth service, so I already have credibility with them - although it also means they can tell me to eff-off, which they do sometimes." The year head identifies participants for the inclusion scheme, who have to agree to take part, and targets are set. It is almost always maths lessons where Calver is needed. He meets the boys five minutes beforehand, then sits with them through the lesson, defusing potential confrontations, with a follow-up session later. "It's not my agenda to improve exam results," he says. "These are 14- and 15-year-old boys struggling with academia. A lot of the behaviour is driven by poor attention span and if I can keep them on an even keel, they can do some of the maths. One boy said I acted like a wall between him and the teacher and the other pupils." Calver, 40, left school at 16 with no qualifications and, until seven years ago, was a bricklayer. He became a trainee at the then new youth centre, while he studied for a degree in community and youth studies. A trip to Kenya in 1986, international youth year, to work in a charity school changed his outlook: "Everyone has so much here. In Kenya, there were 5,000 applicants for 20 school places." Back in Winchester, Calver's inclusion project seems a crazy inversion of his work in Kenya. But he is succeeding - and the school is happy. Five of the six boys he has worked with have stayed in school for three terms; the sixth went to a special unit. He recognises the project has limitations. It is labour intensive and built on one-to-one relationships which, he admits, cannot easily be replicated. The youth centre was set up in 1993 with a bequest from two social worker sisters. Its £25,000 annual funding from Hampshire youth service has now been cut to a share of a pot of £6,000, spread among four full-time voluntary projects in the area. Revenue is generated from after-school clubs and community groups, but Calver is the only full-time paid worker. "I can't spend too much time away from the youth centre, and I don't need the extra paperwork," he says. "We're putting in a bid for European funding for another full-time worker who will spend half the time at the school and half at the youth centre." Calver believes his presence in a class benefits all the pupils, as well as improving the behaviour of the targeted children. "Realistically, it's about them getting through their school life and teaching them that they have to be in a given place at a given time. If they can achieve this, they will stand a better chance in job interviews and then holding down the job, if they get it, and not getting into conflict with authority." After initial scepticism, he feels he has won the teachers round. "Maybe they were uneasy about having me scribbling away at the back of the class. It has taken a while, but the teachers are now starting to ask for my opinion and advice."

webTitle: Charities can provide expert advice on their client groups - but at what price?

fields.headline: Just rewards
fields.standfirst: Charities can provide expert advice on their client groups - but at what price?
fields.trailText: Charities can provide expert advice on their client groups - but at what price?
fields.body:
It's no secret the government has drawn on many voluntary sector high-flyers for its innumerable taskforces and policy units. But some charities are beginning to wonder where to draw the line between influencing public policy and acting as unpaid consultants to Whitehall departments.

Urged to become more entrepreneurial, other charities are looking to use their unique knowledge and experience of particular subjects, or client groups, in gaining funding from commercial organisations - or even charging other voluntary groups.

On the Whitehall front, the Hansard Society for Parliamentary Government is being paid a consultancy fee by the Cabinet Office for its advice on the setting up of the web portal UK Online. "When they asked us to get involved, we realised it would be a big commitment of time and staff, and so we asked to be paid. There was no argument from them as we're one of the leading experts in promoting democratic participation," says director Shelagh Diplock.

When the government takes on private sector consultants, she points out, it expects to pay the going rate. But with the voluntary sector, there is an assumption that everything is free. The hard part was working out what to charge. "We looked at what private consultants would get, about £375 to £1,000 a day, and decided £500 a day seemed fair."

Others have found Whitehall less cooperative. At the Maternity Alliance, which has advised several government departments, the Home Office turned down a request by the charity to be paid for its work on how pregnant women are treated in prison. "They wanted the equivalent of a day a week for 13 weeks, which was a very big commitment for a charity our size," says director Christine Gowdridge. When the Home Office refused to budge, the charity continued anyway. "We're in a quandary because we want to influence government policy, and that's part of our role, but at the same time we provide an awful lot of time providing expertise, which takes us away from other projects."

Diplock draws a distinction between helping form government policy, by appearing on taskforces and committees, and being asked to contribute large amounts of staff time to particular projects. "There's a balance to be struck, but it's sometimes difficult to judge when giving advice in an ad hoc way, or working on a campaign issue, crosses over into delivering ongoing advice for specific government projects."

As well as with government, charities are waking up to the value of their knowledge base in relations with commercial organisations. Help the Aged won a tender for a multi-million pound "partnership agreement" with British Gas, largely on the back of its knowledge of the needs and behaviour of older people. Since 1999, the company has given Help the Aged £4m in funds or benefits in kind, financing charity campaigns on issues such as fuel poverty and initiatives, including an advice helpline.

Simon Henderson, community affairs manager at Centrica, which owns British Gas, says: "All the voluntary organisations we are involved with have specific knowledge of communities and customer groups, which helps us improve our services to those groups."

One example was advice from Help the Aged on the fact that older people frequently preferred to pay cash, rather than direct debit. They were missing out on direct debit discounts, while the company was losing a reliable income stream. "With the charity's help," Henderson says, "we were able to put in place a 'pay point' system at post offices, which allowed older people to pay in cash on a regular basis, and those payments were converted into a direct debit-style process."

Charities which have such commercial arrangements need to be aware, though, of the risk that they may end up benefiting the company without helping their own client group. Debbie Broadhurst, Help the Aged's corporate relations manager, says: "There may be times when we feel it's not appropriate for us to get involved in particular commercial projects with a corporate partner."

Andrew Mawson, chair of the Bromley-by-Bow regeneration project in east London, says charities need to take a more business-like approach in how they market their expertise.

The Bromley-by-Bow centre has attracted attention as an innovative example of inner-city regeneration and as a pioneer of healthy living centres, a concept the government is now backing. "We were getting people calling us all the time wanting to visit and find out what we were doing, and how we'd achieved it, and it was becoming very time consuming," Mawson says. Eventually, the centre decided to organise regular one-day seminars, including a tour of the centre and a briefing on how it was financed and put in place. The seminars cost £100 a head but, if someone genuinely cannot afford to pay, the fee may be reduced or waived.

Mawson says: "We don't have any compunction about charging because it's often only when people pay for something that they value it."

webTitle: End of the line for family policy centre

fields.headline: End of the line for family policy centre
fields.trailText: Social policy research has suffered a heavy blow with the collapse of the Family Policy Studies Centre (FPSC), the independent unit which has done much to inform and moderate debate on the family over the past two decades.
fields.body:
Social policy research has suffered a heavy blow with the collapse of the Family Policy Studies Centre (FPSC), the independent unit which has done much to inform and moderate debate on the family over the past two decades.

In the face of severe financial problems, the centre's governing council has decided to put the organisation into voluntary liquidation. Talks are under way about transferring some work and staff to the Policy Studies Institute (PSI), as a stand-alone family policy group.

The FPSC, a registered charity, is blaming its demise on lack of funding. In a letter to supporters, director Ceridwen Roberts says: "There is a lack of financial support for this kind of work in Britain, and the unresolved problem of core funding for small voluntary organisations has also contributed to the centre's financial difficulties."

The centre was set up in 1983 by Sir Campbell Adamson, the former director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, who died last year; its director until 1992 was Malcolm Wicks, now government minister for lifelong learning. Its work has been prominent in controversies over lone parents, working mothers and teenage pregnancy.

In her letter, Roberts claims the centre has occupied a "pivotal" place in family debate. "We have worked extensively with government as well as practitioners working with families in the statutory and voluntary sectors. A unique and much valued aspect of our role has been the bridge we offer between the academic research community and the policy and practice worlds, which increasingly draw on research evidence to inform their activities."

The centre's council believes strongly that there is a continuing need for such work, Roberts says. "And this underlies our decision to move to the PSI, an independent charity with the same purposes as ourselves, which is looking to strengthen both its family policy capacity and its dissemination work."

Speculation will inevitably link the centre's closure with the creation two years ago of the government-inspired National Family and Parenting Institute. At the time, some thought the centre should be developed into such a body. But Mary Macleod, the institute's chief executive, insists the two bodies were co-existing comfortably.

"From our point of view, from the beginning we have had a different, much broader remit than theirs," says Macleod. "But there were areas of overlap, obviously, and we have been very careful about those - just as we have been with Parentline, the Parenting Forum and other groups.

"That's not unusual in the voluntary sector, to have to try to keep your feet off each other's turf. We were working with them quite well, we thought. I feel very sorry about the closure of the FPSC because it did have a really good history."

The institute was in fact funding an FPSC research project, mapping family policy work being done in universities and by voluntary groups across the country with the aim of setting up a database. The project will now be taken back by the institute, with a view to its completion elsewhere.

The institute has also agreed to take on another two of the centre's pieces of work: a regular policy digest, aimed at practitioners in family work; and a scheme designed to produce research resources and texts for those in the field.

webTitle: How painting is helping a group come to terms with being adopted

fields.headline: Art strings
fields.standfirst: Raekha Prasad on how painting is helping a group in the north west to come to terms with being adopted
fields.trailText: Raekha Prasad on how painting is helping a group in the north west to come to terms with being adopted
fields.body:
Talking over a personal problem is widely seen as a wise first step to restoring someone's sense of well-being. But for people who struggle to express their emotions, the pressure to tell others how they feel can add to their sense of failure.

For teenagers, silence is a common tool for establishing independence from parents. It may also increase a young person's sense of isolation. Julia Mansfield, children and families manager of the north west-based charity After Adoption, recognised that adopted teenagers have problems speaking about their personal lives. So when she was approached by an artist wanting to work with young adoptees, she realised that painting might be a conduit for revealing their emotions.

The result is Splat, the creative workshops run by artist Darren Bradshaw and After Adoption for adoptees aged 10 to 16. Six sessions have taken place in Salford since December; three are planned in Bolton.

Ms Mansfield says: "There was so little available for a number of adopted children who do not find words an easy way of communicating. Splat is a recognition that for youngsters who are adopted and who have difficulties, words are not a good medium - particularly in relation to youngsters whose placements have broken down." Although the charity runs more than 100 groups a year, including a young adoptees club, "words are not the answer to everything".

After a social worker asked Ms Mansfield if any support services were available for a 12-year-old adoptee whose placement had broken down - "He'd lost three families and I felt pretty grim about that" - she called Mr Bradshaw, with whom she had already devised the idea behind Splat. They successfully bid for £3,000 funding from Salford health and social services to run six workshops, with the support of Samantha Taylor, a post-adoption worker.

Ms Mansfield argues that some issues "predictably" crop up for adoptees. These include feelings of loss ("To be chosen you have to be rejected"), difficulty in integrating ("Life has been fractured. Adoption is a legalistic severence and reconnection") and issues of loyalty towards their adopted family, which may conflict with a desire to search for their natural parents.

Mr Bradshaw is adopted and says his background is a touchstone, allowing him to introduce the subject at the beginning of sessions. He tells the group that he is an adoptee as well as an artist, and shows them some of his work and childhood photographs of his adopted and natural family.

"The approach is fun and accessible," Mr Bradshaw says. The group use disposable cameras, clay and scrap material. "They never choose to take pictures of their parents - it's always the cat, friends and their bedrooms. We don't get them in and say 'We're going to tackle adoption'. We chat informally. Adoption comes into the sessions from the beginning. I might be asked where I was born. Some may tell me they're thinking of searching for their natural parents."

Many of the young people choose to focus on identity. "We seem to do a lot of hand-prints and mother totems," Mr Bradshaw says. "The idea is to unlock their creative potential. Underneath I can see there's a sense of alienation and low-self esteem. There's power in numbers. We're a group and we're overcoming shyness. It's not said. It's just happening."

Mr Bradshaw, now 37, found his natural mother 10 years ago. He was adopted when he was a month old and counts himself lucky - his adoptive family were loving and supportive. His adoption was explained to him as soon as he was old enough to understand it. Until his mid-20s he used to fantasise about what his natural parents looked like, but did not feel compelled to find them. But a chance meeting with another adoptee changed his mind and for two years the idea of searching for them dominated his thoughts.

Through the local adoption agency, he eventually found his natural grandmother's address in Eccles. "I felt like a private detective. I went to the house and looked at passers-by, paying particular attention to women in their mid-50s, but was too scared to knock on the door."

But when he eventually did, he knew that he was related to the woman who opened it. "The eye contact was amazing. It was a gut feeling."

His mother was 17 and his father 18 when he was born. "My grandmother asked me if I was angry. I told her that I understood that it was a different time and that the pressure was intense." His grandmother phoned his mother, who lived 20 minutes away, and she immediately came to meet him. "We stood in the middle of the room and ran our fingers through each other's hair. It was emotionally charged."

Mr Bradshaw has two half-brothers and a half-sister. His father died in the mid-80s but he has developed relationships with other members of the family.

The discovery dominated Mr Bradshaw's work. He made portraits and sculptures of his natural mother and at the same time began to attend a support group, run by After Adoption, for adoptees of all ages and at different stages in their search. Mr Bradshaw says he began to realise that he had low self-esteem. He kept in contact with the organisation for several years before Splat was formed.

"There's always a missing link. As a kid, I was always rooting around under the stairs, sure that something had been kept from me. At Splat we want to lessen the secrecy and create openness."

Mr Bradshaw's story and Splat are featured in a BBC1 series, A Family of My Own. The programmes show 36 children, in care or permanent fostering, desperately seeking adoptive parents. The first series, which ran last year, caused a stir, with accusations that it was exploitative and would attract would-be parents seduced by the glamour of television. But social services and fostering and adoption agencies support the series.

All prospective adoptive parents are vetted, and Planet 24, which makes the programme, takes great care to ensure that the children are not portrayed as being "on sale", while realising that media publicity to find adoptive parents for 10,000 children is crucial. The first series prompted 25,000 requests and up to half of the children featured were either placed or in the process of finding a family.

But, as Splat shows, placing a child is often only the first step in healing deep-rooted feelings of rejection and isolation.

Snippets of Splat's comment book are testament to the enthusiasm for the group. One adoptive mother of a 13-year-old boy says he is "the kind of child who's hard to get involved" and, consequently, she is always on the look-out for ways to help him mix. The boy does not find it easy to make and keep friends. His early life was full of disruption. He is not very successful at school. "But he's creating things. He's very excited about that. It's a place where he can go and be himself - where he's the same as everyone else."

After Adoption is on 0161-839 4932. A Family of My Own is showing daily at 2.55pm on BBC1 until Friday

webTitle: Community groups praised for insight into local needs

fields.headline: Solid foundations
fields.standfirst: Community groups praised for insight into local needs
fields.trailText: Community groups praised for insight into local needs
fields.body:
Jack was an isolated 15-year-old, bullied at school and no longer living with his parents. Since linking up with a young people's project, however, his life has been transformed. Recently, he was even nominated for a civic award for his volunteering work.

Jack's case is among those highlighted in a report to be published today on the potential role of community foundations in tackling rural poverty and social exclusion. The project, working specifically with marginalised young people, is one of 70 funded by Wiltshire's foundation as part of its anti-poverty programme.

Also featured in the report is Sandra, a young mother who had endured many years in an abusive marriage. She found support and strength through a women's centre also funded by the foundation. "This organisation saved my life," she says in the report. "If I had not discovered this group, my husband would have killed me."

There are now some 30 community foundations in the UK, holding among them about £100m in endowments. The report on Wiltshire, Changing the Future, will be launched later today at the opening in Bristol of the biennial conference of the Community Foundation Network, which represents the fast developing movement.

Anna Marsden, the foundation's director, is quoted as saying: "If you asked me the one cause that we . . . should support, I would say transport, because you can support most disadvantaged groups at some time or another through the provision of transport."

"The local aspect of a community foundation, and its closeness, can also lead to a less complex yet well informed grant-making process."

webTitle: Could credit ratings help councils secure private investment?

fields.headline: Points mean prizes
fields.standfirst: Could credit ratings help councils secure private investment? Kensington and Chelsea certainly thinks so. Chris Wheal reports
fields.trailText: Could credit ratings help councils secure private investment? Kensington and Chelsea certainly thinks so. Chris Wheal reports
fields.body:
Only those at the top of the class get straight As - the top credit rating - and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has achieved this. The west London council has been put in the premier category "AAA stable" by rating agency Standard & Poor's (S&P).

Many of the big banks and other financial institutions cannot muster a triple-A, so it sounds impressive. But surely all local authorities work under the same regime, and cannot go bust. Why do they need individual credit ratings?

That was the argument councils used in the past to justify their refusal to be credit rated. Kensington and Chelsea is only the second local authority - after Huntingdonshire - to announce a rating. But those in the business say the truth is these days very different.

Nick Preston, public finance director of S&P, says: "Local government is not all triple-A by any stretch of the imagination. If you look at metropolitan cities, if one turned out to be a triple-A credit you'd have to think: 'Why? This can't be right'."

In an indictment of the level of public funding for local services, Preston reckons that a metropolitan council which fully carried out its social responsibilities simply could not gain a top rating. Similarly, a housing association that achieved a triple-A would, he says, be just a "land bank", sitting on its assets and investing its cash. It could not be looking after the tenants properly.

"I think that would be very much the case for a metropolitan city," he argues. "With all the financial burdens and statutory responsibilities to carry out on infrastructure, housing, social services, it would be extremely unlikely that it would be triple-A."

But Preston still thinks it is worth a local authority such as Liverpool getting rated. "Arguably, if Liverpool did go for a rating, everyone would know it wasn't going to be triple-A, but it would be Liverpool saying: 'Hey, by the way, we're not nearly as bad as everybody thinks we are. Mark us, and watch where we're going. We've made ourselves transparent and you can see where we are.'

"That's going to attract the right sort of investment, both locating in the area and in terms of the people they are going to interact with in respect of private finance initiatives (PFI) or outsourcing projects or housing projects," he says.

The government recently announced plans to allow councils to bor row more from the private sector. This would depend on the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy coming up with some prudential indicators to help lenders decide on the merits of each council. But Preston reckons the City will prefer credit ratings.

"There are lots of funders who would love to do UK local authority leasing deals, but they won't because there are no rated entities," he says. "There is no doubt that the institutions, both corporate and financial, will understand, much more clearly, the local authority with a credit rating than the one without."

In the private sector, the stronger the credit rating, the cheaper the finance. And that's a significant factor behind Kensington and Chelsea's decision to get itself assessed.

Finance director Derek Reeve says: "I'm just hedging my bets if we want to borrow more money and we have to go back to the money markets. In the US and western Europe, they are used to dealing with municipalities that have credit ratings. The global markets will be much more interested to look at the credit rating now than they were 20 years ago. If we have one, particularly with the triple-A stable, it might shave our borrowing costs."

Reeve also endorses Preston's view that it will help with potential PFI deals (the authority is looking to build a new school). "With the PFI schemes, if we want to do some capital investment with the private sector, I think they will look more favourably at giving us a decent rate if they can look at our triple-A rating," he says. "That practically guarantees the revenue stream that they want to get from the scheme, so it will help with that too."

But Reeve insists that getting a credit rating is also in line with government policies. "In this current regime of 'best value', when we get government inspectors crawling all over us and looking for evidence of things we do well and provide best value, the credit rating is a very extensive and comprehensive assessment," he says. "It's about the best external accreditation I could get for my department."

It is in the money markets that the three As will make a real difference, however. "It's worth a lot more than a best value report," says Reeve. "Best value is a bit like chartermarks - nobody really knows what level of service that means - whereas with a triple-A rating, the private sector knows exactly what that means. In my dealings with the private sector, I'd much rather rely on a triple-A rating than I would on best value."

Reeve rejects criticism from detractors. "Some of my colleagues have asked: 'Why have you done this?' I don't think it's any more divisive than school league tables, social services reviews or performance indicators.

"And in any case, I'm looking to provide the most economic borrowing costs to the residents of the royal borough - that's my job."

webTitle: The pressure on local authorities to act as food cops

fields.headline: Poison chalice
fields.standfirst: The onus is on local authorities to act as food cops, but they can't afford major investigations. Will the government foot the bill? Or will public health pay the penalty?  Paul Humphries reports
fields.trailText: The onus is on local authorities to act as food cops, but they can't afford major investigations. Will the government foot the bill? Or will public health pay the penalty? Paul Humphries reports
fields.body:
The latest crisis in the farm-to-fork industry has brought added burdens for local authorities, with their environmental health and trading standards officers in the front line. These local government investigators - who have been on the trail first of BSE-infected meat, then of the sources of E.coli - now find themselves playing a key role in the battle against foot and mouth disease.

But some hard-pressed councils, tired of having to juggle budgets to meet the ever-growing demands on their food safety officers, are warning that the government must stump up more resources to protect public health - or pay the penalty.

It cost North Yorkshire county council £30,000 when it was pushed by the government to bring the first and only prosecution in England against a restaurant for serving beef on the bone in defiance of a ban. The case collapsed, and the council's request for help with legal costs was ignored by ministers.

What has since angered North Yorkshire is the government's decision to set up the food standards agency (FSA) with a £120m annual budget, equivalent to the entire cost of local government food enforcement. The authority argues that the new watchdog has caused extra work - with no additional funds to pay for it.

This year, the authority's trading standards department asked the council for an extra £220,000 but was given only £56,000 because of budget pressures. The council's director of business and consumer services, Gordon Gresty, says: "The answer is not to continually set up organisations to oversee our work, but to provide sufficient resources for frontline staff."

The FSA's request that local councils step up checks, to ensure that no imported beef sold should be from cattle under 30 months at the time of slaughter, illustrates the point.

"The FSA omitted to say how it expected local officers to check that a piece of beef came from an animal that was either under, or over, 30 months," says Gresty. "Enforcement officers will tell you there is no way of checking. When this was drawn to the attention of the FSA, they said 'Check the paperwork', but foreign paperwork doesn't state the age of cattle. I support the agency and its values, but if it demands of our officers extra work then there must be extra resources."

It took a four-year investigation by Rotherham council staff to reveal a nationwide racket, passing off condemned meat as fit for human consumption. Environmental health officers, working with police, discovered that at least 1,500 tonnes of condemned chicken and turkey had been laundered into the commercial food chain and served to schoolchildren and the elderly in residential homes. The unfit poultry meat, designated as pet food, had also been sold in restaurants and takeaways, and had found its way into supermarkets. It produced an estimated profit of £2.5m for the syndicate behind the scam.

The gang was stopped only by the dedication of three young environmental health officers who had instigated the investigation, conducted partly in their own free time. Another 50 council clerical staff worked shifts and weekends to photocopy, reference and catalogue about 500,000 documents seized in the investigation.

When five defendants were jailed at Hull crown court in December last year, Judge Peter Heppel commended the Rotherham environmental health officers, and the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health (CIEH) praised them for their "commitment and professionalism". South Yorkshire police, which had brought its expertise to the investigation one year after it had begun, said that the local authority had "done a marvellous job in collating documents and exhibits".

Praise indeed - but fine words pay no bills. Rotherham council found itself left with a debt of £500,000 for the four-year investigation. That has had to be paid from the council's own coffers, and other services in Rotherham have suffered as money is shuffled from other budgets to balance the books.

This, says environmental health officer Lewis Coates, who headed the Rotherham investigation, could prevent the authority from ever again starting such a mammoth project. He says: "I don't think we could contemplate such a large size inquiry without funding from a central point. The onus is on local authorities to act as food police but they must be promised the resources to undertake major investigations."

Sue Ellis, the councillor heading environmental services in Rotherham council's cabinet, says: "The authority has received no financial assistance whatsoever, even though this was a national investigation with implications for public health at a national level. We need to know what, exactly, is the role of the FSA, and whether it should have offered financial assistance."

One investigation that the FSA has helped to finance involves Amber Valley district council, Derbyshire. Last month, a joint operation led by council staff, the FSA and Derbyshire police moved to crack another alleged condemned meat fraud, with warrants served in five counties. It was the climax of a four-month probe involving 100 police, as well as some 50 local authority environmental health officers and meat hygiene service staff.

The FSA has paid for one member of Amber Valley's staff to be seconded to the investigation. The council is still funding other members of the team. Sue Sonnex, Amber Valley's director of environmental health, has welcomed the FSA's help so far but says she wants the position reviewed as the investigation progresses.

A spokesman for the FSA says it is aware of claims that some local authorities may be finding it difficult to fulfil all their responsibilities as food authorities. "Although," he adds, "it has to be said that the agency has introduced very few such new obligations. We are undertaking an audit programme at the moment, under an agreement we have with local authorities, that should identify any resourcing difficulties, in which case further resources could be made available."

Braintree district council, in Essex, is one of the authorities which have just been audited by the FSA. A recently noticed increase in the problem of "smokies" could mean an even bigger burden for its food safety officers. Smokies are sheep and goats burned with a blowtorch while still fully skinned. Banned in this country because of the danger to health, the animals' meat is a delicacy in some part of Africa. Illegal slaughterhouses and processing plants are on the increase to meet the growing demand from some communities in the London area.

Peter Tattersley, head of environmental services at the council, has just seen his officers complete an operation with the local police and the RSPCA, leading to the successful prosecution of two men for producing smokies. He knows this could be one area which, in the future, could mean an increase in work and a further drain on resources.

"We have had to move resources in the department from other activities and these areas have suffered," Tattersley says. "We have had to train up people from other jobs to help us out in the food section. We have not had a 100% inspection rate, but we did well in the audit. I think they understand the problems."

Whether or not the FSA does understand the problems, it has made no extra resources available. As its spokesman says: "Local authorities allocate resources to services on the basis of local service demands and this does sometimes 'squeeze' regulatory services, but these are often issues that need to be resolved at a local level."

Rotherham's Labour MP, Denis MacShane, does not agree. He has been pressing ministers to cover Rotherham's debt, and says: "Rotherham delivered a national service and as such should be recompensed by the government."

North Yorkshire's head of trading standards, Stuart Pudney, puts it bluntly: "Some requirements of the food standards agency are impossible to meet within the resources available. We are doing the best we can, but we are settling for less than the standards they are setting. In some cases we are letting down the public.

"It is not good for morale when we have no chance of hitting the minimum targets."

webTitle: End of the line for family policy centre

fields.headline: Closed shop
fields.standfirst: End of the line for family policy centre
fields.trailText: End of the line for family policy centre
fields.body:
Social policy research has suffered a heavy blow with the collapse of the Family Policy Studies Centre (FPSC), the independent unit which has done much to inform and moderate debate on the family over the past two decades.

In the face of severe financial problems, the centre's governing council has decided to put the organisation into voluntary liquidation. Talks are under way about transferring some work and staff to the Policy Studies Institute (PSI), as a stand-alone family policy group.

The FPSC, a registered charity, is blaming its demise on lack of funding. In a letter to supporters, director Ceridwen Roberts says: "There is a lack of financial support for this kind of work in Britain, and the unresolved problem of core funding for small voluntary organisations has also contributed to the centre's financial difficulties."

The centre was set up in 1983 by Sir Campbell Adamson, the former director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, who died last year; its director until 1992 was Malcolm Wicks, now government minister for lifelong learning. Its work has been prominent in controversies over lone parents, working mothers and teenage pregnancy.

In her letter, Roberts claims the centre has occupied a "pivotal" place in family debate. "We have worked extensively with government as well as practitioners working with families in the statutory and voluntary sectors. A unique and much valued aspect of our role has been the bridge we offer between the academic research community and the policy and practice worlds, which increasingly draw on research evidence to inform their activities."

The centre's council believes strongly that there is a continuing need for such work, Roberts says. "And this underlies our decision to move to the PSI, an independent charity with the same purposes as ourselves, which is looking to strengthen both its family policy capacity and its dissemination work."

Speculation will inevitably link the centre's closure with the creation two years ago of the government-inspired National Family and Parenting Institute. At the time, some thought the centre should be developed into such a body. But Mary Macleod, the institute's chief executive, insists the two bodies were co-existing comfortably.

"From our point of view, from the beginning we have had a different, much broader remit than theirs," says Macleod. "But there were areas of overlap, obviously, and we have been very careful about those - just as we have been with Parentline, the Parenting Forum and other groups.

"That's not unusual in the voluntary sector, to have to try to keep your feet off each other's turf. We were working with them quite well, we thought. I feel very sorry about the closure of the FPSC because it did have a really good history."

The institute was in fact funding an FPSC research project, mapping family policy work being done in universities and by voluntary groups across the country with the aim of setting up a database. The project will now be taken back by the institute, with a view to its completion elsewhere.

The institute has also agreed to take on another two of the centre's pieces of work: a regular policy digest, aimed at practitioners in family work; and a scheme designed to produce research resources and texts for those in the field.

"But there were areas of overlap, obviously, and we have been very careful about those - just as we have been with Parentline, the Parenting Forum and other groups. "That's not unusual in the voluntary sector, to have to try to keep your feet off each other's turf. We were working with them quite well, we thought. I feel very sorry about the closure of the FPSC because it did have a really good history." The institute was in fact funding an FPSC research project, mapping family policy work being done in universities and by voluntary groups across the country with the aim of setting up a database. The project will now be taken back by the institute, with a view to its completion elsewhere. The institute has also agreed to take on another two of the centre's pieces of work: a regular policy digest, aimed at practitioners in family work; and a scheme designed to produce research resources and texts for those in the field.

webTitle: Community fund's new leader signals a change of heart

fields.headline: Core costs lottery call
fields.standfirst: Community fund's new leader signals a change of heart
fields.trailText: Community fund's new leader signals a change of heart
fields.body:
National lottery money should be used to pay for voluntary groups' core costs as well as for new projects, according to the incoming England director of the community fund - formerly the lottery charities board.

The assertion by Richard Gutch will be seen as a clear signal that the community fund is to change its policy on an issue identified repeatedly as one of the most pressing for voluntary organisations. The Family Policy Studies Centre this week is citing lack of help with core costs as a reason for its decision to go into voluntary liquidation.

Gutch, who takes a up his new post next week, says: "I hope we will move towards a more flexible approach towards core costs where we think: 'What is the best way to achieve the outcomes that we all want?' If this is going to mean funding core costs for some applicants, then we should."

If the community fund does move away from meeting the costs only of new projects, the change will come in its new strategic plan due to be submitted to parliament next March. Gutch, who is leaving the charity Arthritis Care, where he has been chief executive for nine years, is already sounding out key figures in the voluntary sector on what they would like the fund to do.

Of 40 charity leaders he has written to, 15 have so far responded. Eleven have specified core costs as a priority issue and nine have said the fund should be more flexible on length of grant funding, breaking the ubiquitous three-year mould.

Gutch would also like to see the fund doing more to help with volun tary organisations' infrastructure, assisting perhaps with trustee training and development. He says: "There is general agreement from everybody I have spoken to that the community fund needs to have a more focused approach with clear strategic priorities, much more emphasis on outcomes, so that you can actually see that this is the kind of effect we are going to try to make in these priority areas. Then, five years on, you can look back and try to demonstrate exactly what difference has been made."

At 54, Gutch sees his move to the community fund as "one last challenge". It also represents a return to a more general role: before joining Arthritis Care, he was assistant director of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations.

He leaves a charity that has been transformed from an archetypal centralised and paternalistic organisation into something of a model of new practice. User involvement has been introduced at all levels, with key posts now reserved for people with arthritis; the governance structure has been modernised, with a board of 50 trustees pruned to 18 and new regional tiers put in place; and the charity has pioneered self-management techniques for those living with arthritis - techniques now being used by the Department of Health as a basis for its "expert patient" programme.

Last year, in an initiative to raise awareness of arthritis, the charity took a roadshow on a national tour of 43 locations. Gutch reflects: "I think it has been possible for what was a traditional charity - over 50 years old - to move from being an organisation for people with arthritis to being one of people with arthritis."

With an earlier background in local government, focusing on community development, Gutch is enthusiastic about the potential of the community fund's £180m grants budget for England. But he recognises it will take time to achieve his goals, particularly on funding core costs. As a first step, he believes all grant applicants should be required to spell out the management, administrative, support and training overheads of any project.

"There is a lot of work that has to go into developing this approach, I would the first to admit that," Gutch says. "One challenge is to develop clear criteria as to under what circumstances do you fund core costs. But the starting point has got to be that any project has got to recognise its core costs."

webTitle: National lottery funding makes healthy living a priority

fields.headline: Peak practice
fields.standfirst: National lottery funding makes healthy living a priority
fields.trailText: National lottery funding makes healthy living a priority
fields.body:
The Peak District, famous for its spectacular Derbyshire scenery but less well-known for its rural deprivation, will tomorrow receive £1m national lottery funding to develop one of the planned network of "healthy living centres".

The award will be one of six, totalling £5.2m, made by the new opportunities fund (NOF) - the lottery grant distributor which works to a framework set by government. In all, £300m is earmarked for healthy living centres, of which 45 have been approved so far at a total cost of £35m.

The first project to win approval, St Augustine's in King's Lynn, Norfolk, is due to be opened on Friday. It will mean that a locality with one of the worst health records in the county will, for the first time, have its own GP and primary healthcare services.

Based in the Hope Valley, the Peak District project aims to bring to local towns and villages a range of activities, including advice and exercise sessions, youth services and a peak walks programme. Exercise will be provided "on prescription" by GPs, who will refer patients to physiotherapists for swimming and gym workouts.

Julie Hirst, of the Peak District Rural Deprivation Forum, says the announcement is timely. "Fears about the mental health of farmers have been heightened by the problems caused by the foot and mouth outbreak. There are also high levels of stress and depression in this community, which often go untreated due to cultural taboos. This funding will enable us to offer fully integrated support and advice where it's most needed."

Stephen Dunmore, NOF's chief executive, says: "Building on the track record of the partners [behind the scheme], I am sure this project will soon demonstrate a tangible impact on the health and well-being of the whole community."

Other awards to be made tomorrow are £1m for a healthy living centre in Croydon, south London; another £1m for a project in Wigan and Leigh, Greater Manchester; £1.2m for a scheme in Derry, Northern Ireland, aimed at improving the health of children and their families; £700,000 for a project in Bangor, Gwynedd; and £300,000 for a scheme to meet the health needs of homeless people in Hammersmith and Fulham, west London.

The King's Lynn centre is to be opened by the Bishop of Norwich, the Rt Rev Graham James. The project manager, Lin Twell, says: "The provision of a locally-based GP and primary healthcare service has taken us many years of hard work to achieve - so it is with a sigh of relief that we can finally say that we have finished the job we set out to do."

St Augustine's will be more than a GP surgery, however. It will also accommodate a fully equipped childcare centre, a community cafe, a learning centre, a large arts studio, a range of advice agencies, and allotments where people can learn to grow fruit and vegetables.

webTitle: New course offers good news for doctors who have to break bad news

fields.headline: Hearing the worst
fields.standfirst: Adam James on a new course that offers good news for doctors who have to break bad news
fields.trailText: Adam James on a new course that offers good news for doctors who have to break bad news
fields.body:
When my consultant told me that I had leukaemia, she had a hint of a smile on her face. It was not, of course, a smile of glee. Instead, it was one of understated warmth. It conveyed a sense of compassion and hope. Her smile was saying to me: "Sorry this is bad news. But don't worry - all is not lost."

The subtle messages signalled by my doctor's non-verbal behaviour are firmly lodged in my memory - as they are for many patients or relatives given shocking or bad news. But ask clinicians about the first time they told a patient he or she had cancer, a man that his wife was brain damaged from an accident or a new mother that her child was diagnosed with Down's syndrome, and the memory might be hazy.

And not unreasonably; after all it is part of the job to regularly break bad news. Yet formal training for doctors and nurses on how to disclose distressing news to patients or relatives is markedly inconspicuous. In fact, it is often a lowly"special request" or appendage on clinical undergraduate and postgraduate training.

While most professionals develop their own appropriate techniques for breaking such news, they can be inadequate. Some methods, as patients have pointed out time and time again, are horrendously crass. Studies in the child disability field reveal that about 50% of parents are dissatisfied with the way news of their son's or daughter's disability was given to them.

This can have detrimental consequences for parents' subsequent relationships not only with medical professionals but with their own child. "If news of a disability is portrayed negatively by a doctor, it can affect the bonding of parents to their child and particularly their view of disability later in life," says Robina Shah, a clinical psychologist working at St Mary's hospital, Manchester.

In its own effort to address these training inadequacies St Mary's has offered, over the last three years, a "sharing the news" workshop to clinicians and nurses. The participatory workshop, developed by Shah, aims to refine professionals' communication skills when delivering distressing news.

By focusing on the patients' perspective, it allows professionals - perhaps for the first time in their career - to devote a whole day to reflection on the details of how they break unpleasant news.

In what room should they meet patients and relatives? Should they sit or stand? How much or how little should be imparted? How much medical jargon should be used? What is the best tone of voice to use?

General rules about good eye contact, sensitivity and honesty are paramount - as is checking that pagers are switched off and that correct names are used. And even though consultation time is limited, doctors are encouraged to allow patients or relatives the feeling that they have their unwavering attention.

Shah says: "The training offers professionals the time and space to ask themselves the question: 'Can I do this better?' It offers them the opportunity to share models of good practice."

The Royal College of Physicians, which has accredited Shah's course, recognises there is a lack of adequate training in communication skills and urges that training be made "high priority" in formal medical education.

All the more reason, one might expect, for professionals to welcome the opportunity to sign up to such courses. Some doctors, nevertheless, remain sceptical of being formally taught how to communicate. They insist that "hands-on" experience remains by far the most effective source of learning.

Charles Essex, consultant neurodevelopmental paediatrician at the Gulson clinic, Coventry, is convinced that being in the same room as a senior colleague, and watching as they disclose distressing news, is the key to self-improvement.

"I would not have learnt how to break news if I had not been with my senior colleagues and seen them do it," he says. "It is like training to be an astronaut - you cannot do it until you have been with other astronauts. And it is during peer reviews that you learn what works for other consul tants, and how one particular way of saying something is perhaps better than another. Reflecting on what you do and say is quite right; but this is something I do the whole time."

Essex, who regularly has to tell parents of their child's disability, or even that the child may not survive long, accepts "there is a place" for courses such as Shah's. But he says he "probably would not go on one".

Aware that this hardened attitude risks others dubbing him as old fashioned, Essex adds that it is a question of crude reality: bad news is bad news and cannot be dressed as anything else. "I often give parents their worst nightmares, and no one will ever say: 'Thank you doctor.' If I say to parents that their child is going to die, or has autism, they should be angry or sad - if not, I have to question whether they have really heard what I said."

It is such understandably distressing reactions by parents, Essex argues, that help explain statistics supposedly showing that relatives are dissatisfied with how bad news is broken to them.

Nevertheless, other professionals who have attended Shah's workshop believe her approach does have place on the learning curve - particularly because peers cannot always be relied upon to give adequate guidance. Ian Dady, a consultant neonatal paediatrician, says: "It is difficult for one doctor to advise or correct colleagues. There is an awful lot to remember when disclosing bad news and it can be beneficial to refine your skills."

In addition, Shah explains, not all doctors have had exemplary peer role models to follow. "They might never have had the opportunity to unlearn inappropriate things they picked up," she says.

With the government emphasising clinical governance and lifelong learning, demands to improve professionals' communication skills are likely to come from the top.

"There will always be doctors who deliver news badly, and patients' complaints will reveal this," says Shah. "This will always be something we have to work on. Formal training will always be a good complement to other forms of learning."

How to deliver a bitter pill

 Sit down on the same level as the patient or relative - it is courteous and reassuring.

 Note questions or topics avoided.

 Respect the patient's right to "denial". They will often "selectively perceive" information they can cope with.

 Realise that most patients become aware of their situation gradually, rather than during one meeting.

 Appreciate that patients can, and do, cope positively with truth about illness.

 End a meeting where bad news has been imparted by arranging to meet again.

 Tell staff what has been said. They might be involved in future discussions.

webTitle: The advantages and problems of adapting business practice for non-profit organisations

fields.headline: Cash of cultures
fields.standfirst: The voluntary sector involves big money. As its key annual event takes place this week,  Roger Cowe  looks at the advantages and problems of adapting business practice for non-profit organisations
fields.trailText: The voluntary sector involves big money. As its key annual event takes place this week, Roger Cowe looks at the advantages and problems of adapting business practice for non-profit organisations
fields.body:
Charityfair, the key annual event for the voluntary sector, this week celebrates its 10th anniversary with more than 180 events for people working and volunteering in the voluntary sector - or thinking of doing so. The sector is big business these days, so much so that the world's leading management consultants want a piece of the action.

Both McKinsey and Bain - US-based global consultancies which are leaders in giving strategy advice to multinationals - have recently moved to address what they like to call the non-profit sector.

McKinsey has set up a team to serve non-profit customers - though they'll still be charged fees. Bain has established a separate but associated firm in the US, called Bridgespan, and wants this to be a model for other "professional service" firms to follow around the world.

These organisations believe they can help charities be more effective by applying the traditional analytical and strategic techniques which help the world's leading businesses decide how best to make money.

But they have discovered it is not as simple as that. The companies they work for are relatively simple. Multinationals such as Unilever, Shell or IBM may be huge, with a global network of offices and relationships. And their activities embrace many products, processes and markets. But their overriding objective is simple - making money.

Power structures in business are also relatively straightforward, even if it doesn't seem like that to somebody stuck in the middle of a corporate hierarchy. Essentially, however, the chief executive reports to a board which is normally quite remote and uninvolved. And however many staff there are, they all owe at least theoretical allegiance only to the company; that is, the boss.

Tom Tierney, the former global chairman of Bain who left to set up Bridgespan, characterises consultancy work for such firms like this: "The corporate chief executive has an enormous amount of power. As consultants, we come up with a dazzling and insightful programme. All the chief executive has to do is implement it and everybody applauds - he or she is a hero."

He contrasts that set-up with the non-profit sector: a much more influential board, as well as donors who a chief executive cannot afford to neglect; plus volunteers who will not automatically jump to attention just because their chief executive says so.

Tierney also points out the difficulty of measuring progress where there is not the single simple goal of showing a profit.

"In business the bottom line is clear, but in some mission-driven organisations it is not always clear what the final outcome is. The complexity of running even a small charity is quite a bit more challenging than running most businesses," he says.

Bridgespan managing partner, Jeff Bradach, has studied the voluntary sector at Harvard university. He acknowledges the challenge for his firm, used to working with complex business problems but where the parameters are clear and there is usually ample data.

He cites a housing charity, Habitat for Humanity, a past winner of a Guardian charity award for its work in Belfast, which has an approach to construction that he says would appal business managers if they did not appreciate that means are as important as ends for the organisation.

"The problems are really quite distinctive. It is easy to see how you could get into trouble by simply applying business methods to non-profit organisations," Bradach says.

Reflecting on the firm's first year in the field, he says he's impressed by the level of skills evident in the first batch of non-profit clients: "All of us have come away impressed by how much people in these organisations get done with so little resources. The entrepreneurialism and resourcefulness is truly remarkable. We stand in awe, frankly." These are not only the conclusions of US consultants, although the American appetite for management consultants and gurus does mean their ideas are being widely disseminated there.

For example, business management expert Peter Drucker has set up a "Foundation for non-profit management". Its vision is to "bring the best leadership and management voices, with a focus on providing social sector organisations with the ideas and tools that enable them to better serve their customers and communities."

That sounds a bit like teaching charities what management is all about, but Drucker knows more about management than most and is not as naïve as that. He says: "The 21st century will be the century of the social sector organisation. The leadership, competence and management of the social sector non-profit organisation will largely determine the values, the vision, the cohesion and the performance of society."

The message is that businesses have as much to learn from voluntary sector managers as vice versa; a message which is just as applicable in the UK, according to Stephen Bubb, chief executive of the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations (Acevo).

He cautions against the caricature contrast of big bad business and terribly nice charities. "There's a mindset that thinks of charity as sweet and nice. It's a shock for some when they find there are lots of first-rate professional staff who could have been very successful in the private sector."

While acknowledging that there are differences, Bubb argues that each can learn from the other. For example, he suggests charity managers are not always good at getting to grips with restructuring and other tough challenges which might involve redundancies and other difficult personnel issues.

On the other hand, businesses are often struggling to come to terms with the fact that old-fashioned command and control does not normally yield brilliant results even in the commercial world.

"People often think in terms of what the private sector can bring to charities. But there is a hell of a lot of good leadership practice in the voluntary sector which businesses want to learn about. They want to learn about motivation and inspiration - the softer skills that commercial people are often bloody poor at."

Voluntary sector managers often have to lead volunteers. "They don't have contracts of employment. You have to use a lot of skills which commercial leaders would be better for having."

That is just one instance of the complexity of life in the not-for-profit sector, which the commercial world wants to influence as well as learn from. And of course there is a lot less money around.

That doesn't stop executives abandoning the financial rewards of corporate life in search of a more fulfilling role in the voluntary sector. David Earnshaw, a former lobbyist with the drug company SmithKline (now GlaxoSmithKline) who has turned gamekeeper as head of Oxfam's campaign in Europe to sell Aids drugs at affordable prices in Africa is the latest example of this.

Many like him have suffered culture shock after such a transfer. Elaine Smethurst of the training organisation Working for Charity, who yesterday presented a Charityfair workshop on transferring skills to the voluntary sector, says some business people have no understanding of the cultural differences. "Bulls in china shops spring to mind," she says.

But her experience is that size matters more than the type of organisation. Managers with big company experience struggle with the varied demands of smaller organisations, whether businesses or charities.

On the other hand, middle managers from medium-sized businesses are just as likely to succeed as civil servants. And they will know how to deal with the management consultants when they come calling.

For full coverage of Charityfair 2001 see www.societytheguardian.com/voluntary
