fields.bodyText: Charityfair, the key annual event for the voluntary sector, this week celebrates its 10th anniversary with more than 180 events for people working and volunteering in the voluntary sector - or thinking of doing so. The sector is big business these days, so much so that the world's leading management consultants want a piece of the action. Both McKinsey and Bain - US-based global consultancies which are leaders in giving strategy advice to multinationals - have recently moved to address what they like to call the non-profit sector. McKinsey has set up a team to serve non-profit customers - though they'll still be charged fees. Bain has established a separate but associated firm in the US, called Bridgespan, and wants this to be a model for other "professional service" firms to follow around the world. These organisations believe they can help charities be more effective by applying the traditional analytical and strategic techniques which help the world's leading businesses decide how best to make money. But they have discovered it is not as simple as that. The companies they work for are relatively simple. Multinationals such as Unilever, Shell or IBM may be huge, with a global network of offices and relationships. And their activities embrace many products, processes and markets. But their overriding objective is simple - making money. Power structures in business are also relatively straightforward, even if it doesn't seem like that to somebody stuck in the middle of a corporate hierarchy. Essentially, however, the chief executive reports to a board which is normally quite remote and uninvolved. And however many staff there are, they all owe at least theoretical allegiance only to the company; that is, the boss. Tom Tierney, the former global chairman of Bain who left to set up Bridgespan, characterises consultancy work for such firms like this: "The corporate chief executive has an enormous amount of power. As consultants, we come up with a dazzling and insightful programme. All the chief executive has to do is implement it and everybody applauds - he or she is a hero." He contrasts that set-up with the non-profit sector: a much more influential board, as well as donors who a chief executive cannot afford to neglect; plus volunteers who will not automatically jump to attention just because their chief executive says so. Tierney also points out the difficulty of measuring progress where there is not the single simple goal of showing a profit. "In business the bottom line is clear, but in some mission-driven organisations it is not always clear what the final outcome is. The complexity of running even a small charity is quite a bit more challenging than running most businesses," he says. Bridgespan managing partner, Jeff Bradach, has studied the voluntary sector at Harvard university. He acknowledges the challenge for his firm, used to working with complex business problems but where the parameters are clear and there is usually ample data. He cites a housing charity, Habitat for Humanity, a past winner of a Guardian charity award for its work in Belfast, which has an approach to construction that he says would appal business managers if they did not appreciate that means are as important as ends for the organisation. "The problems are really quite distinctive. It is easy to see how you could get into trouble by simply applying business methods to non-profit organisations," Bradach says. Reflecting on the firm's first year in the field, he says he's impressed by the level of skills evident in the first batch of non-profit clients: "All of us have come away impressed by how much people in these organisations get done with so little resources. The entrepreneurialism and resourcefulness is truly remarkable. We stand in awe, frankly." These are not only the conclusions of US consultants, although the American appetite for management consultants and gurus does mean their ideas are being widely disseminated there. For example, business management expert Peter Drucker has set up a "Foundation for non-profit management". Its vision is to "bring the best leadership and management voices, with a focus on providing social sector organisations with the ideas and tools that enable them to better serve their customers and communities." That sounds a bit like teaching charities what management is all about, but Drucker knows more about management than most and is not as naïve as that. He says: "The 21st century will be the century of the social sector organisation. The leadership, competence and management of the social sector non-profit organisation will largely determine the values, the vision, the cohesion and the performance of society." The message is that businesses have as much to learn from voluntary sector managers as vice versa; a message which is just as applicable in the UK, according to Stephen Bubb, chief executive of the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations (Acevo). He cautions against the caricature contrast of big bad business and terribly nice charities. "There's a mindset that thinks of charity as sweet and nice. It's a shock for some when they find there are lots of first-rate professional staff who could have been very successful in the private sector." While acknowledging that there are differences, Bubb argues that each can learn from the other. For example, he suggests charity managers are not always good at getting to grips with restructuring and other tough challenges which might involve redundancies and other difficult personnel issues. On the other hand, businesses are often struggling to come to terms with the fact that old-fashioned command and control does not normally yield brilliant results even in the commercial world. "People often think in terms of what the private sector can bring to charities. But there is a hell of a lot of good leadership practice in the voluntary sector which businesses want to learn about. They want to learn about motivation and inspiration - the softer skills that commercial people are often bloody poor at." Voluntary sector managers often have to lead volunteers. "They don't have contracts of employment. You have to use a lot of skills which commercial leaders would be better for having." That is just one instance of the complexity of life in the not-for-profit sector, which the commercial world wants to influence as well as learn from. And of course there is a lot less money around. That doesn't stop executives abandoning the financial rewards of corporate life in search of a more fulfilling role in the voluntary sector. David Earnshaw, a former lobbyist with the drug company SmithKline (now GlaxoSmithKline) who has turned gamekeeper as head of Oxfam's campaign in Europe to sell Aids drugs at affordable prices in Africa is the latest example of this. Many like him have suffered culture shock after such a transfer. Elaine Smethurst of the training organisation Working for Charity, who yesterday presented a Charityfair workshop on transferring skills to the voluntary sector, says some business people have no understanding of the cultural differences. "Bulls in china shops spring to mind," she says. But her experience is that size matters more than the type of organisation. Managers with big company experience struggle with the varied demands of smaller organisations, whether businesses or charities. On the other hand, middle managers from medium-sized businesses are just as likely to succeed as civil servants. And they will know how to deal with the management consultants when they come calling. fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: society letters
fields.body:
Vulnerable argument

So the voluntary sector should "learn the lesson that efficiency and innovation can co-exist" (Shut or bust, April 18). You haven't convinced me.

You cite three examples of failing services, but why are they failing? Because the health authority didn't refer enough people; because the health authority and the voluntary organisation had different ideas about treatment models; and because the council only wanted to pay for limited staffing for a project working with very vulnerable people. In this last case, the project had remained open, but only because it "no longer takes people with such challenging behaviour". Who does?

What are the common themes? Inefficiency on the part of the voluntary organisation? Or is it the statutory sector's refusal to face up to the real costs of working with the most vulnerable people?

There are two critical differences between the voluntary and business sectors. The first is that the voluntary sector operates within a highly manipulated market. The funder and the user are not the same people. Secondly, voluntary organisations come into existence because of individuals' profound passion and commitment to righting social injustice. The skills of leading and managing passion and commitment are not always to be found in the business sector. The business sector has at least as much to learn from the voluntary sector as we do from them.

Christina Schwabenland
Chief executive, Elfrida Society

 I am not convinced that many charities only pay lip service to market forces. If they did, they simply wouldn't be around any more.

My belief is that most charities became sensitive to market forces many years ago and have invested a great deal of time and effort in ensuring they provide well-targeted services in areas of real need.

The big issue the article does raise, though, is the frequent underfunding of voluntary sector work. Why do some statutory sector commissioners appear to think the voluntary sector deserves to be paid less for providing good quality services? In theory, "best value" mechanisms should ensure a level playing field. But not all comparisons made by local authorities are like-for-like, nor are they transparent. We had a specialist mental health community support service compared with a generic in-house home care service. Not surprisingly, we were told we were too expensive.

The danger is that charities, in their desire to win statutory bodies' funding, will be tempted to accept underfunded contracts, subsidise them, and hope for the best. This cannot be good for users of services and it isn't going to do the charity much good in the medium to long term either.

Gil Hitchon
Chief executive, Maca (Mental After Care Association)

Showing we care

You quoted me in your interesting and timely article about mental health problems and friendship (Stigma ties, April 18), but did not say everything.

Sufferers themselves, let alone family and friends, want more information and more time with their doctors, but there are serious shortages of psychiatrists, nurses and other professionals. For example, 14% of consultant posts are vacant.

Public education is part of the job, but it is seldom possible for us to give priority to schools, health interest groups, carers' meetings and so on. Real support for this difficult, yet frequently rewarding, work is required. Care in the community can work, but the community does have to show that it cares.

Dr Larry Culliford
Consultant psychiatrist, Brighton

Rough and ready

Your article about the homeless of Tower Hamlets (Posh and shove, April 18) implies that hordes of street- and squat-homeless people are languishing, ignored, while the area busily yuppifies itself.

The locality does have major challenges of homelessness, housing shortage, overcrowding and poverty, but it is not true that there are known to be 1,130 people on the streets or in squats. While the rough sleepers' unit's official count of street homeless (one!) is not accurate, nor is the extreme figure in the article. There are, however, about that number of people living in hostels in the borough, many of which have been refurbished and re-provided in recent years through the co-ordinated efforts of the lively local voluntary and statutory sectors dealing with homelessness.

The change of use of great, gothic, unwieldy Tower House from homelessness to private accommodation - to the financial benefit of the local authority - might not be a great loss to social housing. The housing economics of London are a mess and this redevelopment is symbolically captivating. But if readers want to know about homelessness in Tower Hamlets, they should know about the long- standing co-ordination among health, social services, housing and the homelessness voluntary sectors that pre-dated the rough sleepers unit initiatives - and will survive it.

Ruth Allen
Manager, HHELP Team, Mental Health and Social Care for Single Homeless People in Tower Hamlets and the City

Work it out

Malcolm Dean (April 18) states that, according to a Cabinet Office report last year, a third of people between 50 and state pension age did not have a job - almost 3m -yet only 150,000 said that they did not need to work. It therefore appears that there were 2.85m folk in that age group who were involuntarily unemployed.

Am I alone in finding those figures hard to reconcile with the recent report that unemployment had dropped below the "symbolic" 1m mark?

Bob Heys
Halifax

webTitle: Manchester centre brings together eco-protesters, local people and councillors

fields.headline: Space of waste
fields.standfirst: Imagine a centre that brings together eco-protesters, local people and councillors - and which is fun too.  Hilary Wainwright  reports
fields.trailText: Imagine a centre that brings together eco-protesters, local people and councillors - and which is fun too. Hilary Wainwright reports
fields.body:
The stubborn idealism of four green and egalitarian protesters turned constructors, is transforming a site of Britain's industrial revolution into the birthplace of a revolution to overcome the destruction that early dynamism brought in its wake.

An old cotton mill on the banks of the Ashton canal, en route from Manchester city centre to Beswick, where the 2001 Commonwealth Games will take place, has been reclaimed. Not by yuppie property developers, but by the Manchester Environmental Resource Centre Initiative (Merci), whose intention is "to create a focus and a tool for a sustainable and equitable model of regeneration".

In 1997, after several years of activism against roads, airports and GM foods, Cath Miller, Jane Pickering, Chris Walsh and Helen Woodcock decided protesting wasn't enough. "Boundaries are being pushed by direct action groups like Earth First and Greenpeace, but the vacuum between the sparse ungreen reality of everyday life and the ideas of the most advanced green thinkers is being filled by Shell oil and their solar panels. The 'alternatives' of these corporations do nothing to improve the quality of life for the most under-resourced communities," says Walsh.

In Merci's thinking, people and the environment, equity and sustainability are inseparably bound together - for them the importance of Bridge-5 Mill's location is its closeness to two communities - the Cardroom and the Ridgeway estates - and its history as the old Ancoats Lads Club.

The idea of an environmental resource centre which would bring together eco-protesters, local people, and even some suits from Manchester council, came out of talking to like-minded campaigns which wanted premises that were more than an office, but had no time and energy to create them. Activists also wanted somewhere which would allow them to be integrated with local people. "We felt we weren't starting at home," says Pickering. "We were doing all these things on GM food and roads, it's all out there, but it's not reaching the people it needs to reach - local people."

Four years, many a knock-back and much pragmatic fundraising later (they began with £100 in the bank, this year they've had a turnover of £1m), Merci is a magical building, with a different buzz for everybody.

For local kids, it's a fun palace built from a load of old rubbish. "I come here every day now," says Michael Jenkins, "because I can play on computers and meet interesting people." People like Neil Corney from Omega, one of the 11 campaigning groups which have moved into the second floor, says: "It's a really enjoyable building to be in physically; people get to know each other, get to integrate with the local community and end up with lots of new ideas and new initiatives."

For visitors, even going to the toilet is an education: "Before coming to Merci, the most I did about the environment was take my bottles to Asda; now I know about collecting rainwater and using it to flush toilets, how to save energy and put to good use wasted materials," says Liam Ryan, from the Cardroom estate.

Education is an essential part of Merci, whether you're on the top floor absorbing the You are Here exhibition reflecting on what it would take to make Manchester a sustainable city, and exactly how much rain does fall each year, or admiring the work of Whole Space, the environmental interior design company responsible for the colourful, light atmosphere and for reusing the silver heating pipes as railings on the ramp down to the building's welcoming entrance.

The buzz reverberates outwards. Liam Ryan and Elaine Kilroy are on a steering group responsible for the regeneration of the half-derelict Cardroom estate. "We'll be taking ideas from here into the discussions, especially avoiding anything that could be toxic, and the emphasis on recycling old stuff," says Kilroy.

Another reverberation has touched the lives of 15 local young men. They did the bulk of the work fixing doors and windows from nearby demolished schools and hospitals, reusing timber brought by local builders who remembered boxing in the building when it was the Lads Club. Scooping up the leftovers from the Lowry gallery construction site, at first, Dean Centenara thought it "was completely mad; all my friends thought I'd turn into a hippy. I did stop shaving for three weeks." But now a year and a completed building on, still clean cut, Centenara says: "I've learnt to respect people with dreadlocks; my friends are really impressed that I can lay timber, put in a door and windows and weld window bars." (The bars he welded are works of art, designed by local children to convey underwater scenes - waves, starfish, and all the life they want to see in the canal).

The buzz has reached the imposing doors of the executive members' office in Manchester's town hall. Martin Pagel, deputy leader, drives the councils' policies on the environment. Merci has inspired him to get together a consortium of social enterprises concerned with waste: "We need a critical mass of voluntary projects and enterprises covering all the waste streams - from building rubble through to abandoned cars - who treat waste as a resource and an opportunity for creating jobs and training." He praises Merci: "It's practical, it works. It helps me convince sceptics, or the 'can't be arsed' brigade - who don't go beyond environmental talk."

Merci is part of the Network of Centres for Change. The best-known is the Centre for Alternative Technology in Machynlleth, south Wales. They are all making contributions to environmental and social change. Merci's distinctive commitment to use environmental ideas to tackle poverty and inequality comes partly from attitudes the founding members carry over from their protesting days. Pickering explains: "I took with me a feeling that the way you change people's minds is through practical example, rather than bombard them with your own ideas."

When they launched their building, Merci effectively launched a new style of regeneration. Now that the building is in working, living order, some of the restless Merci mob are moving on. Pickering is planning a new build programme, learning from the successes of the New Deal young people with the existing building. "There's lots of derelict houses, lots of people needing training in skills. We know a lot about ecological refurbishment and providing good quality training. It's not hard to see a solution to bring this together," she says. They are also planning to establish a community business centre. "Our aim is an economic strategy which the community can control and ensures money circulates as much as possible within the local economy," says Walsh.

Over coming years, the practicality of Merci's model will be put to the test. While the council smiles benignly on the activities at Bridge-5 Mill, on site nearby, its jointly-owned company New East Manchester, is hosting what will be the largest Asda Wal-Mart in the country. As the vanguard of a revolution in retailing which, according to critics in the US, has pulled apart local communities, created a downward pressure on wages and sourced its supplies from companies employing sweatshop labour, Wal-Mart presents a different model of regeneration to that offered by Merci. The Wal-Mart project also poses a challenge to Merci's commitment to be close to the people, because after years of neglect and decline local residents welcome the new development.

Manchester city council is insisting that Wal-Mart employ's local labour and is negotiating what it can in terms of the design of the building. Merci has two stones in its sling in face of such a goliath. First, long-termism. "We won't win short-term battles, but we're here for the next 30, 40 years - goodness knows what will have happened to Wal-Mart then," says Walsh. Second, they inherit the hardworking non-conformity which helped to drive the industrial revolution along the Ashton canal.

Wal-Mart has survived all the words US progressive movements can throw at it; how will it cope with a real living alternative?

Contact Merci on 0161-273 1763 or email: merci@gn.apc.org

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Environment news
fields.body:
Pointing Percy

Norwich last week was the epicentre of the international GM debate, with the John Innes centre - Britain's leading GM research group - bringing together scientists worldwide to debate how to feed the world. Most, unsurprisingly, were in favour of GM. Meanwhile, environment groups attracted 350 people to a parallel meeting which featured women from the Deccan Development Society (DDS) who argued that GM was useless and harmful. Also, there was Percy Schmeiser, a Canadian farmer who had recently lost his case against Monsanto after his land was found to be growing GM crops which he had not planted. Last week, someone tapped him on the shoulder and the White House changed tack, announcing a pro-environment initiative every day. Could that have anything to do with the upcoming Earth Day.

webTitle: Why repudiating the Kyoto protocol is based on wobbly logic, Mr President

fields.headline: Bushwhacked
fields.standfirst: Why repudiating the Kyoto protocol is based on wobbly logic, Mr President
fields.trailText: Why repudiating the Kyoto protocol is based on wobbly logic, Mr President
fields.body:
Not only has President George Bush distorted science and reneged on commitments made by his father, but his refusal to tackle climate change is a counsel of despair.

Bush has given three main reasons for repudiating the Kyoto protocol - all of which lack substance. He maintains that: the science of climate change is uncertain; that the US should not reduce emissions unless developing countries are obliged to limit their emissions too; and that cutting emissions would set back the US economy at a time when things look set to get rocky, especially in the energy sector. Athough there is a grain of truth in all of these, they are substantially incorrect.

The contention that the US cannot afford to reduce emissions, and that it might lose competitiveness if it does, is bizarre. The US would certainly have to make a big effort to meet its Kyoto target of reducing its emissions by 7% from 1990 levels during 2008 to 2012. This is because, for all of his talk about tackling climate change, Bill Clinton did not actually do much about it and US emissions have risen since 1990.

The fact that a big effort is needed does not necessarily mean that cutting emissions will be costly. Most energy efficiency measures can be achieved at a net benefit, not a net cost, and there is huge scope for energy savings in the US. It is, after all, the world's most profligate user of energy. The US has a huge potential for renewable forms of energy generation.

The next shaky plank in the Bush platform on climate change is that developing countries should take on obligations to limit their emissions. To insist that developing countries took on a legally binding commitment to cut emissions would have gone against everything the US had already agreed to in ratifying the UN framework convention on climate change.

The convention, signed by President George Bush (senior) and ratified by a predominantly Republican US senate, repeatedly stresses the need for developed countries to take the lead in tackling climate change and the need for developing country emissions to increase. Its first principle states "the developed country parties should take the lead in combating climate change and the adverse effects thereof." It is difficult to see how this wording can be interpreted as meaning that developing countries should be legally obliged to cut their emissions before developed countries cut theirs, which the US most certainly has not. It is even more difficult to see how Bush junior can completely repudiate the Kyoto protocol which basically just puts flesh on the bones of the original framework convention. For Bush to wish to renegotiate some aspects of the protocol might be understandable. To reject it out of hand when negotiations on its details are still under way smacks of very bad faith.

Looking at the science, it is true that there are uncertainties in climate science. There are uncertainties in all science. That is the nature of the beast. But the underlying basis of the science of climate change is about as certain as science gets. The greenhouse effect exists; it is what stops the Earth from freezing. The effect is caused by a set of well-established physical phenomena. There is no serious doubt that adding greenhouse gases to the atmosphere increases the temperature. The uncertainties on the temperature increases mentioned in the recent report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), frequently referred to by Bush supporters, are not so much due to wobbly science, but to different scenarios thatunderlie temperature forecasts.

Because future human activity could take many different courses, the IPCC used many behavioural scenarios, which resulted in a wide spread of possible temperature increases: between 1.4C (34F) and 5.8C (42F) by 2100. It is this figure most often quoted in the "uncertainty" argument of Bush supporters.

In fact, what the IPCC scenarios actually say is that if human beings adopt future courses of action that result in low greenhouse gas emissions, then there will be little global warming. If they take actions that result in a lot of emissions then there will be a lot of global warming.

So, if we adopt the Bush option of doing nothing about climate change, then we will head straight up the IPCC's maximum 5.8C trajectory.

John Lanchbery, is the climate change policy officer at the RSPB.

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText: RockinÕ role
fields.body:
RockinÕ role

An Elvis impersonator from Bolton, Greater Manchester, is offering his services as a special guest at weddings. Bolton Evening News, 20.3.01 (K Elliott, Bradshaw)

Mast hysteria

Police, firefighters and a helicopter were called out when people were seen on the roof of a tower block in Islington, north London, notorious for suicide attempts, but discovered they were workmen installing mobile phone masts. Highbury and Islington Express, 6.4.01 (David Wilmott, London SE11)

Luck runs out

Police are investigating the theft of a three-foot high wishing well from a garden in Dumfries. The Herald, 6.4.01 (Alison Prince, Whiting Bay)

Farther than planned

A 13-year-old boy competing in a 2.5km road race in Hastings, East Sussex, ended up running a half marathon because his father dropped him off at the wrong starting point while he went to park his car. Hastings and St Leonards Observer, 23.3.01 (Greta Wade, Fairlight)

Still life

The owner of a lifesize sculpture of a sheep has received a warning letter from the Ministry of Agriculture about the movement of livestock after it disappeared from outside his hotel in Stow-on-the-Wold, Gloucestershire, then mysteriously reappeared a few days later. Western Morning News, 12.4.01 (Jack Luttman, Kingsbridge)

Late recovery

The owner of a garage in Oldham, Greater Manchester, got his final wish when his coffin was carried to the funeral on a truck bearing the slogan "24-hour recovery". Birmingham Evening Mail, 10.4.01 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Budding genius?

A photographer from London is using cotton buds to recreate classic film moments, such as the shower scene in Psycho and the opening sequence of Reservoir Dogs. Sunday Independent, 8.4.01 (Ray Rose, Plymouth)

The bill, please

A duck has abandoned the riverbank nesting grounds in Shere, Surrey, and laid her eggs in the window box of a tea shop called the Lucky Duck. Surrey Advertiser, 6.4.01 (M Mathew, Kingston)

Bare-faced cheek

A naked man who knocked on the door of an elderly woman in Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, and said he had been mugged and robbed of all his clothes, stole her £1,000 savings while she went to get him some of her husbandÕs clothes. Huddersfield Examiner, 9.4.01 (John Rossington, Bradford)

Frosty welcome

The landlord of a new pub in in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, ordered 450lb of 2,000-year-old ice from Greenland to serve in customersÕ drinks at the launch. Worcestershire Evening Mail, 7.4.01 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Peck pocket

Police are trying to trace the owner of a wallet containing a large amount of money which was dropped by a seagull in Looe, Cornwall. Cornish Times, 6.4.01 (Malcolm Mort, Liskeard)

Behind bars

A thief who robbed a garage in Twigworth, Gloucestershire, was tracked down by police following a trail of stolen chocolate bars he had dropped. Birmingham Evening Mail, 9.4.01 (Simon Briggs, Bearwood)

Safe but sorry

A major bomb alert was caused by a driver who parked his vehicle in the car park at Corringham police station, Thurrock, because he thought it would be safer there. Thurrock Gazette, 6.4.01 (ST Miller, Grays)

Heavy penalty

A bodybuilder has been banned from a gym in Peterborough after other members complained that he grunts too loud while lifting weights. Metro (10.4.01)

Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.

webTitle: New course for doctors who have to break bad news

fields.headline: New course for doctors who have to break bad news
fields.standfirst: It is part of the job to regularly break bad news, yet formal training for doctors and nurses on how to disclose distressing news to patients or relatives is markedly inconspicuous, until now.
fields.trailText: When my consultant told me that I had leukaemia, she had a hint of a smile on her face. It was not, of course, a smile of glee. Instead, it was one of understated warmth. It conveyed a sense of compassion and hope. Her smile was saying to me: "Sorry this is bad news. But don't worry - all is not lost."
fields.body:
When my consultant told me that I had leukaemia, she had a hint of a smile on her face. It was not, of course, a smile of glee. Instead, it was one of understated warmth. It conveyed a sense of compassion and hope. Her smile was saying to me: "Sorry this is bad news. But don't worry - all is not lost."

The subtle messages signalled by my doctor's non-verbal behaviour are firmly lodged in my memory - as they are for many patients or relatives given shocking or bad news. But ask clinicians about the first time they told a patient he or she had cancer, a man that his wife was brain damaged from an accident or a new mother that her child was diagnosed with Down's syndrome, and the memory might be hazy.

And not unreasonably; after all it is part of the job to regularly break bad news. Yet formal training for doctors and nurses on how to disclose distressing news to patients or relatives is markedly inconspicuous. In fact, it is often a lowly"special request" or appendage on clinical undergraduate and postgraduate training.

While most professionals develop their own appropriate techniques for breaking such news, they can be inadequate. Some methods, as patients have pointed out time and time again, are horrendously crass. Studies in the child disability field reveal that about 50% of parents are dissatisfied with the way news of their son's or daughter's disability was given to them.

This can have detrimental consequences for parents' subsequent relationships not only with medical professionals but with their own child. "If news of a disability is portrayed negatively by a doctor, it can affect the bonding of parents to their child and particularly their view of disability later in life," says Robina Shah, a clinical psychologist working at St Mary's hospital, Manchester.

In its own effort to address these training inadequacies St Mary's has offered, over the past three years, a "sharing the news" workshop to clinicians and nurses. The participatory workshop, developed by Shah, aims to refine professionals' communication skills when delivering distressing news.

By focusing on the patients' perspective, it allows professionals - perhaps for the first time in their career - to devote a whole day to reflection on the details of how they break unpleasant news.

In what room should they meet patients and relatives? Should they sit or stand? How much or how little should be imparted? How much medical jargon should be used? What is the best tone of voice to use?

General rules about good eye contact, sensitivity and honesty are paramount - as is checking that pagers are switched off and that correct names are used. And even though consultation time is limited, doctors are encouraged to allow patients or relatives the feeling that they have their unwavering attention.

Shah says: "The training offers professionals the time and space to ask themselves the question: 'Can I do this better?' It offers them the opportunity to share models of good practice."

The Royal College of Physicians, which has accredited Shah's course, recognises there is a lack of adequate training in communication skills and urges that training be made "high priority" in formal medical education.

All the more reason, one might expect, for professionals to welcome the opportunity to sign up to such courses. Some doctors, nevertheless, remain sceptical of being formally taught how to communicate. They insist that "hands-on" experience remains by far the most effective source of learning.

Charles Essex, consultant neurodevelopmental paediatrician at the Gulson clinic, Coventry, is convinced that being in the same room as a senior colleague, and watching as they disclose distressing news, is the key to self-improvement.

"I would not have learnt how to break news if I had not been with my senior colleagues and seen them do it," he says. "It is like training to be an astronaut - you cannot do it until you have been with other astronauts. And it is during peer reviews that you learn what works for other consultants, and how one particular way of saying something is perhaps better than another. Reflecting on what you do and say is quite right; but this is something I do the whole time."

Essex, who regularly has to tell parents of their child's disability, or even that the child may not survive long, accepts "there is a place" for courses such as Shah's. But he says he "probably would not go on one".

Aware that this hardened attitude risks others dubbing him as old fashioned, Essex adds that it is a question of crude reality: bad news is bad news and cannot be dressed as anything else. "I often give parents their worst nightmares, and no one will ever say: 'Thank you doctor.' If I say to parents that their child is going to die, or has autism, they should be angry or sad - if not, I have to question whether they have really heard what I said."

It is such understandably distressing reactions by parents, Essex argues, that help explain statistics supposedly showing that relatives are dissatisfied with how bad news is broken to them.

Nevertheless, other professionals who have attended Shah's workshop believe her approach does have place on the learning curve - particularly because peers cannot always be relied upon to give adequate guidance. Ian Dady, a consultant neonatal paediatrician, says: "It is difficult for one doctor to advise or correct colleagues. There is an awful lot to remember when disclosing bad news and it can be beneficial to refine your skills."

In addition, Shah explains, not all doctors have had exemplary peer role models to follow. "They might never have had the opportunity to unlearn inappropriate things they picked up," she says.

With the government emphasising clinical governance and lifelong learning, demands to improve professionals' communication skills are likely to come from the top.

"There will always be doctors who deliver news badly, and patients' complaints will reveal this," says Shah. "This will always be something we have to work on. Formal training will always be a good complement to other forms of learning."

How to deliver a bitter pill

 Sit down on the same level as the patient or relative - it is courteous and reassuring.

 Note questions or topics avoided.

 Respect the patient's right to "denial". They will often "selectively perceive" information they can cope with.

 Realise that most patients become aware of their situation gradually, rather than during one meeting.

 Appreciate that patients can, and do, cope positively with truth about illness.

 End a meeting where bad news has been imparted by arranging to meet again.

 Tell staff what has been said. They might be involved in future discussions.
